ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
£25 for three recycled trams from TramSim in a generic city. Gameplay is very restrictive and you must drive exactly as the game asks (e.g. you cannot close the doors less than four seconds after they open).

Even ignoring this, game is very glitchy and does not run well on my medium-high end system. Found many inaccuracies within only an hour of gameplay.

Have requested a refund.

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
С мощных и скоростных поездов, разрабы перешли на городской, рельсовый транспорт. Трамвай. Это классно! Да! Задатки у симулятора хорошие! Графическая составляющая хорошая, звуки окружения, звуки трамвая, аппаратуры, щëлкающих релюшек, кнопок, звуки дверей - всë хорошо! Физика! Чувствуется скорость, чувствуется тяжесть машины! Тут тоже хорошо! Конечно, продукт в раннем доступе, не без недостатков: трафик, местами, чумовой, тупит. Пешеходы "сбиваются" врезаясь в стоячий трамвай, трафиковых трамваев тоже нет. Пассажиры "не умеют" садиться в салон. Салон пуст ВСЕГДА! Дорабатывать и дорабатывать! Но зная разработчиков, которые, параллельно, активно занимаются TSW, а точнее: многочисленными выпусками платных DLC, обновление чего продукта будет ооочеень редким, или, к сожалению, их не будет вовсе. А будут выпуски платных DLC и выпуски новых частей трамвая! Хотел бы я ошибаться. Очень хотел бы! Разрабам, за разработку, за реализацию - хорошо! На раннем выпуске, как есть - хорошо! Рекомендую! Дорабатывайте!

the Ai trams drivers cabin have no screens ect.. Its just all grey, 9/10 no passengers, still get stuck at some parts on the road ect.. Destination screens not change automaticly even tho i have this option turned on. Passengers are glitched into the flooring of the trams, Pedestrians crossing mid street where there is no crossing, even walking on top of the tram stop. I even have seen Ai trams crossing red lights as well. I get accidents with cars even tho there is no car i drove into. accidents with ped even tho i did not. This game is far from finished. This game went to early in full release. As long all this bugs, problems are not solved the game is not finished and is still an early-access game in my opinion. Then, about the city. The graphics of the city look very good but there is not enough life. It looks a little to boring. They did not put enough effort in it. About the depot. I dont like that at the depot there is only 1 gate open, there are no other trams parked except for those small yellow work trams. There is no people over there like the dude in Tram Sim Vienna who told u where to park ect... There is no washing street to clean the tram. The depot looks not realistic enough. I would like to see more life in the city, more trams parked at the depot, a guy like in tram sim vienna who is standing at the depot and a washing street. Maybe a tunnel system and one more thing. Driving in the game is not really fun because its constantly 50, 20, 50 then 30 and then there is one part where u are allowed to drive 60. There are to many intersections. Change this please. I cannot recommend anyone to buy this game for now.

I do recommend this tram sim for those that want a great tram sim experience this is it.

Ich empfehle das Spiel leider nicht


Was ich mag:
Ich mag viele der kleinen Details, sei es, dass das IBIS tatsächlich funktioniert, dass man Weichen mit einer Weichenzange umstellen kann, dass alle Fahrzeuge alle ihre eigenen speziellen Funktionen haben oder allein die Kirchenglocken die sich manchmal zur passenden Zeit hören lassen. Ich finde dass man es den Entwicklern anmerkt, dass sie Spaß hatten bei der Entwicklung und tatsächlich auf solche Details geachtet haben.



Was ich nicht mag:

Meine Erfahrungen beschränken sich hier ausschließlich auf den Karriere-Modus, da ich nur diesen gespielt habe. Keine Fahrt die ich gemacht habe ist bisher ohne Bugs verlaufen. Die harmloseren Bugs sind z.B. schwebende Weichensignale die nicht entfernt wurden oder die Oberleitung die durch hoch montierte Ampeln durchgeht. Ärgerlicher wirds wenn Weichen nicht das tun was man will oder das Spiel nicht erkennt, dass man schon auf dem Weg zur nächsten Haltestelle ist (in dem Fall hilft leider nur ein Neustart der Route).
Um Fair zu bleiben, Bugs wie Straßenbahnlinien die an Orten sind wo sie gar nicht hingehören, aus dem Open Access, sind nicht mehr aufgetreten.

Zudem fühlt sich die Spielwelt leer an. Man fährt eine Linie in der Großstadt Tramau, für die man im Linienplaner eine sehr hohe Auslastung prognostiziert bekommen hat, aber es fahren leider doch immer nur 10 oder 12 Leute mit. Die großen Straßen sind mit einer Hand voll Autos gespickt, die den ganzen Platz leider auch nicht verbrauchen und die zudem auch teilweise aus dem nichts auftauchen und verschwinden.

Die Progression im Karrieremodus ist auch sehr ermüdend nach den ersten 15 Leveln. Man fährt halt seine eigenen 4 Linien die man gemacht hat und das wars. Man kriegt zu wenig Punkte um in guten Abständen neue zu planen und man will auch nach dem vierten Mal nicht alles über den Haufen werfen und zurück ans Reisbrett gehen. Von meinem Ziel, den Typ D / Flexity freizuspielen, habe ich mich auch inzwischen gelöst.

Und zu guter letzt nervt natürlich die Dovetail Manier, alles einzeln in DLCs zu packen aber wem erzähle ich das noch. Ich kann von Glück sprechen dass ich vieles davon umsonst bekommen habe durch den Early Access.




Ich wollte dieses Spiel mögen. Es hatte so eine wunderbare Idee und im Early Access hat es tolle Fortschritte gemacht aber eben nicht genügend. Viele Sachen wie Fahrgastdichte, unsauberer Mapbau, die DLC-Kultur oder die viel zu leere Großstadt sind Haare in der Suppe die soviel mehr hätte werden können.
Alles in allem kann ich dieses Spiel nur dann empfehlen wenn du über sowas hinwegsehen kannst. Ich dachte ich könnte es auch, aber es macht wirklich keinen Spaß mehr.

Bought this just slightly before it left Early Access, so I received the StadtRegioTram, Type D tram, and Team Depot DLCs at no additional cost.

The handling and operation of the trams itself seems and feels great, and I love the novelty of being able to design your own route! I appreciate some of the attention to detail put into it, but it also feels like it has been rushed out towards the end.

The biggest downside and the reason I am NOT recommending this is that the pricing now that it's out of early access is nonsensical. The Tram Depot/Southern extension of the map is a few streets and some tracks that run into a barn. The city itself isn't that big, and doesn't really feel realistic or have much variety.

It's a fun game, but not really a simulator. I would recommend this if it were positioned and priced as a complete, all-inclusive package that serves as a nice merge between a driving sim and a management game. But instead, it's a product that's overpromising as a simulator, with DLCs which means it's lacking in content and overpriced.

This Game is Fantastic!

I am a long-time Train Simulator and Train Sim World player, and this game is so much better than both of those titles.


There are so many good things about this game I am not sure where to start!
1. I love that you have to build and manage a network. I think the management aspect has a lot of potential and should be developed much further. But it is a great start.
2. I love that you have to drive the trams around your network to unlock more features and new trams.
3. I love that the driving is challenging and realistic, there are more features that could be added to make it more challenging.
4. I love how vibrant the world is. This is a huge contrast to TSW and Train Simulator. Here the world has life. There are sounds, pedestrians, traffic, etc...

1. Skipping waiting time does not change the other train positions around the map very well, this screws up the AI time tables.
2. AI trams can sometimes get stuck at stations leading to large lines of stuck trams.
3. At some intersections you can be waiting behind a line of cars stuck at a red light. This light is red to give the tram priority so that you can go through the intersection, but doing so is impossible because of the line of cars, so everyone is stuck forever.
4. The stop marker should have a distance countdown. Is is actually very difficult to see what a perfect stop is from the driver's seat. Also a perfect stop should be based on more than just stopping position. If I slam on the emergency brake to stop in time and then happen to stop on the marker, that should not count as a perfect stop. I think a perfect stop should be traveling from one station to the next, stopping at the correct point, with no mistakes or emergency brake applications.

1. Terminating stations that require switching ends. Not all terminating stations should be massive loops.
2. The ability to edit the livery of all trams on the same line, so each line has a specific livery or color.
3. More buttons and required actions in hard mode.
4. Better game economy. For example, lines should generate profit and have expenses. Deciding to run a line 24/7 should result in a higher operating cost. Similarly, low demand routes with high frequency should be able to loose money. Management should involve optimising where the route is, how long it operates, how much demand it has, what the interval is, and what trams are running on it.
5. Maintenance should also be a consideration. The longer a route is open, the more often its trams should need to be serviced. Also, if I ram my tram into a car there should be a maintenance penalty.
6. Instead of having multiple game financial currencies, just use 1 for everything.
7. Please add scenarios with interesting stories and rewards upon completion.
8. Eventually please add new cities and areas to be unlocked or purchased via DLC.

This is a great game with a lot of potential. The developers should embrace both the driving and management aspects of the game. The driving should become more comprehensive in hard-mode, requiring more driver actions. The network management should become more complex and based on finances. Driving and proper network optimization should yield high incomes. Conversely, bad driving and poor network planning should loose you in-game currency.

Exogate Initiative is two good ideas (Stargate and Evil Genius) that combine in a neutral medium and congeal into an unpalatable result: like mixing ketchup and soy sauce in a glass of tap water and drinking it. I liked all these things, you say, but yuck.

After the massive disappointment that was Evil Genius 2, I had high hopes for Exogate Initiative, which despite its clunky name, appeared to be a sort of spiritual success to the original villainous dungeon manager Evil Genius. After all the, idea of a game that functionally copies the plot of Stargate but allows the player to manage an underground base dedicating to exploring the stars sounds capital.

But where Evil Genius is consistent in its tongue-in-cheek tone and addictive in its gameplay loop, Exogate Initiative feels inharmonious and quickly runs out of steam. While the subject matter of exploring strange new worlds in nothing but a lab coat and flak vest might demand a gritty realism, it has none. While the tone of the dialogue and story events feels like the game will be a carefree celebration of science and discovery, the game actually delivers a ruthlessly exploitative vision of patenting every wonder in the galaxy. Patent, license, slap it on a lunchbox. Scientific discoveries on an alien world are reduced to their usefulness to the textile industry. The resulting discordant experience conspires to make the game less than the sum of its parts suggests it could be. In Evil Genius, you would ask, “What shall I do next?” and in Exogate Initiative, you will find yourself asking “Is this all I can do?”

The art style of the close-ups is frankly baffling. If I wanted a dose of cell-shaded, balloon-headed, cutesy avatars, I’d go down to my garage and dust off my Nintendo Wii. The game’s ask that I care about these grotesque FunkoPop homunculi is a bridge too far.

Nevertheless, the game isn’t all disappointment. I found myself genuinely interested in some of the tech tree systems, and the mechanic of spending power for a constant connection with ever-more distant worlds is inventive. The base can also be fun to manage, even if those mechanics are lifted directly from the original Evil Genius.

Kudos for what is essentially a good idea in an often neglected genre. But Exogate Initiative has a long way to go before it can live up to the legacy of Evil Genius, and it’s already made some missteps that aren’t easily fixed.

I want to love this game, as the theme is fantastic. However, the UI is terrible, meaning that you cannot compare information between your characters without searching all their individual screens for it and then remembering everything there.
In the end I stopped caring about any of their stats, which changed nothing in the gameplay in any noticeable way, thus making all characters irrelevant beyond overall level and their role.

The game loop becomes boring rapidly, because there are no overarching storylines of interest/significance. You get invaded which should be interesting, but you have no real control over anything which makes it all boring.
Most of the upgrades you can get don't actuaelly change anything, they just accelerate the same gameplay loop. You can research better beds, so you send guys out quicker. You can research animal specimens, but they just give more science compared to plants not anything different. You can get engineers to mine, but it's just the same loop as the scientists except the icon they bring back is different.

There is no semblance of story elements which create interest. There should be events which are actually interesting and written properly, and FAR more things which occur in the facility. You have characters going through a stargate and the only things which happen are occasional invasions?

The pathing and decision making of chartacters is terrible, so units get lost in your base or move back and forth between needs without ever actually addressing them. So even though you've upgraded the facility to speed up how quickly they can recover their stats, it often doesn't help as they wander back and forth between rooms without interacting. Or they stand around in the middle of the base and just don't do anything.

There are options to change priorities of training, what they focus on doing etc, but it's crippled by that poor UI. Actually making those changes isn't feasible even part way through as there are too many characters to keep track of and no easy way to change things quickly. A schedule wouldn't be hard to put in (pre mission prioritise X. After mission for Z days, prioritise Y), or screens which allow us to actually compare all the characters quickly and make changes without needing to navigate through other screens first.

It has a great concept and so much potential but it is almost entirely squandered by lazy writing and implementation, and giving only the barest minimum of things to do (and no, doing the same thing with a different name is not something else to do)

This is an initial impression with only a few hours of play, a more full review will be made/rewritten upon further play

==========================================================================
sidenote: I feel as though a lot of people in reviews for base building/dungeon builder games have some very rose tinted glasses, that isn't to say any of their criticism or opinions are objectively wrong, much less subjectively invalid, but they seem to have extremely high praise for the, older, pioneers of the genre. Having played many of the older ones, i.e. dungeon keeper and evil genius 1, I personally think people hold them in much higher regard than those games deserve (outside of paving the way for the genre). Pretty much all dungeon/base builders fall off, have a diminishing returns on replay and have a heavy enjoyment fall off after reaching certain points within campaigns, are not all that well balanced, and have some questionable design choices in regards to GUI and especially progression.
end of sidenotes
==========================================================================

The game seems to run fairly well, and I have not had any meaningful/noticeable crashes or bugs/glitches. The overall concepts are quite enjoyable and well thought out. The game and UI are pretty enough, but not distracting; all the SFX and VFX are satisfying without being too over-the-top or distracting.

The balance mostly seems ok, but this may depend on the difficulty settings you use and your experience level. However I noticed that, in the play-through I've done, I seemed to have essentially infinite money but was struggling to get the research points i needed to keep up with the pace of the game; this is likely due to how easy/quickly I blazed through the quest/grants and explored planets. I suspect there is a specific pacing that the developers anticipated and balanced for. There's nothing, in my opinion, inherently wrong with this and this is something incredibly difficult to smooth out without entirely ruining the game in the process; however it's something to keep in mind and as you do more playthroughs this is likely to be of an issue.

Something that I'm willing to say is that the game on one hand does a very good job teaching the player how to play, but in other ways it neither prepares/telegraphs important points in the campaign nor gives you good clear info where it is most needed.
For instance, it will tell you how all the mechanics and items/rooms work well enough that those new to the genre should be able to easily pick it up. The game doesn't very clearly warn or prepare you for invasion, and if you don't have the resources setup to prepare for it you will be left with a base that has 0 ability to defend itself (regardless of how many soldiers you have) and your run is ruined.
Furthermore there's so much info everywhere, but in the planet screen it can be difficult to quickly assess important information such as which planets you have done an initial exploration and also it's difficult to really easily find which planets have what teams assigned for recurring missions, and even initially difficult to see where you have wormhole connections (which use up base energy). You find this information, but it's kinda difficult and confusing initially.
There's also no quick and easy way to sort through employees injuries or wellbeing without having to go in and individually click things.

Interesting concept but has some significant issues. First you should understand that YOU / your perspective will never go through the gate or see ANYTHING that exists on other worlds. Basically you're talking to them by radio (not even a video link) so never see anything other than your base. I thought there would be more but there isn't so FYI.

The concept of this is interesting, its kinda like running the SGC. But the game balance is AWFUL. For example you can't visit a bunch of the worlds until you have Exosuits (think advanced space suits). You have to build exosuits which requires you to research them and research is extremely slow to progress. But you also need rare elements that you have to mine from other worlds to make them. You can't mine a world until you've claimed it and you are very limited on what you can claim (takes forever). None of the planets with these materials were near Earth so they all required long chains of claimed worlds. What does this mean in practice? After playing for many hours I got frustrated and started cheating. Over a few hours it went from just infinite money, to adding infinite research and finally infinite influence to claim worlds. So after playing a game for ~19 hours and massively cheating I STILL WAS NOT ABLE TO EQUIP A SINGLE TEAM WITH EXOSUITS! Seriously. The balancing is ridiculous.

Each team member also has a host of needs and most of them end up stressed or with mental issues and you have to micro-manage them to resolve. But the GUI doesn't really provide the high-level tools to filter and update them efficiently. So you'll spend heaps of time just flipping through management screens making micro adjustments. Which is not fun.

Like I said above the concept is really need, but the implementation is poor. Its unlikely that I'll replay this unless they do a massive overhaul.

Original review (after 17 hours) below:

The short: Surprisingly deep yet simple to play base-builder. Very fun.

The long:
When I started playing this game, I expected a 10-hour campaign of exploring a few worlds, meeting some aliens, and that would be that. First 3 seasons of SG-1. But nope, it's kinda the whole series, in scale.

While the game does start off gently (just keep churning Patents), the tech tree is deep enough to provide variety and fun, the galaxy map surprisingly large, and the diplomatic and territorial challenges in the later stages add a lot of depth.
I feel this is a better design choice than in Evil Genius 1, where the globe was ... static. Here, you can build your empire, and it's much fun.

Issues: I've encountered an AI bug when I manually reassign beds - they don't search for a new bed on their own, but pop a bubble that they don't have a bed, and I have to do it for them. Also, after 6-8 hours of continual play, the game starts stuttering (memory leak?). Restart fixes it.
Also, after researching and building the ultimate power generator, I've found out it take less than a minute for it to reach zero maintenance, and explode. Far too little time for my robots to reach and repair it, even when placed relatively close by. I understand there's a game reason for it to require more maintenance, but I feel this is too excessive. Devs, please fix.

Conclusion: Very fun, mostly polished, some bugs, great game design. easy-to-play-yet-moderately-hard-to-master.

Fortunately for the devs, the Stargate theme is unique... it's not like tavern or blacksmith sims with a dozen options to choose from. If there was a single other option, I'd buy it and uninstall this immediately.

I love the base building and away mission game loops, but the terrible UI design, lack of information and lack of quality of life makes playing this game irritating.

It starts right in the game options. The standard game length is 100 months but can range from 12 to 1200. The only way to modify it is with a slider that doesn't 'hit' every number from 12-1200. Want to play for a nice round 10 years instead of 8 yrs, 4 months?? You can't.. the slider goes from 118 to 122. Why aren't there arrows to either side so you can increment by 1? Or, better yet, why isn't it a field where you just type how many months you want the game to be?

Speaking of game length, there's NOTHING in-game to tell you how many months you've played - just the current date. I hope you enjoy calendar math - because you'll have to figure out when the game ends from the easy to remember start date of Nov 1, 2057 lol

There's no financial statement. There's a monthly summary (which can't be brought back once you dismiss it) and that's it. That's not as bad as it sounds because the only expense is salaries, there's no maintenance costs, but still.

The "start away mission" sound effect much louder than every other sound in the game. My effects volume sits at 35% to keep that sound at a reasonable volume. Unless I scroll right into a room, the only sound effect I hear is the 'gate opening' - very quietly. Every other sound effect is just asmr white noise when I'm scrolled out.

There's no use of color for information. All the resource icons and amounts are black and 'tied' to each other by a light grey box they share, sitting on a white background. That light grey on white makes that 'tying' of icon to amount less than obvious, especially because of the amount of open space between the icon and the amount. It's noticeable on the starmap because the position of energy and influence are reversed, they're pushed close together at the top right of the screen and the black bar between your amount of influence 'ties' to the energy icon, because that grey on white isn't obvious.

Your characters relationships affect their XP on away missions.. but there only way to check their relationships are on their individual character sheets (which you can only get to on the main menu, not if your in the starmap making your away team). You shouldn't have to dig to the character sheet level - on the screen where you make away teams, the character summaries should have green/red emoticons for whoever is currently assigned to the away team.

I could go on.. and on.. but those are the biggest irritants that come quickly to minde.

Despite *most* of those irritants, I was still enjoying the game.

It was starting because the economy felt too easy, and noticing the game length option issue, combined with realising there was no game month tracker that finally broke me. So I turned it off, wrote this review, and will load up something else until there's hopefully a patch that addresses some of the terrible QoL and UI.

If you're the type unbothered by terrible UI, you love Stargate and management sims AND you like calendar math, this game, in it's current state, is for you.

If UI issues can make an otherwise fun game unplayable for you - especially when basics like "how much longer does the game last" are missing.. then DO NOT waste your money here.


Edit - I appreciate the quick response from the dev explaining that you can see the game length in the Aliens and Artifacts screen.

I have to ask... do you think that's the best place to hide it? You don't think it belongs right by the date or it may be in the monthly summary? There shouldn't be a need to dig through menus for basic information. I think game length qualifies as basic information

The game is decent for its price already at 1.0 launch, so I do recommend it. There is enough content for at least 15-20 hours of gameplay before you start running out. It is definitely nowhere near as buggy as the reviews make it out. You should be prepared for basically a short "base-builder" with fairly simple systems, as long as you understand that the base building aspect is actually fairly simplistic.

The core game loop revolves more around assembling teams, deciding what order to tackle missions in and with what team members; things like diplomacy and invaders are adjacent and honestly barely matter. Even some core systems like food/social feel fairly pointless because you can't really influence them in any way beyond building the rooms (or expanding them) and unlocking plain +X% bonuses via research.

That said, the end-game devolves into tedious repetitive mechanics right now, with very little automation meaning you end up spending more time clicking through things than making any worthwhile choices. Assigning equipment to pawns, setting up missions, filing patents, etc are all pointless busywork after the early game and should just be something automate-able, but this is something that could be improved later.

I'm not sure as there was no text, no pop-up info on the icons, nothing. Once I submitted it, no matter what I did, it never wrote. An hour later, I finally found I had to click on the desk itself and "assign" a scientist to it. Absolutely nowhere else that I've found so far did I have to "assign" anyone other creating a team (more on that in a minute.) By this point, I was out of money and she refused to work. I had no money coming in so I had to restart. I just did a refund instead. That first hour was not fun. I wasn't about to deal with running into this issue at an even later stage, as I'm sure it's there. And how do I know? Let's go back to the Team.

When you do a recruitment campaign (which itself isn't all that intuitive), you can hire Gaters, but you then have to create a team. Not assemble a team. That's different. On the screen with the gaters, is a "Create a team" button. But that's literally all it is. You give it a name, a color, and an icon. You'd think you would add people to this team from the Gater page, but no. You do THAT at the map screen, after connecting to a planet. Then you can select you "Team," just don't forget to edit the roster otherwise it has nobody in it. It's quite possibly the most un-intuitive and stupid round-about way I've ever seen in a game. That was already concerning enough, but then when I ran into the above issue with the patents, I decided I did not want to delve any deeper into this wreck.

There's some ideas here that could work if done just slightly better. The missions are interesting, but once again a lack of useful information just leads to picking random choices and seeing the outcome. It looks good, and the concept is one desperately needing made, but what should have captured the essence of Stargate SG-1 ended up being "Wormhole X-Treme!"

This is a great game for fans of base builders and sci-fi alike. Made by only a small team, there are some areas that could use more polish, e.g. animations, but the gameplay is fun and innovative. I've really enjoyed playing this game throughout early access and seeing it evolve and the theme is unusual and fun - would definitely recommend!

I'm not sure what all the random negative reviews are about. I haven't run into any bugs to speak of, although the combat AI in base is a bit wonky. People being "stuck" in medbay are probably just waiting to be treated by a medical officer. It is true that the tutorial more explains general concepts and leaves you to poke around in the details yourself, rather than highlighting specific buttons and telling you to "click here". Other than alien corpse investigation, I haven't found anything particularly difficult to figure out. People getting "stuck" (particularly in the medbay), are waiting for someone to come treat them, and in some cases, like the psychological treatment desks, you have to assign specific medical personal to each desk (similar to how patents work, which they explained in more detail). YMMV I guess.

Pros:
That said, overall, I find this game to be pretty damn fun. It is _very_ Stargate centric, and I am really quite impressed with how they captured the various scenarios one saw in the shows over the years. In particular, I really like how each "gater" class was made meaningful and useful in their own ways--it's really quite enjoyable. The strategic decisions about how to combine various gaters to make special purpose teams is also pretty fun. For the price, I'd say it's absolutely worth exploring if you like base building games and were a fan of Stargate. The range of scenarios captured is really quite satisfying, and the game is easy to lose oneself in.

Cons:
So what are the cons? First, the combat system is pretty kludgey. This isn't an RTS or combat game in any way, really. Combat is mostly about base building and layout, combined with research, gear, and personnel management. The actual "fighting" is clumsy and largely not controllable by the player. This is not an XCOM game, at least in terms of focus. In fact, it's the exact opposite. The focus of the game is base building, tech research and gate link influence/politics. Overall, I don't mind the lack of combat controls as it works with the overall flow of the game--combat is just involved enough to be an interesting break from other goals, but not too distracting from larger goals and projects. Also, while there are interpersonal relationship management stuffs, the tools for managing them are scant, and the impact is relatively minor. I paid attention a lot in the beginning, and quickly just started moving people around as needed by injury/stress, etc. later on.

For the me, the primary con is the nagging sense that I get with some games that just makes me wish they had done more. They have all the pieces and ingredients for a game with legs to be an amazing roguelike with tons of replayability. My sense, thus far, however, is that's not what we have at this juncture. Although I'm still probably mid-game in my first serious playthrough, my sense is the aliens you meet are preset every "game", their attitudes and roles are the same and so on. The characterization of the alien factions are pretty shallow something akin to mid era Star Trek, focusing on some hyperbolic trait, which may help distinguish them quickly, but isn't particularly flavorful. The artifacts, independents, etc. are probably all the same every playthrough, and basically, you just wish there was more, with a cleverer universe procgen. The tech tree is also relatively "shallow". I haven't gotten to the end of it, but it starts fully revealed (afaik), and there isn't _that_ much more to grab. Overall I consider this generally a sign of a solid base game--you just want more.

And perhaps if the game is popular enough, there will be more added in updates or DLCs. One can only hope. What is there now, however, is certainly pretty fun, and definitely worth the price, even at full price (and it is on sale atm).

For me, it's a fun nostalgia trip, and replaying the campaign was quite enjoyable. But for others, it may be a disappointing experience, if they expect to see a more traditional RTS. Wait for a sale is my advice

Ты вот давеча спрашивал, чем Battle Realms такая особенная. И тебе ответили, что для многих это просто игра детства.

Я всё же чуть пооблизываю то, что мне в ней нравится.

В ней прикольно сделано древо развития фракций. У каждого клана есть крестьяне, которые автоматически штампуются. Они добывают ресурсы и строят здания. При этом они — основа армии. Чтобы получить воина, надо обучить крестьянина. Построил додзё, отправил туда работягу — и оттуда выходит умелый копейщик. Построил стрельбище, послал туда очередного заурядного рабочего — оттуда выходит меткий лучник. Но на этом их путь может не заканчиваться. Если копейщика отправить на стрельбище, оттуда уже выйдет юнит второго тира — воин Дракона. У него есть здоровый дрын меч и он может стрелять энергетическими шарами.
И таких начальных зданий, в которых тренируются юниты, три штуки. И столько же возможных комбинаций второго тира. Если воин Дракона пойдёт обучаться химии в хижину алхимика, то он преисполнится знаниями о таблице Менделеева, потеряет способность стрелять энергией, но зато вспомнит, чему его учили на стрельбищах, и наденет доспехи. И станет самураем.
В дополнение к основной ветке развития есть ещё саппорт-юниты типа всяких гейш. Мы в детстве всегда угорали, когда отправляли крестьянина в купальни, а оттуда выходила женщина. Прикинь! Разрабы вставляли повест_очку до того, как это стало мейнстримом!

На карте есть дикие , которых крестьяне могут приручать. И свою армию можно посадить на коней. Это дополнительное здоровье, скорость, мобильность и способность огреть копытом неприятеля.

Несмотря на наличие юнитов более высоких тиров, актуальность начальных не падает. Это к слову о . Например, лучник всегда будет стрелять лучше самурая. Самурай эффективен за счёт брони и универсальности, но как стрелок он довольно средний. Зато лучника можно обучить огненным стрелам и поджигать здания врага. Ах да! Помимо того, что можно просто сломать здание, его можно поджечь. И крестьянам нужно бегать и тушить свои домики.

Каждого воина можно обучить навыку в специальных зданиях. У кланов Дракона и Змея есть выбор, какую именно способность дать. У клана Волка на юнита всего одна способность — через благословение друидессы… друидини… Женщины-друиды, ну ты понял! А вместо второй способности юнита можно одеть в броню из специального минерала, и он будет поглощать больше урона. У больных yблюдкoв из клана Лотоса, чтобы юнит изучил специальное умение, нужно получить благословение одного из трёх мёртвых братьев (они же герои клана). Причём для юнитов высоких тиров от каждого из братьев достаётся своё уникальное умение.

У каждой фракции есть герои (), которых нужно покупать за особую валюту, зарабатываемую в бою (Инь/Ян). Некоторых из них также можно посадить на лошадей. У каждого героя есть уникальная способность. На мой взгляд, самой paз**бнoй была способность лидера Лотоса — чел вызывает грозу, которая не только x**pит молниями врагов, но и поливает посевы риса дождём.

Короче, можно доx*я рассказывать о тонкостях и нюансах игры, но самый прикол в том, что она тебя этим не душит. Тебе даже статы не показывают. Просто есть полосочки здоровья и стамины. Многие детали оставлены под капотом. Не знаю, плюс это или минус для тебя, решай сам.

Сами клёвые. Кланы Дракона и Змея — по сути, добрая и злая противоположности. Драконы более монашеские и преисполнившиеся, а Змеюки — обитатели вертепа. У них начальное боевое здание — таверна, а в армии служат разные маргиналы, бандиты и ниндзя.
Остальные две фракции посложнее. Лотос — это какие-то технологичные маги/религиозные фанатики. Из-за того, что они практикуют магию, их тела деградируют и разрушаются. И чем дальше юнит идёт по тирам в своём развитии, тем меньше в нём остаётся человеческого. Ты только послушай как называются их юниты второго тира: Нечистый, Больной и Заражённый! Пи*дец, конечно...
Клан Волка состоит из первобытных людей, которые фанатеют по природе и используют каменное и другое примитивное оружие. Единственный клан, который не может приручать лошадок, но может скармливать их своим ручным волчарам, которых затем пускает в бой. Друидессы могут благословлять берсерков даром ликантропии. На первый взгляд, отсталые инструменты и оружие клана на самом деле не уступают по функциональности продвинутым технологиям конкурентов. Особая броня очень хорошо защищает от магии. А чувак, таскающий на своём горбу целую, бл*дь, балисту, вообще вызывает уважение!

Ну и вся вот эта азиатская эстетика с музычкой на этнических инструментах радует. Довольно занятные кампании. В одной из них — в Путешествии Кендзи — есть вариативность.

А так... Да.

I grew up playing this game, alongside Age of Empires 2. I liked this one more.
It's unique in the way you create your units, both workers and army.
It's unique in the way you can set fire to buildings, or put out the fire.
The projectiles, the horses, the rolling boulders, the growing of the rice, these are all interesting mechanics, some of which I've only seen in this game.
Units change their attack type and animations when switching between ranged and melee combat.
The music is amazing, emotional, pumped up. Each song has a "normal" version and a "combat" version and it switches smoothly between versions depending on the situation.
I honestly have only praise for this game. There has never been anything like it.
And it warms my heart to see it brought back to life on Steam after so many years.

Didn’t play since the balanced patch because I don’t play garbage, but since it’s been out of early access for a month already, let’s review.

Pros :

- The AI is significantly smarter than in the legacy version.
- The graphics are slightly better.
- This is a chance to redeem yourself for pirating the game back then.

Cons :

- There are more sync errors than in the legacy version.
- Old bugs have been fixed by around 95%, but new bugs are introduced with each patch, creating a never-ending cycle.
- There is no *2 speed option in campaign or single-player mode.
- Many important core game mechanics have changed that nobody asked for (such as fire, stacking, toggle order, training time, etc.).
- Balanced by a casual yet high egotistical team in an echo chamber that has had drama with the pro community.
- The balance has reached a point where it removes what makes Battle Realms unique compared to other RTS games.
- There is no LAN support; online play is available only through Steam.
- The promised 1.50q release has not occurred.
- AI is too difficult and deemed impossible by filthy casual.
- There is not full support for Windows 11; workarounds are needed to play. The same can be said for the legacy version.

TL;DR
If you are new to the game or a casual player that want to play with friend, maybe this is for you.
If you are an old-timer/veteran or a competitive player, this game is not even worth pirating. go back to GameRanger.

Short Review
Battle Realms is a fantastic RTS with a unique combat system that's easy to pick up yet challenging to master. While strategic depth exists, a little spam-clicking can go a long way. The economy system is well-designed and engaging.

The campaign? Solid. The story? Enjoyable. The art style? Distinct and visually appealing. Overall, this game delivers a great experience.

The downsides?

-Occasionally frustrating unit pathing.
-No visible stat numbers to analyze (though the game leans more toward a rock-paper-scissors combat system). Is this really a con? Maybe, maybe not…

-----
Personal Review
I’m writing this as someone who owned the original Battle Realms box and CD back in the day.

I just finished Kenji’s campaign for the first time—after all these years. Back then, I wasn’t great at RTS games… but now? Now, I’ve learned from countless others. Returning to this classic with actual strategy instead of a smooth-brain approach felt incredible.

Finding this on Steam was pure joy. No waiting for a sale—I bought it immediately. The nostalgia hit hard, but despite its age, Battle Realms still holds up on its own. I place it among my personal favorites: Age of Empires II, Dawn of War: Dark Crusade, and StarCraft 1 & 2.

You made something truly special.

Well done, devs.

-----
Feature Request: Map Conquest Mode
I’d love to see a map conquest mode added. The way the campaign map works already feels like a perfect foundation for it. The only other game that truly nailed this was Dawn of War: Dark Crusade.

I don’t need extra story (unless you want to add some). I don’t need gear unlocks for heroes. I just want to play as the Lotus Clan and conquer the map, fighting against the other clans.

So, I guess Lair of the Lotus needs to be dusted off. :P

If there’s even a small chance of making this happen, tell me what I need to do. I’ll gladly donate my free time—whether it’s writing C++ code or creating concept art. Whatever it takes.

The legendary RTS from Ed Del Castillo is back!

The living resource system and Yin/Yang resource awards for combat make this game special.

You want to have elite soldiers? Train a peasant in multiple buildings until he becomes a Samurai or Sorcerer. A weak militia unit is enough? A weak but effective crossbowman or spearman can be trained much quicker. Want special equipment? Give the warrior a horse or caltrops from another building.

Sounds hard to build an army? Yes, but you get rewarded with Yin/Yang points for combat which allow upgrades and recruiting of powerful heroes and special units. The further away from your base (buildings) you fight, the more Yin or Yang you get.

If you need water to extinguish a burning building or water your rice, you need to send out a peasant to do the job. Peasants also tame wild horses for battle or work, construct your buildings and of course harvest rice.

Each faction can recruit various heroes and has a super unit or ability. Weather, forests and line of sight all have an effect like in the real world, with rain making rice grow faster and forest hiding units for example.

Battle Realms takes part in a far-east Fantasy setting that reminds of both medieval/renaissance Japan and China. Four clans (the factions) battle it out in two different campaigns, skirmish and in multiplayer matches. Lots of maps are available.

Contains the expansion Winter of the Wolf.

Ed Del Castillo and friends are still improving the game and come chance would definitely make more games set in the Battle Realms world.

There are plenty of both examples, and links, in-game to teach you more about the topic(s) if you're interested (even some non-machine learning topics). On top of it all, the game is very silly and humorous. It doesn't take itself too seriously, however, there's still a lot of depth; it doesn't completely write itself off as a joke like some games might when going for a similar vibe. I really recommend it.

Okay, as a Factorio veteran (merely 1k hours) I want to notify that this is not a good factory game. It both fails to explain core concepts AND have an unreasonably high but bland logistic difficulty.

The core loop looks simple: you sell goods in the shops, obtain money, research new tech. However, to have a good shop you need to bring into it 6 (!) belts - one with cat, 5 with goods. and you need multiple shops with different goods if you want to be effective. That's crazily complex. Factorio, DSP, Satisfactory, Shapez 2 rarely have more than 3 item input. Yes, ultra-hardcore Factorio mods could have 6, 12, even more. But that's on totally different level, with double-sided belts, lots of additional mechanics and options, on the most complex mods many hours after you start those (usually after hundreds of hours in the base game). Here you have that complexity from the get-go, with no tools, crazily little space and without even understanding the newer concepts of this game.

And by saying crazily little space - yes, while the space is fully terraformable (much later in the game) its mostly resembles puzzle-like Factorio scenarios where you are trying to cramp an industry in a smallest area possible.

This unique little platformer reminds me of Mario64 a little bit- you pick up speed and height from jumping consecutively, you have a series of "worlds" you go into, where you can run around, and climb stuff, break boxes, find coins, and practice the moves you'll need to use in the next part, where you down pipes to do individual time trials in that world, it's very much like "Grassy Hill Zone level 1-1", ect.

This is precision platforming where you find yourself just hitting restart the second you start wrong, and if you like the perfectionism of it, there's a lot of speedrunner ghosts to compete against, and this game is SUPER international, leaderboards have America in the vast minority. I'm not breaking any records but It feels like within reach if you practice hard, some racing/parkour games like Death Runner or Phantom Abyss have a lot randomness that can feel a bit too unforgiving most of the time, here it's all your fault when you miss that jump, but-

Sadly there's no multiplayer, but you can race ghosts in real time and there's a solid leaderboard that doens't seem hacked. It doesn't feel designed for multiplayer though either, it feels more like a Sonic course in a Mario wrapper with some light BotW climbing mechanics.

Really solid game if you like this genre, plus, it has a demo so its not like you have to buy it to check it out.

I like to describe this as Sandbox Parkour!
Not in an open world kind of way, but they way each level is treated! You can run or jumps on almost anything you see! Often multiple ways to get to your goal. And there are a lot, I think close to 70 levels? I haven't finished all of them.
For each level you can get Bronze, Silver, Gold or Ultima medal, but there are also leaderboards, and you can play against the ghost of any player, or you own ghost.

Apart from individual levels, there is a hub world for each of the 4 unique areas. These are big open areas that contain puzzles, secrets and token for you to collect (tokens unlock skins), as well as a way to access each level (You can also do so from level select menu for a quick way around).

I bought this game in Early access around 2020, and the thing that immedietly got me hooked was the feel of the game, it is very responsive and well animated. I never get bored of wallrunning XD
The development was on hiatus for a while but they came back strong and made a lot of improvements, AND, a Level creator!

It is called Create Mode and it some of the most fun I've had creating something in a video game!
It is super intuitive and you can create almost any level you want. And then you can play it and share it with everyone.
Around half of my time in this game I've spent in create mode, I just find it so addicting XD

As a lover of Parkour games, I can 100% recommend this.

Art and Music quality went up, very happy to see it.
Very nice to see actual dialogue between the characters compared to the very little dialogue in EL
While i enjoyed it for most of the part there are a few small things i want to nitpick:
- The story is a bit harder to follow this time, lots of new characters with hard to remember names and terms,
- Mid game mobs doing half of your HP in 1 hit feels very unbalanced for the Normal difficulty X1 damage modifier, bosses in the same area do less damage than the mobs.
- Some mid game bosses dying a bit too fast (Gilroy 1st encounter, No.7)
- The boss Velgrynd's hitboxes and overall fight design are very bad, worst fight in the series.
- Didn't feel as attached and invested in Lilac and squad as much as i was to Lily and her squad.
- Assuming the mysterious priestess is Lily, wanted more of her and what she has been up to for the past decades.
- Minus points for the same boss fight repeats in the Land of Origins with a total of 2 attacks each (the vine wall and the ray blob)
- The main attack summons you can use feel rather underwhelming compared to Nola especially Yolvan whose ranged abilities get powercrept by another late game character whose range also feels underwhelming for a rifle user.
Altho i feel my bias towards Ender Lillies, Ender Magnolia is a solid sequel exploring another part of the world affected by the Blight. If there is another sequel i will gladly buy and play it.

The game itself is fun, I like the rate of unlocks too.
The soundtrack is amazing.
Lower Stratum is pretty fun,
Central Stratum gets kinda bad.
Upper Stratum is a bit worse, because it's the same issues, plus it's now a walking simulator. some bosses are a full 2 minutes away from the respawn point, and can kill you in mere seconds.
When you reach the Central Stratum, bosses' designs just abuse the absence of invulnarability window to insta kill you. Any lasting effects, like a beam, a frost bomb, name it (every monster has one at that point), can hit you multiple times per seconds.
Most attack that can one shot won't allow a response too, They can also overlap different AoE that will compound and be impossible to evade if the timings are not in your favour.
You can also be shotgunned if an enemy release a bunch of projectiles at the same time (even from their origin).
Burning damage will kill you before you even have a chance to extinguish it (if you even have the space for). If feels miserable.
Hitboxes are kinda weird. Range of enemy attack is hard to determine and can change through a fight.
Most bosses' attacks are not telegraphed, they just... happen?
The last boss is just so bad.
You won't win a blind fight, it's just not possible with those kinds of issues.

Winning unfair fights is not satisfying, it's just the end of a chore.
There is also a tower later with multiple miniboss fights, where losing a single one makes you redo all of it. It's kinda lame. It's not hard, but what a waste of time XD.
The auto bird is never on by default, and will be off when you starts most bosses.
Life upgrades are irrelevant because monsters' damage increases at a higher rate. Your effective life just go down even with all of them. Just exploring is a hassle because those trash monsters can actually kill you quite easily.
I'm pretty sure 90% of my deaths were due to some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I could do nothing about, not even talking about skill here (I cleared the game anyway, beat the last boss twice too).
I mean, this is just a collection of weird decisions. Makes you wonder if they even played through their game. I honestly don't think the game was tested past the Lower Stratum.
Wondered a few time why I was still playing, sunk cost fallacy probably

I was a huge fan of the theme, story, and gameplay of Quietus of the Knights so playing this game was a no brainer. It brings you to a city falling apart at the seams while you try to piece together your scattered memories. It has intense and fun combat as you explore the beautiful world, finding items and getting stronger. I've nearly finished this game and am loving it but there are a couple issues that have stuck out to me throughout my playthrough.

The story of the Quietus of the Knights put you in a post apocalyptic setting where every character and item found helped to stitch together the story as you retrace the steps of the white witch. Magnolia something similar but most characters add little to nothing to the story.

The theme of Quietus by means of it's background art and music allowed the character to feel the corruption that has spread across the lost kingdom as it builds in intensity. In Magnolia, there is reference to fumes that are causing the corruption but it is displayed the same in every area. A character might comment on how bad the fumes are in an area but there is no visual representation. This leads to the corruption of the deep underground feeling the same as the highest points of the city.

The combat is fun and intense but I do have a couple complaints. I played with the difficulty settings on 1.5x and found it a nice challenge. However, every enemy hits for the same damage. So, a large enemy has a long wind up and hits for half my health but a smaller enemy has a 2 hit chain with each hit also doing half my health. There are many enemies that have little to no telegraphed hits but can kill you in half a second if you get too close. This causes the larger imposing enemies to not be imposing, as the smaller and faster enemies are far more deadly. I think the longer the charge up the more damage it should do is a reasonable rule to help diversify enemy types.

Posting on behalf of me bud Kupo because the game is on my account and not his, but I whole-heartedly agree with it all!

In short:
A gorgeous looking MetroidVania that is satisfying gameplay wise and is an improvement compared to the first.

ENDER MAGNOLIA is the Sequel to ENDER LILIES the same way Nier: Automata is the sequel to NIER. A shared world separated by hundreds of years, you need no previous knowledge to enjoy this game, though knowing does give some well deserved "oooo" moments.

Gameplay consist of standard metroidvania powerups, difficult bosses, exploration, and build-building all refined to the razor's edge of perfection. The non-linear map makes getting a new skill or tool an absolute joy, searching for hidden paths rewarding, and fighting bosses, although tough (Most kill in 2-3 swipes) challenging, but can be made easier by experimenting with your loadout.
The map is well tuned to exploration, with custom pins, easy to read connectors, and fully explored indicators, 100%ing the game was actually enjoyable!

The story itself gradually unfolds as you "Attune" to the memories of various "Homunculi" who become your allies. Questions like, where is the line between homunculi and human? What constitutes as sentient? Where is the corruption coming from? Who is this sassy, lost child? Are all answered in time.

All in all, if you enjoy Metroidvania's, you WILL like this game
10/10

Some balancing tweaks and some specific boss fight behavior tweaks or enemy layout changes in the end would have reduced frustration without really taking anything away from the game.

Saw both endings in 14 hours of play. Perfect amount of time for me for this kind of game.

Also would recommend looking at Nine Sols if you want something else to play in this vein

DISCLAIMER: I'm only an hour in! However, I think it's so easy to recommend based on the price point and what I've seen so far, and as an active fan of the genre.

If you have not played Ender Lilies:
Gameplay: The combat is fluid and fast. The game doesn't waste your time at all: fast travel is unlocked within the first hour, and you get some standard movement abilities right away (dodge, double jump, aerial dodge). The stun/Break system feels so good to use: different abilities have different stats, so you can prioritize using a certain skill to break before going in with your hard hitting ones.
Vibes: Melancholic, creepy, beautiful. The care put into the artwork is matched by the text: there won't be any long, waxing poetic scenes to make you feel something. Instead, everything flows naturally and makes you want to know more.

If you played Ender Lilies:
Everything that made EL fantastic is here, and improved. If you loved your ghosts as much as I did and wishes you could speak to them, the conversations at respite locations is SO nice. Lilac is a speaking MC too! The combat is so much faster than EL so far, since you can mix and match homunculi together. Play it :)

Going into Ender Magnolia, I wasn't expecting a whole lot more than Ender Lilies, with its 9 major bosses, a third of which I didn't enjoy, a crap ton of mini bosses that just padded the boss count, and a few extremely annoying levels and the rest simply being service. Now, that all isn't to say I didn't enjoy Ender Lilies, I did, but it wasn't much more than a solid, overall enjoyable game for me, a 7/10. But that was good enough for me to be willing to try this one, and man am I glad I did.

Ender Magnolia improves on basically everything that Ender Lilies did. The main bosses, the mini bosses, the levels, everything. Even the music and art style, the best parts of the first game, got even better. And there's a lot more than I expected, to. I was thinking there would be like, 12 or so major bosses, but no, there's 16. And, seeing as most of the bosses in Ender Lilies were on the Steam Trading Cards, I thought most of the trading cards would be bosses, but again, no. There were plenty of surprises in there for sure, and I loved it. Coming across new stuff completely unspoiled is such an amazing feeling. And on top of numbers, the bosses are overall really good. While a bit basic and (in my opinion), easy, they were very fun. Nothing they ever did felt ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and the damage they dealt never felt way too high. And trust me, the final boss of Ending B definitely made up for most of the other boss encounters being somewhat easy. The only real thing I have with the main bosses is that most of them are enjoyable, or even at least passable. So that makes it even more annoying for me that there's exactly 1, only 1, that's annoying as hell and just not fun in the slightest. It was so close to perfection in the boss roster, but that 1 fight has to exist. Still, a huge improvement over Ender Lilies (especially in the final boss department).

Of course, there aren't only main bosses. There are mini bosses. And while they are much less numerous than Ender Lilies, I'd say that makes them much better. They're not just normal enemies given 1 new move and a boss health bar. While they are based on regular enemies, you fight them rather differently. They have enough new stuff to feel unique, and it didn't feel like a waste to fight them as a result. And, of course, there are the levels between all the bosses. They're fun. There's lots to explore, and plenty of actually useful items to find. And none of them were ever all that annoying. There's nothing close to the level of infuriating that was Ender Lilies final area. But I would be lying if I said they're great. Exploration is, admittedly, somewhat limited, and thanks to the fact you never increase your max amount of heals, the levels are typically smaller. And there's no sense of discovery quite like the best metroidvania’s. Overall they're good, but probably play the biggest role in this game being a 9/10, not quite a 10/10.

As a whole though, Ender Magnolia is an amazing game, with some really good bosses, solid levels, and fantastic art and music. Definitely would recommend.

For anyone who enjoyed the first game, Ender Lilies, I cannot find any reason you would not enjoy the sequel. For fans of Metroidvanias, the combat is fluid, the exploration is engaging without bordering on frustrating and the story is just your average anime house of emo albeit without voice acting.

It seems the devs have opted to favor horizontal progression with your moveset. Instead of multiple summons with various abilities you get fewer but have the option to customize which ability of theirs you want to use. Each ability requires different items to upgrade with little overlap which will often incentivize swapping on a first playthrough to use the current highest level abilities.

Ender Magnolia features a wonderful soundtrack which will likely find its way onto many playlists among the playerbase. I have run into no bugs or errors as of yet although the game keeps prompting me to install the latest GPU driver every time I start the game warning about some sort of DX12 issue.

Overall a strongly recommended metroidvania from a team who hit the ground running on their first attempt and have yet to misstep.

First off, this is such a wonderful successor to Ender Lillies. Atmosphere and music-wise, Ender Magnolia is as good if not better than Lillies for the most part. The map system is also incredibly comprehensive in comparison, and feels just perfect in design.


As I've recently 100%ed it, I do have some things to say (some big spoilers for those who have not yet complete the game):
- I wish some areas were more expansive and/or interesting (e.g. the Frost Estate Ruins). They felt like they went by slightly too quickly, but I know this is a big ask since they've already probably put many hours into level design already.
- In addition to the above, I wish secret paths in general were more challenging to find, but I suppose that's difficult to work around considering what Garm and Lars can do as well as the minimap improvements making path finding way easier than in Lillies. That said, I felt that the map could give away too much at some points, where I found it sometimes marked items that were clearly outside of my observable view.
- Some items and abilities are misleading from their descriptions, such as how the protective carapace seems like it's supposed to replicate the Ender Lillies parry from its description, but instead it doesn't knock enemies back like it claims and instead works like a worse impact carapace and just does damage. And unless I'm misunderstanding what "power" means for abilities, it doesn't make sense that Nola's vanquisher has less of it than her soul harvester.
- As someone who played with the max possible difficulty (2x normal values) except for health, I think this should have been an "intense" preset after "hard"; I feel that this way genuinely made the game more fun and anti-cheese than playing even on hard as I had to actively switch around my equipment, relics, and abilities in order to clear the map/beat bosses.
- Even with the difficulty I played at, I think Yolvan is kind of busted. He probably needs a damage and/or break damage nerf on all his abilities and his attuner art. At some points it was kind of like "why use anything else".
- I feel like Garm should have been one of the main homunculus as a cooldown, it just made sense for him to be.
- The completionist in me is sad that there are no achievements for refining all relics and reaching level 100.
- I hope for boss rush and for New Game+ mode to be added in the future, just like in Lillies.
- Even though it would make the game way harder, I would have loved it if more bosses had second phases like with Yolvan. In fact, I'm kind of disappointed that the final fight with Gilroy didn't have one as I went in assuming he would; In terms of boss design he is way better than the Blighted Lord, but the lack of a second phase left me wanting more.
- In addition to the above, the ending came a bit too quick; I wished there was more dialogue and/or scenes depicting the aftermath, like how Lily talked to Fretia and the knight after beating the Blighted Lord.
- The writing for many characters felt somewhat lacking, with most of the reason being because of what information the notes gave and how often you found notes about the characters; In sheer quantity, Lillies has 20 more notes, and considering how much larger in scale Magnolia is, it's odd that it has less. Most of the notes in Lillies also were written either by the relevant characters themselves (e.g. Fretia's memoirs) or by others directly observing them (e.g. White Priestess' Bastion Letter). In Magnolia, most of the notes were used to describe what was going on in the world, but there were very few that were written from or about the main cast (There is only a single note written by Lilia). If it didn't make sense for notes about the characters to exist, then I wished information was written into the game via dialogue.


All in all, a very solid 8/10 game, where one point is dropped mostly because of the somewhat weak and rather abrupt endings and the other due to some character writing weaknesses. I really hope to see a third installment (more Mili music please!), though I wouldn't be surprised if this is the last game taking place in the world Ender Lillies started.
At least, if anything, I hope they make more Metroidvanias as the developers clearly know what they are doing.

UPD: Ну а теперь, после полного прохождения, можно написать и о самой игре. Скажу сразу – очевидный прогресс и работа над ошибками. Видно, что разработчики прислушивались к мнению игроков по поводу Ender Lilies. Если предыдущую часть в основном хотелось крыть пиками точёными, то тут только хвалить. Много где слышал мнение, что игра стала намного легче предыдущей части + где-то было интервью разработчиков, что они решили «упростить игру». Но как по мне, игру не сделали проще, её сделали удобнее и понятнее, ибо большинство «сложностей» Lilies были вызваны раковыми решениями. Вообще сказать хочется много чего, но увы, ограничения стима по количеству символов не позволяют это сделать. Но если максимально кратко:

- Музыка. Всё так же на высоте. Mili знают своё дело.Темы «Старого города», «Стальной улицы» и финального Гилроя на концовку Б автоматом попали в мой основной плейлист.
- Сюжет и лор стали намного лучше и понятнее, так как мир игры стал живым, и у вас есть огромное количество NPC для общения. Вам больше не надо ждать видео от именитых лороведов, чтоб понять происходящее
- Карта теперь максимально понятная и отмечает всё необходимое. Больше никаких квадратов
- Сами уровни и джамп пазлы скакнули вперёд и играть намного интереснее
- Боевая система стала в разы лучше. Топорная прокачка из Лилис - ВСЁ. Теперь вы можете спокойно прокачать всех гомункулов до максимума за одно прохождение. Так же всех неободимых гомункулов вы получите в обязательном порядке, так как это обязательные боссы, а не второстепенные как в Лилис. И так же, почти каждый из них, максимально эффективен для игры. Больше нет ограничения по использованию, теперь влияет лишь кд скила
- Реликвии стали более разнообразными и полезными. В дополнение появились ракушки и браслеты. Единственный нюанс - спутник. Как по мне, "Кит" слишком имба, так как имеет доп заряд ульты, доп хилку и абилку по восстановлению 100% хп, если ваша полоска упадет ниже 15%. Он тупо ставит крест на всех остальных, тем самым обесценивая их
- Боссы стали интереснее и разнообразнее. Особенно хочу отметит Ларса и Седьмого. У Ларса бой разделен на три отдельных сражения на разных аренах. А Седьмой имеет перед собой 3 куклы, которые каждый раз надо побеждать перед тем как сразиться с ним. Ну и хочется упомянуть финального Гилроя, который как по мне, смотрится намного лучше в финале игры, чем "босс голова" саммонер Король скверны в Лилис, который вызывал лишь скуку и уныние

В целом, это, наверное, всё что я хотел бы сказать. Повторюсь ещё раз, Магнолия — это определенно большой прогресс и достижение, и за разработчиков можно порадоваться. На основе Лилис сделали более совершенную и прокачанную игру, которую уже не стыдно рекомендовать своим друзьям. Да, не без недочётов, но всё же. Однозначно рекомендую к покупке и прохождению

So I 100%'d Ender Magnolia like 2 days ago. I'm coming down from the high of playing it, and wanted to give my thoughts of how this game compares to it's predecessor.

It is Ender Lillies but 10x as amazing. I have only 3 legitimate complaints, but none of them detracted from the actual experience of the game.

The best thing I liked about Magnolia was how they implemented the unique movement systems from Lillies directly into the progression of Magnolia. It made the platforming so much more fun since the small little unintended tricks you would do to get places in Lillies are actually legitimate intended moves in Magnolia.

The story was so much better in Magnolia, especially now that we had a narrative and speaking protagonist. There were also a ton of side characters who move around the map, and small side quests to discover. You can also talk to your Homunculus (this game's spirits) at rest points to learn more about them & the world.

The setting in the game was pretty good, but I personally enjoyed Lillies more. Lillies gave a way more post-apocalyptic grimdark setting, whereas Magnolia was way more mid-apocalyptic setting. Where the locations in Lillies was always filled with death and decay, Magnolia you can still find life and civilization still struggling amidst the ongoing threats. This lowers the grimdark horror backdrop that people may have enjoyed in Lillies, but Magnolia doesn't completely forgo these vibes as there are a few very specific levels that I argue are creepier than most places in Lillies. (A very certain Estate comes to mind.)

The combat in the game is way better balanced than in Lillies, but does suffer from limited variety in choices for a good majority of the game. Not being able to utilize more than 1 style from each respective Homunculus results in you feeling as though you have to play a hybrid combat style utilizing 2-3 different types of Homunculus (There are 4 action slots available, but no single combat style has 4 Homunculus. The most that one has is 3.). If you do try and limit yourself to a single style of combat, you'll feel as though your severely limiting yourself.

However, by balancing having the combat be balanced around the idea that you are utilizing multiple styles, the boss fights in this game end up being so much better than Lillies. You can go into nearly every boss fight in this game with whatever setup you've grown accustomed too, and feel as though it's viable and fair to use against them. Which does lead me to the fact that boss fights in this game are magnificent. I cannot wait until the boss refight/rush mode to be added, because I want to try my hand at finishing some of the fights without getting hit.

Lastly, progression in this game my feel linear to some, but after comparing my progression route to my friends, and looking deeply into how things unlock, the progression in this game is actually way more unlocked than Lillies, it's simply that the game actually gives you hints in where to go, so it can feel as though the game is handholding you towards certain areas.

Ultimately, an amazing experience that feels as though they took all the good parts of Ender Lillies and improved upon them 10fold.

Suffice to say that if you enjoyed the original, you will likely enjoy this one. For those that haven't played that, I recommend starting with Ender Lillies - despite some of the gameplay improvements Magnolia offers, the setting and story of the first game resonated with me much more deeply, though the story here is also pretty good.

Besides that, Magnolia is a highly competent, visually arresting metroidvania like its predecessor, that doesn't do too much differently from the standard ability gated progression you might expect though its offensive ability system is pretty unique, your character doesn't have any direct attacks but can summon others to fight on her behalf (think Stands from Jojo), though in practice it doesn't feel too different from other metroidvanias. Difficulty is completely at the players discretion - like with Nine Sols the game difficulty can be tailored so that pretty much anyone can beat it or ramped up to be very hard. I played on normal and it was quite easy apart from a couple of bosses.

Oh and the map is great - enough info to make going for 100% completion fun but not tedious. It has pins you can set but I never needed them once thanks to the automatic markers. 100% + all endings took me about 35 hours.

A very strong Metroidvania, highly recommended.

A great follow-up to Ender Lilies. If you liked that game, you'll like this one. The difficulty's engaging as always, the bosses are well designed and fun to fight, the areas are enjoyable to explore and never feel like a slog. If I wish for anything, it's that it was a little less linear. Not that it's completely linear but it feels that way at times. And maybe to get one-shot from full HP less on hard mode, though I did kind of sign up for that.

The visuals are great, the music's great. Generally, the gamefeel is just overall top-tier, very high quality, I noticed 0 bugs as far as I could tell which is a good sign.

The story feels a little less emotionally impactful than Lilies', though the ability to chat with your party members was a huge boon, given you can actually have more than one character in the story now.

Overall? A+. Very good game, highly looking forward to anything this studio does next.

Могу сказать что магнолия смогла меня удивить, своей атмосферой, персонажами и геймплеем. Игра попадает в одну из лучших для. Игра заняла у меня 20 часов, 17 часов наиграл в бету версий игры перепроходя её больше 6 раз. По сложности игра не такая уж и сложная, играл с кастомным модификацией больше сложного. Сюжет в игре очень приземленный, и из-за того что я проходил не в хронологической части, он мне казался очень странным и не логичным. геймплей и фишка метроидваний мне очень зашла, и дает больше подумать как решать определенные пазлы. На 100% проходиться не очень нудно, по крайне мере если подбирать колектоболы во время игры. Про РПГ составляющие игры, не сказал бы что тут есть большое разнобразия в билдах под определенные тип геймплея, но их предостаточно.

Перейдя обратно к сюжету, хочу обсудить каноничность концовок прошлой игры. Считаю что концовка А каноничная, да и гештальт с дождем не заканчивался для магнолии. Мне нравится как показали общение и взаимодействие персонажей, но меня больше всего выбешивает от того, что белого рыцаря(забыл его имя) и его раскрытие с Йораном меня не то что не тронуло, но еще и раскрытие толкового нет. Один разговор с этим гомунколом где показывает его как типичного нормиса

мне честно больше нечего сказать, я и так некоторую часть заспойлериk.
Моя оценка к игре 9/10. Одна из лучших для меня игр, но честно мне Лилий больше запали в душу. Хоть и магнолия в геймплее лучше, но возможно это моя вина из-за быстрого подхода к игре. Я не успел так сильно проникнуться к персонажам и миру. Но признаюсь от финала хорошей концовки, я чуть не заплакал. Магнолии действительно удалось прыгнуть выше головы, и я могу рекомендовать к прохождению или как минимум к просмотру сюжета.

пост возможно поменяю со временем дополнив, или изменив что либо. Думаю перепройду игру заново в ближайшее время

Достойный продолжатель серии.
Что понравилось:
1. Боссфайты - в меру сложные, в меру рандомные. Биться интересно.
2. Рисовка локаций - приятные глазу. Сцена битвы с Йорваном вообше отпад. Аллюзия на БигБена.
3. Игра не затянута, проходиться довольно-таки быстро.
4. Музыка - хорошие композиции.
Что не понравилось:
1. Навыки - очень несбалансированная система.
Первое что не устраивает: момент открытия навыков - зачем мне новая "Основная" атака перед финальным боссом? Зачем мне эта непонятная "башенка"? Если бы напарников было меньше - ничего в геймплее бы не поменялось.
Второе: после открытия 3 варианта атаки Йорвана (вихрь), ты понимаешь, что это имбалансный скилл на всю игру, от которого ты и будешь играть. Нет причин играть по другому. Немного это расстроило.
2. Музыка - малое количество композиций быстро приедается, очень чувствуется на первых локациях. Дальше - лучше.
3. Механика "ракушка". Этот своеобразный "паладинский бабл". Её вообще кто-то использовал? Зачем нужна эта механика, когда есть нормальный уворот(dash)?
4. Во время боёв с боссами не хватало акцентирования ГГ. Её фигурка просто временами теряется.
Если не путаю: В предыдущей игре было некое выделение (белый цвет, свечение), которое помогало понимать, где основной персонаж.
5. Очень не хватило левел-дизайна в плане загадок для открываемых навыков передвижения. Они есть, они интересные, но их как-будто немножко недостаточно.
6. Немного смазанное ощущение от финального босса. Госпожа ведьма заставила потеть намного сильнее (и это было классно).
Итоги: очень крепкая метроидвания с хорошим визуалом и приятным геймплеем.
Настраиваемая сложность под себя даёт некое разнообразие, хотя я почти сразу врубил себе сложный режим, как только его нашёл.
Я бы поставил ей крепкую 4+ из 5. Надеюсь, что к игре выйдет какое-нибудь дополнение, которое даст нам какие-либо дополнительные вызовы.
Я рад что поиграл в эту игру.

The storyline is simple, but honestly the exploration, world design and the boss fights are top notch.

When I first started playing Magnolia, it was difficult to truly enjoy it. Mostly because the game chugged so it was hard to not look at it funny. Yet, even after a patch had fixed the game and the lag. It started doing it again, in the final hours of my play-through no less. By then I was used to it though and it didn't subtract from my overall experience.

Having played Ender Lilies i'm not quite sure which is honestly better. Lilies had better combat, in terms of freedom to play how you like. Magnolia cut back on the options but also added more mechanics. Like parrying, which was somewhat annoying when my game is chugging. That aside. The combat was overall smoother and refined, which i enjoyed. It also felt less forgiving than Lilies overall combat. Like i just didn't have as much health or defense. Even against the final boss.

In terms of story however, i'd have to give it to Lilies. That world felt so lived in and connected, beautiful and tragic. Exploration didn't feel like a hassle, more so an adventure. Whereas Magnolia felt quite a bit of the opposite. Still much the same as Lilies world of course. Yet it just felt more tragic and overall a hassle. Ever since the crimson forest, exploration was just more annoying than enjoyable. There were still some good areas, like the academy. But it felt like a downward spiral nonetheless.

I still think this was a good game. But do i think it was better than Ender Lilies? Not really. I'd still give the first game a solid 10. And this game a 9.5 at worst.
