Great game. Worth every penny and second spent on 100%'ing it. Amazing art, nice character designs, perfect atmosphere, passable/okay/good combat (nothing special, but competent), feels good to move around the world. Also, I want to mention that I love how they did their achievements, no soul crushing BS ones. No forced "Beat the game on all the difficulties" nonsense. I play games on the hardest or at least harder setting for my enjoyment, but having achieves try to force me to play on easy or gimmick difficulties is always lame so I'm glad this one didn't do it! Also more games need to use this style of difficulty settings!

I will say the last boss is lame, but the thing is... the combat in this game is just okay. The focus isn't on the combat, it isn't super fancy and it can feel a little stiff or janky on rare occasion; the focus is on vibe, art, story, atmosphere, and so on.

The world is generally enjoyable to move around in, and my favorite part is just HOW much freedom you have. I was chaining attacks, jumps, dashes, air stalls, ect... together and reach places in unintended ways constantly. Getting things a little earlier than intended all the time, but it never breaks the game or make you overpowered. It feels like they had their intended ways to reach items, but also carefully took into account how much mobility you'd have access to if you're a player like me and planned the placements and what items specifically would be where according to that as well.

I did my playthrough entirely on 1.5 in all of the difficulty meters, which is higher than the "Hard" difficulty, and I felt it was nearly perfect at all 1.5's. I would recommend Hard as the absolute minimum difficulty you play on, cause anything less would just make the game zero fun.

The biggest gripe I have with it is that the final boss is lame... it's just... not impressive or fun. It's a very specific type of fight that almost forces a specific play style... almost; you CAN get away with any play style, but if you don't do what the game WANTS you to do, you will feel it the entire time you're fighting him. Every time you fight him. It's not the WORST... but it's not good. It's not fun. It's not "challenging" as much as it is tedious and draws itself out to near exhaustion. And if you die... you have to trudge through it all again.

The run backs in this game are mostly extremely short, there are a few here or there though that will test your patience if you end up taking a couple tries on those bosses.

!!!!------Spoiler Below This... Kinda... It's About My Feelings On One Of The Themes------!!!!
|
|
|
|
|
|

The theme of "Life is only worth living cause we die, living forever isn't good." Is extremely overused and thoroughly just plain wrong. It's insane that people try to sell that concept... "Oh well if you lived forever you'd have to see all your loved ones die."... that's no different than normal life. The only difference is that YOU might get "lucky(?)" and die first, thus forcing your loved ones to deal with YOUR death. But otherwise, we all have to watch all of our loved ones die, for the most part. It's such a worthless perspective to try to sling. In this game's case it's a situation where IF they keep living forever, it's a terrible existence that is void of any hope for improvement. So it kinda can get away with it, but it will always rub me the wrong way when people think they're making some sort of deep commentary about life, the value of life, and what makes life worth living when they regurgitate that nonsense. It's only lightly touched on here or there, so again, it didn't grate on me much during my playthrough, however the ending just takes that deflated ball that's been being sadly flopped about as you progress and spikes it like it just did something worth noting and the groan and eye-roll it induced was enough to make me want to add this here. Also BUY THE GAME AND PLAY IT!!!!

---see where this game landed on my Metroidvania tier list beneath this review!---

This was a really nice metroidvania to start the year off, possibly would have been my metroidvania of the year had it released in 2024.

The game took me around 20 hours to fully explore and get the good ending. Unlike Ender Lilies, to finish getting all of the Steam achievements would mean spending MANY additional hours farming currency to buy everything, which doesn't seem like fun to me.

I've found that some people who hated the first game had a blast with the second, I'd say the sequel plays better and is more accessible.

I was split on whether I felt the first game was a soulslike or not.. leaning towards probably, but I don't feel that this sequel is. Not a good or bad thing, just a gut feel and observation.

Movement is a little slow, a little floaty, but felt good enough for me, I was happy with it.

Your character can level up and equip 4 different attacks from a pool of options to choose from. There is a parry option, though I wasn't forced into ever using it.

You also have 4 slots for equipment (items in these slots are mostly + to stats, with some exceptions).

You also can equip a number of relics/charms (that mostly give passive benefits) and your charm/relic limit will increase as you collect more containers for them (just like the first game if I recall correctly).

The game throws enough of a challenge with some of its boss fights, but there was nothing I was stuck on for very long. You can lose 70% of your hitpoint bar to some boss attacks and even big chunks of HP from regular enemies. Now I would prefer to be able to take more hits, but I think the game difficulty is finely balanced as it is and I don't think they should touch that at all. In a perfect world, I would like to be able to take more hits, and perhaps enemies would be designed to be faster and more relentless to make up for their reduced damage.

The map is improved compared to the first game. This one shows room geometry and your position in the room as well. While the first games map had its critics (I was more than fine with it), I imagine most people will be very happy with this one. You can place map pins, but I only pinned 2 things. The map does such a good job that you don't really require them. The map is great.

There was a decent amount of non-linearity for a metroidvania. ..at least enough that it should get the thumbs up from most die-hard metroidvania fans.

The music.. I wasn't a big fan of the first games soundtrack. I know it has its fans, so its a taste thing, but I found it dull but with a couple of notable exceptions that stuck in my head (, ). ..so I wasn't sure what to expect from Ender Magnolia, given it had the same composer. With this sequel, I disliked the first music track or two as there was a bit of an "easy listening anime sound" too it that I'm just not fond of. Fortunately this was just the first couple of tracks and the music was actually on the plus side for me afterall. I think those two Ender Lilies tracks remain my favourite work from the composer, but at least in this game I wasn't consistently as bored with the background music.

In conclusion, Ender Magnolia was a very good time and pretty easy to recommend. It kind of did what Blasphemous did with their sequel by making something that is (at least arguably) better and more accessible. ..so much so that these games have the potential to be a good time even for players that disliked the first outings. Two thumbs up!

Solid Metroidvania. Improves over the first game, in small and large ways. Your minions/abilities are no longer limited to X/rest. Some have short cooldowns. There's also more NPCs, with sidequests, and the brilliant notion of having the NPC initiate conversation if you're carrying a relevant quest item. Because the cast... ain't that memorable, though they greatly add to the feel of the world.

The world is gorgeous. The animations are good. *Most* bosses are good. I didn't care for a couple that could kill in two hits. And I really did not appreciate one's "shield" that, when hit, would unleash an attack that might kill you outright. It wasn't well telegraphed, so when the shield went up, I couldn't stop attacking unless I was already out of range.

But I suppose the solution to that would be less aggression on my part. Or, what I did... turning the difficulty down.

There were other fights I did change my loadout for, and those felt good.

Worth the price of admission.

Добил таки игру, одна из самых лёгких платин в моей скромной коллекции. Видно что старались сделать лучше первой части и в общем это даже вышло, хоть и не без недостатков.
Насколько мне помнится в прошлой части боссы были плотнее, а мувсет у них очень частично открывался по мере убавления хп, тут же в целом это так явно в глаза не бросается. Зато бросается почти одна и та же атака с бурением земли(босс встает на месте и начинает в обе стороны спамить кучей рандомных снарядов с навесной траекторией). Вообще пусть боссы и в целом стали интереснее,есть и прям неприятные (привет огромному роботу с очень широкими атаками и рывками на пол арены и ведьме с отхилом), но на крайний случай всегда через менюшку на скамейках можно срезать им статы, что по факту вроде бы только фарм валюты для доп.контента влияет(всякие картиночки за неё можно открывать).
Ещё зачем-то почти на каждой локе есть хоть один моб у которого в жизни одна цель: напустить какого-нибудь аоешное облако из-за чего без дальней атаки грустно, благо хоть теперь все спеллы не имеют зарядов, а стрелка нам дают самым первым из самонок вообще.
А ещё есть очень неудобный, душный даже по меркам жанра лес-лабиринт(но его обещают понерфить), я на нём настолько заблудился что перекачался и босс после него расклеился быстрее некоторых мини-боссов. Но кроме него локи приятные, платформинг простой, секретки благодаря подсветке исследованных областей искать удобно.
Короче, игра всё равно хорошая, звучит и выглядит всё ещё классно, я доволен, хотя мне в последнее время вообще редко что-то нравится

Beautiful game. It maintains a lot of the strong visual and sound design identity from the original while making sure it's uniquely distinct. New combat mechanics make it more fun, enjoyable, and dynamic when fighting bosses. Areas aren't as memorable and the parallax backgrounds aren't as awe inspiring as Ender Lilies. For anyone who played "Ender Lilies", it's more of that, and that's probably all that anyone with that experience needs to hear.

For those not familiar with the previous game in the series, this is an excellent "souls-lite" metroidvania style game focused around exploration, gaining abilities, and relatively difficult combat.

Combat is usually reasonably balanced by both enemies and the player being extremely lethal to each other. Difficulty can get a bit wonky near the end - the boss I found hardest was a few away from the "True End" boss, for example. It is very possible for the player to 100 to 0 combo an enemy, and it's very possible for enemies to one-shot and/or 100 to 0 combo the player, which results in an interesting gameplay flow alternating between careful movement and the ability to recklessly destroy a vulnerable or out-of-position foe. Enemy attack damage, attack frequency, health, and stagger rates are all adjustable for those finding the game either too easy or too hard.

Exploration is generally reasonably rewarded - I never felt like I was wasting my time exploring an area, and I also never felt that any reward for exploring was too much of a jump in power compared to the effort to receive it. Zone completion is displayed on the map, and requirements for specific abilities are usually automatically marked, which makes it easy to tell when to backtrack to different places - I'd say this makes the exploration generally "introductory level", and may be a bit easier than some players want, but for most people it's a nice set of QoL features.

World remains interesting, and generally shows enough to give interesting details without over-explaining. Story can be a bit thin at times, but does not detract from an otherwise excellent experience.

Devs are very responsive so far, and have already released an update patch only a few days after the game has come out to address community flagged issues.

TLDR: If you liked the first game you'll like this one.

Improvements from the first game:
Combat just feels smoother. The fact that the first movement unlock/upgrade is the air dodge just makes the earlier combat feel better than the first game. One of the big changes as well was to make the spirits run on cool downs and not limited uses which makes exploring feel better.
Spirits/homunculi are a lot more detailed. While I'm not far into the game it does seem to have fewer spirits than the first and while it may be a bit of a downside the improvement is that each one feels completely unique with a new upgrade system.
The rest areas also are much better in the fact that there are times when you speak to each homunculi you get. I really like how the homunculi talk to each other and not just us, it just makes their stories and personalities that much better.

Downgrades:
The only real complaint I have is with the human npc's. It's just a bit strange/uncanny how a lot of them just say their random thoughts out loud to us for no reason. It's a bit weird to describe, but other then a few of them if you replaced them all with journal scraps I wouldn't have noticed that much of a difference in the game.

Замечательная игра. Помню как давно проходил лилию, игра была также хорошей, но не без минусов. Из таких, саунд дизайн и слишком уж простая история боссов, где ты их убиваешь, а потом, оказывается, они не были плохими, и выглядело это все довольно натянуто. В сиквеле очень сильно над этим постарались и прокачали режесуру, история мира стала комплекснее и сложнее. Так же понравилось введение новой концепции, и что при этом механика битв осталась такой же, но при этом сильно прокачалась. Игра стала чуть менее красочной, как мне кажется, но более мрачной и в антураже первой части. Понравилось то, что ввели чуть ли не полноценные катсцены, и разговоры с персонажами, из-за чего по мере прохождения игры они действительно становятся для тебя товарищами, а не безликими куклами как в первой части. Так же поработали над звуком, он стал куда приятнее и отклик от ударов и получения урона ощущается иначе. Так же из интересных моментов, они оставили систему зачистки карты и перерисовки ее в синий, и при этом сама карта выглядит адекватно, а не как нагромождение прямоугольников, что вгоняло в ступор. Но самое главное лично для меня - у игры осталась все та же прекрасная музыка. Первую часть в свое время я так полюбил именно из-за нее и приятно осознавать, что в сиквеле она ничуть не пострадала(чего я, на самом деле, боялся). По итогу, хочу сказать что разработчики сделали большую работу над ошибками, кардинально улучшили геймплей и укрепили историю и лор игры, и игра своих денег стоит. Надеюсь, это не последний раз, когда мы слышим о Дымной стране и Запределье

Gameplay - 9.5/10
There were some parts that felt a little awkward but otherwise i had no complaints. The combat is smooth, and the build variety can change heavily depending on your playstyle. You can have a build where you just unload projectiles non stop and dump out damage but you're relatively squishy or a build entirely around counter attacks and playing a more slow defensive game. There were some enemies that i felt hit a little too hard but nothing that felt unfair or game breaking.

Music 10/10
Just like their first game, the ost is amazing. From beginning to end there was no song that I did not like listening to. From a sad/somber music to a bit more energetic to even some unsettling this game has it all. I would sometimes find myself just sitting in an area for a couple of minutes just to appreciate the songs.

Story 8/10
The story doesn't bring anything crazy or new to the table but it does what it does really well. It felt a little more straightforward than their first game but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. There are a lot of little lore pieces scattered around the world on items and equipment. Even the character/model viewer has some extra bits on them. If you've played a lot of JRPGs and/or consumed a lot of anime/manga chances are you would've encountered a very similar story.

Overall 9.5/10
I love metroidvania games and Ender Magnolia is definitely in the top 5 I've played. There hasn't been any point in the game that i disliked and the exploration felt nice. The combat is smooth, the music is fantastic, the environment/art is incredibly well done.

TLDR; Game is good, highly recommended.

After waiting for ages for the second game to come out it finally came out! The sequel to the previous game, Ender Magnolia is a fairly good successor to the previous game. While I don't think its as good as Ender Lilies, I still think its one of the better Metroidvania games out there and absolutely worth buying and playing. I 100% the game on hard mode and here's my experience with the game.

Music in the game is top notch. Along with the first game the team behind it really knows how to put together some amazing tracks. I don't have much else to say on it I didn't say for Ender Lilies in that review. While the game and the tracks are more hopeful than the previous game's this fits better with the Dystopian world vs the Apocalyptic world of the first game.

Story wise, Ender Magnolia has far more dynamic and interesting characters than the first game, but I just couldn't get into it as much. Lilac is a nice character, and I do like her but the issue is this world has other people in it, and presumably other people who are not only adults but more capable of taking on the tasks the game has to offer. So to have certain parts of the game were people are relying on a child to solve their issues like save people, I just found my immersion breaking at that point. A minor gripe, but its not the only issue I have with the story. While the world building is pretty decent, the Amnesia plot for Lilac and Nola created more of a barrier for me to connect with the characters than it did make me want to solve the mystery. In this regard, trying to piece together what happened in the first game from the perspective of a character who wouldn't know vs trying to recover memories and getting those memories jumbled with other character's memories really makes Ender Magnolia's story a bit of a mess in comparison.

As far as controls go, the game is tight. It absolutely improves on the first game in nearly every way. Lilac feels much better to play than Lily did here I have to bring up another issue I had. The abilities in the first game are better balanced than the second game. While in the first game you had your unlimited abilities which could be used forever and your abilities which had ammo and some abilities had a cooldown Ender Magnolia does a away with ammo to the game's determent. Because of this once I got two attack abilities with no cooldown and no animation lock which are both ranged the rest of the game became trivially easy. I could dish out thousands of damage in a second and build my super meter within seconds. Even with as busted as some of the abilities are in Ender Lilies they don't compare to just how over the top Ender Magnolia's abilities are.

The Relics and equipment are both pretty good systems. I really liked how these worked. Other than the Parry they're mostly just stat buffs which is fine by me. Some of them give you health on defeating an enemy or dealing damage, which is nice. I found myself swapping them out frequently depending on what I was doing early in the game. The Equipment was a bit different though as they had some uniqueness to them. While the rings were pretty standard the Parry device and the other device were far more interesting actually creating real choice. I ended up going with the parry that shot projectiles and the device that gave me a second attuner art bar by the end of the game. Although the passive health regen was really useful as well.

Upgrading stuff was pretty tedious. I personally dislike shops in metroidvanias as I find them to be a distraction from doing the main thing I want to be doing... Exploring. The fact I needed to head back to a shop to check out what I just discovered then potentially grind to upgrade it to go back and buy it was just a level of padding I don't like. This isn't a problem exclusive to Ender Magnolia, but it has become a stable of the genre I was so happy Ender Lilies decided against and Its inclusion in Ender Magnolia is a stain on an otherwise good system. Exploring areas to discover something and instead finding an upgrade component or a ring I find the schematics for a ring or component I then need to take back to the shop to then find out I don't have enough scrap so I need to grind to then go back AGAIN to finally get the thing I found an hour ago.

As far as the map and environment goes, I think its great for the most part. Visually the game is stunning! The maps are super pretty and exploring the map was still very rewarding. Its still easy to discover everything like it was in the first game since the maps go from grey to blue once completed which is a nice feature. I really enjoyed exploration overall, even with my complaint about how the shops were integrated into that system its still really fun to discover stuff.

Overall the game is great! I highly recommend it. I don't think you'll be disappointed by the game at all.

To be clear, the point isn't to just boost gameplay hours, but to thoroughly appreciate what the team put together. I guess it'll make for a better replay experience once I let it sit for a while.

Ehhh it's alright.
Bit of a disappointment compared to the previous game. The quiet, somber atmosphere is gone - there is just so much NPCs around, the protag is no longer mute and the helpers are quite chatty as well. Sure it's not as depressing of a world as in Lilies but not as gripping as well. It just feels like even if we weren't around, the world would do just fine without our involvement so there is less of a push to actually do anything. It's more of a personal story of the main heroines and it's a matter of preference if you are into that shift I suppose.
Speaking of main characters, it's also a bit of a downgrade. First game worked really well because it knew how to tickle that monkey part of the brain that made you want to protect this helpless and precious creature from all the evils of the world. Here the player character feels much more capable and well, way less cute so it doesn't work as well. The striking juxtaposition of pure girl and brutish, almost monstrous helper characters protecting her is also gone with Homonoculi feeling much more human - which is the point I know but just isn't as interesting.
Other than those two glaring problems I think the game is still pretty good, music quality has been retained and hits really well here too, controls are on-point, gameplay is great if a bit too easy (even on hard difficulty) and a bit too grindy (with currency grinding, levels are not that much needed) at times. Map is humongous, took me like 20 hours to explore everything and game retained it's very player friendly feature of coloring map squares when everything in that section has been found.
Overall - play the first game it's better in my opinion. If you played it and liked it you will probably like this one too but consider grabbing it on sale as it has some issues.

Вот и прошёл эту игру. Её предшественницей, Ender Lilies был крайне доволен и несколько раз перепроходил её на тру концовку, так что Ender Mognolia ждал с нетерпением.

Видно, что разработчик слушал игроков, и очень многие аспекты прошлой части, которые хромали, были доведены почти до идеала: карта стала самой удобной среди всех метроидваний, в которые я играл, рисовка и дизайн игры стали ещё роскошнее, все персонажи имеют свои личности и характеры, и даже появились небольшие побочные квесты, пройти которые не составит труда тем, кто играет в игру (в отличии от Afterimage, где доп квесты были словно в Dark Souls, где ничего не понятно, кому нести и куда идти). Новая система сопартийцев с уменьшенным количеством, но зато с разнооборазными навыками, прокачка которых прямо зависит от прогресса в исследовании карты - отличное решение и играется очень хорошо. В целом, с геймплейной точки зрения, игра во всём превосходит предшествиницу. А теперь перейдём к тому, что получилось, на мой взгляд, не очень.

Сюжет в прошлой игре был незамысловатый, но зато подавался так, что ты и с немой главной героиней проникался его аспектами, гнетущей атмосферой дождя смерти, ужасом, которые переживают осквернённые, теряя себя и превращаясь в монстров. В Ender Mognolia того же эффекта не удалось достичь по следующим, как я считаю, причинам: персонажи заимели свои реплики и главная героиня стала мочь спрашивать их обо всём, вследствие чего подачу сюжета изменили, добавив интриг в борьбе могущественных кланов магов, взаимоотношений настройщиков и их гомункулов и т.д., но по итогу получилось немного перегружено и осталось больше вопросов, на которые ответа либо нет, либо он скрыт между строк текста и описания реликвий. Главная героиня, Лайлак, не столь располагает к себе из-за того, что, как я и писал выше, её история получилась перегружена и содержит многовато недосказанностей. В Ender Lilies была одна сюжетная линия, и от неё отходили маленькие рсотки сюжетов призраков и осквернённых, как, например, бастард Юлий, но в этой игре наоборот, несколько сюжетов сводятся в единую картину, или, скорее, пытаются свестись, ибо по итогу остаётся несколько важных белых пятен, и из-за раздробленности главного сюжета и того, что какой-то важной детали, на подобии лаборатории в осквернённых землях прошлой игры, где нам раскрывалась главная цель сюжета, и дальше вся картина начинает складываться, то в здесь такой элемент отсутствует. Так же я не совсем понимаю, в чём связь с прошлой игрой, ведь в ней мы покончили со скверной, а тут и новый дождь, и новые осквернённые. Разве с ними не было покончено в прошлой части? Так же неожиданное появление, как рояль из кустов, "жрицы из далёкой страны", благодаря которой мы и побеждаем напасть. Происходить словно обесценивание прошлой части и того, что мы в ней сделали. В общем, сюжет вышел неплохим, но улучшали его только увеличением масштаба, из-за чего потеряли в напонении.

По итогу мы имеем отличную игру, превзошедшую во многих аспектах предшественницу, однако идеальной Ender Magnolia назвать сложно, так как сюжет стал больше, добавились полноценные нпс и все наши гомункулы стали полноценными личностями, однако ценой за это стало ухудшение понимания, общая драма и интрига сюжета. Если прямо полностью закрывать контент, то выйдет 30 часов отличной игры. Очень советую )

I loved Ender Lillies, and this game improves upon it in just about every conceivable way-- even the music, which was already a highlight of its predecessor.

The color design in the areas makes them all feel so much more alive and unique than the hauntingly melancholic shades of brown and gray that desaturated the first game. There are ten unique partners with three abilities each, and they have skit-like conversations sprinkled throughout the game that give each of them more life-- which some may like and some may dislike. The combat was wonderful and smooth throughout, the movement abilities felt amazing to obtain, there's incentives to play more and crank up the extremely modular difficulty to unlock an *extensive* in-game art gallery faster via a currency that you earn by simply playing and fighting things.

It was a beautiful experience and one of the very few times a game I waited years for was worth every minute of the wait.

I was ecstatic to learn that ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights was getting a sequel.

When I found out that it was out, I soon bought and beat what was available in the early access. (takes around 2 hours)

This game can very well surpass it's predecessor when fully released. Binary Haze Interactive did an outstanding job improving the animation quality of the in-game/cutscene animations. Instead of the still imagery of ENDER LILIES' cutscenes, ENDER MAGNOLIA's animations have seemingly come to life. The base mechanics are relatively the same, except for the swapping of spirit sets, which was removed entirely for the early access. Spirits, what are now known as Homunculi, have different skill paths that you can devote resources into to give them different weapons/effects, making for far more build potential.

The music is about the same as the first game, which is fantastic. (Listen to "Shackled Beast 01" by far my favorite track in the early access)
Since this game only has 2 hours of content I can't really say much for the story, as there's really not a lot. Your character "Lilac" has just awoken and doesn't seem to have much memory of her own past. Seeing as this game is a SEQUEL to ENDER LILIES, albeit by a few centuries (supposedly), I'm hopeful to find pieces of lore/story about the blight and the canon ending of what happened to Lily.

COME JANUARY 22nd! REJOICE!

Ender Magnolia is a sequel massively improved compared to its first game Ender Lilie. If you could finish Lilie you can actually start this game on Hard difficulty and it's probably still easier.

-Rewarding stun bar and parry
-Various unique environments
-Fair boss and enemy attack design

It's a very balanced experience that no matter if you are hardcore Metroidvania enjoyer or newcomer of the genre, it just feels very enjoyable.

Having now 100%'d the game, I'm going to give my full review. Short version, it is a solid game. If you liked the prequel, you'll like this one. It's a solid sequel with only a few issues that it's predecessor also had.
Long Version - The great, good, okay, bad and ugly.

The Great
- The music. Much like its predecessor, the music is a banger. There is one track I'm not too keen on, but it's still well made (I don't think a cheery chant is really fitting for the Steel Factory, but it is what it is)
- The art direction. Again, like the prior game, it's superb. The backgrounds are interesting, the enemies and characters are well designed, and the art direction/lighting is great.
- The character writing. The interactions between Lilac and the homunculai are great. I loved the witty banter at the benches.

The Good
- The bosses. There are a couple stinkers. Like, MAJOR stinkers. But there's also a lot of REALLY great ones. So I averaged it out to good as there are more good than bad.
- The Summon system. There are only 10 summons, but they all have their uses and come with a variety of skills you can select. They're also infinite use, which is awesome. The problem is, a lot of these abilities are... situational at best, worthless at worst. A few summons like Nola, have 3 amazing abilities. Others tend to just have one that I used the entire game, and never touched the other 2 because they were just not as effective or reliable.

The Okay
- The story is decent. There are a lot of plot points they set up to try and build some intrigue and mystery but... they don't really go anywhere? A lot of plotlines just END, and don't really feel satisfying. The main story is more of the same from the first game, which is good, but the lacklustre side quests and "plot twists" that don't even feel like twists drag it down for me.
- The map layout. I don't really feel too strongly either way honestly. A lot of the map is very simple and direct. It all looks nice, as stated in the art direction, but overall the actual map distribution and progression did nothing for me.
- Difficulty options. I thought Ender Lilies was a bit too erratic with its difficulty at launch. You would clear a huge swathe of the game, then find 1 boss or elite enemy that just 1 tapped you and became a wall. The difficulty overall for this game is more linear, and the difficulty options are nice, but it's very clear the devs didn't balance anything beyond hard mode. I played the game at 150% difficulty and it's quite apparent that it's not how the game is meant to be played as you never ever feel stronger, merely like you're always just scraping by to try and not get 1 shot from even basic enemies. All in all it was a decent idea but I don't think it was executed too well either.

The Bad
- Equipment. Okay future devs, listen up. You do NOT need to have every piece of gear be a trade off. Just because something is good for stat A, doesn't mean you need to have it lobotomize stat B. Sometimes gear can just be GOOD. Now if one piece is AMAZING for one stat, yeah you can have it debuff others, but I swear 90% of the totems and carapace's are worthless, and over half the bracelets are too because they just take too much away from you vs the boon you get. I wound up using the same totem (and the stronger version later) and same carapace for the entire game, and only upgrades my bracelets when there was a CLEAR boost to my stats. The relics are okay, but there are a few you will ALWAYS have on, and some you will only use for niche situations, and about 33% you will never ever touch.

The Ugly
- Nothing of note.

Russian and English Review

Russian
Достойное продолжение первой части, боевка причесана, добавлены разные навыки, хотя многие имхо тольок для галочки т.к. пользы мало, сюжет есть, подача, ну довольно стандартная уже, посредством воспоминаний и записок. В меру сложная, биомы разные что понравилось, что не понравилось - мало вариаций атак боссов - только по 2-3 на брата, так что вся битва становится лишь заучиванием паттернов и таймингов, вариативности немного. на платину выбивается легко. В общем если понарвился первая часть - смело брать и играть, стоит своих денег. Для тех кто не играл в 1 часть - может показаться странной, можете попробовать но понравится не всем

English
A worthy continuation of the first part, the combat is combed, various skills are added, although many IMHO are only for show because there is little benefit, there is a plot, the presentation is already quite standard, through memories and notes. Moderately difficult, the biomes are different, what I liked, what I didn't like - few variations of boss attacks - only 2-3 per brother, so the whole battle becomes just memorizing patterns and timings, little variability. It's easy to get to platinum. In general, if you liked the first part - feel free to take it and play, it's worth the money. For those who haven't played part 1 - it may seem strange, you can try it but not everyone will like it

Exploration: 4/5
Ender Magnolia has a richly interconnected world filled with hidden areas, secret items, and lore that reward thorough exploration. Each area is distinct and unique, featuring a variety of enemy types. Almost every area has a reason to be revisited later to find everything. The game is somewhat nonlinear, providing players with the freedom to chart their own paths with minimal explicit guidance. The map has been greatly improved from Ender Lilies.

Gameplay: 4/5
The controls are responsive, and platforming segments demand precision. Combat is both challenging and satisfying, offering a variety of enemies and bosses that require different strategies. The combat system is well-designed, with a variety of attacks and abilities that can be performed through Homunculi allies. Relics, carapace, and totems offer a large amount of character customization. I was a little disappointed with the dash, as it's quite short with minor visuals and we barely get to use the roll before unlocking the dash.

The game features substantial progression from start to finish. Players can find and enhance various equipment, relics, and items throughout their journey. Resources obtained from the environment and enemies can be used to upgrade these items, providing a sense of growth and empowerment. This system encourages exploration and experimentation with different builds and strategies.

Set after the events of Ender Lilies in a nearby land, the game presents a vast, grim industrial world with much to uncover. The world-building is excellent, drawing players into a narrative that explores themes of artificial life and corruption. While the main story focuses on Lilac's quest to purify the corrupted Homunculi, the surrounding characters and NPCs are intriguing, with their stories adding layers to the game’s world. This game is excellent at revealing pieces of the story through character memories, conversations and discoverable lore items.

The game boasts detailed and atmospheric visuals that wonderfully portray the world. There are many scenic areas with beautiful designs that reflect the intended tone. The design of the environments and characters is unique and memorable, contributing significantly to the game's identity. Animations are fluid and detailed, especially during combat sequences, enhancing the overall aesthetic experience.

The music, made by Mili, is absolutely incredible. In every case it's perfect for the setting, and it's both beautiful and an absolute vibe. Every intended emotion is conveyed wonderfully, and I have nothing but praise.

The game presents a fair challenge, with a difficulty curve that is manageable but still demanding. The bosses are great, with clearly telegraphed attacks and general fairness. Contact damage is now gone, which might be partially responsible for why I found the game easier than Ender Lilies. There are difficulty settings that can be used to make the game easier or harder.

Ender Magnolia offers replay value with its multiple endings and the depth of its exploration elements. The game provides a substantial amount of content, with plenty of secrets, side quests, and collectibles to discover. Achieving 100% completion can extend playtime, but it still isn't that long of a game. Difficulty settings and a variety of available Homunculi attacks can allow for more playthroughs, but at the moment there isn't a new game plus mode or a way to refight specific bosses.

After getting all the endings in hard mode, I've got to say: this is a worthy sequel to Ender Lillies.

The most important improvements in this game are the QoL changes. You get double jump and dash super early, which is really nice. Also, now you don't get hit by simply touching the enemies, which was a really annoying thing in Ender Lillies. In turn, this also makes the combat much better.

Speaking about the combat, it's pretty nice. There are a lot of abilities that fit different playstyles, though there were some that felt pretty useless (the owls) There's a great variety of enemies, all of them pretty great, except for the RATS (my god they bodied me so hard) Although I would have liked more variety of enemies in the Land of Origin or whatever was it's name, especially the mini bosses.

The bosses were pretty great, though there were two I found a bit annoying for different reasons. (Spoilers: the Dung Beetle, because dashing through his ball was just not possible. And Luiseach the witch, purely because in 2nd phase she gets a minion who constantly heals her. This would be perfectly fine if the minion could be done in with one combo, but at least in my case, this was not possible)

Last thing about the bosses: FINALLY WE HAVE A GOOD FINAL BOSS. One of the worst things of Ender Lillies was it's underwhelming Final Boss Fight, where it was just killing the minions that she spawned or else get two-shotted by them.

Now about the map. The map in itself is pretty great, being decorated instead of simply being boxes. I also feel the level design improved, and the end-zone doesn't feel so infuriating to traverse like was the case of the first one. Also the movement is really improved from Ender Lillies, so it feels nice to explore.

The soundtrack is great as always. I mean, it's Mili, what else can I say?

But obviously this game has some flaws. The story still feels pretty weak, and is like a repurposed version of the story in Ender Lillies but more convoluted. In Ender Lillies I didn't really mind, but considering the foucs on the characters that Ender Magnolia puts, it's just more noticeable.

Finally, the ambience. It's still pretty great, but compared to the brilliant work they did in Ender Lillies, is just not up to that standard.

Overall, 9/10. If you enjoyed Ender Lillies, you'll also love this one.

This is a top-tier Metroidvania!

Loved the equipment, ability, and customization options. Really felt like I could fine-tune my approach to each situation as needed. Combat, especially boss encounters, are engaging and well designed, with touches of souls-like elements leaning in to enemy attack tells, dodging, and parrying--although the ability options allow for a variety of play styles if you prefer to take safer approaches. It's also good to see they're still fine-tuning some of the balance--I found it very well balanced for the most part, but occasionally some enemies were over-tuned (those damn rats!).

Level design and exploration is fun, with a variety of mobility options unlocked along the way that scratch that Metroid itch well. Fast travel is very generous, and the map takes much of the guess work away when trying to hunt down every little item around the map, which all but eliminates the tedium folks sometimes associate with the genre (though it does take away a bit from the feeling of discovery when in other games you sometimes find something super hidden you had no idea was there).

All-in-all, really loved my time with this game. From a game design perspective it's a clear improvement over its predecessor, and I look forward to future games from these excellent developers.

I don’t usually write reviews, but I wanted to show some more support other than just buying the game.

First off, if you liked Ender Lilies, you will like Ender Magnolia. After having finished what I believe is the entire early access section of the game, I can say that EM has improved upon EL in almost every way.

I Liked:
- No longer getting hurt from walking into enemies
- How Lilac can actually speak (poor mute little Lily)
- Piecing together how the worlds of EM and EL are connected from notes
- Being able to modify fighting style for Homunculi rather than having to pick specific spirits
- How the soundtrack did some REALLY cool things (look them up…EM – Tethered Steeple vs EL – Bible Outro)
- Background art and enemy design
- Pretty much everything and too much to list

The only thing I can say that is even remotely negative (which the devs seem to have already stated they will address) is the difficulty. Now obviously the bosses in the early access are clearly the early game bosses, so comparing them to say Ulv or even Silva from EL is a bit unfair. However, I still feel like every boss over telegraphs all their attacks a bit too much.

All that being said, so far EM a visually and aurally beautiful game with great improvements on EL. I highly recommend it if you are into the genre and even more so if you liked EL. I cant wait to see where it goes from here.

Ender Magnolia is a really well-crafted game, and this is one of those times I wish I didn't have to leave a negative or positive review and something in the middle. My issue with the game, despite all it does so well, is that there is too much "hand-holding". I know most people wont agree with this, especially more casual players, but they are my feelings.

There are not really any secrets in the game when each, relatively small, area indicates immediately when you have went everywhere and found everything in it. I know this is popular in games lately, to make things not so obscure, but at one point is it too much? Finding secrets is part of the allure of the Metroidvania genera since I can remember. If I had to leave a title for this review it would be "Going Through The Motions", because that is what it feels like I'm doing. I'm marching forward through the game, with very little thought or concern. I know there is no penalty for dying, or anything really. I can always just fast travel back to where I was. I can turn the difficulty down at any point. It's the opposite of punishing, and is an extremely, extremely... extremely sparing game. I know I can always look at my map to see if I missed something, which might as well be indicated in real time as soon as you miss it...not literally, but it's nearly that. It's the very opposite of Animal Well in that regard, a game that is very obscure. There is just a certain emptiness going through it. And it's been pretty easy so far, even after turning up the difficulty to max. I'm finding with the right equipment you can counter most enemies.

Beside that it is nearly perfect - music, graphics, atmosphere, combat, lack of technical issues. I can see why it has such high reviews and probably deserves it, but for me, I can't ignore what it is "missing". If you don't care about the "hand-holding" and the sparing nature of the game then I do recommend it, which will probably be the case for most players.

review_text:
Пользователей, посчитавших обзор полезным: 4 0
Рекомендую
32.9 ч. всего
Опубликовано: 27 января
Ender Lilies оставила после себя просто бурю положительных эмоций. Ender Magnolia закончил проходить вчера и могу сказать только одно... мало! Понимаю что на деле то все четко, не затянуто, не забито душными сайд квестами. Игра дает ровно столько, сколько должна дать в идеале, но блин... все равно мало! Ни один трижды хваленый и распиаренный изо всех утюгов ААА проект, даже близко не стоит рядом с ней!
Да, что в Лили, что в Магнолии есть свои минусы, но к ним не хочется придираться. Да по факту они и не существенны. Единственный главный минус для меня я написал выше. Хочется глубже исследовать этот печальный, увядающий мир. Хочется побывать в том покосившемся доме с парой светящихся окон вдалеке, свернуть на неприметную тропку в лесу и добраться до заросших яркими цветами руин, узнать больше мрачных тайн института биологии пробравшись в его недра... однако сказка так или иначе быстро подходит к концу. И пускай это и справедливо, но все таки грустно...

game_title: ENDER MAGNOLIA: Bloom in the Mist
review_text:
Пользователей, посчитавших обзор полезным: 15
1 пользователь посчитал этот обзор забавным 2
Рекомендую
41.3 ч. всего
Опубликовано: 29 января
Почти год назад (18 января) мне подарили Ender Lilies и заставили в неё играть, что я и делала сквозь слёзы и сопли, и это в корне изменило мои игровые привычки, вызвало любовь к сложностям и преодолениям. Новость о том, что почти к годовщине этого знаменательного события выходит продолжение, очень меня обрадовала.

Получился идеальный сиквел (довольно частое явление в мире игр такого жанра), где слабые моменты оригинала улучшили (хотя я раньше и не догадывалась, что они таковыми были), а то, что прекрасно работало, оставили неизменным.

Способности переделаны так, что оружие ближнего боя можно одновременно иметь только одно. Остальные же способности делятся на имеющие кулдаун, автоматические (как ворон в первой части) и бесконечные (аналог стрельбы), которые просто работают, пока держишь кнопку. Такого, как в первой части — где число использования большинства способностей было ограничено и восстанавливалось только на скамейке — нет. К сожалению, у меня очень не гибкий мозг, не приспособленный к изменениям, поэтому всю игру я бегала с теми способностями, что дают первыми (пацан, стрелок и парирование).

Карта нарисована великолепно, с обозначением пропущенных (но увиденных игроком) коллекционок и препятствий. Препятствия тут даже промаркированы красным значком, если пока нет способности, чтобы их преодолеть, или голубым, если способность есть. Зачищать карту, искать скрытые проходы и решать опциональные платформинг пазлы, чтоб поднять очередной предмет, было одно удовольствие.

Вайб «маленькая беззащитная девочка чужими руками nиздит врагов на фоне пульсирующих комков плоти» немного потерян, потому что тут главная героиня выглядит более самостоятельно, она разговаривает и иногда даже ругается с персонажами, да и в целом почему-то впечатление такое, что она вполне может и сама кого-то отnиздить, если вдруг придётся. Кроме того, мир и враги выглядят более технологично и менее… биологично.

По наполнению, количеству локаций и боссов сиквел показался на треть, а то и на половину больше первой части. Боссов тут тьма, самые сложные это паук, ведьма, подводник, шкаф на фабрике и, конечно же, финальный.

Вещи, заставившие плакать:

— Лес. Мне «повезло» пройти эту локацию до патча, выпущенного через пару дней после релиза, добавляющего туда шорткаты. Я желаю, чтобы у человека, задизайнившего лес, отвалилась жопа и он не мог больше какать.

— Четыре возрождающихся мини-босса подряд без скамеек. Трудно описать эмоции, когда я идеально прошла трёх первых, не потеряв ни одного хп, а потом пошла на последнего и он в первые 5 секунд сделал «икс» (cyка, у Ульфа научился, что ли) и снёс мне этим всё хп. И да, мне опять «повезло» пройти этих челиков до патча, который их нёрфит.

— Крысы. Стоит ли уточнять, что их тоже понёрфили после того, как я уже всё прошла?

— Финальный босс. К моменту, когда я наконец его одолела, научилась проходить первые три фазы без получения урона вообще. Но ваншот атаки на 2-й и 4-й фазе — это очень жестоко. Очень.

— Опциональное испытание, где надо проплыть большое расстояние в отравленной воде.

Прокачка, а точнее, экипировка барахла тут немного поменялась. Для начала, есть целый раздел со снаряжением, где можно надевать предметы, меняющие характеристики персонажа (уровень защиты, силу лечения, силу атаки и т.д.), дающие дополнительные хилки и/или +1 бар для усиленной атаки, а также позволяющие делать быстрое парирование по RT (которое я так и не осилила, уж очень точное у него окно). А есть и классические реликвии, занимающие разное число слотов, причём с ограничением на число одновременно надетых.

Прокачивать можно реликвии (фармя детали, пробивая врагов с высоты) и способности, причём последние можно прокачать все за одну игру практически по сюжету. Число навыков для продвижения и открытия новых локаций, кстати, неплохо так увеличено, финальные — супер-прыжок и полёт от стен — особенно порадовали.

Я осталась в восторге, было бы круто получить ещё продолжений, названий цветков всё-таки ещё много осталось.

A solid 8/10. If you enjoyed the first one, or Metroidvania in general, you will probably enjoy this one.

Has a map that feels significantly larger than the first game, but is both very easy to navigate and includes several QOL features that make progression and finding collectibles much easier to manage. It also thankfully does not waste time at the start withholding fast travel ( which can be used at any time once obtained) and some basic traversal abilities that are very standard in Metroidvania, giving them within the first hour.

Now for the two major complaints that bring this down to an 8/10:

1) Story. Or more specifically the way the story is presented. There is, a lot going on in this story and a lot of characters to keep track of. The narrative doesn't always mesh well with the very minimalist storytelling style that was carried over from the first game, and it can at times be hard to keep track of what is going on and what, in a story sense, you are actually trying to do. The story itself I thought was fine, not bad but nothing particularly memorable.

2) Enemy Damage. Let me preface this by saying this game has difficulty sliders that can modify many aspects of the "numbers" behind things, which I highly encourage you to use if you have issues with difficulty. Overall, I found the mechanical difficulty of the game just fine, some boss move sets were more difficult to learn than others, but there were only one or two times I felt like bosses have legitimately unfair moves.

Where I feel this game has an issue is specifically with damage output. Many bosses hit hard, very hard. On "normal" difficulty, most bosses can kill you in 3-5 hits, some can stunlock you or hit you multiple times, a few have moves that may as well be OHKO ( they aren't, but 95% of max hp damage is functionally the same most of the time). At first, this is limited to the bosses, but my the end of the game, even the normal enemies were doing this level of damage, and this was with a majority of the hidden health increases and some of the best defensive gear available. In general, be prepared for a massive difficulty spike in the latter half of the game. At this point, many of the enemy types felt much more dangerous, the areas had significantly more hazards in them, and the damage output issue became very apparent.

My completion on normal difficulty, with about 95% map completion and all areas visited, took just over 20 hours. Expect your time to be roughly half that if you rush and ignore optional collectibles and areas.

Having played the original "Ender Lilies" I was looking forward to the sequel but wanted to wait until it's out of Early Access. Well, it's finally released and everything I could have hoped for. More variety in terms of combat, more areas to explore and discover, another great soundtrack and beautiful art direction - which reminds me ever so much about Vanillaware's games.

In typical Metroidvania fashion, unlocking areas step by step with the abilities you gain is paramount and if you would like to see all the content, you'll have to explore quite a bit. Runtime for me was around 20ish hours with some extra-backtracking and all achievements, that should give you an indication of how long you can expect the game to be.

Bosses range from easy to moderately difficult with them ramping up in difficulty as you get more abilities for your main character and collect more items. At the endgame you'll have plenty of items and equipment to choose from so you can build a setup to your liking.

Two bits of criticism that I have, is that if you're affected by a status effect they can really creep up on you ( especially fire ), as your eyes are focused on the action while you're burning or electrified and the very small icons below the healthbar are not enough to alert the player of it. There are also sounds that plays when it's the case but with the music and other sound effects playing at the same time, I found it to be quite hard to notice nonetheless.

The second relates to a specific boss called Velgrynd in a later area that likes to charge its attacks off-screen while the camera is constrained to the middle of the battlefield. When either their left or right arm are hidden off-screen, you don't know the windup time of the animation and I found that to be a little frustrating as the boss itself can also multi-hit you with the same attack during the animation. That feels a little off to me when you compare it to literally every other boss where this isn't the case. I feel this one needs a bit of either a camera adjustment - so you can see more of combat arena or in general a look at the hitboxes. Probably my least favorite boss of the game.

Outside of that I have no complaints as the game was very entertaining from beginning to the end. I am happy to have played the game and am looking forward to the next one the developers are cooking up - fantastic work!

ENDER MAGNOLIA: Bloom in the Mist? A Beautiful Yet Safe Sequel! (ฅ'ω'ฅ)

"A dark fantasy Metroidvania that expands upon its predecessor’s foundation with enhanced combat, fluid exploration, and stunning music—though not without its flaws."

[1] Intro :

ENDER MAGNOLIA: Bloom in the Mist is the spiritual successor to ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights, set decades after its events. In this dark fantasy Metroidvania, players take on the role of Lilac, an "Attuner" with the power to save Homunculi, artificial beings driven to madness by toxic fumes. Exploration and fast-paced combat take center stage, with a revamped battle system, over 30 unique skills, and a richly detailed world steeped in tragedy and mystery. Featuring gorgeous hand-drawn visuals, a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack by Mili, and new difficulty options, ENDER MAGNOLIA seeks to refine its predecessor’s gameplay while offering a fresh yet familiar experience. However, while the game succeeds in world-building and presentation, its level design, challenge balancing, and exploration mechanics have sparked mixed reactions.




Set in the Land of Fumes, a once-prosperous kingdom now drowning in toxic mist, ENDER MAGNOLIA delivers an atmospheric and melancholic world teeming with abandoned cities, ruined laboratories, and towering factories. The visual design is breathtaking, with layered backgrounds and a masterful use of light and color. Each area feels distinct yet thematically cohesive, reinforcing the isolation and sorrow central to the game’s story. However, some players feel that the game lacks a true sense of wonder, citing linear progression and predictable level design that minimizes the excitement of discovery.



The combat system builds upon ENDER LILIES, offering: (1) 30+ unique skills obtained from fallen foes. (2) More attack variety with a mix of melee, ranged, and magical abilities. (3) Fluid air mobility, allowing double jumps, air dashes, and mid-air attack chains. (4) No contact damage, making movement-focused playstyles more viable. (5) Two different parry mechanics, adding defensive depth. While combat is tighter and more customizable, balancing issues have been noted. Some players feel that damage output is underwhelming, while enemies hit too hard, making boss fights feel unfairly punishing. The lack of meaningful scaling in healing and status resistance has also been a common critique.



While the game introduces fast travel from anywhere and clearer UI markers, exploration itself has divided player opinion. The map is highly detailed and user-friendly, making backtracking less tedious. Abilities enhance traversal, but progression often feels predictable (e.g., obtaining an upgrade and immediately knowing where to use it). Some feel the hand-holding approach removes the thrill of exploration, reducing the sense of accomplishment when uncovering secrets.















ENDER MAGNOLIA: Bloom in the Mist is a beautiful yet flawed sequel that refines ENDER LILIES in many ways but struggles to truly evolve beyond it. Combat is smoother, traversal is more fluid, and the world is stunning, yet predictable level design, frustrating difficulty spikes, and limited innovation hold it back from being a top-tier Metroidvania. If you enjoyed ENDER LILIES, this game is still worth experiencing, but don’t expect a groundbreaking evolution. For newcomers to the genre, it’s a solid and accessible choice, though veterans may find it lacking in originality and challenge.

Final Rating: 9/10 – A Beautiful Yet Safe Sequel

This review is mostly from the perspective of an avid fan of the previous title, Ender Lilies
This was my most anticipated game for this year, and it is not disappointing.
If you've played Ender Lilies, this entry is will reintroduce all of what made that good and upgrade it ten-fold, and more. The quality-of-life adjustments to all the mechanics makes experiencing this game so much smoother, but without diluting the difficulty where it matters (no contact damage is a godsend 🙏🙏). The visuals are absolutely stunning, with so much care and attention to detail brought in to immerse the player in the Land of Fumes as if they were in it. The animation, character design, and particle effects have been magnified from Ender Lilies and really bring its characters and environments to life like never before. The intriguing story and the way it unfolds helps to craft amazing world-building themes that brings the game's writing to new heights. And, of course, the return of the amazing music composed by Mili.
Without a doubt, a massive upgrade from Ender Lilies and the best gift that Binary Haze could have delivered to the fans.

Наконец-то дождался игру с момента выхода в раннем доступе.

Разработчики сделали довольно гибкую настройку сложности, давая игрокам возможность с помощью ползунков самостоятельно выбирать хотят ли они разбираться в приемах обычных врагов и боссов или просто расслабиться под шикарный ост. С измененной с первой части системой боя доступны 4 боевых навыка из 30 возможных, которые могут быть полезны в платформинге (задержка в воздухе с помощью анимаций атак для более раннего получения некоторых полезных предметов) и при определенных ситуациях (парирование, атака друднодосягаемых врагов за щитами или стенами, установка ловушек, восстановление здоровья итд). Каждый из компаньонов обладает спец. способностью и может быть немного усилен (сила атаки, скорость наложения статуса, дальность, кулдаун навыка), причем игра даёт возможность прокачать каждого в пределах одного прохождения.
Экипировка тоже состоит из нескольких видов - спутники, добавляющие пассивные эффекты на лечение и набор
шкалы спец. атак, раковины, наделяющие парирование доп эффектами, браслеты, влияющие на базовые параметры персонажа, и реликвии с разнообразными эффектами. Есть два вида карты - мини-карта, которую можно увеличить или отключить нажатием кнопки, отрисовывающая элементы уровней автоматически по мере прохождения, и стандартная для таких игр карта через меню с опциями поставить себе маркеры или переместиться на уже открытые контрольные точки в любой момент времени.

Потрясающая игра, рекомендую к прохождению.

Edit: Don't listen to the people whining about difficulty. Sure some parts can be annoying, but honestly, easier than Ender Lilies, and if I can first try the final boss, you can beat it. Combat is just so much smoother than Ender Lilies, can't believe more negative reviews aren't about the drop in story quality.

Ender Magnolia was a... interesting experience for me. I played Ender Lilies on a friend's recommendation, and I liked it (maybe not as much of a raving fan as my friend was but anyways). And literally after I finished it I found out a sequel was coming in less than a month. So I was pretty hyped.
The game is very good and well designed. There were a couple of parts that were not super fun (I hate the boss rush in the battle tower or whatever it's called). But overall I think it is much better than Ender Lilies game play wise. It feels smooth, the combat is fun and overall I enjoyed playing it a lot. I somewhat missed the spirit system as having each homonculus give you 3 very similar abilities felt awkward when I didn't like the ability in the first place. But especially mid game, there was enough variety for that problem to be solved.
As for the story, I have the caveat of playing the first game. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from theory crafting with the knowledge I already had, so I can't say how good it is for a incoming player, but it was certainly fun. With a non-silent protagonist and a world that still has people in it, there is a lot more character interaction which is nice. Honestly I think overall I enjoyed the story more, up until the end. The ending of the game was unsatisfying in a way that Ender Lilies wasn't. I won't say too much, but the "final" ending of the game has very little build up. The solution that was used didn't really have a lot of precedent from the knowledge given to the player and so it kind of felt like "oh we'll do X, and it'll work!" and I'm left wondering what the heck X is and why that would ever work. It was just bittersweet since the rest of the game was so good.
At the end of the day I'd still recommend it, but the ending probably dropped the game from a 9 or 10/10 to an 8.

The rats are hellspawn, some of the equipment/stats feel negligible, and some of the skill variations are underwhelming.

that's the bad.

the good.

Absolutely fantastic map design (barring a couple of exceptions) that makes full use of your gradual improvement of traversal skills to keep even end game platforming engaging and challenging.

Smooth and Responsive combat. Ever power you earn has several variations that change up how a skill functions, some more so than others.

If you're coming from Lilies you'll already know, but some of the best music around. it all fits into the atmosphere of the area you're in and it can range from serene to eerie to energetic and it all fits.

Very solid difficulty. There's a very solid challenge throughout the game that organically grows without feeling too sharp or too smooth in areas. there's a handful of areas that feel particularly punishing but nothing that can't be overcome with practice. Taking the time to learn the mechanics, especially the parrying, feels super rewarding and can change the way you approach almost all of the fights.

The UI design is simple, easy to navigate, and the in game map design works extremely well. Being able to look at a color detail of a map and know for certain you've found everything there is for an area makes 100%ing areas a breeze.

The story is very serviceable. I think I was left with a few minor questions by the end but it kept me engaged and entertained.

all in all I'd say a very deserving 9/10. I hope we eventually see some of the inclusions that were added to Lilies post release but for a solid 30-hour experience I'd say my only regret for this game is that it ended. Play Lilies, Play Magnolia.

The Bad
Almost all characters and even allies are very unmemorable outside of some conversations.
Story feels rushed halfway through the game
Bosses do not feel very challenging even with dynamic difficulty.
Rats are evil.

The Mehh
The music is good but nothing really sticks out too much,
Having access to double jump and air dash so early on is fun, but feels somewhat wrong.

Ender Magnolia is a very fun experience in the sense of being a rather simple metroidvania while having a very customizable set of abilities to use. Whether you want to play a melee or ranged build, status effects, break damage, or even "MP" related; anything goes, once you have the appropriate items, you can do whatever build you want. Like Ender Lilies, the fun of finding new items and theorycrafting potential equipment and ability combos makes combat and the metroidvania aspect of the game very fun. Sadly, even with the dynamic difficulty settings to amp up the stats of enemies and bosses, due to the limitations of what bosses are able to do: just about every boss in the game pretty much can be melted down with little to no stress. It's kind of a pity that a boss can be defeated first time while potentially not even seeing all of it's abilities. From what I've observed, aside from a few moments of bosses being untargetable from phase changing or dodging: the only real way bosses tend to keep themselves alive is by literally running away from the player constantly. With dynamic difficulty settings, it's nice to know that if a boss has annoyed me enough: I could just turn down the settings abysmally low and just get it over with. While this situation has never happened for me, it's a shame that the bosses themselves are either not designed mechanically too interesting or the difficulty settings don't really let you raise them high enough. At this point even a simple yet boring answer to enable the difficulty slider to raise the boss's hp even more or outright negate status effects and break for more of a challenge seems like a welcome idea. The most difficult thing you can really do in this game is enable 1-hit death along with maxing out enemy aggro.

It's been awhile since I played Ender Lilies, but piecing together the story in Lilies was a very lore-rich experience. In terms of Magnolia however, the story feels like it was rushed the moment you reach the halfway point of the game. By the time I reached the midpoint of the game, I would constantly feel like I was missing something or I would question if I sequence breaked the game and saw a cutscene out of order(I'm 100% sure I've done it at least once by being some places I wasn't supposed to be at the time). I assumed that I would run into some particular cutscenes that would fill in the gaps since they seemed like obvious sprinkles of story that should come up next, but said scenes in mind never came around and I was simply left to fill in the blanks myself. While the NPCs in the world had some sidestories of their own to follow, I found myself more preoccupied trying to find the references to the previous game instead of paying attention to the current story instead. Long story short, I found it extremely hard to remember which characters did what in the game. If anything, the only blatantly memorable character to me might as well been Levy. Even the MC themselves feels fragmented in my mind due to how little breadcrumbs of story the game gives you. While the main idea of the story isn't a bad one, the severe lack of story events and even items to read lore from make the it seem like there was no story aside from defeat the bad, the end. Basically, the story was okay, but the storytelling itself leaves much to be desired.

Overall, Ender Magnolia is a another fun game for gameplay aspects and exploring the world in general: but like Ender Lilies, don't expect bosses to be that interesting as the majority of the fun will likely be traversing through maps with whatever equipment you find. As for story, well; the game feels like some DLC content would be very welcome.

Ender magnolia is overall an extremely good game, but it has its flaws too, just like anything else, as nothing is perfect. I played through all of Ender Lilies and loved it, so I was excited to play through this one too. After getting 100% completion in Ender Magnolia, I feel like I can give a thorough opinion on what the game did well, and what it didn't do so well.

PROS:
+Enemies deal no contact damage, which is really nice compared to Ender Lilies.
+The OST is just amazing. Every track fits each part of the game really well, and its a pleasure to listen to the tracks.
+The artstyle of the game is beautiful.
+The overall feel of the combat is smooth, and there's a large variety of ways to approach enemies, depending on how you want to play.
+The map interface is extremely well made, and you do not need to unlock anything extra to get the full map functions. Fast travel is unlocked relatively early, and it can be used easily. Every completely explored room is highlighted in a different color.
+The world is overall really open, and you can explore mostly in whatever order you want to.
+Dying does not make you lose much progress at all. If you die, you will respawn at the last respite you visited, and all your progress is still saved, including items. This makes the game nice for casual players too.
+Difficulty settings can be adjusted to your own liking, at any point in the game at a respite. The difficulty settings only affect how much"fragments" you get, which are used to purchase extra content in the menu, including concept art for you to view.

NEUTRAL:
+-There are less abilities compared to Ender Lilies, although each ability has 3 variants.
+-You do not always get a new combat ability when you defeat a boss, some are only for exploration instead of being considered "abilities".

CONS:
-After a certain point, the bosses become extremely tanky, which can be annoying.
-Some hitboxes are a bit janky, leading to parrying and dodging being difficult when it comes to certain moves.
-The game is far more grindy compared to Ender Lilies, as there is a shop ("craftery") where you can purchase upgrades and items in exchange for materials you find, which you can get around the world as you explore and break objects (which respawn after resting at a respite).


Overall, I recommend the game and think its a great metroidvania. However, the combat is difficult, but not too difficult, and you can always change the difficulty if you feel like doing so.

Somehow, this ended up being the best Metroidvania I've played since the Nintendo DS Castlevanias.

The first game in this series didn't really leave a lasting impression on me. It was unique and I enjoyed the ghost conjuring gameplay, but the girl was too lonely, the world was too blandly morose and the sad piano music got on my nerves after a while. This game started on the same notes, with a sad girl fighting sad enemies while someone played a sad piano.

But slowly, something starts to change. The sad girl starts to talk to some of her ghosts and she doesn't actually seem that sad anymore. The sad pianist meets a violinist and goes through therapy. All of a sudden, I had this feeling that I was making this sad world a better place for people and that all of my Metroidvania exploration was in service to a greater good. And that's when this game became something special.

Three points:

1) I 100% explored the map and only consulted a guide once to get into one room. Exploration in this game is intuitive with subtle visual cues to indicate where there might be a hidden room and a really great map that makes it easy to figure out where you still need to look around.

But beyond that, the level design was just top notch. I don't really like exploring things for the sake of just getting 100% exploration, but in this case I wanted to see all the rooms. The way they place enemies, the way they set up movement puzzles and the way they handle new powers was just joyful. It never is just 'hey there's the red door that you can open up with the red laser'. It would be things like 'You can use a charge attack to open this barrier, but it needs a wind up, so now we'll set some platforming challenges so you can open this door". And it all just blends together so seamlessly that it was just a pleasure to get everything.

2) The ghost powers are genuinely cool. Putting together certain ghosts (or "Homonculus" as they decided to be called in this) meant being able to chain together combos and creative strategies to take enemies down. You can go down the route of doing perfect parries and all out melee combat, you can make a firehose of magic bullets or you can get a bunch of summons and let them do the work. Certain bosses are weaker to certain approaches, and it was pretty pleasing when a boss that was kicking my ass would fold after I changed my approach.

There is a gun ghost, but unfortunately you don't get him until the end of the game when he doesn't matter. Boo.

3) The game has cohesion. So much beautiful cohesion.

So many Metroidvanias miss that and just put a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in rooms without any regard to the story. In this, you'll see one enemy type in one region and then the same enemy type in a different region, which signals that the same faction is at play. Little details are really focused on. The evil lab has a secret elevator leading to the castle to explain the tentacled abominations in there. It all just makes sense and is just delicious.

Overall, this is a rare treat and it cost like... 30 bucks? You don't even really need to wait for a sale for that.

Final Score: 9.9324/11

Отличное продолжение первой части. Хотя, как по мне, вышло слабее. Из более фэнтэзийного мира мы переместились в какой-то стим панк. Всё более тёмное, мрачное и технологичное. Лично мне не зашло.
А вот что мне понравилось: НИКАКИХ ПАРИРОВАНИЙ, да, в игре они вроде как есть, если выбрать определенного напарника, но это можно не делать и это прекрасно. Стандартная сложность позволяет проходить игру с минимумом усилий и просто наслаждаться исследованием мира. Наконец то чтоб всё исследовать не нужно покупать или искать какие-то особые способности или предметы. Полностью обысканная зона просто поменяет цвет на карте с серого на синий. Так же все предметы сразу будут обозначаться (если вы их видели краем глаза). Можно ставить свои метки, но я даже не знаю зачем. Все закрытые проходы сразу будут обозначены и даже изменят цвет, как только у вас появится способность чтоб через них пройти. Пройти всё на 100% почти не составит труда. Было только одно место с плаванием, где были трудности, но чутка поэкспериментировав с вещами и оно легко проходится. Так же стоит похвалить чекпоинты (точки отдыха), которые почти всегда расположены максимум близко к боссам и вам не надо раз за разом пробегать пол карты чтоб сделать очередную попытку. Так же есть возможность из любого места переместиться в любую такую точку. В общем и целом в игре всё сделано, чтоб вы получали удовольствие, а не занимались монотонной и бесящей беготнёй из точки А в точку Б.
Из недостатков для себя, я бы отметил медленную отзывчивость в бою. Если происходит какая-то анимация удара, а вам нужно резко уклониться, то вам это не дадут сделать. Это не критично, но частенько приходится останавливать атаки, когда знаешь, что сейчас будет удар босса, от которого надо увернуться. Ну и отход от открытого мира к городскому для меня стал небольшим разочарованием. Хоть всё и красиво, но стилистика механизмов лично мне зашла.
Как итог: отличная игра, в которой все плюсы перевешивают все минусы. Играть однозначно всем любителям жанра и первой части.

==================
Review Update After I Read The Story Again
==================

Gameplay
==================
Absolutely massive upgrade from Lilies, the attack animation feels more natural and smooth. Skill animation looks awesome, I like to play with scythe and counter attack skill really give satisfying feeling. More RPG elements like equipments and upgradeable relics, also the map give more clear visual so you can track which area that you don't touch it yet. (PTSD moment from Lilies' map, lol). And if you played Lilies before Magnolia, I'd recommend to choose hard mode. Overall it's 9.5/10.

Visual
==================
I won't talk much about this because it's obvious :). 9.5/10

OST
==================
I can say for the OST is 9.5/10 except the ending song, feels like something's missing, unlike Lilies that made me cry. I will give 8.5/10 for the ending song. But overall a massive upgrade for the OST, additional instrument really describe how Magnolia's world is looks like. Final score : 9/10

Story (Major Spoiler Alert)
==================
Actually I still prefer Lilies' story, although there is Lily's appearance (I think). Of course we know that Lilia can't follow Lilac to Upstream area because of the Blight, but at least give her a little bit more story on epilogue, like how was she after the B ending, I mean she is Lilac's main goal right? I don't know about the others but I feel that they makes player to forget the main goal story and it become secondary goal instead. The Upstream area feels hollow, rush story writing for me. The final boss doesn't give me impact that much unlike Lilies and maybe that's why I gave 8.5 for the ending song because of this issue. (It would be more impacted if the dev give second health bar, it would be insane). Before The Upstream area, the story are just fine but my main complaint is how they were rushed the story writing when Lilac's approaching the Upstream area and forgetting the main goal and Lilia (yes, Lilia), so many plot hole, so many story aspect that they could dig more deeply. I hope that they can fix this on next series if possible while keeping a good job on the gameplay, visual, and OST. It's 6/10

Total score : 8.5/10. Recommended for gameplay, but for the story you should touch Lilies so you can agree with me on this matter
