aight i did the 100%ing. let's talk about it. they gave me a difficulty option so of course i have to pick hard. they allow you toggle even crazier numbers but if the game says hard i'm not going to argue semantics.

contact damage is situational, some enemies hurt on contact (it's obvious which ones do so) and some don't. the first hour or so is the same as it was back in early access.

they made hidden paths and areas more obvious on the map after you've found them.

i'm pretty sure you weren't able to do so back in EA but when you're buying accessories you can finally compare both equipped at the same time thank god.

there are a lot less overall homunculi abilities, but this is in exchange of each individual homunculi having more of a character development also more useful abilities. you can very much make different builds with these alongside relics like dmg% build, status build etc.

speaking of dmg%, the ATK stat is absolutely king, you can melt anything and any boss in less than a minute if you have around 280 ATK. who cares about heal potency and def if you just kill them all lmao. bosses also give xp so there's 0 reason to take off blighted dice (xp increase on kill) the moment you get it.

nola's upgrade progression finally feels like one instead of the way they did it with umbral knight back in 1. there's also

and lore wise

feel like they took some notes from hollow knight because game really feels like the dev's own spin on that particular formula (even has the , that was fun). i love hk to death so this is perfectly fine. the platforming tricks you can do to do skips is really fun to figure out.

and i swear i will keep doing this thing where i'll get into any project or game that mili is involved in so i can get a sneak preview of a new mili banger. i do it for limbus and now i do it for this game.

overall much better than the first game with more streamlined progression. this one's worth it friends. things are very streamlined, so this imo is a pretty good game for someone who has never played a metroidvania before to try the genre out.



basically more of the first game (which i reviewed ), so if you liked that, then well, you definitely will this one too.

Honestly more disappointed than anything else. It's a well made game, sure, but it's also very safe and pedestrian as far as metroidvania games go. There's nothing new, nothing interesting, no wow factor, it's just very vanilla ideas retreaded again and again in countless other games (many of which do it better). If you're a genre veteran looking for something great, you may be somewhat satisfied with this but likely not all that enthused by it. Less savy metroidvania gamers, probably will vibe with this a lot more.

What's most disappointing is that, for being their 2nd game, they didn't seem to learn anything from their previous game. All the same problems and deficiencies in the first game are here too, like the rather poor sound design that makes the game feel very unfinished (every single cutscene is completely silent for no good reason), the extremely linear maps that don't feel good to navigate, the over-correction of "QoL" features that handhold far too much and take away all sense of discovery and exploration, the lack of a proper crafted experience they want you to have from a difficulty perspective (which leads to hilariously bad balancing with many enemies either ignoring the rules of the game or turning it into a bullet hell which you lack the tools to deal with), and many other odd choices that don't fit this genre.

Despite turning dials up as high as possible, the game never actually finds a way to push back against you, it all ends up being very trivial, compounded by choices the dev made to remove staple mechanics like contact damage and the brief invuln period upon taking damage. This leads to a complete lack of physicality and strategic gameplay, where proper spacing, zoning, and area denial tactics are invalidated and you're left with just spam any button for maximum effect with no consequences or thought behind it. Or conversely, you explode instantly without even knowing what happened because an enemy decides to do a multi-hit/projectile attack and you instantly take 10 hits simultaneously. But since you can just walk into enemy hitboxes, and through them, you can also just confuse the AI and get it stuck in turn-around animations since there's no penalty to just living inside the enemies either. It's all just so unsatisfying and not well thought out.

Status ailments are yet another (commonly) poorly implemented afterthought. You'd think you could take advantage of it against enemies but you don't have a reliable method to inflict them to take advantage of them either, every enemy is resistant and you only have a small chance to inflict a temporary ailment for a few seconds, and the effect on enemies is negligible compared to when used against you, which you have no resistance to and the one that enemies love to use more than anything else is burn, which does 5% of your life per second and you have to do the dumb dance of spam dodge 4 times in a row to make it go away or it actually just kills you. Heaven forbid you're trying to do that in a boss fight, which many of the bosses inflict burn. Did I mention you only have 3 heals for basically the entire game, and the only way to get (1-2!) more is by equipping very specific end-game gear that you may not even want to wear and could have drawbacks? Whose potency is also tied to your gear choices and never gets high enough to make a difference?

At the end of the day, if you're looking for a very simple, run of the mill, vanilla metroidvania that's at least well put together, you can certainly do worse, but Hollow Knight or SotN or Axiom Verge or Ori or Dead Cells etc. this ain't, and the challenge just wasn't there even with maxed out difficulty dials.

Obviously a Metroidvania in the same vein as the original, with very similar aesthetics: Young, paleskinned girl (not even a teenager) with a compassionate streak awakes as an amnesiac in a world ruined (yet still beautiful in its own way) by some form of contagion, protected by spirits/homunculi she can purify/tune after defeating their blighted/infected forms in battle, while gaining skills like double jumps, charges that can break walls, etc. along the way, accompanied by lovely music from the band Mili.


I greatly enjoyed this game, though I'm not certain I'd call it an improvement. The setting is slightly different, a steampunk world with mechs rather than a purely medieval setting, which I liked. There's a lot more dialogue in this game: Lilac, unlike the protag of the previous game, can talk, and you can have convos with your homunculi at save points, which is appreciated, and there are also actual towns with townspeople to talk to who have escaped the infection, but while the dialogue is serviceable, the characters are all standard anime tropey. I enjoy the classic tropes, so I thought that was good, but other folks might prefer the original's lack of protagonist dialogue, as the 'silent hero' is more old school (see games like Dark Souls, and even going back further, the old Ys and Zelda games).





Aside from that though, the battle system is a little different: You no longer have a variety of enemies to absorb, but a handful of plot relevant homunculi, and you can upgrade them with extra abilities as time goes on to make up for the lack of variety. This leads into the actual gameplay, which is wonderfully smooth and looks beautiful in action. The levels are satisfying to navigate, well organized and put together, and beautiful to look at, the most important parts of a Metroidvania. The music is FANTASTIC, as good as the original's, which is high praise indeed. Imo there's even more variety, which is even better! Also, as a nice addition that wasnt present in Ender Lilies, as the game progresses you can unlock neat extras like art, backgrounds, animations for all characters and enemies, and so on! Very nice.


Some complaints: The levels have plenty of secrets, like any good metroidvania, but a little on the scanty side, there are some secret areas but for the most part the secret rooms are just tiny alcoves with maybe an item inside them. Certain enemies are overtuned, but those will be nerfed in a patch soon (at the time of this writing). Some of the bosses are ill balanced--there's one in particular who's white on a pale white background, making her very difficult to see, especially with how the camera zooms out as you fight her. The plot is also more or less derivative of Ender Lilies, including the endings (no spoiler), even though it still has the souls style arrangement of much of it being vague and only revealed through item descriptions. Still, these are minor caveats compared to the accomplishments this relatively new (Ender Lilies came out in 2021), small studio has to its credit. I recommend this game with no reservations!

Ender Magnolia improves on EL in almost every way with lots of new QOL changes along with more polished movement and combat along with a lot of other points many people have reiterated.

But for me, while all the bosses were good, none of them were really amazing, almost all of them had easy to dodge move sets excluding the final boss.

And the new system for homunculi instead of spirits decreases the variety for quality with a maximum of 10 homunculi with 3 variations, but a big complaint that I have about the 10 homunculi is that you only get a few early on along with no way to unlock the variations and your essentially stuck with your small repertoire till mid to late game, along with the fact that you don't really get a second primary till you are nearly finished with the game making you stick with noel if you plan to use a primary

My only other complaint is in the execution of the story, I expected they would improve from EL with another tragic and heartbreaking story. This game is to Ender Lilies what NieR Automata was to NieR Replicant: It's bigger, better and introduces androids something a fair bit more complicated than androids as a narrative focus.
If you haven't played Ender Lilies you should probably get on that before playing this one, since it kind of assumes you're familiar with the major story beats of Lilies.
If you have played Ender Lilies you should already roughly know what you're in for with this game, so here are some of my main takeaways regarding what's new instead:

+ Our new protagonist, Lilac, is a lot more agile than Lily from the get-go and feels a lot snappier and more responsive to control, especially in combat. The boss fights benefit from this tremendously, being both more mechanically challenging and feeling more fair overall.
+ Magnolia introduces a few new moves on top of the ones from Lilies (nothing you haven't seen in other Metroidvanias already, but still), and the game takes full advantage of that by making you mix and match mobility options to explore the map. The level design stays consistently fun and varied throughout the game; There was never a point in the game where i wasn't having fun exploring each area.
- Hollow Knight will forever be the gold standard for Metroidvania map design in my eyes, and unfortunately this game still doesn't quite reach those heights. It's an improvement over Lilies for sure, with larger, more intricate individual areas, but looking at the bigger picture you'll still notice that your path through the game ended up being pretty linear in the end.
+ In Ender Lilies pretty much the entire plot of the game had already happened by the time Lily woke up, and she was left with fragments of a story to piece together after the fact. In Ender Magnolia not only is Lilac an active participant in the story, she even gets to have actual dialogue with actual living people! Including all the companions she picks up along the way! (Seriously, the rest site conversations between your companions, even as few and far between as they are, are such a nice addition.) The game's whole narrative feels a lot more alive (duh) and engaging as a result.
* Here's a hot take: I don't think Mili's music always hits the right notes in these games (so to speak). They tend to go for a purely instrumental approach, which usually sounds nice enough, but doesn't always match the tone or energy of the game. Still, for every "Taboo" this game does also have its "Root"s, so it balances out.
+ This should go without saying, but: game pretty :)

Basically, if you liked Ender Lilies you will love this game. If you thought Ender Lilies was only OK you should consider giving this game a shot anyway, it might surprise you! Personally, as a Metroidvania connoisseur this one sits pretty high up in my tier list already and might even get a replay or several in the future.

An amazing metroidvania and a vast improved in terms of gameplay and quality of life over Ender Lillies (which is a prequel to this game).
Magnolia has absolutely stunning parallax backgrounds and area design with lots of depth, great atmosphere reminiscent of NieR: Automata, and a beautiful soundtrack.

Some of the best addition to game is 100% the new map. It's not your old empty squares anymore - now you have an actual functioning map that changes color of the segment after you've cleared everything, shows closed doors and various roadblocks with abilities you need to use to clear them. You also have your markers, but I rarely ever used them.

Additionally, you unlock the fast travel function really early, and you can fast travel to any respite from the map. All of this combined made the experience of exploring and collecting everything really enjoyable.
As for the hidden stuff, the game has a fair share of loot cleverly tucked away behind hidden walls or locked behind the jump puzzles, which are still present, although they've become much easier compared to ER. You can still sequence break a lot of the stuff with your abilities and even jump infinitely, but you don't need to.

I also really adore the approach to difficulty settings Magnolia took - instead of your average Easy, Normal and Hard you have sliders for enemy health, damage, quantity of attacks and resistance to status effects - you can freely change any of those, and the overall modifier dictates how many resources you get by defeating them.

There's of battle abilities you can use, mix and match, which are now split up into groups - ranged ones you can use by holding the button (while still having the ability to jump, move, etc.), automatic abilities from followers or "totems" of sorts that attack while you are close by, your main sword / scythe / hammer and some additional flavor stuff you can use even while shooting or attacking.

The only downside to this system is you can't swap the abilities freely (only on respites), and you also can't use more than one ability from a character - I understand why, as you can already make some really broken combinations as is, but that would be fun nonetheless

I also really liked the way the game encourages you to change your loadout at times, especially on new areas / bosses, and when handling shielded or flying enemies. I didn't use everything, as some of the abilities get overshadowed quickly, but the variety is there, and you can choose the playstyle you are comfortable with.

Now as for the downsides, the lore / story of this one felt a bit rushed and all over the place in my opinion, and the endings of the game are not nearly as fulfilling as they were in Ender Lillies. There're a lot of areas, but they tend to look same-y by the end, and there were some moments when I got stuck because of a convoluted level design of some of them. The final boss was also quite lackluster in my opinion, although it got better in the hidden ending. Overall I also feel like the bosses in ER offered quite a bit more fair challenge with less ways to cheese them, and I still remember most of them - can't say the same for Magnolia, although I still enjoyed every fight.

Overall, I feel like this is a giant step forward for the developers and a game absolutely worth your time and price, especially if you are a fan of metroidvanias like me.

Ender Magnolia is a worthy sequel to one of my favorite metroidvanias, but it makes some questionable design choices along the way.

Magnolia is Lilies with more polish, better movement options (granted you have to wait until the last few hours to get the crazy ones), and notably higher difficulty. My main complaint about Lilies was how much of a cakewalk the vast majority of the game was, and the developers definitely felt the same.

This focus on higher difficulty comes with some issues, certain bosses feel significantly worse to fight than the worst fight in Lilies. I can narrow this down to 3 particularly painful bosses: Declan, Luiseach, and Velgrynd. The majority of bosses range from fine to very fun, especially Gilroy, it's mainly just these 3 that gave me a headache.

Declan and Luiseach share the same issue of spending their fights almost exclusively running to the other end of the arena while shooting at you, having a ranged ability slotted in is basically mandatory in these fights as you'll only be able to get in a hit or two before they run away again. Luiseach is also irritating because towards the end of her fight, she'll begin to summon a homunculus that will fly around trying to heal her. She has NO COOLDOWN on doing this so the moment you kill the healer she can immediately throw out another. Velgrynd is one of a select few enemies that can't be staggered at all, and boy does it take advantage of this by throwing out massive swings every second that do large chunks of your health. I ultimately just baited out the rushing slash it does at long range to brute force my way through the fight.

Certain areas are a lot harder to navigate than the vast majority of Lilies, the Crimson Forest is the most egregious example of this however they've already announced a patch adding more shortcuts to it coming soon. Climbing up the Arena tower also felt a bit exhausting with the enemy density. I feel like at least an hour of my playtime was spent just standing at a ledge chipping away at an annoying enemy with a ranged ability so I could platform in peace.

I got all achievements on normal difficulty (there's no achievements tied to difficulty) in about 16.5 hours cutting out the time I played in early access and time I spent AFK, this is on par with the time I spent in Ender Lilies but I was able to 100% Magnolia completely blind compared to Lilies where I needed to look at a guide to figure out the combination of attacks I needed to use to reach certain secrets. My only complaint about the 100% grind is a specific item in the Land of Origin that needs you to get a lot of healing charges and one of the two totems that will instantly full heal you when you get low enough, everything else was fun to figure out. However I do have to point out this is notably less playtime than what they suggested Magnolia would have on Twitter ().

Overall I loved the game and I imagine it'll be even better a few months from now with some updates, 2025 is off to a great start and I'm excited to see what the developers do next.

I've only played ~3h so far, but as of right now, ENDER MAGNOLIA does pretty much everything ENDER LILIES does but better... and that's saying a lot considering how good ENDER LILIES already is.

The difficulty seems to increase slowly the further you get and seems to be slightly above its predecessor. It's not punishingly hard like some other metroidvanias, but isn't a walk in the park either.

A lot of people disliked the way ENDER LILIES managed its minimap, where you don't have actual room layouts, but rather only boxes that show you in which room you are in. This has been changed for its successor and the minimap now shows precise room and area layouts.

Another thing I want to point out is its fast-travel system. ENDER MAGNOLIA has save points called "respites" that also act as locations where you can upgrade your abilities, change equipment and difficulty etc. You can fast travel to those respites from anywhere on the map, which makes backtracking and completing already visited areas a lot more enjoyable.

I've only briefly tested it on steam deck, but it seems to run pretty much flawlessly.

Magnolia is an improvement on Lilies on every front except maybe lore and story, I can't speak about that because I didn't really pay attention to Magnolia's lore and do not remember Lilies' lore at all. But everything else, including combat, level design, UI design, music, art etc. were simply better, some more than others.

The combat feels so much better and more fluid. You have so much more mobility and control over your character while attacking, making the combat more dynamic. Your parry is a core part of your kit (you can choose not to equip it but the buffs you get for foregoing it are so meager you might as well use some sort of parry), and parrying feels satisfying especially with the damage shockwave parries. Perhaps the biggest change was removing contact damage on (most) enemies, which was very unnecessary in the first game and limited the player's freedom when fighting enemies for no reason. You no longer have limited uses on abilities, instead they are split into 4 groups: primary (like most of the main skills in Lilies, infinite uses and your main attack), pressure (somewhat weak ranged option which can be constantly held down to keep "pressure"), cooldown (like the subskills in Lilies but without a use limit), and autonomous (you spawn them and they follow you around, attacking enemies by themselves). This new system allows you to adjust your build according to your playstyle, if you're very proactive you can go with 1 primary and 3 cooldown skills, constantly trying to exploit openings and checking your cooldowns, or if you're passive you can use 1 pressure and 3 autonomous, mostly dodging while holding down your pressure skill, winning out wars of attrition. Getting rid of the limited use mechanic on skills was a great idea and feels like going from DS1/DS2 to DS3/Elden Ring. You have a more limited roster of "spirits" you can call, but each have 3 different attacks you can pick between to suit your playstyle better. My major complaint with this system is how late some of these spirits are unlocked. For example Reibolg, your second primary ability spirit, was unlocked so late I had already decided on and gotten used to my current build to consider experimenting with him.

Level design in Magnolia is weird. I do think it is an improvement on Lilies, but there are so many "teleports", where you get an interaction to pass through a door or something and end up getting transferred to a completely different room. There is even an area with this as an entire gimmick. It's not the end of the world but I think it was kind of lazy, and it makes the map feel very disjointed, both while looking at the actual map itself and while playing. Maybe it is unfair to expect every metroidvania map to be as interconnected as Hollow Knight or Rabi-Ribi, but it got kind of jarring at some points. Still, I do think the map design overall was better than Lilies.

One of the primary complains people had in Lilies was the map. I didn't mind it very much myself, but it's fair to say Magnolia's map is definitely a whole lot better. Unlike Lilies' map which was boxes put next to each other, Magnolia's map is actually a one to one representation of the physical world, with rooms and segments which are unexplored or still have a collectible or two to collect being grey, and 100%ed rooms being blue. The new map made it so much easier to keep track of everything.

The art was one complaint I had about Lilies. I think the proportions were weird, and enemies/characters which tried to look edgy and cool ended up looking kinda goofy. Magnolia has much better art, especially NPCs and spirits look so much better, but some enemies still look somewhat weird. Magnolia's music is also a lot better than Lilies, and Lilies already had pretty good music so that's saying something. But Lilies did have an odd track here and there which I noticed and disliked, and there was nothing that stood out to me like that negatively in Magnolia.

Overall I think Magnolia is an all around better game than Lilies. Definitely not perfect, as the game loses more and more steam as it goes on and imo it peaks at Gilroy's first fight which is the best boss in the game, but still pretty good. Would recommend if you liked Lilies

I very much liked Ender Magnolia, but Ender Lilies had a better plot in my personal opinion.

The way all the cardinal directions of the not-speed-booster are used to gate progress kind of annoys me since I would have preferred that to be a single upgrade and have some more unique movement options and more complex map design in the late-game. It feels too generic and has been done too many times before. That's not to say the map design is bad but I feel like compared to the late game map design in Lilies or other Metroidvanias this game's late area map design isn't quite as good, relying on enemy placements instead of interesting locale or platforming with most areas being pretty bland compared to early game. I did however, like those two endgame rooms that probably caused most people undue suffering. No, you do not get a triple jump or acid immunity. There should have been more of that.

The combat is an upgrade over Lilies due to the removal of contact damage. That made some parts of Lilies pure suffering, and the game is better off for not having it. Mechanically, it's also better in basically every way (except parrying, simply because I dislike parrying compared to dodges fundamentally.) In terms of boss design I'd say most are pretty good.

All in all, I'd recommend it. But do play Lilies first.

This metroidvania is an absolute blast. For those familiar with Binary Haze's other game, Ender Lilies, you will be right at home.

Now that is has released into 1.0, I only have positive things to say about it. Combat is fun and there is a good level of variety in your abilities and item selection to play how you would like to play. Although, some abilities you unlock later than others.

The general difficulty is fine and I never felt as though it was too easy or I died from something cheap.

The entire game runs smoothly and I had literally zero issues throughout my 100% play through.

The music is fitting and pleasant, the combat is solid (I played with status effects and parrying), and the interconnected map is more expansive than you realize for a metroidvania.

I absolutely recommend this for anyone looking for a solid platformer with light rpg elements.

Ender Magnolia is a fine example of a great metroidvania. If you liked Ender Lilies, you're going to love this game too.

It builds on previous game in every way, making it even more smoother and fun to play. The combat improvements are great and while somewhat lacking in quantity of options compared to Ender Lilies, it more than makes up in quality, offering you more polished variety of skills. Addition of new equipment also allows for different playstyles as well.

The only thing this game falls somewhat flat on is the ending of the story, I felt that first game did a much better job at executing the ending. However, it's still great and made me feel things.

OST is once again composed by Mili and is a treat for ears, I never grew tired listening to it while exploring the world.

Speaking of world, it's quite big and cleverly structured. The visuals are fantastic, a lot of varied areas with distinctive feel to them. The massively improved map system is also a big positive.

Hoping for the eventual sequel. Meanwhile, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

The gameplay itself is a great improvement: Assortment of skills, able to be changed/improve, no use limit (not that is was a problem in Lilies), crafting like armor and upgrades, diverse enemies, decent bosses, great weapon style and visual effects and variety in type effect/use (like main/supress/single use). Together with all the classics like prayer, respite, movement, the map...

Everything around it however:
Lilies had a unique kind of art style, Very beautiful, very dark and each region had its theme. Most of the world building and story was told with only visuals. You had your short cutscenes, but just walking through a regions gave an idea where you were and what happened.
Magnolia replaces most of this with characters' conversations and (improved cutscenes). I do like the increase in interactions with you compagnions. But it does remove the power of mysterie and magic.

Traversal is also a downgrade. Stuff like dash and double jump (2 important upgrades you get half way through in Lilies) are both instantly given at the first area of the game. In Lilies they gave you the feeling of: "Hey, with this I can now go here and do this." It feels dumbed down and less special in this one. Just given so you can fight better.
Personally I also prefere the more medieval fantasy style of game compared to this futuristic style (but that is a debatable opinion)

Overall this game is an improvement and still give it an 8/10

I will start getting the main question out of the way: yes, this game is an ABSOLUTE MASTERPIECE. It is a direct improvement from Ender Lilies in almost every way. Inevitably, I'll be making some comparisons to Ender Lilies. ( without spoilers )

-- Story/Characters - A story of rancor, war, forgiveness and of people that fight to their last breaths for a brighter future. The plot unfolds in the same universe from Ender Lilies a couple of decades after its events but it the feels much more expositive and dynamic than the first one, the characters have much more lines and participation. All of them have a clear reason to there and a pretty godd amount of character development. Now sometimes you get an option to talk with them in the respites, where Lilac ( the main character ) talk to the homunculi ( the equivalent of the spirits from EL ) about what's happening at that moment. This gives much more depth to the relationship between Lilac and the homunculi.

-- Presentation/Soundtrack - It is exactly what you could expect from an Ender Lilies sequel. The visuals are beyond gorgeous and the soundtrack is SPECTACULAR, created by the same people that made the Ender Lilies OST. You have that same aesthetic contrast between innocence and tragedy, athough I would say that Ender Lilies is more dramatic, melancholic and carry more sadness. Lily felt more innocent and weak compared to Lilac which behaves more confident and plays more a lead role in the story than Lily. The game also have several different enviroments and it feels less repetitive than EL. All of this will make the game touch your heart.

-- Level design/Exploration - Another big improvment. By any means EL has a bad level design, but here they made even better. The maps are bigger and more complex and each one feels unique. I fell in love with some of them for being challenging with complex pathings that will demand your attention and focus.
The exploration is very well made and it is what you can expect from a good metroidvania. The overall map is bigger this time and the game rewards you a lot the more you explore, with many important collectables and currencies used to upgrade your equipments, making exploration directly attatched to your overall combat experience

--Enemies/Bosses - This is for me the bigger improvement from Lilies. In the first game some of the bosses felt like enldess hit sponges that created long and frustrating fights. They completely evolved here, where every single boss feels fair and fun, without any of the frustrating EL bosses mechanics. And don't get the wrong ideia, they're still very hard and challenging, but here you feel you have more creative ways to play against them, since the game has several different builds, attacks and equips for you to customize your experience. Many of the bosses made me change my biuld to adapt, which made the game feels more dynamic and rewarding. The commom enemies are pretty good as well, and will also make you consider change your build to adapt to each area emeny type.

-- Progression/Mechanics - You still have the same relic system from EL but now with the addition of a proper equipment system that allows you equip acessories to improve your atributes and grant some bonus effects like more healing charges, a regen effect and more. Also the collectables that increases your HP and your relic slot size are back, pretty much the same way it was done in EL. Another new addition are two currencies, one used to upgrade the relics and another one to buy equipments and itens from a permanent shop.

-- Combat - Similar to EL, you equip specific spirits/homunculi in four button slots that will attack in your stead, each one corresponding to a different move. Here the combat feels more fluid and fast paced than the first game and everything works perfectly good. You will find different homunculi more effective in some especific combat situations, stimulating you to change your build often, although not 100% necessary. There's melee combat, ranged attacks, automatic attacks, coordenated moves and even two different parry systems that works very well. One very cool addtion to Ender Magnolia is the new status effects, burn, shock and freeze, each one giving you or the enemy different debuffs that both you and the enemies can infflict, creating even more depth to the combat possibilites

In a more personal note, I love video games and together with Ender Lilies, Ender Magnolia is one of the games that changed my life, it has everything I ever expect from a game and a metroidvania. In an age that video games became products, with generic formulas just to make profits, seeing a pure and sublime work of art like Ender Magnolia is revigorating.


--- From the bottom of my heart, Thank you Binary Haze ---

The game is great to look at. The art and the soundtrack are stellar, but man actually playing the game kind of sucks.

Your dash is a fixed length and your iframes end before the actual animation does, so you will dash through something, only for it to still hit you. There are also no iframes on taking damage, so more than once I died the instant an enemy showed on screen because they started attacking before I saw them and killed me with a beam attack.

Enemies have no set pattern so sometimes a boss will just spam teleport multiple times in a row or just sit in the corner never letting you even get near them. You can only parry 1 singular attack, so you can die from a successful parry if an enemy spams attacks or projectiles (which they all do).

Thankfully you can adjust the difficulty, but why do enemies have so much health and do so much damage in the first place? Many of the bosses just turn into a slog because they have such an enormous amount of heath. Why does every boss fight start with a cutscene, even if you're not fighting it for the first time?

Special Note: Whoever decided a boss summoning a healing minion was a good idea needs a solid smack on the head

Alright I usually don't do yapfest yapsessions for reviews only funnies and sometimes long thoughts after clearing the game but I have a few things I really need to get off my chest about this game. (what I'll be saying is purely after getting 100% in game so my thoughts are fresh and I didnt look at any devlogs or updates about what is why or why not, yes it will be spoilery a bit)

So my biggest gripe is that the amount of summons became less here and there were 4 slots to use he summons not the 3+3 like in Lilies, but to remedy the scarcity of them instead of 1 summon having 1 ability its 3 abilities, the variety is... okay I think? Like sure I couldnt do the double poison nuke combo like in Lilies but I was still able to experiment and see what and how works for me.
One thing about having less summons now was that all of them had personalities and voiced their thoughts at rest sites on matters that currently were to happen/happened and this I genuinely liked and of course the main character had her own thoughts and voice too on matters.

Something that became clear after the first few zones is that Magnolia...it had people and homonculi everywhere trying to live, there was hope even in trash and filth trying to survive unlike in Lilies where it was pure despair and the singular sliver of barely attainable chance of Lily making it to the end to purify the Blight. And honestly? I vibed a lot more with how Lilies was a fight against the impossible.

I enjoyed Magnolia, the music was good and had me engaged and listening to it closely, the visuals were beautiful, the story was alright it was good and enjoyable.
But...
I have to be honest with this. The world that Lilies showed me, the vibe, the music and the overall hopelessness fighting for an impossible chance, it resonated with me more than Magnolia.

Would I recommend Ender Magnolia to anyone? Yeah it's good, but play Ender Lilies first in my humble opinion.

Ender Lilies was a big surprise for me when it released a few years ago, and Magnolia lives up to its predecessor and then some. Binary Haze just really nails map design and progression pacing, and the compulsion for exploration kicks in for me in a way that sometimes doesn't with other titles in the genre. A large part of this is the game's movement system, which puts a lot of emphasis on aerial maneuverability; even combat abilities like the scythe will give you a good amount of lateral flexibility, and combining these together with genre staples like double jump and air dash - both of which are obtained early - gives the player a lot of agency in both exploration and combat.

Combat gives the player similar flexibility with four different attack types spread between eight summons, with three unlockable (and upgradable) attack variants within those, and an otherwise basic equipment system is elevated by the ability to upgrade certain pieces. There's a nice difficulty curve that makes your choices feel meaningful, and there were a handful of bosses that benefited from switching up my load out. You're just encouraged on all sides to experiment and explore, and mechanically the game coalesces in a consistently satisfying way.

That's to say nothing of the production which, like the first game, is immaculate. The atmosphere is gloomy, albeit not as isolating as the first title, and is punctuated by a gorgeous OST and incredible art style that makes each area feel bespoke. The game also runs at a solid 60fps on Steam Deck and I experienced no crashes or bugs in my nearly 23 hours of playtime.

These games will live rent free in my head forever. Both Ender Lilies and Magnolia have a sort of unmatched feel to them that I have a hard time pinning down. On paper they're pretty standard Metroidvanias, but the freedom of experimentation and overall production really put them a step above for me. Highly recommended if you're a fan of the genre; Ender Magnolia goes head to head with the greats.

Bosses
One of the things that I find weak in this genre is the bosses and this was even true of Ender Lilies, some really good fights but none that I would call stellar. Not the case with this game, so many stand out boss fights that actually had some challenge to them. I actually had to focus and really give it my all against a couple of this games major bosses.


I think that calling Ender lilies a platformer is a stretch, it really had almost no challenging platform sections and I think the dev's realized that. They made so many fun levels in Magnolia and the variety of top notch quality zones with really fun platforming sections was fantastic.


Just fantastic across the board, every aspect of it is just stunning, I could not wait to see the next zone just to see the artwork for it. It was all just gorgeous.


I really enjoyed it, all the background lore and the Extra's page to read up on enemies and characters for more background info was really welcomed and I thought it added a lot. I think the thing that added the most though is the rest area conversations between the characters, I really enjoyed all of them and it added so much character to your companions


Mili killed it again with the OST, Ender lilies and now Ender Magnolia are two of my favorite game OST's of all time. They really set the tone for each zone, character moment, boss fight. I will be listening to both of these soundtracks for years to come.


It took me 20 hours to 100% this game and not even for a second did I want it to end. It was just fun from beginning to end. If you are a fan of metroidvanias this is a must play, if you are not a fan of them then this is a must play. I would not call this genre one of my favorites and normally I struggle to finish them but Ender Magnolia has so much character and love put into it that you cant help but enjoy it.

This is a hot take, but I think this game is a bit overrated. Its fun, but its also really frustrating. Combat with multiple enemies boils down to a spam fest of dodging various attacks from all directions. The damage is so high that any enemy can kill you in three hits. Its also not uncommon for flying enemies to shoot multiple projectiles at once causing you to die very quickly. All that said, this makes a lot of run backs very long having to repeat the same sections over and over going through the same enemies.

There are always respites right before bosses. The bosses are generally health sponges and, of course their damage output is huge. The carapace options are nice and helpful for blocking damage, however, your melee attack can't be canceled, so you're animation locked and can't block. You can block while shooting projectiles, so these fights devolve into standing in one spot spamming your own projectiles while blocking attacks. Given how little damage you put out and how much damage you take, these fights boil down to whittling away at the boss while hoping for almost perfect blocking.

I don't mind hard games, Elden Ring, Sekiro and Hollow Knight are some of my favs. This one just isn't clicking.

Also, why the owl goes away when resting or entering a boss arena is beyond me. Many times I go an entire fight without the owl because I didn't realize it automatically turned off.

Pretty game with a rushed story, some frustrating battle mechanics, and less heart than it's predecessor. I bought this in early access to support the devs and waited until launch to play. Overall, I rate this game as a "meh" but being a fan of Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights tipped it over into "meh, sure".

Pros:
- Polished look and feel.
- Catch sound track.
- Cool character and homonculus designs.
- Map areas are precise and track completion by going from grey to blue when all collectibles/secret paths have been discovered.
- Fast travel to all save points.

Meh:
- Get ready to get one or two shotted A LOT. I know they're slated for rebalancing but f*** those f****in rats, man!
- Close quarters combat never felt intuitive. The enemy types and their ability to kill you instantly thanks to very brief damage invincibility window encourages you to rely on taking enemies down from afar using projectile attacks.
- Story was convoluted and not that interesting. Because each spirit (called homonculi in this game) gets air time (versus only having brief lore descriptions attributed to them, as in the original game), it felt like there wasn't as much time spent developing the few core characters. Nola, the main homunculus featured on most of the cover art, mostly gets washed out by the others except from the beginning and end of the game. As a result, the story felt pretty non-cohesive and I was left feeling pretty apathetic about the fate of the characters.
- Equipables didn't add much interesting variation to the gameplay.

The first thoughts I had while playing Ender Magnolia were way back during the early access release. I kept thinking to myself 'the demo area will probably end around this next corner'. Despite that recurring thought, the map just kept going, and I was absolutely delighted for it.

Indeed, I was experiencing the next game in line after my favorite metroidvania of all time, Ender Lilies, and things continued to shape up undeniably favorably. The combat was smooth, and reminiscent of everything that I loved from EL. The music, drenched in the musical prowess of Mili, was there, right alongside the subtle and tasteful worldbuilding, and the scattered notes which fed you the story one agonizing hint at a time, which left me feeling as if I were sweeping dust from a gorgeous tapestry with an excavator's brush. Every single ingredient needed for a stellar work of art was present, and they were blending together right before my eyes.

Gameplay-wise, Ender Magnolia is an upgrade from Ender Lilies in nearly every way. The abilities that Lilac amasses throughout the course of the game are all high quality, though some are definitely more consistently usable than the others. Where Ender Lily's Lily had a large quantity of attacks that she received in relatively short intervals, Ender Magnolia's Lilac trades off quantity for a smaller selection of higher quality attacks with no usage limit, unlike the last game. This has got to be one of the best decisions from the gameplay side that the developers have made, as switching to a cooldown system emboldens the player to charge forth and make the most of their abilities without fear of rationing out their offensive capabilities.

Now, on the topic of combat, I want to give the developers a specific measure of praise for their custom difficulty selector being unlocked from the very start of the game. This is a massive boon for all players, of all types. Speaking as someone who absolutely loves making their gaming experiences harder than they need to be, I loved the great range of options and parameters available to tweak until one is able to find their comfortable difficulty niche. At one point in the early game, I felt that enemies were dying too quickly before I was able to get a satisfactory combat experience out of them, so I jumped the enemy HP up in a cinch, and got rewarded for it with costumes, lore, and (GORGEOUS) concept art in the same breath. This is just such a wonderful idea. It encourages difficulty, while giving players who need a reprieve from high pressure action an outlet with absolutely no missed content or shame.

Story-wise, they manage to make another absolute banger which subtly uses Ender Lilies as a foundation to great effect. Characters are all strongly felt, from Lilac herself, to the companions with whom she travels, and the narrative is probably even easier to follow than Ender Lilies' was. The music is just as good as it was in Ender Lilies; Mili is still the absolute best pick for the job, who continues to deliver unrestrained emotion and atmosphere into every nook and cranny the world has to offer. The narrative of Ender Magnolia is one in which the unseen hand of the antagonist carries not a malicious air, but instead one that simply carries out nature. This is a tale of things that came to be from circumstances that no one foresaw, and even fewer know how to contend with. It begs the question of who is left to pick up the pieces after large-scale conflict tears a hole in the lives of people who wish only to live normally.

How did they do it again? How can their output be so consistently good? Music, story, characterization, gameplay, freedom of gameplay options, all of it is just immaculate. They really, really brought it home for Ender Magnolia, and I cannot say enough good things about it, at least not enough to match the way that this game makes me feel inside. Go play Ender Lilies, and then, when you're done, come play Ender Magnolia.

Beautiful art, responsive gameplay, good localization, internally-consistent setting. Some combat skills come online closer to the true end of the game than I'd like, and it can be frustrating to get two- or three-shot by basic mobs on Normal difficulty (lookin' at you, rat factories the rat factories were fixed), but the movement is fluid enough that you can usually run past mooks to get to the good stuff.

I did need to use a map guide to get the true ending. While there are no mandatory secret paths on the basic ending (which have always bothered me in the 2D Metroid games), the true ending does require you to find secret passages (thankfully, no secretly-breakable walls in this game) and navigate through an environment that constantly damages you.

The platforming is never too difficult, and any puzzles are pretty limited in scope. You get a forgiving dodge and a super strong shield-parry pretty quickly, and I think they were made to be so strong because bosses will regularly steamroll you if you get hit even once. If you find the game too easy, there's plenty of difficulty customization, including an option to have any hit kill you instantly... though honestly, speaking as a pretty experienced Metroidvania player, I don't think anyone but the genre's most hardcore players will find this game too easy.

Overall, super solid game. Absolutely give it a shot!

Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist is the successor of Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights - and it's an extraordinarily successful one at that.

This game is everything you could ask for for a sequel: A big expansion of the universe, many quality of life changes, interesting character designs, innuendoes of the past game even, a captivating story... Honestly, I really cannot think of one major flaw this game has. I loved Ender Lilies, but this one? I would have never expected to have even more fun!

Even if you have not played the prequel, you will understand 95% of the story. It is not crucial for the plot of this one, but the innuendoes and the knowledge of what happened in the prequel will give the plot even more depth.

Other than that, the praise Ender Lilies received also applies here. Biggest plus is the aesthetic. It is beautiful to look at, same as listening to the OST which made me tear up in some scenes.

I cannot say anything except that I wholeheartedly recommend this game. A 10/10 in my eyes. One of the best Metroidvanias I have ever played.

Great Metroidvania! Visuals still as beautiful as in Ender Lilies. And almost everything gameplay-wise (i.e. combat and exploration) is an improvement on its predecessor. Personally, I enjoyed both the music and settings/aesthetic of the areas in Ender Lilies a bit more, but that's pretty much it. There are a few nitpicks I have (particularly concerning certain attack telegraphing by enemies, which both of these games generally do pretty well, with a few exceptions), though. A few enemies, have some attacks that don't get the same red flash indicator that others do. Which would be fine if the enemy sprites had sufficiently recognizable (e.g. charge-up) animations to indicate the oncoming attack, but that really isn't always the case here.
Some of the bosses have mechanics that incentivize waiting around for a surefire opening to attack, which I dislike a lot.

Vague mini spoilers coming up here...

Namely, some aoe spells (most of them are fine and can still be used for ranged attacks by the player but I do believe there are some that really require you to just wait for it to finish which can become annoying pretty quickly) and especially one boss who can essentially parry you. It doesn't happen TOO frequently, but the fact that he even has this ability and can use it whenever pretty much without wind-up means that as the player, MOST of the time you can't really execute your full primary weapon combo on him even if he seems "vulnerable". Again, this can be circumvented by a more careful playstyle, I simply found it a bit dissatisfying. So, nothing major.

For some reason, I seem to have enjoyed most of the bosses in Ender Lilies a tad bit more than the ones appearing in this game. Most of the bosses here either felt extremely underwhelming, since on the standard difficulty you can burst most of them down in like 20 to 30 seconds, or when they took a few more tries I just didnt find them as memorable as in its predecessor. Sometimes the movesets just weren't that fun to me, and the character designs also seemed a bit less interesting.

The areas in this game I found much, much more enjoyable than in Ender Lilies, partly due to the much more prevalent inclusion of more and more NPCs for sidequests and the like.
So eeeh yeah, very good game. Can't really go wrong here if you liked Ender Lilies. 8.5/10,

This game is an upgrade from Ender Lilies in every way. I love how they've redone the system in which you pick which abilities to use. There are a total of 10, let's say characters, to pick from, but each one has a 3 variations. So that gives you a total of 30 Abilities to mix and match. You can only pick one of the variations from each character at a time though, but they stay powerful enough throughout the game. This helps remove the feeling that I had in the last game where one of the characters I had invested in would eventually become obsolete down the road. Each one is powerful and useful in their own way. Also, you can only equip a max of 4 abilities at a time, they've done away with the swap to another set option. For me, that is honestly an improvement, because managing six and making use of them effectively was kind of complicated at times. They have replaced the limited uses with cooldowns, so you will never run out of your favorite attack.

The combat in this game in my opinion is very enjoyable and challenging. I played through the game on hard difficulty + 1.2 times enemy, and that felt like just the right amount of challenge on my first playthrough. The difficulty is relatively customizable though if you get temporarily stuck. I always felt the desire to explore every little corning because the map incentivizes you to clear it, by changing to blue when you have found everything. Overall a great game. I'm looking forward to them introducing new game + so I can use all the attacks I get late in the game early on.

I normally review games when I beat them, but unless the game drops the ball in its second half this review is going to stand.

All of the people saying that this is just "more of the same" (even in a positive manner) are smoking crack. This game runs LAPS around Ender Lilies in just about every way. All of the core mechanics that were interesting but incredibly underdeveloped in Lilies are done tenfold better here.

Combat is probably the biggest aspect of this. While Lilies gave you a lot of options, most of them were frankly pretty terrible. The best loadout in the game could be gotten in the first two areas (the bird and the flying witch along with the starting sword knight) and then you really never needed to use anything else. Here, I am constantly swapping around my moves to fit different scenarios or just to spruce things up a bit. And the combat feels so much BETTER too, with a more responsive moveset and enemies that aren't as much of a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ as before.

Tying into those abilities is the storytelling, since your abilities are also the characters/bosses that you gradually rescue along your journey. Lilies had this too, but with the exception of the titular Ender Knight, they all had, at most, one unvoiced cutscene and MAYBE some lorebooks if you were lucky. They didn't talk, they didn't interact with each other, they didn't comment about anything in the world, etc. They felt like nothing more than the abilities that they functionally were.

Magnolia does all of that. There are thirty abilities spread evenly across ten characters, as well as a few others that are exclusive to world abilities (the grapple hook, the super dash, the ground pound, etc), and ALL of them are constantly commenting on things in the world, or showing up to just chill out when you're saving, or actually appearing in cutscenes. They feel like real characters. If you can make me emotionally invested in my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ grappling hook, you're doing something right.

Also, NPCs. This game has good NPCs compared to the first game in the fact that they...actually have them. Ender Lilies was void of ANY NPCs (outside of the fast travel horse I guess) and while it did contribute to the distinctly depressed and lonely feeling that the atmosphere was going for, it didn't really help an already bare bones story with a mute, personalityless protagonist. Not only does Lilac speak compared to Lilly, they have an actual personality. The NPCs you meet, while not deep or really as interesting as any of your spirits (called homunculi in this game), are at least THERE. You feel like an active participant in an ongoing plot rather than just the janitor cleaning up after the party.

You get your moveset a LOT quicker too. Lilies had you unlock every movement upgrade around the 2/3rd mark, while Magnolia gives it to you around the 1/3rd mark. It allows for level design and bosses to be a lot better since they know you'll have more to work with. They even made that parry ring from the first game into its own equipment slot with different variants for added flavor.

Relics are mostly the same. They're just Hollow Knight charms, and that's a good thing. But you also have equipable armors and relics that have other effects that are more interesting than the relics and their passive buffs. In general there's just more variety and things to find and it makes exploring easy.

Also, the MAP. By and far the best map in a metroidvania. Full stop. You always know if you're missing something, and while Lilies was also helpful with its "change the area color when you have all items" thing, Magnolia has that except the map is actually detailed and you know where in the vague box-shaped room you're in actually might have something hidden.

Overall? Best metroidvania of 2025, following up Nine Sols as the best metroidvania of 2024. Silksong (if it actually comes out this year) has some real competition for the top spot I say.

Ender Magnolia was one of the games I was most looking forward to in 2025. It is the sequel to Ender Lilies, a dark fantasy metroidvania, that I quite enjoyed whilst waiting for Hollow Knight Silksong. Here we are several years later, and no Silksong. Ender Lilies was a fantastic time so expectations were riding high going into Ender Magnolia. I am happy to report that Ender Magnolia not only meets the high bar set by the prior game but exceeds it in every way.

Comparisons to Ender Lilies is inevitable but I will try to keep it to a minimum. Instead of the prior game's dark mideval fantasy metroidvania, Magnolia is set in a dark fantasy steampunk environment. Both take place in the same world though Magnolia is set many years into the future. Like in the prior game, you control a small girl (Lilac) who has Homunculi fight for her much in the same manner spirits did for Lily. There are far fewer Homunculi but their personalities are better explored than the prior game's spirits. The Homunculi also operate on cooldowns while a number of spirits had a certain amount of ammunition. As a result, Lilac feels significantly stronger than Lily, though her healthpool feels smaller. Lilac is very much a glass cannon with most boss fights ended up in me destroying the boss easily or the boss killing me in two hits.

The Ender series is a triumph in not wasting the players time. As in the prior game, you can warp to savepoints at any point during gameplay. You don't lose half your money upon death, you just die. The map and UI of the Ender series are my favorites in the genre. The map and UI are remarkably clear and the map rooms change color once you find all items and pathways leading out of it. Unlike in the prior game, the story is fairly straightforward and the environments are dynamic and varied. Magnolia may start in an underground research facility but shifts to a forest, a sorcerers academy, an eastern feudal lord's estate among many others. While the color pallet is muted, it definitely stands out from it's mostly monochrome predecessor.

I cannot think of any complaints one could have about this game. The worst thing you could say about Ender Magnolia is that it does not innovate a great deal from its predecessor, which admittedly was not a terribly innovative game in and of itself. This said, every idea in Ender Magnolia is so executed so perfectly, that I am really not sure where said innovation could take place. In my 20 hours of playtime, I have had a phenomenal time with Ender Magnolia and this is my early leader for game of the year. If you liked Ender Lilies, you should check this out. If you didn't enjoy Ender Lilies, I would still recommend giving Ender Magnolia a try- it's just that much incrementally better that you should give it a shot.

A very good metroidvania that deserves all its praise. Traversal and combat both feel great. Lilac is a very agile character to control thanks to an early double jump and air dash, and of course traversal gets even smoother as more abilities are unlocked. Somehow, combat feels even better than the traversal. Lilac has access to many different offensive options thanks to the homunculi she encounters. The primary attacks flow well and parries feel especially satisfying to land. The game also allows for complete control over various difficulty options, allowing you to make the game easier or harder as you see fit (including No Healing, and No-Hit options available for those that want to use them). The story is enjoyable, however there are a couple of plot points that seem to be either dropped or inadequately explored. It really goes without saying, but the art design and music for this game is standout. Each biome is breathtaking, with backdrops that are sure to stun. The music is again provided thanks to Mili, and each track goes so hard. Overall, the game is a great experience and and very fun to play.
Now, as a sequel to Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights, the game is both better and worse. The moment-to-moment gameplay feels more fun, as Lilac controls much better than Lily did. The homunculi also carry some of Lilac's momentum whereas Lily's spirits would mostly root her in place. However, as somebody that fell in love with the story that Ender Lilies told, Ender Magnolia just can't compare. The first act of Ender Magnolia manages to be rather compelling, asking questions about the conflict between House Milius and House Frost, the origins of Lilac and Nola, and the mysteries behind attuning. However, as the second act plays out, there are multiple plotpoints that get introduced then concluded, without getting much time to breathe. Some of the more compelling points from act one feel like they get dropped almost entirely. That being said, we see interactions between not just Lilac and her homunculi, but also between them and various denizens of the Land of Fumes. As such, while the overall plot can't stand against the very focused, heartfelt, and agonizing tale of Lily and Land's End, the characterization is stronger. So, while Ender Magnolia is a better game that many people will likely prefer, I can't say I enjoyed it nearly as much as Ender Lilies.

Everything I hoped for in a sequel. Ender Lilies was already peak, and this game improved on nearly every aspect I loved from the original.

The soundtrack was, once again, absolutely enchanting, and the art for this game is gorgeous.

The difficulty felt perfect for me on Hard. I had a great time at that level of challenge without it being too rage inducing. They do have sliders to adjust it to your taste, but maxing those out is not for me. Lilac’s movement also felt more fluid compared to Lily in the first game, enhancing the overall.

I felt like there was a decent bit more dialogue in this one, but it provides just enough context for the story and overall the gameplay wasn't bogged down by it. I also loved the added touch of hearing companions’ thoughts at the benches, it added a nice bit of personality to the cast.

Finally, I felt the UI was quite clean. The menu had a beautiful shot of our main characters in the summary page, and all the inventory stuff was sorted pretty neatly. The ONLY thing I wished for was a way to sort our messages by order of picking them up, because I accidentally skipped through one and couldn't find it later. The map is a standout improvement from the first game though, the icons on items and other points of interest is very much appreciated and, on top of letting you place markers on places to revisit, made tracking my progress a breeze.

Anyway, play this game. If you haven't played Ender Lilies, play that game too. They're both amazing.

A magnificent sequel to ENDER LILIES. You could play the game without having played LILIES, but you will miss some lore and story context. Both games have a similar length (based on my total playtime to 100% both).

The story takes place in a different land after the events in LILIES and there are tons of direct connections to the prior game. I won't elaborate further to avoid spoilers. While it maintains the same beautiful dark ambiance as its predecessor, MAGNOLIA does have dialogue and other characters you interact with. I enjoyed both experiences and thought it gave each game a bit of its own identity.

The gameplay is similar but even cleaner than LILIES'. Level design was wonderful and both combat and exploration felt smooth throughout. You choose up to four active/passive combat abilities to use at a time (out of 24 unlockable/upgradable abilities) which provides plenty of choices for different areas and bosses. On the default difficulty early game bosses felt really easy, but mid-late game had some more challenging bosses which felt fair and satisfying to fight. That aside, there are a bunch of difficulty customizations available at any time from the start for anyone that wants to tune their experience.

The art and music were both gorgeous just like in LILIES. I'll be adding the OST to a playlist alongside LILIES' as soon as it releases on streaming services.

Overall, I was quite hyped for this game after playing ENDER LILIES, and it absolutely delivered on my expectations. I hope we see more ENDER sequels exploring the other nations in the future.

Love this! Ender Lilies is my favourite metroidvania and this game improves on almost every aspect of it! The only part that wasn't as good as the first is the story, which is still pretty solid, but man that first one made me tear up this one did not.

Like the first game this one has some of the most gorgeous puppet animation I've seen, right up there with Vanillaware but in a dark watercolour gothic style. I bring this up because a lot of games that use this style of animation wind up looking and feeling floaty, that's not the case here at all.

The progression feels great, the abilities feel great, the sound is still great! A lot of the abilities are really useful with only a couple under performing. Although I did read another review where someone praised one of the abilities I wasn't as big a fan of so maybe it's just my play style.

The bosses! So good! I've not yet beat the game so there's still a few more to go, but so far every one of them has been solid with only one late-mid game boss being unexpectedly easy. Every other one put up a really enjoyable challenge so far. Even that kinda weaker one felt great to just wreck face on. Kinda fitting as so far they're someone that feels great to beat up.

One small gripe I have is a lack of I frames after getting hit. This can lead to a couple moments where you die almost instantly from attacks. I'm sure a lot of people mentioned the rats who swarm but that's getting nerfed. I've run into a late enemy that has a similar issue where if you mess up one dodge you're basically dead. Luckily they're not particularly hard to navigate but it feels like a rather steep punishment in comparison to everything else.

And that's about it. Oh I had a slight stutter very rarely on steam deck. It was super uncommon, but figured I'd mention it as it's so far the only technical issue I've run into which is a great place to be. Luckily the three times it happened were all outside combat. One was during a bit of tricky navigation which caused me to miss the timing on some of my inputs. It went away as quickly as it appeared and I just attempted the section again.

This game does not dethrone Ender Lilies for me, but that's because I enjoyed the story there more, maybe it picks up some more in the last act. It does however do the upgrading and collecting better and if you are more of a fan of that then this is for you! Also gone are the limited use abilities.

What an excellent game!

Let me give a short statement and say that if you played Ender Lilies and enjoyed it, you will enjoy Ender Magnolia. If you didn't enjoy it, then you won't enjoy this game.

That out of the way, I was first drawn to these games by the music. Both games have a beautiful soundtrack, and I put them up there with Nier in that respect.

As far as gameplay goes, the controls are pretty intuitive, and if you dislike the keybinds you can rebind them at will. I haven't encountered any major bugs, which is a big deal for release day. You'll bump into the occasional typo or two, e.g. "suppply," but again, it's release day.

The story has a similar feel to their previous game. I won't spoil anything for anyone who hasn't played Ender Lilies, but the way the game starts and the initial motivations for the main character are very similar. I'm okay with that, but for some people it might be a little too redundant. Compared to Ender Lilies, the world is much more alive; more towns and npcs, and it seems like all of the homunculi you recruit have unique dialogue, which is pretty cool. There are a lot of nods to Ender Lilies in the game, but they are indirect enough that it gives you a reason to go play the other game without spoiling things. You still have to do some digging to find all the lore and plot items, but as someone who plays Dark Souls I kind of enjoy that aspect of the game. It gives me motivation to explore.

One thing I will say about pacing is that you get a lot of your movement abilities (double jump, for instance) very early in the game. I like this, because it makes the world feel more open. At the time of writing I think I've made it about half way through the game and I haven't found any points where it felt like the game was stymieing my progress because of that. Certain treasures will require later game movement abilities, but that gives you a reason to revisit old zones instead of spending all your time in one place.

As far as difficulty goes, the game isn't too hard. If you enjoy a challenge, there is a very customizable difficulty settings page. I haven't played with it too much, but it looks like you can independently customize a lot of different aspects of the game to suit your preferences. Some like it wildly difficult, and some are just along for the story. The devs seem to respect that.

As a little touch of nostalgia, there is a fun little extras tab at save points where you can spend points earned playing the game to unlock detailed character descriptions, concept art, other outfits, and some other goodies. This was a fun discovery for me because it reminded me of when I was a kid playing Jak and Daxter; you could do the same thing in those older games.

Overall, I think this is a fantastic game and you should give it a try. I hope someone finds this helpful!

Ah Ender Lilies, my favourite beloved metroidvania
Hold-up this is the sequel to that?
Well then this better be the best, super awesome iteration to a masterpiece of a game...
*takes sip*
You got lucky

Jokes aside, this is a phenomenal sequel to what was an already great game, let alone of its metroidvania genre
The world building, the characters and not to mention the music (<3 Mili) are amazing

At first, I was concerned that giving a voice to the main character takes away from the mysteriousness that Ender Lilies' MC Lily had, but now that I've completed the game 100%, I do like what they've done with this game's characters
The story is conveyed in a simple to follow way, with enough intrigue to have world depth and character development especially with the banter scenes at respites

The tiniest detail that I miss, was the dodge animation that Lily had in the first game. That tiny stumble leap was adorable

The ability progression is wonderful as it was in Ender Lilies, and this time each ability and attack come from characters that you interact with, adding to that depth mentioned earlier
The fact you get real early is a godsend

The adjustable difficulty (like enemy hp/dmg/stun) was a great touch, and giving us compensation for making it near stupidly hard is such a great idea that a lot of games should take on board (feed our gamer-egos moar!)

TLDR:

Came to leave a review after going for a full completion and 100% on this and wanted to say, hands down, this is an incredible game. If you're on the fence of getting it, I'll tell you that it's worth it. You can choose if you want it to be on sale first or not, but the price tag is worth what you get.

Starting with the gameplay itself, it feels great. There is a lot of quality of life things put in compared to the first game that enhances the feel for it. The combat can be hard at times, but extremely rewarding when you learn how to dodge and counter effectively, whether it be damage or just not outright dying. An added bonus is that if you're the type of person who would rather play through very casually while enjoying the story and environments, you can adjust the difficulty at any time at the respites by turning down enemy HP, damage, recovery, attack frequency, and so on. If you're looking for higher difficulty, you can increase them, but I will say that past about 1.2 damage, enemies will frequently two shot you, with some others outright killing you in one hit. The controls feel fluid and each ability rewards you in different ways for how you use them. Some may animation lock you, but you learn the timing over time, and again, if it's hard, you just adjust the difficulty.

Secondly, the environment along with music. The art style of the environments were phenomenal. Each area feels unique and the music attached to each area enhances it. I could describe how these two come together, but it's honestly better to just sit there and listen for a bit for each area. You'll get what I mean if you just sit there and listen for a bit.

Lastly, story and lore. The story definitely follows the rhythm of the first game in regards to how it plays out, but it has a different spin to it. Rather than people outright being transformed into monsters and you're put into a world where it seems you're the last one, you get to interact with other characters and see life among the people while everything around them is going to hell. Each character feels unique in their own way and you get to learn so much about the areas while exploring and finding secrets laid around. It's also an added bonus that, since this takes place in the same world as the first, there are ties to Ender Lilies that make you go "Hey, I remember that! I know this!". If you didn't play Ender Lilies, you'll miss out on some ties and certain aspects of the world, but you won't feel lost in the story, but having played it gives you a ton more insight.

And if you're looking for total game time and are looking to fully complete the game(all achievements, extras), you'll be looking at around 20-25 hours if you have the fragments drop at 2.50x in the difficulty settings.

Just finished the early access content thus far, the game seems promising.
Besides the "recycled" mechanics from Ender Lilies, such as Bone Pulverizer, Nola's third weapon and the plunge attack barriers, the game feels fresh and much more polished than the predecessor.

I think that completed rooms should still not show the whole room and leave the player to explore it in case its the first time. With that said, the fast travel and minimap are amazing, the fact that you can see details is a huge improvement from Ender Lilies.

Плюсы и Минусы
+Визуал и стиль игры
+История
+Управление
+Музыка
-------------------
Минусов я для себя не нашёл

Чтож, товарищи геймеры, сегодня мы рассмотрим сиквел Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights. Скажу сразу, первая часть мне очень понравилась, она была с своими недочётами, но всё равно проект вышел хорошим, поэтому когда я узнал, что будет продолжение был очень рад и вот спустя год раннего доступа игрп наконец-то вышла!

Сюжет Ender Magnolia происходит спустя несколько лет (или десятков лет) после событий Ender Lilies в совершенно другой стране с названием "Дымная страна", здесь сильно скакнул прогресс и местные маги стали создавать гомункулов, искусственных живых существ, которых стали использовать во многих сферах жизни, но как и в первой части из недр земли пришла напасть "Дождь смерти", что искажал души людей и сводит с ума гомункулов. Сюжет будет вестись от лица Лайлак, девушки настройщицы, которая может настраивать (восстанавливать) гомункулов, которые после этого будут становиться её спутниками и помощниками.

На этом с сюжетом я пожалуй закончу и перейду к тому, что же натворили разработчики. А натворили они много, если быть точнее то они прислушались к критике игроков и исправили карту, убрали урон от касания противников и убрали ограничения на использование способностей. Также были привнесены изменения в систему прокачки, кроме артефактов появились и другие предметы, которые влияют на характеристики главной героини, также разработчики решили изменить количество атакующих способностей, если в Ender Lilies было большое количество духов, каждый из которых имел атакующую способность и их было много, достаточно много, чтобы выбрать подходящую себе способности для прохождения и за это отвечал каждый сюжетный и мини босс, то здесь у нас могут атаковать, только сюжетные боссы (и то не все), зато у каждого из атакующих гомункулов появились разные атаки, которые нужно открывать и прокачивать, благодаря этому не нужно искать сквозь кучу способностей необходимую тебе и позволяет иметь свой билд удобный для прохождения. Также теперь с спутниками можно разговаривать чего очень не хватало в Ender Lilies. В целом мир стал живее и больше, чему я рад. Музыкальное сопровождение, как обычно на высоте, спасибо группе Mili за прекрасные песни)

Ender Magnolia учла ошибки предыдущей игры, исправила их и улучшила те аспекты за которые игроки полюбили Ender Lilies, поэтому если вам по каким-то причинам не понравилась Ender Lilies, то эта часть вам может понравится.

Игра стоит времени и самое главное времени, чтобы погрузиться в этот прекрасный меланхоличный мир, поэтому покупайте и играйте, вы об этом не пожалеете.
