Review of Ender Magnolia

I like this game a lot. If your a fan of the Metroidvania genre or the previous game Ender Lilies. you should get this game.

The combat is the standout feature for me. It feels like jousting: you rush in, block or dodge the enemy’s attack, and then unleash your own. It rewards you for learning enemy patterns, and it feels especially satisfying when you shut down a boss completely. While I do miss the collectathon aspect from the first game, the new system is more streamlined and flows better.

Exploration is also a highlight. The areas are distinct, and unlocking new powers makes traversal feel fluid. There’s hidden movement tech like in the first game, which is difficult to pull off, but feels satisfying when you finally reach that hidden collectable. Until, you realize you didn't need to do all that work, you just needed to wait until you unlocked the right traversal power.

There are a few aspects I’m not a fan of. The character animations and cut scenes still feel stiff, and the absence of voice acting or any sounds from enemies in general leaves the game feeling strangely silent. In the first game, this worked because you were one of the last humans, but here, people are everywhere. The loneliness of the previous game’s atmosphere doesn’t mesh well, and the music isn’t strong enough to fill the gap.

The narrative context is also a step down for me personally. In the first game, you played as an innocent girl tasked with reminding spirits of their oath to the kingdom. She felt fragile, and you wanted to protect her. kind of like a flower blooming in a hostile land. In Ender Magnolia, you play as Lilac, a small child who claims to care for the Homunculi but then kills hundreds of them with ruthless efficiency. Lilac feels much more independent, and I didn't really feel a connection in comparison. Plus, the reliance on the AMNESIA cliché is annoying. The shift from a Gothic kingdom setting to a magical dystopia also feels meh. It’s not bad, but the themes of worker drones being exploited and tossed out kinda hit a little too close to home for me. They don’t have the emotional draw like some bits in the first game.

Lastly, the game runs smoothly with very few bugs. In today’s market, I feel that deserves some extra credit. And to compare it to the previous game, I feel like this sequel is three steps forward, one step back.

Overall, I loved playing this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys the Metroidvania genre.

Loli(?) Bizarre (but not too sad) Adventure Part 2 – 9/10

After falling in love with Ender Lilies, I had high expectations for Ender Magnolia, and wow I'm so glad it delivers in almost every way—improving the gameplay while keeping the hauntingly beautiful aesthetic of the series. But while the gameplay shines, I can’t help but feel like something is missing in the story and world compared to the original.

Pros
1. The gameplay got improved in every way, maps are no longer weird empty rectangles! They actually have detail (like those with treasure icons + terrain outlines) and scale now. You won't have to worry about not finding the right place for items and important story bits, and it really scratch that itch the previous title had left with me (well you'd still get lost in some areas, esp the Forrest part, but that's just how the map design is, in which i didn't really found it too difficult like the others said tbh, it just felt bit long and slowed the pace)
2. Enemies actually got staggered more often with how much attack types you can customise, and that the attack animation is much more fluid so that you can have an easier time to telegraph when the attack is actually gonna land.
3. Parry is now more emphasised with how relatively generous in the input time and much more useful than the original, it basically carried me half of the boss fights
4. Did I mention they also removed enemy contact damage? Coz thank god, no more getting stun-locked to death because an enemy hitbox randomly clipped you
5. Oh and the final boss is actually hard this time, had to die for almost an hour until actually having my successful run lol, but in a good way since it really encapsulates the "hard but fair" feel so its really just comes down to the battle of skills and reaction time (yes im playing on hard mode btw)
6. Last but DEFINITELY not least, the music is still S+ tier. I don't know what mist Mili are smoking, coz they are still delivering absolute fire soundtracks one after another. Boss themes like are absolutely insane, their soundtrack is what makes these characters so much more memorable. And the Stage music? God its just perfection. all blends into the world’s tone so well that I kept stopping just to vibe


1. One thing that particularly irked me is the setting of this game. In the prequel, Ender Lilies felt like you were traveling through the ruins of a dead world, humanity seems extinct and what's left is just pure despair. While Ender Magnolia is still tragic, but now it’s more like an ongoing crisis rather than full-blown post-apocalypse. I mean like there are people still alive (tho not very well) and some form of society is still functioning (well, barely), which kinda takes away that complete "all hope is lost" feeling. Don’t get me wrong it’s still beautifully bleak, just that it's not as emotionally devastating and the stakes doesn't seemed as high as the previous game
2. Another thing is that there's a ton of cool worldbuilding and character potential, but it feels like the game never fully commits to it. Some major characters like barely had any time to develop, which is disappointing because the initial setup were intriguing, i really wanna see how they plan out the story in the future but it just ended very abruptly. Which kinda lowkey feels like parts of the story got cut, oof...
3. Oh and the companions is a bit mixed bag for me? Like in Ender Lilies, at least every companion you picked up had a memorable final stand, with a heartbreaking memory sequence that really made you feel their tragedy. Well this game your companions can actually talk mid resting, which is great but not that much deep diving into their characters really, and their memory sequences feel more like lore dumps rather than giving us a deep emotional connection. Most companions don’t stand out as much as before (except maybe , who is an actual chad that carried me for most of the game haha)

That said, gameplay still hard carries, so it’s not a dealbreaker, and the plot is actually still engaging to me all the way to the end, but it feels like a step down from the soul-crushingly beautiful storytelling of the first game. Like, I was expecting to be emotionally obliterated again, but instead, I got a cool, less tragic story that didn’t wreck me. Which is fine, but I was expected to suffer you know?

TLDR:
A 9/10 worthy successor, if Ender Lilies was a tragic tale, Ender Magnolia is an action-packed melancholic adventure. It’s still hauntingly beautiful, just… less soul-crushing. The gameplay is peak, the music is legendary, and the improvements they made are more than welcoming. But if you came in hoping for another round of "this game is gonna emotionally ruined me for a week", you might not get that this time. Still, gameplay-wise, this is a 10/10 metroidvania, and if you liked Ender Lilies, you're gonna love this! Keep it up development team!

За что я могу укорить новую игру, так за не достаточно выразительную химию отношений между главными героями и запинающуюся подачу истории.
В первой игре покровительство рыцаря не знающей мир девчушке было прописанным наследием, проклятием, отягчающим душу выбором. А тут случайная встреча в руинах, и с амнезией уже оба. Половину игры Лайлак и его спутница не понимают, откуда они, что делали раньше, и что их связывает сейчас. А я не поняла основ их привязанности и после финала. Как и интриг с магическими хитросплетениями, приведших к катастрофе.

Во всем же остальном игра превосходит первую часть на голову. Удобная, долгая, богатая метроидвания. Карта великолепна: с прорисованными деталями, обозначенными преградами, проставляемыми маркерами, с обозначением завершенности, возможностью телепортироваться с любой точки на выбранный чекпойнт. Гуляй- не хочу.
Сражения стали менее вариативны на виды атак. В бой можно взять лишь четверых бойцов, а не шестерых. Но уже не стоит волноваться, что закончится число их применений. Не нужно бояться задеть врага краешком волос - контактного урона нет. Сложность можно настраивать на свой вкус. А артефактов и снаряжения так много, что десятки минут я проводила на скамейках, просто выбирая финтифлюшки на следующий заход.

В общем, комфорт во всем. Приятно чувствовать на себе заботу игродела, приятно видеть его работу над ошибками и рост молодой франшизы. И приятно поощрить эту игру покупкой. Советую.

Incredible game. If you loved Ender Lilies then you're eating good with this one. Pretty much everything is a flat upgrade from the last game, with a few notable exceptions (I personally liked the main character sprite work and the music more in the original). But the gameplay, exploration, progression, and visuals got a huge facelift. In particular I love how much of the map you open up at intervals. Getting a new exploration talent often unlocks 2-3 new areas and you can start exploring either of them or both of them as you like. And the upgrade progression manages to remain fairly linear due to the way upgrade materials work. It's really brilliantly designed.

Let me preface this by mentioning that Steam's playtime shown is wrong, it took me 14 and a half hours to 100% the game.

An improvement to Ender Lillies in almost every way. And I do mean almost.

Much like Lillies the atmosphere is incredible but in a very different way. This game is less dreary and more focused on the state of society and the whims of nature which reflects in a number of more upbeat and industrial tunes that the game has to offer.

Speaking of the music, Mili and Cassie (their singer) absolutely blew it out of the park once again. Creating music that makes you drown in the area you're in. Absolutely worth the price of admission alone for me.

Luckily the gameplay is also very solid, exploration feels very rewarding and there's a lot of options for steering the game in a direction you like to play, you can be tanky, focus on your special attacks or just stack a bunch of damage.

Much like in Lillies you get your moves from third parties, unlike in Lillies you are locked to a set number of them with 3 moves and a special each and you can only use 4 unique characters at ones (so no doubling up on one character's moves), for most of the game I stuck with the same ones but when NG+ and the boss refights come out I'll try and toss a bit of variety in there.

For most of the natural gameplay you'll have 2 roads to take until it all culminates into two final areas, one optional and one not.

I do want to touch on those, as they are severely undercooked. The Upper Stratum is an unbalanced mess with a ton of empty space and no meanungful encounters. It has one good puzzle and that's it, you're at the end. The optional area takes some bits from the endgame area of Lillies and it's a nice throwback but when you get all the bits and bobs in order for the true ending and open that gateway you expect another dungeon but it's just... one room? A bit of a letdown to be honest.

As for the story. I've seen a lot of criticisms of it and I do somewhat agree. There's a lot of moving parts and betrayals happening between factions which makes some characters not get the proper development they could have used. In the end, the story's only slightly worse than Lillies' for me and not really a detriment. I could still immerse myself into the world. (having actual people that speak outside of cutscenes also helped a lot).

To summarize, great game, please give me the boss refights faster cause they are the absolute highlight of this game. The true final boss took me a solid half hour of attempts just cause the crescendo of that damn theme made me tear up every time (also it's just a pretty tough fight).

Starting up Ender Magnolia years after finishing its predecessor, I felt like I’d never left. The protagonist I took control of might have been different, as was the location of this new journey, but the general feel of the world – its grim yet beautiful melancholy – very much remained the same, making me feel right at home, especially with the soundtrack’s lovely piano tunes and soft vocal backing in certain areas.

All in all, I’m very pleased with the Early Access state of the project: it’s most certainly the kind of game that immediately grabs your attention with its gorgeous world and atmosphere, all the while tweaking and polishing what worked in Lilies. The combat system – that is, using “spirits” as weapons that fight for you – is as enjoyable as its counterpart was in the original, and the option to upgrade Homunculus abilities in order to diversify your lineup and try new play styles adds ample amounts of variety to gameplay. So far, Ender Magnolia very much seems like a worthy successor to Lilies, and I can’t wait to see more.

I completed it today. Great game!

The map system was excellent at presenting gates in the metroidvania map layout, and I really liked how the gate icons were changed from red to neutral colors as you acquired the keys and abilities needed to progress. The clear color coding of "unsolved" rooms was great as well, like it was in the previous game.

Gameplay wise, I liked how abilities were grouped in threes as aspects of a fewer number of significant characters that you recruited, compared to the more chaotic list of abilities in the previous game. The progression systems were more varied, more fun to interact with and more complex than in the previous game as well. Bosses were maybe slightly easier than in the previous game, due to larger opportunities to use synergistic aspects of the progression system. The "pressure" abilities were really effective and fun to use, but it stands to reason why you would use a puny sword instead of a gigantic poise breaking drill or continuous magic AoE damage and status effect generators.

I kind of liked the story and setting. The music was maybe not up to the standards of the previous game, but there were some standout tracks like the old city vocal track.

In short, this is a great metroidvania title that most people who enjoy the genre will enjoy playing.

An INCREDIBLE metroidvania that does everything right.
Music: Impeccable. Maybe some tonal shifts here and there but overall the style captivates me so much. The vocals in the calm tracks, the hype in the boss fights, it does everything I'd want from a soundtrack and more.
Visuals: The backgrounds are one of the most incredible things about this game. I literally had to screenshot every pretty shot and send to my friends because of how incredible everything looks. The character and enemy designs are nice. They have some boring patterns on the beginning but get really creative on the second half. Bosses are visually interesting and super memorable.
Mobility: Extremely smooth and fun. The movement overall was tuned really well with some details metroidvanias don't do that people don't notice, but allow some really fun shenanigans, mainly the fact you refresh your air dash after a second jump, so you can chain Run -> Jump -> Dash -> Double Jump -> Dash. Or even better with the main attack, Run -> Jump -> Attack (x4) -> Dash -> Attack (x4) -> Double Jump -> Attack (x4) -> Dash -> Attack (x4) to get absurd horizontal movement.
Combat: is really nice! The abilities are simple and I've been ignoring a lot of them, but I can notice they're all balanced and everyone would have a different experience with them. They make for really fun cycles during bosses!
Bosses: Like aways, they're a big highlight for me. I personally found them in the first third of the game really easy, but after moving to Hard it got into a perfect sweet spot of attempts and suffering
Story: is a lot better than Ender Lillies for me. Not that the first one was bad, I was just not paying attention as much... But here there are a lot more characters I managed to enjoy. The sorcerer Declan and the Combat Puppet No. 7 were my favorites for now, but I haven't beaten the game yet so I might edit this later! Overall, the vibe of the story is perfect if it's the style you like.

Edit: The ending is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amazing. Peak difficulty, peak story, peak music, peak everything.

10/10

Just finished the early access, and the game is just.. too beautiful, both its art and music

Compared to Ender Lilies, this game has improved significantly in every aspect. But first, I love how the game now gives a lot of human NPCs scattered across the stage and have their own dialogue too, which support the games enticing lore so its easier to follow and not just rely on notes or item description instead. The spirits/homunculus here are also have travel banters when you rest in Respite, with different set of dialogues based on what homunculus combination you currently equipped, making your journey less lonely.

For traversals and progressions, it feels much easier and efficient since you're given access to double jump and air-dash from the beginning, and given lunge attack shorty after defeating the specific early boss, so no more rooms left uncleared and you can fully explore everything from the start (at least this is what I experienced from the early accessible stages for now). The stage navigation is also straightforward since we're now given an indicator in the map of where to go.

Now we're talking about combat and this is where I enjoyed the most, the combat is more fluid and have realistic physics as you can now juggle your enemies mid air based on how 'heavy' the enemy is, contact damage is no more, and homunculus can act as combo extender. The homunculus also have up to 3 different attacks through their upgrades which you can customize to suit your playstyle, and what's more the protagonist now has equipment slots up to 4, the equipments here are craftable using currency you've collected, expanding a further customization to not just rely on Relics. Also you can change the attire too!

Still, the best thing this series offer to me personally is its music, having another music sets from Mili is always appreciated <3

Another banger from Adglobe and Live Wire. Ender Magnolia is substantially similar to Ender Lilies in tone and structure, but with refined gameplay mechanics that elevate the game over its predecessor.

- You get a double jump and mid-air dash almost immediately - within 20 minutes of starting the game. This gives you a great amount of control right from the beginning, and the game's platforming and puzzles are designed with this in mind.

- Homunculi (Ender Magnolia's version of spirits) are not limited-use. Every homunculus ability can be used an unlimited number of times, and four can be assigned at once. Many of them have cooldowns or have particular trigger conditions in lieu of charges. But you now no longer need to fret about stretching your ability uses out between respites.

- Fast travel allows you to move to any discovered respite, no matter where you are in the world.

- There are fewer homunculi than spirits (10 compared to Ender Lilies' 26) but each homunculus has three abilities, resulting in more overall options in your arsenal. The homunculi are also all characters in their own right, showing up in cutscenes and conversations at respites.

I finished the game 100% all achievements in about 20 hours. Like its predecessor, the game conveniently marks off map areas that you have completed, taking the guesswork out of looking for secret passages or hidden treasure - a real boon to the OCD people out there.

Good music, beautiful art, crisp platforming, and (as far as I experienced) zero bugs. Strongly recommended if you liked Ender Lilies, or are a fan of Metroidvanias in any capacity.

Amazing from start to finish, great as an introduction to the Ender series but definitely has some moments that are much more impactful after finishing Lilies first.

Everything about combat was polished to near-perfection; the bosses are more punishing than Lilies', and can two-three shot you with their strongest attacks, but you don't find yourself screaming at their unfairness (most of the time. looking at you ). I've completed the entire game on Hard and felled most bosses in 1-5 tries. If you however find yourself stuck, there are difficulty sliders which can make the game much easier (or harder. difficulty also affects how many "fragments" you gain but those are only needed for bonus unlockables like costumes and concept art). Compared to Lilies, there are way less characters who aid you in combat but I found each of them more useful than 70% of Lilies' spirit roster. Dodges and parries are now also cleaner. Don't think I've ever used the ring of parrying or the headless defender in Lilies but here it's Shackled Beast all the way baby. Absolute GOAT of an ability and a character.

In terms of visual design, Lilies is aesthetically more similar to Dark Souls , while this one I found more like Nier. Overall I'd say the visual design is as good as Lilies but now there are like 3 times as many locations which are all well-made and serve their purpose in Magnolia's setting. There are now way more NPCs (partly because, unlike lilies', ), which works as both a blessing and a curse because some of them definitely need more lines and screentime. ESPECIALLY , who are shown as important to the lore and the story but fall short of any real exposition. Overall I'd say I enjoyed Lilies' story more but definitely wasn't disappointed with Magnolia's.

They also improved exploration and QoL a lot and the soundtrack is honestly quite incredible again yadda yadda that's kinda whatever and has been said a lot already. In conclusion it's an absolute must-play and all of its downs are overshadowed by its ups. Hope to see the next Ender game more than Silksong atp

Ender Lilies was one of my favorite Metroidvanias. As hard as it is to believe, this game improves on the original in almost every way while retaining the things that made Ender Lilies great, like the beautiful art.

- The story is much easier to follow than the first game.
- Scalable difficulty sliders are available from the start of the game that can be adjusted at any time.
- Standard movement abilities like air dash and double jump are available near the beginning of the game.
- Cooldowns are used for initial abilities instead of the charges system from the first game, encouraging more regular use.
- An optional healing ability on enemy defeat is available near the beginning of the game
- Immediate fast travel
- The map is the best of any Metroidvania I have played. Many areas of interest, such as locked doors and upgrades, are automatically added to the map. Areas that still have secrets remain a different color. This is much more fun to me than wandering around blindly looking for things.

Fantastic metriodvania. The combat is a huge step up from the first game, and overall the gameplay is largely improved across the board. The presentation is just as good as before, with stellar music and visual setpieces.

It took me ~19 hours to 100% the game, using the hard mode difficulty sliders with the exception of one boss fight where I dialed it back to normal. As an aside, I love just how customizable this game's difficulty is, you can tailor the experience to whatever it is you're looking for.

I do have some criticism, which I am elaborating on in-full as the developers have shown themselves to be responsive to feedback. By listing so much criticism I understand that this review may feel negative overall, but again I do really like this game, so if you're just looking for a recommendation, stop reading and give this game a try!

*LARGE SPOILERS BELOW*
- as a whole, thankfully the developers have already announced changes to this area.
- lots of backtracking and packed full of highly damaging enemies. I'm fine with this area being challenging, it's the last area after all, but it could use either more shortcuts or increased enemy variety. What enemy variety there is is largely offset by the sheer quantity of enemies, making this area feel like a slog to progress through.
- The True Final Boss has some problematic moves. Their 'ice parry' can start up while you are mid-swing, leading to what feels like unavoidable damage. I also had two occasions where their large area of effect attack at the start of phase 4 pinned me to a wall, leading to an instant death. Maybe both of these examples are simply 'skill issues' but I only have my personal experience to go by.
- The story. This is more difficult to give constructive criticism towards, as it's much harder to fix a story than an area or a boss fight. So to keep it somewhat brief, I wish there was more time spent on several of the major revelations that occur towards the end of the game. The name reveal came and went in the span of a single cutscene, and did not carry much impact for me. I also would've liked more time with all of whom who had very little presence in the game despite being some of the central drivers of the game's plot. Almost all of motivations are revealed in a single Finding, it feels like there's something missing.

Now THIS is how you should make a sequel. If you have already played Ender Lilies then don't even waste your time on reading reviews and go play Magnolia right now. There's literally 0,1% chance that you'll regret it.
Every aspect of this game is an upgrade from prequel and the last one was already a masterpiece.
We have here the best map in metroidvania. This line you'll see a lot in reviews, and it's true. Not only the map will show you which room is completed, but now it also marks collectables and cover unvisited parts in fog, which makes backtracking not a chore anymore.
Expressive and fluid animations, responsive controls and a bunch of different customizes for abilities makes combat and movement feels great. Add this to the fact that enemies here don't have a classic contact damage (with exceptions, ofc).
While the style and setting are jubjective for everyone, the game still looks amazing. Art is gorgeous.
OST is atmospheric and fits every location and boss fights - thx Mili and team, as always.
Completing prequel isn't necessary to understand the story, but you will miss some details and references, obviously.
Overall Magnolia is an amazing metroidvania, great game in general, and one of the best sequels that not only follows the roots of the first game, but still manages to improve the gameplay and QOL.

Ender Magnolia is a great sequel to their original Ender Lilies. If you played the original, you'll know what to expect, but they've tuned everything to feel just a little better,

Story-wise, you'll get a bit more out of this game if you've played the original as well - and that game holds up so I advise you going through that one first.
100% Completion for me was 19 hours, and it did not overstay it's welcome. I think a playthrough where you just want the first ending, is probably around 12 hours, but you are going to have to judge how undergeared you want to face bosses then.

There are a lot of Metroidvania out there, and to be honest most of them are lackluster if not actually pretty bad. Ender Lilies was a pleasant surprise, and one of my favorites of the genre. I was very excited for Magnolia, and surprised to find that it more than lived up to my high expectations. Everything I loved from the first game returns in this one: outstanding soundtrack, beautiful visuals, intuitive gameplay, satisfying boss fights. What they've added is an even longer campaign and what feels like more variety in the map. In fact, the game feels huge and I found myself addicted during my roughly twenty hour playthrough. While it doesn't quite capture the magic the first one did just because the first one was such a unique experience for me, the fact that it is such a polished and sequel just shows how talented the team behind the game actually is. I can't recommend this game enough, but I highly suggest giving the first game a run first. They compliment each other very nicely and this game's story does a wonderful job building upon the first without leaning too hard on it.

A fantastic sequel to one of my favourite metroidvanias of all time, Ender Magnolia comes close to perfection. This is a mandatory purchase for any fan of the genre.

It isn't quite perfect. I think the game progression loses something in front-loading so many of the mobility power ups, and the level design has what I regard as comparatively few unlockable areas one can go back for. I suspect these two issues go hand in hand, since from only an hour or two into the game you have more than half the movement tools, it leaves fewer options a level designer can take to include currently inaccessible content.

And in terms of personal preference I liked the world, setting, and soundtrack of the first game more. The quality of all three remains phenomenal in Ender Magnolia, but I found myself drawn more to the prequel.

Gameplay however is a step up in just about every regard. Controls are tight, fights are challenging but fair (I never once felt like a death was cheap, it was always my lack of skill or knowledge), the abilities no longer having finite uses is brilliant, and in general I just can find almost nothing to complain about in how the game plays and handles.

TL;DR: Absolute cinema, if you liked Ender Lilies, definitely play Ender Magnolia; if you never played Ender Lilies, play Ender Magnolia anyways
~~~~
Imagine if you took the already goated Ender Lilies, expanded on every game mechanic and aspect that made it so good, seemingly doubled the amount of content, and made the world about three times less monochrome. World design and background art are somehow even more stunningly beautiful than before, Mili cooks with gas for the OST yet again, the story and worldbuilding are great, and the gameplay really did feel like just a direct improvement and expansion on the previous game in every aspect. I encountered no noticeable bugs on a day 1 playthough.

The most notable difference in terms of atmosphere is that while Ender Lilies gave off the vibes of being all alone in an unceasingly desolate world, Ender Magnolia is a lot more lively while still retaining that grimdark vibe. Both Lily and Lilac are survivors, but whereas Lily felt like the janitor of a world that just needs to be put out of its misery, Lilac felt more like an explorer searching for the answers of her past and people in need of saving in a world that, while bleak, still teems with people's hopes for a better future. Hell, you can even have Lilac and her allies talk with each other during downtime, fleshing out their relationships with each other and their backgrounds (Lilac in particular is super cute and way more expressive than I thought she was going to be, which tbh isn't saying a lot because I was kind of expecting Lily 2). Naturally, the fact that NPCs and even bosses can have actual dialogue also does wonders for characterization and worldbuilding.

You get a lot of the basic movement upgrades shockingly early in the game (they give you air jump and dash fresh out of the tutorial, for one), and in exchange a lot of the platforming bits are much more creative than I expected. Combat feels more fluid with smoother animations, and ability usage was decluttered significantly - they're are now tied to cooldowns instead of ammo, you can only use 4 abilities (instead of 6 across 2 swappable loadouts, which I always found kind of excessive), and they cut out a lot of the "filler" abilities in favor of giving each Homunculus 3 abilities to choose from, with each Homunculus having a defined role in the flow of combat. In addition to the Homunculi aiding you, there's also the revamped equipment system that lets you equip more passive and active items in addition to the usual Relics/Charms, allowing for even more customizability.

Enemy variety has been expanded greatly, and a lot of them use more creative and downright nasty ways to send Lilac back to the nearest bench - I'm not sure if it was just me, but the game did feel much more unforgiving than Lilies was in terms of how hard things hit and how little mercy invincibility you have, as I found myself being one or two-tapped by most enemies starting from the midgame on Hard (+20% damage), while the last boss was dealing 250-500 damage when my HP maxed out at 350. At the same time, dying has virtually no consequence as you keep all items and exploration with fairly frequent save points, you have plenty of tools to defend yourself (in particular, defensive moves have absurdly generous invincibility frames), and even attacks that come out of seemingly nowhere had a pattern I was able to identify in time. Pretty much the only enemy that genuinely upset me were the infamous infinitely spawning sewer rats (who are getting nerfed, thank the lord).

On top of this, they also took time to address many of the criticisms of the previous game: the minimap is super detailed, all of the SFX are way heavier, and they even outright removed contact damage from enemies that aren't actively attacking (unless they're on fire or electrified), on top of overall polish on nearly every single aspect of gameplay.

It seems that the developers listened too much to the players, and this is what came out of it... )

I can't give a negative rating, as it's the successor to Ender Lilies, but I hope that from now on, the developers will make games as they see fit, and the 3rd part will be more similar to the 1st than the 2nd! I really hope so!

I discovered the game Ender Lilies not so long ago when Ender Magnolia was already released. After playing it, I thought it was probably my favorite metroidvania; everything in it was perfect: graphics, not easy difficulty, music, mechanics. But I noticed in the comments that some players complained about the difficulty and gave other advice on "how it should be," and what was the result...

the game is VERY easy; with the set of the very first spirits, you can easily kill any enemy - shoot from a distance, run up and finish them off. If there is an opportunity to change the difficulty during the game, then the game will be remembered as uninteresting. The brain always looks for the opportunity to take the shortest path, so after a few attempts, you will stop picking a set for passing and memorizing enemy attacks. Switch the difficulty, pass it, and FORGET about the game ) Respect for the game is lost. All top games are remembered precisely for their balance when it's hard for you, then you take a break, then it's hard again. And when you overcome this difficulty, you get a special pleasure, thanks to which games become favorites. And that's how the first part was. I wanted to play it again and again.
In Lilies, there was a very convenient map. The shape of the location and either it was cleared or not. Minimalism + convenience. Even knowing the not fully opened locations, I couldn't find secrets in some places for a long time, and it was interesting. In the new version, the map is more detailed. But this is not perceived as a plus..

in Ender Magnolia, the graphics made a small step from 2D to 3D. Modern? Probably. Is it better this way? I don't think so. I love metroidvanias in the old-school 2D style but modernized. And Ender Lilies, in that case, is perfect. But Magnolia already looks somewhat overloaded... That melancholic minimalism in 2D is gone, which is a pity.

In Magnolia, I ran around for 3 hours, I didn't have any difficulties in passing, and I don't want to launch it anymore. And I sometimes think about replaying Ender Lilies.

Мозг ищет всегда возможность пойти кратчайшим путём, поэтому после нескольких попыток ты перестанешь подбирать сет для прохождения и заучивать атаки врага. Переключил сложность, прошел и ЗАБЫЛ об игре ) Теряется уважение к игре. Всё топовые игры запоминаются именно балансом, когда тебе сложно, потом ты передохнул, потом опять сложно. И когда ты эту сложность преодолеваешь - получаешь особое удовольствие, благодаря которому игры и становятся любимыми.

в Ender Magnolia графика сделала небольшой шаг от 2d к 3d. Современно? Наверное. Так лучше? Мне не кажется. Я люблю метроидвании в олдскульном 2д стиле, но осовремененные. И Ender Lilies в таком случае - идеальна. А вот Магнолия уже выглядит как-то перегружено... Пропал тот меланхоличный минимализм в 2d, жаль.

Из мелочей еще: В Lilies была очень удобная карта. Форма локации и либо она завершена, либо нет. Минимализм + удобство. При этом даже зная не до конца открытые локации я долго не мог найти местами секреты и это было интересно. В новой версии карта более детальная. Но это не воспринимается как плюс..

В Ender Lilies хотелось играть и играть. В Магнолию я побегал 3 часа, у меня не возникло никаких трудностей в прохождении и мне уже не хочется больше её запускать. А мысли перепройти Ender Lilies бывают.

Ender Magnolia should be an instant pickup for any metroidvania fan. They kept everything that made Ender Lilies amazing and expanded upon it while fixing some of the weaker parts (mainly the story) to make a game that’s twice as long.

From an exploration standpoint, the map in Ender Magnolia offers one of the best experiences I’ve seen in a metroidvania. It keeps the same mechanic from Ender Lilies that changes the color of a room on the map screen when you’ve found everything and adds on even more features.
The game marks basically everything for you as you play which makes it easy to remember where items were that you couldn’t get to or where doors were that you couldn’t get past without an upgrade. Beyond that, for doors, it’ll even tell you what ability you need to get past something from the map screen after you get the upgrade. Adding on the ability to fast travel to any save point from anywhere makes 100%-ing the map seamless and quick for completionists.

The music is every bit as gorgeous as it was before, it truely does just feel like an upgrade over the previous game.

My only point of contention is the exploration, in the previous game I there were areas I had to back track to with new abilites to find new items, I couldn't just explore the whole world straight away. In the early access it seems everything in a zone is accessible with the upgrades you got in that zone, I was able to find everything straight away, I'm hoping this is a feature of the early access demo rather than the full game.

A nice follow up to their first game. Ender Magnolia is much closer to Castlevania games than the game before it.
It has improved on the background music, especially the music in central stratum.
Map design and interface is improved.
In terms of abilities, some of the traversal abilities resemble Hollow Knight's and I find it stale.
However, they did well expanding on the combat ability types from the previous game and you find this game's roster of abilities far more useful than the previous game's, where some are highly situational and never find use. Abilities in this game can be mixed and matched to anyone's play style. And I finally understand why the first game had little to no ranged abilities, it's easy to cheese some bosses with ranged abilities in this game. The lack of ability uses/durability has significantly made this game easy as well.
Story-wise, I found it enjoyable, sharing the same style of twist with the first game, though I preferred the first game's flavortext type of exposition and the fact that you're alone in Land's End resembles Shadow of the Colossus. On the other hand, I love that the characters get to have chats at respites, a nice touch.
In all, a very enjoyable game and a fine addition to the metroidvania genre.

(Spoiler Alert) Don't read if you don't wanted to be spoiled or a long review. I also did a lot of Ender Lilies comparisons so if you haven't played it yet you might not understand a lot of the things I'm talking about.

I played Ender Lilies around 2021ish and its one of my favorite games I've played so when i heard about this sequel I had very high hopes for this game and it delivered for the most part. I played on Hard after I beat the Shackled Beast cus I didn't know it was a thing until then. Took me 18.5 hours to beat for both endings only missing some achievements where I need to clear out the shop.

Gameplay:
They made a lot of gameplay changes from Ender Lilies so many that it would make this review 10x longer. One thing I would mention is they have no contact damage which makes sense for a couple bosses but I had times where i cheesed some attacks because the bosses just body block u rather than contact damage.
Bosses felt around the same difficuilty as Ender Lilies except for the last boss and Luiseach which were harder than I expected. Some attacks were hard to telegraph but overall its small gripe. The attacks where pillars come from the ground (idk what they're called) were very hard to read though and you could barely see where they come out.
For Abilities you will get up to 30 different abilites they all felt like they had their own place and had good synergy with each other.
Dodging was a little harder since dash was nerfed compared to ender lilies so some bosses you had to rely on parries.
Compared to Ender Lilies there was a lot more build variety since your slots are cut down from 6 abilites per loadout to 4 and there are just more mechanics such as auto abilites and status effects. For example if you want to focus on dodging go get yourself 2 birds and a blind maid then they can do all the damage for you.
Speaking of status effects, I think they were decent. The main complaint was burn lasting way too long to where around 1/3 health would be gone from one burn proc (especially on the final boss). I don't really mind burn being percentage damage but at times it felt like it lasted forever.
Equipment felt like a replacement for certain relics from ender lilies such as getting extra heals, healing potency and just defense in general. Parry carapaces are goated. Totems were ok I just stuck with the ones with extra heals or recover to full after going under 15% health I didn't really like any of the other ones.
For relics there were a lot more compared to ender lilies (Not exactly sure but probably around double the relics). You also get a lot more relic slots as well (if you have the money for it cus holy they get expensive) so you can swap around depending on your loadout and playstyle.

Story:
I'm not really a lore nerd so I don't really have an opinion on the whole story yet but I'll do with what I got. I love how you can interact with your other Homunculi the little tid bits while your resting and they're having a conversation is so cute. It was the one thing I wished Ender Lilies had for their story. Some of the later Homunculi such as Lorna, and Reibolg got like one or 2 of these and I feel like they deserved a little more screen time. I did notice very imporant things got brushed over such as Nola's real name, The Frost Estate and Lilia in general. I was hoping for a better explantion on what happened in between the games. I might've missed somethings but what ever happened to Lily I need to know what happened to her. Hopefully they do like an epilogue portion or some dlc to fill in some of the holes in the story.

Map:
Holy they fixed the minimap from Ender Lilies. Its a lot more readable and I can see what the room actually looks like. One thing I would though is for them to map out where the warps and portals go to after you go in them cus even though I played the crimson forest and academy in one day I can imagine it being hard for people to keep track of where they're going.
The overall map was looks bigger but felt smaller than Ender Lilies. The main reason why is because you get a lot more movement in this game such as super jump and super dash. So on paper they made the map bigger with more rooms and opened out areas its just that new abilites just made them a lot easier to traverse. For the areas before you get these abilites its a lot more straight forward to get to the main boss other than the bio lab so they take too long for me to explore. The exploration difficulty wasn't too bad other than the early game where the rats in the waterways 2 shot me(thank god they're nerfing those mfs).

Visuals:
A lot more flashy and detailed compared to Ender Lilies. I like how they still keep that ruined city vibe but still have a lot of vibrant colors to go with it. The character design was a huge step up as well with more detailed effects and designs. Personally Luiseach is my favorite character give her that screentime.

Music:
I heckin love Mili.

Conclusion:
Overall I think I would give this an 8.75/10 for now but depending on what they do later on it can definitely got up to a 9.5/10. I think this was a step up from Ender Lilies in terms of Visuals and Gameplay. The story on the other hand is mainly whats keeping this away from a 9. I loved the story in Ender Lilies but in this game it just hasn't felt complete yet. If you managed to make it to the end. Thanks for reading :). (Edit:) Now for the Boss Rush waiting room.
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Visuals:9.5/10
Story:7.75/10

Ender Magnolia is an incredible game. I mean, I just got 100% and didn't know it... I was scrubbing around the map for about an hour trying to unlock a 3rd ending before I quit to get food and saw I was *done.*

FWIW, it's Ender Lilies 2.0: Many similar enemies, many similar themes/story beats, many similar... Everything, really. However, if you liked Ender Lilies that's not a bad thing at all...

The artwork is gorgeous, the story is captivating and the music really pulls you in. The gameplay loop is pretty satisfying as well, as you tend to level up at a steady pace and then the store progressively opens up and then they add an option to upgrade your items.

The biggest issue with Ender Lilies was the map. The team has absolutely outdone themselves this time by making what might be the best Metroidvania map I've ever seen. It's very, very easy to see where you've been and if there's anything left to do. It also finally looks like a real map with the spaces all making sense now.

I liked how they also cut down on the number of abilities / companions you have in order to streamline them. It keeps things simple while they also offer options to tweak their attacks to your liking. I do wish I could map more than one of their moves per set, though. I'm not sure why I can't have Nola's sword attack on square and her axe attack on triangle.

It isn't all sunshine and rainbows, though... Like Ender Lilies before it, the bosses in Ender Magnolia can suddenly spike in difficulty, leading to frustration. It took me about 50 tries to beat the Ending B boss because of bugs (seriously, I kept getting stuck on him while trying to evade) or outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ("A screen filling attack that does 80%? Pillars of damage that bounce you between them like a basketball? Yeah, ship it.") It feels very weird to go from curb stomping the prior boss or two to absolutely getting wrecked in 5 seconds. Oh, and the rats - ♥♥♥♥ those guys.

I also wish the equipment felt more... Useful. It was like Homer buying the cursed Krusty Doll. "You get 50 more defense! But a small man will keep kicking you in the balls when you heal." I guess they were going for build variety, but in a game where generic enemies can do 30% of your health in a single hit, why would I equip something that obliterates my HP?

But again... I couldn't put this game down. It's an improvement on the original in many, many ways. It's an incredibly addicting and fun game. Now I'm just waiting around for NG+ to drop so I can do it all again. I played a ton on Steam Deck where it runs flawlessly as well as on my main PC to see the art on the big screen. Grab this at any price point if you're interested in it, because it's worth it.

Superior in almost every way from the first game. Visuals are stunningly beautiful, music is as good, exploration is very satisfying and combat feels right.

This is also the metroidvania game I've played that respects your time the most. It features one of the most detailed minimaps I've seen, marking whether an specific area has been fully explored, as well as tons of details that will save you from unnecessary backtracking. Moreover, pretty early into the game you will already unlock fast travel across Respites (savepoints).

Even with all those timesaves, the game provides of ~20h of content, with lots of areas easily identifiable and new enemies on each of them.

It has less companions to unlock than in the previous title, but they have greater depth, with more lore and variants to give them extra options for combat. There are more equippable items as well, making almost every collectible in the game worthy.

The storyline is a bit difficult to follow and in some aspects I felt it suffered from being as interesting as the gameplay, but overall it gives extra context for dialogues and how areas are connected one to another.

Boss fights were probably my least favorite part of the game. Most of them felt much easier than navigating the areas before them, and overall their design wasn't that remarkable for most of them. They weren't terrible but simply worse than the rest of the game.

Still, overall this is a great sequel and aside from some annoying areas, I've had a great time with it and it is well worth the full price. A very solid title on an extremely competitive genre.

Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist, is an absolute banger follow up game after Ender Lilies:Quietus of the Knights, thats improvement in literally every way possible.

I absolute love Ender Lilies and its really nice to see how the developers learned alot and improvement its elements with Ender Magnolia. The game gives you very important QoL mechanics quite early into the game, the exploration is kept nice and simple (I cannot talk much about it quite yet since im still fairly at the start of the map) at the start. Which is a sweet touch for people like me that always try to explore 100% as the ways go. I expect to spread out the maps and paths you can take, like in Ender Lilies (I will update the Review).

One thing I will personally always like more in Ender Lilies is the setting and areas. However Ender Magnolia has remained with the same art stlye and expanded the art with more details, which makes the areas so far very pleasing to look at. And its always unique.

The NPC and Main Character interactions are much more fleshed out, although sadly still a lack of sound effects and no voices (Im fine with the text that the Characters use to express themselves, but theres are no sound effects to enhance the feel of interactions which was the same case in Ender Lilies).

The game in general feels like an complete improvement compared to Ender lilies with many QoL Features being improved, enemy variety increased, combat being expanded and improved on (Looking at you, removed Mr. Contact damage).

This review will be updated once I have completed the game 100%
But here are a few extra notes so far.

This game is absolutely worth playing if you enjoyed Ender Lilies. You will not need to play Ender Lilies at all to start with this one, but I would recommend it. Or play Ender Lilies once you completed Ender Magnolia.
Worth the price 10/10

Damn this game sucks.
1) Lack of recovery time. If you happen to be on a pathway of multiple projectiles... yeah you are eating all of them. You found yourself in some poison cloud or other constant AoE attack... your health drops in a second. Or you are being attacked by multiple enemies. You are getting hit by every single sweep. And its not like you can take a lot of hits :/
2) Levels and stats do not matter. I can't feel any difference between me having 25 or 30 level. And at some points bosses kill you with 2-3 hits either way
3) The game does not become more challenging over time. It becomes more annoying. The restart points are more and more far away from bosses so that if you lose you can not instantly try again... you need to run through enemies and obstacles before you will get back to fight the boss again and if you will lose too much health along the way... yeah you might as well reset back to the starting point.
4) Inconsistency. You got dogging to avoid enemy attacks. Most of the time they work but quite often you can swear you dogged the attack perfectly yet you still get hit. There are also some timing skills which let you counter the enemy. The same... sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't. I had a one time token that heals me up when my health is below 15%. Sometimes it works... sometimes doesn't.

Game is pretty yeah. But I was unable to finish it because re-trying a boss fight where you are trying to tickle him to death (but he gets to kill you in 2 hits) its not fun.

Yes, it's like the first but with better map.
Combat-wise I loved it, on hard mode it requires you to understand well the parrying system (carapace) and how to make a proper build, some bosses are weak to armor break, others better with automatic homunculi, and so on.
Took me around 12 hours to platinum it, but I think it's close to 20, because Steam Deck doesn't register well. It's a perfect game for Steam Deck.
The OST is gorgeous, the world is charming, the characters could've been fleshed out more.

Safe for some enemies (some they addressed in patches after I finished, like the rats) and some bosses (big robot hitboxes are nuts), most of the combat can be easily dealt using parries and specials correctly. I also love you can exploit the map, not in the same extent as the first game where the second attack you got would propel you up letting you reach areas you were not intended, they understood this and saved the exploit for the half of the game where you get a relic that lets you do this exploit if you read between the lines. You get access to some upgrades but nothing that breaks the game, on the hard mode even with end game upgrades (not equipment or relics) you still have to know what you're doing. Metroidvania wise I feel I had way more fun with this combat than almost any other Metroidvania.

Overall I think for the price range it asks it's more than perfect, I feel I got more than what I paid for, and I love Binary Haze, this is a huge improvement and I cannot wait to see what they have next.

Brilliant, such an improvement over the first game. Must-play metroidvania.

This is more Castlevania-style than Metroid-style. Has some Hollow Knight inspiration mixed in with the relic system. Very satisfying combat system with a surprising amount of variety in playstyles.

The main drawback for me was the somewhat linear exploration. It opens up a little around the middle half of the game as well, but never reaches quite the level of openness as games like Hollow Knight, Environmental Station Alpha, Super Metroid, or Dark Souls. You probably won't ever feel like you're lost, although for some that might be a plus!

Note that it starts off quite easy but becomes more satisfyingly challenging as you continue.

This is basically a straight improvement on the original game in so many ways, and I say that as a big fan of Ender Lilies.

The map is color coded, interesting, and perfect for encouraging exploration and completionism.

The combat is just as snappy, tight, and fluid as the first, but with a lot fewer weapons. This might sound like it would be a step back for combat, but I actually found myself using a much wider variety of weapons now that they're more specifically designed for different enemies and areas, rather than feeling like a random smattering of weapons where you would typically pick two or three favorites, and stick with those for the entire game.

The music was phenomenal! I actually found myself just stopping and listening to the haunting, lilting, playful, and occasionally epic soundtrack for long stretches of time.

Overall, this is definitely among my new favorite metroidvanias, and I imagine it'll be a while before it gets topped.

Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist - 9.6/10

Gameplay - 9.1 / 10
+ One of the biggest QoL improvements of this game is definitely the map. Ender Magnolia's map is way more detailed compared to Ender Lilies. I feel like the cutscenes forward the text too fast.

Like Ender Lilies, mili
See Mili's Old City for more details

Think of it as a more expanded and a more complete version of Ender Lilies despite being in early access.
While this game is equally priced as Ender Lilies, it will have its price increased once early access ends.

This is an amazing sequel to Ender Lilies, it improves and expands upon what made that game so great and made it better,
areas are more expansive, there is a far greater emphasis on traversal and the enemy variety is improved massively, unfortunately I feel like there are some aspects of the game that still need some work,

the poison water is wrong; every game ever tell you to never swim in poison water yet you have to and are never given any indication outside of having nothing else to do that you have to,
there isn't enough backtracking outside of the occasional secret and the paths to new levels there isn't enough use of new powers/traversal abilities, by the way the abilities are laid out they designed each area and it's power separately so outside of that area and the next area you are very unlikely to see a reuse of that power outside of the occasional secret, at no point does the game go "hey you have this new power this previously locked area is now explorable" every time these areas appear it is to lead to an area transition,

leveling: the same system is back again this game though this time you don't need to max it out I ended the game at level 73 after doing some grinding for concept art, you also don't need to buy out the shop or upgrade all your relics, as grinding for all the material or scrap needed would take hours

combat: this feels on par with Ender Lilies, the first game had is fair share of problems and this one whilst fixing those introduced its own, on some bosses attacks are too quick or not telegraphed well, the final boss of the game uses the same animation to do three different variants of the same attack which must be dodged in different ways, how often you will die to attacks that just feel unfair in this game is criminal, for an example there is a flame thrower enemy early on in the game it shoots out a bunch of fireballs which move slow in obvious arcs but do a ton of damage, unfortunately because of the way damage and invincibility is worked you are only invulnerable to that source of damage for about 0.3 of a second or until you are hit with a different attack, each of those fireballs is a different attack meaning if you have 2 overlapping fireballs then you will take damage each tick from alternating fireballs and die in milliseconds,
now onto your combat options, Nola will be your bread and butter until you get a single healing relic then I never used her again, around the mid to late game there is a relic which heals you for 1 HP every time an attack lands, the gun has the fastest damage rate in the game meaning once I had that ring I could sit further away from enemies and just keep on firing, once I had that ring I never died outside of my own stupidity or to bosses it trivialises the game

Difficulty: I love how this game handles difficulty, in the game there is an extras menu with things like alternate clothing colours, character/enemy animation sets and some concept and reference art. It is entirely optional but you can only unlock it with fragments you get from defeating enemies, you can adjust the difficulty to be harder to increase the rate at which you earn these fragments up to 2.5 times, or decrease the options to make the game easier at the expense of earning less fragments, the specific options you can tweak are great as well with; enemy health, damage, break resistance & recovery and attack frequency, and these can go from 0.7 all the way to 2, though you don't need to max out the settings to earn the max fragment count, though if you do decide to max out the parameters be prepared for every boss to 1 shot you,

environmental details: once again they have hit it out of the park, everything looks gorgeous and unique though I do wish some areas were larger and that the transitions between levels was a bit more natural, a bright blue crystal cave next to a deep red fleshy blight or a biological testing facility that transitions directly into some noble quarters with white marble and golden furnishing is jarring

music: nothing much to say its all great though it often took a back seat as the audio balancing this time has it more in the background often overshadowed by the sound effects you create when doing literally anything,

overall this is a fantastic improvement to the series but does need some polishing and some more creative abilities and traversal options as 5 power-ups are used just to let you move through various kinds of barrier,

A great follow-up to the first game.

The Pros
+The overall map is quite large, but never feels like it's wasting your time. Individual screens encourage the use of movement abilities to traverse quickly, and checkpoints are placed well so that death doesn't feel like too big an inconvenience.
+Movement abilities are unlocked at a good rate to keep the pace and sense of progression going strong.
+Combat is a healthy level of challenging, with the player's steadily-expanding moveset balanced against the hard-hitting hordes of enemies and aggressive bosses.
+The OST sets a fantastic tone, and is even better than the first game.
+The protag and spirits all having dialogue with each other help to give the party much more of a sense of cohesion compared to the first game.

-The use of amnesia to drive the plot drags it down a bit.
-Although the dialogue between the protag and spirits is a nice addition, the discussions often don't amount to much. I'd like to see it go more in depth on the characters or world.
-Some enemies hit way too hard for what they are (looking at you, tiny rat enemies).
-A few bosses had a nasty habit of busting out instant kill attacks when they shift phases.

Beautiful art, animation, music, character design, and level design all blighted by what feels like an incomplete story that ended too abruptly.

The first game, Ender Lilies, had a terrific story and everything was easy to follow. The mystery unraveled slowly and satisfyingly with each boss defeated and collectible item obtained, It finished with a truly beautiful (True Ending) conclusion. Ender Magnolia really ruined the Ender world's lore with its plot.

Ender Magnolia's story seems at odds with itself, unsure of exactly where it's going and seems to steer in all directions. It has a very cop-out True Ending and a very short (4 seconds of cutscenes) and unsatisfying not-True Ending. It almost seems like the devs were too ambitious, wanting to craft a Game of Thrones story, until they realized their budget and had to make cuts to all the subplots and also the main plot. It's evident the devs bit off more than they can chew. There's even evidence of this in the game design. The majority of your high-tier skill upgrades are thrown at you one after the other at the 85% mark of the game. At about 95-98% of the game, you'll get a final skill set that seems like it was added in because the devs probably planned for the story to continue way further but needed to quickly needed to end the game.

Ultimately, this game pales in comparison to Ender Lilies, and it's a shame because there could have been such a great story had they either finished making the game or cut down on a lot of the nonsensical subplots in trying to chase that Game of Thrones plot complexity that I don't think Ender Lilies fans even wanted.

Finished 100% barring full collection. Improves on multiple aspects over the first game. Multiple QoL improvements such as no contact damage, fast travelling from anywhere, abilities no longer needing currency to upgrade on top of material etc. make it a smoother on-boarding experience.

Having Lilac be a speaking protagonist over Lily being mostly silent was an interesting change, and the story is overall a lot less grim - people are actually alive this time, meaning NPC interactions and mini-quests. The world feels a lot more lived-in, a civilization running on embers rather than a long-collapsed ruin.

Difficulty is...wonky. It is customizable to your preference, with enemy HP, Damage, Break/Status resistance, Break/Status recovery and Attack Frequency all being adjustable. Higher difficulty awards more echoes, an optional currency for unlocking alternative outfits and a compendium/gallery. However, one of these is way out of tune with the others - Damage.
For context, I've fully cleared EL twice and gotten all achievements, as well as 100%'d a few other difficult metroidvanias, so I was coming into EM with some experience. I set a custom difficulty of 1.5x everything, which I quickly changed to 2x hp and 1x damage; enemy damage scaling is utterly absurd, maybe even worse than before. At normal damage, late game enemies easily dealt enough to kill me in 3-4 hits, even with the most defensive equipment in the game. Not to mention there are no damage recovery i-frames - getting caught in a lingering AoE is almost always instant death. This is an aspect I wish was not kept the same, though it certainly helps that contact damage no longer exacerbates it.

While most bosses still function identically albeit harder at higher difficulties, certain bosses in the mid-late game are absolutely not meant to be fought at said difficulties: being the most egregious example with higher HP and/or attack speed due to . Certain attacks such as do not have visible telegraphs for their affected area, meaning you have to rely purely on memory for gauging their expected location.

All in all a very enjoyable experience, building off the legacy of the previous game whilst maintaining its own distinct identity. Highly recommended.

They also somehow made bearable. These developers are sorcerers I swear.

An incredibly polished modern metroidvania experience. HIGHLY recomended.

If you have played the first one, this is basically the same, but better in every aspect.

If you haven't — Ender Magnolia looks great, sounds great and plays great. While the unlocked traversal abilities aren't anything novel, they are very well implemented. The map layout is near perfect (with an exception of some light teleportation mazes that I personally find questionable, YMMW).

The thoughtful enemy placement makes it fun to try out different combination of attacks (you can have four of them equipped at the same time, with twenty four total to chose from).

The overall QOL is top notch, too, with some clever design descisions here and there. Here are three examples of that. When you quit, the game reminds you how much time has elapsed since your last save. The map screen has every bit of info you need. There is two diferent types of parry, each of them entirely optional. Of course, there are more.

All in all, ENDER MAGNOLIA is as good as this kind of game currently gets, and is a must play for any metroidvania fans out there.

I enjoyed Ender Lilies, but despite feeling like this game has in some ways improved upon it, a few design choices ended up turning it into a really dull experience for me.

The game fails to let players feel creative or clever, instead locking you to a fairly strict path through repetitive encounters with rewards that are either given to you without any real effort or require backtracking once you get some specific upgrade, never really allowing clever ability use to access even a small reward early or requiring any problem solving or skill to reach anything beyond trial and error.

The map is improved over Ender Lilies! -but I think this is the single thing that most ruined the experience for me. It now clearly identifies what you can do where with what mobility tools, your exact position within an area, and the exact extent you've explored every edge and platform, removing the satisfaction of learning to navigate complex areas and remembering a past area you could employ a new tool in to find a treasure. Instead you'll simply look over your map and go through a checklist of icons on it each time you gain a new tool, making it feel like a chore going around to collect obviously listed rewards rather than a personal accomplishment for finding treasures others might've missed, and removes any need to really take in your surroundings.

The game offers a large selection of skills, but you can only pick 4 at once and only when resting at checkpoints. 2/3rds are situational alternative versions of another ability, which I found weren't usually worth using over the regular more generic and consistent abilities. If the game provided the option to switch between alternate versions of skills on the fly it would've made unlocking them much more satisfying, but instead I used the same 4 skills for the vast majority of the game as they were simply more universally useful than other options, and swapping out even one skill to play with a new one is too much of a setback when you can only equip 4 at once.

The gameplay itself isn't terrible when you get to minor and major bossfights and I enjoyed them well enough in the early to mid game, but exploration was at best tedious and made up the majority of the game time. You follow a checklist of point-a to point-b travel through uninspired level layouts and the occasional trial-and-error-based maze with dull and repetitive enemy encounters with no need for resource management as you endlessly spam the same wide-angle long-ranged abilities to safely eliminate enemies the same way every time and regen HP without limit. There might be pretty looking environments, but you spend most of your time looking at the minimap or scanning walls for hidden passages rather than taking in the really quite visually detailed backdrops.

IF YOU LIKE METROIDVANIAS, GET THIS GAME NOW.

I perfected both Ender Lilies, and Ender Magnolia, and I can say without a doubt that this title is a major upgrade over the first entry in all aspects. Mind, Ender Lilies is still an incredible game, but this one's such a step up. If you have played the first title, you'll be able to appreciate this one more, but let me make one thing clear: You don't need to play the first game. This title can stand on its own.

I encountered ZERO bugs throughout my playthrough. These folks know how to do an early access and polish it really well, something most triple a developers in this day and age can hardly pull off. This team also listened to constructive feedback during early access and actually USED it to improve the game. We love it when devs listen! They're getting feedback even now, and I'm sure they'll make use of it, too.

My favorite part about this game (besides everything) was having to use Steam Discussions to ask players ahead of me where to go during a certain point in the story. The answer was essentially "did you try going right?" Lmao, shout out to my mans on that post! Now like I said there, while there might be some empty space in my brain, I DID play the game for at least a handful of hours straight...!

Anyways, GAME GUD. MUSIC GUD. COMBAT GUD. STORY GUD. CHARACTER GUD. SHMOOVEEMENT GUD. ME LOVE THIS GAEM.

Hopefully another Ender entry in the future! Until then!!

Excellent 8/10
Buyable at full price
ENDER MAGNOLIA: Bloom in the Mist is an excellent dark fantasy metroidvania set in the same world as ENDER LILIES, which featured an melancholic tone and a masterful soundtrack. Like its predecessor, ENDER MAGNOLIA features an equally masterful score and satisfying gameplay which blend together for an immersive experience that is thoroughly enjoyable for fans of the metroidvania ENDER series and newcomers alike, making it a worthwhile buy even at full price.

Playtime may vary based on difficulty and how much backtracking you do to explore fully.

Being set in the same world as ENDER LILIES, the dark fantasy nature of the world remains as captivating, with lush, eye-catching forests to the darker hues of industrial steel laden factories. Each setting is accompanied by a incredible soundtracks which is easily the star of the game, with each track being extremely distinct and immersive, lending itself perfectly to the each area. Be it resting at town or exploring dungeons, the score always finds a way to elevate the atmosphere further.

The story, while set up well does not recapture the magic of its prequel and is arguably the weakest part of the game, that being said, it does not detract from the incredible presentation of the sound and visuals.

ENDER MAGNOLIA features a non-linear map layout with paths gradually unlocking to deeper areas as you progress through the game, by beating bosses or getting ability upgrades. This makes exploration highly enjoyable as you revisit previous areas to progress further or collect the various treasures and collectibles which sometimes involve solving simple puzzles. The game also features a simple yet effective system in tracking your progression, making exploration highly satisfying.

The only one downside is that some larger zones can be daunting and slightly frustrating to complete as they can sometimes feel unnecessarily complicated.

The game offers a plethora of options for ability combinations that offer many different ways to tackle the game, giving experienced players many tools for skill expression, while offering alternatives for those looking for a more simpler approach. The game also comes with difficulty options to fine tune your experience, though I would recommend the hard option for players familiar with the genre/franchise. There are also numerous items to enhance your abilities and play style, ranging from stat sticks to relics that offers benefits to certain play styles.

Bosses comes in many shapes and sizes, some offering more of a challenge than others, but each victory feeling well earned and satisfying. One critique is when playing on hard difficulty, the segment towards the end of the game, the damage done feels slightly over tuned. This feels especially true for the TLB of the game.


While you can 100% the game for a second ending, there is not much ENDER MAGNOLIA offers for post-game or replay options. Features like new game plus or boss rush is not implemented but there is a possibility that it will be added in a future update, as they did with ENDER LILIES. There is however a custom difficulty for challenge runs (instant death etc.)

While doesn’t fully replicate the narrative magic of its predecessor, it excels and imporves in nearly every other aspect. A equally superb soundtrack, atmospheric environments, and more flexible combat systems come together to deliver a unique experience. If you enjoyed ENDER LILIES it is easily a must buy, and for those looking to step into the genre, this is an easy recommendation. It is a solid 8/10, it’s well worth the full $25

Все прошел и вполне получил удовольствие. Ярких впечатлений по сравнения с первой частью я хапнул немного меньше, но тут не знаю что было фактором, возможно я сам уже другой, наиграный, объетый и какие-то вещи ощущались предсказуемыми знакомыми, без сильной интриги, однако от процесса все равно было очень даже интересно.
Не смотря на то, что у игры много заимствования от своих предшественников, некая самобытность у этой серии все же ощущается. При чем я совсем не любитель меланхолично драматичных сюжетов, такой же музыки и ситуаций когда в мрачном мире из чудовищ и страданий всё разруливают дети. Тем не менее, какое-то впечатление от данного игрового мира после прохождения остается.
По сложности это как раз игры для приятного расслабона по вечерам. Секреты легко все находятся самостоятельно.
Удобная фишка с закрашиванием на карте локаций в которых все найдено. Сразу исключает слепые блуждания по всему миру игры.
Много всяких улучшений, способностей, возможностей которые здорово упрощают жизнь и просто дают возможность побаловаться разными вариациям боев и комбинациями свойств.
Быстро прокачивающийся уровень персонажа, даже не нужно отдельно где-то сильно фармить, он растет прямо по ходу сюжетного пути.
Боссов не мало, но и они не шибко буйные, за несколько попыток все их паттерны хорошо запоминаются.
Даже ачивки очень доступные, почти все получаешь просто проходя игру.
В моем личном топе
Ender Lilies занимает 34 место
Eder Magnolia 40 место
Большинству любителям метроидваний я бы рекомендовал эти две игры попробовать. Мне кажется они позволяют вкусить данный тег без особых заморок. :)

Fantastic game with a lot of potential. The original Ender Lilies is one of my favorite games, but this game has the opportunity to outshine it by a long shot. It has better visuals, a more developed story, more complete gameplay, a more real world, and overall just a better experience.

I will say, though, that this early access version is very overpriced for what you get. The entire thing is completable in less than an hour and there really isn't much to do. Unless you are a big fan of the first game like I am, just wait until it is released.

There are a few things that worry me also. It's very easy. They say they will have difficulty options in the full release, which is good to hear, but a lot of the enemies have fairly predictable attack patterns which might not be fixable with a simple stat increase. There also aren't many secrets, each of the areas can be completed on the first visit with no need for backtracking. Maybe that is a plus for some people, but a big part of what makes metroidvanias rewarding is finally getting that one item you were missing to open up a bunch of secrets you weren't able to access before. I am really hoping that is changed before the final release.

Overall while I am not so keen on this early access version, it makes me very excited for the eventual final product.
