Итак, гештальт закрыт и пришло время подводить итоги. С точки зрения Ender Lilies игра потеряла атмосферу безнадежности и одиночества, что резко сказалось на атмосфере игры, ее не ощущаешь и это ОГРОМНЫЙ МИНУС второй части, без нее игра ощущается "очередной" метроидванией.
По плюсам: Карта стала более приятной для "чтения", появились "квестовые персонажи" и в принципе город ощущается городом за счет жителей (что по сути и "убило" атмосферу первой части). Бектрек стал еще более простым, практически везде в минутной доступности есть точка сохранения с возможностью быстрого перемещения. Появилась система настройки уровня сложности, новым игрокам такое зайдет, да и тем кто хочет либо облегчить себе игру, или сделать из нее челендж. Музыка как и в первой части - прекрасна, особенно из локации Central Stratum - Steel District, можно слушать часами :) Хотя, имхо, музыка из финальной битвы по сценарию Б тоже качает, но тут часами сложно слушать ибо босс файт...
Боевка по ощущениям стала более плавной нежели в первой части, где очень часто сталкиваешься с тем что после атаки, вроде как атака закончилась, а двигаться еще не можешь...
Мест "испытаний" по сути не стало. Может оно и к лучшему, сидеть как на рояле из заранее заготовленных способностей и по кнопкам вовремя бить, чтобы забраться на какую-то башню, потому что обычными мувами туда не попасть :/

Короче как метроидвания игра хороша, как продолжение первой части по атмосфере чувств особо не вызывает, все таки в первой части сбор воспоминаний тех кого уже нет сильнее давит эмоционально, нежели "настройка" гомункулов.

Ender Magnolia is a pretty strong follow-up to its predecessor, Ender Lilies. A great many things were improved and streamlined, which made the experience smoother compared to the previous entry. The adjustable difficulty also lets you tune your experience to your liking. There are almost no bugs or glitches despite the v1.0 release. As a fan of metroidvanias, I consider this an exceptional title. Ender Magnolia might not end up being the GOTY 2025 for me, but it's currently on the list for sure. Overall score: 9/10.

Positives

+ Gorgeous graphics and art style, just like the previous title. The backgrounds alone are a sight to see.
+ The soundtrack compliments the atmosphere really well, and both combine into a very immersive experience. The previous title also had the same composer, and they did a stellar job in that game too.
+ The difficulty is highly customizable thanks to the difficulty sliders. You can make the game unforgivingly difficult if you prefer, or a bit easier if you just want to relax.
+ Movement and combat both feel weighty, which makes them satisfying. Also, there is no contact damage apart from a few select enemies. Refreshing to see it removed, honestly.
+ You get fast travel unlocked pretty early on, and you can fast travel to all discovered checkpoints from anywhere without any restrictions.
+ Points of interests and obstacles get marked on your map, and the tooltip has the required ability if you hover over them. This makes backtracking manageable and somewhat fun, because you don't have to memorize everything or roam around endlessly to find the paths you didn't take yet. Map design is also pretty cohesive.
+ The game is very polished. There are no obvious bugs or glitches.
+ Parrying is not a requirement, but it's very responsive and works really well if you want to use it.
+ The story and worldbuilding are both pretty good.



+/- There are two endings, and you can't miss them because achieveing the second one requires you to wear a certain Relic while fighting the final boss.
+/- There is no penalty for dying apart from having to walk/teleport back to where you were. I find that rather bland, but it sure as hell beats having to run after your dropped stuff.
+/- You don't really "have to" to play the previous title to understand the story in this game. There are just some references and common terminology.
+/- You initiate a dialogue with an NPC if you are carrying the quest item they are interested in. That makes it extremely convenient if you have an idea about where to take a specific item without having to sift through NPCs by talking to them.
+/- You have to use specific attacks or strategies to get a certain currency, but that makes it "limited" in a positive way. You have to play a bit differently to get more of it, and that spices things up.

+/- Enemies only respawn when you rest. They don't respawn when you change zones.
+/- Very grindy if you want to max out your Relic capacity and upgrade all Relics, but there are no achievements related to either of those things. You can just upgrade what you use and call it a day.
+/- Parkour is somewhat bland, but the abilities you get are flashy and feel good to use. Parkour will be easy for you if you played at least a few other metroidvanias before.
+/- Future planned content includes NG+, Boss Rush mode and Boss Rematch. I'm really looking forward to all of those.
+/- Some enemies and bosses share certain moves, which makes it easier to deal with because the timings are the same. Of course, that doesn't mean bosses are unoriginal or anything.



- Some sound effects feel "missing" or are straight up missing. Like how the Tuning a Homunculus has a shiny expanding effect, but it's dead silent. Some enemies have attacks that have no sound effects (ex: Homunculus enemies who wield a shotgun and a sword). The previous game suffered from this to some extent, as well.
- No voice acting whatsoever. Even non-verbal vocalizations would have sufficed to indicate the characters are talking, and it would have costed almost nothing to add that in. Even a few grunts, sighs and chuckles would have made a huge difference while interacting with the NPCs.
- The placeable map markers are low resolution for some reason. A minor detail, but I found it distracting.
- You don't get any iframes when you get hit, which means some enemies can burst you down in an instant if you are too close and if you cranked up the enemy damage multiplier.
- Two bosses have long "run back to it after you fail" segments, but it's not as bad as it sounds.



and





RTX 3060 Ti (no overclock)
Ryzen 7 5800X (at 4.4 GHz)
32 GB DDR4 RAM (at 3200 MHz)
A 1080p 144 Hz 1 ms Gaming Monitor
The game was on an NVME SSD

The game runs flawlessly at 144 FPS without any drops or stutters with everything maxed out. Nothing of note when it comes to performance otherwise.

I had to set my Left Stick Deadzone Setting to 60% in the game's own settings, because the default 25% causes the main character to turn the other way for a split second due to stick bounce. Worth noting, because I'm sure some others will have this issue eventually. This is how you solve it.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My difficulty settings for reference:

Maximum HP: 1.0
Attack Strength: 1.6
Break and Status Effect Resistance: 1.7
Break and Status Effect Recovery Speed: 2
Enemy Attack Frequency: 2

Disable Enemy Attack Tells: On

With these, things don't feel too tanky (unless they can heal) but they can really mess you up if you get hit. Enemy attack tells are red flashing right before an enemy attacks, but all attacks already have enough effects to signify their timing and range, so you'll be perfectly fine if you disable that. Just makes you pay attention to their animations instead of watching out for the flashing.

If I could choose a 'neutral' option I would, but I can't, so I'll err on the side of rating this game positively. In some ways I think that this game is better than Ender Lilies, and in some ways I think it is worse.

I'll start by saying the soundtrack, graphics, and enemy design/variety are great! Mili kills it with their songs and the area themes generally slap. Additionally, exploration is a LOT of fun, and the map UI makes it very easy to find out where you need to go to hunt down items. Hollow Knight's badge system returns and, hey, it's a good system.

I do have some complaints. I think compared to Ender Lilies the bosses are somewhat forgettable, and the lack of unique boss themes for many of them makes them even less of a standout -- a shame, since there are a LOT more boss fights in this game than in Ender Lilies. I have some complaints with hitboxes not lining up with visual effects, and there are certain instances where you can be hit by the same attack several times in rapid succession, killing you instantly. The vibe of this game is very different than Ender Lilies, and in a way I don't really like, and I have some complaints about the story itself, but that would get into spoiler territory and here isn't the place for it.

Overall, I think Ender Magnolia is an okay leaning positive metroidvania on its own, my comparison to Ender Lilies is what drags it down for me. The story might resonate with you and you might like it, but it didn't with me. You might like the combat, but I really didn't. But? But. Traversing the map is great. It's fun.

Coming to this fresh from Ender Lilies was really something, oh boy - this really works better as a sequel. So, if you haven't already, I'd play EL first if you're gonna play this.

First off, the combat is so much more fluid and I enjoy it a lot more. Actually being able to move is very nice, though there's a lack of weapon variety in my opinion. I basically used 5 of the weapon choices for most of the game, out of like 24. Also, whereas in EL you have 2 sets of 3 Spirits, here you get 1 set of 4 Homunculi. This is, as a keyboard player, a downgrade. I would use a greater variety if i had more options at any given free moment.

The map is wayyyyy upgraded from EL. 10/10 no notes.

The shop system is. Well. I'm fine with it personally, but I would much prefer it being fully exploration based. I really dislike the relic upgrading, the currency for it is something you find in much lower amounts and you don't get it from every kill, so it's painful to find.

Ohhhhhh boy, the difficulty. Remember how in Ender Lilies, you could take 3 hits before dying? Well here (on default settings), it only takes around two from most bosses! The difficulty settings are much appreciated. Shame on the devs for putting a ground spike attack on an early boss though.

Mili music. 11/10 no notes.

My initial thoughts on the storytelling were that it was a downgrade from EL, but frankly, it's moreso just a different style. While EL was very much leaning on it's atmosphere, Magnolia likes to use bite-sized interactions fairly often, and there's actual people. So don't expect the same, but it's still really good.

Overall, I would really recommend it if you've played Ender Lilies! Maybe even if you haven't, though I can't really speak from that perspective.

100% completed the game in 17 hours on the "hard" difficulty preset.

In comparison to Ender Lilies, I think the gameplay has improved drastically.

- Combat / movement is more fluid, and the 4 spirits available at all times is much more enjoyable to use in combat compared to the 2 "loadouts" of the previous game.
- The map has been greatly improved, with actual details instead of simple squares, and obstacles / items you haven't picked up yet are marked if you need to come back later.


Unfortunately, while I think the gameplay has drastically improved compared to Ender Lilies, I believe the exact opposite for almost everything else, including the story, atmosphere, music, etc. Maybe it's my nostalgia for the first game, but Ender Magnolia doesn't carry the same "feeling" that made me fall in love with Ender Lilies.

- The presence of other living NPCs doesn't add much to the game, and I feel like they could have been removed to stay in line with the idea that you're the only "living person" left in the world.
- The art is still gorgeous, and the music is still fantastic, but I feel like they don't work together to create the incredible atmosphere / world that was present in Ender Lilies.
- The level traversal feels very disjointed, with an example being leaving a magic academy and ending up in a machine factory.
- The story is incredibly similar to the first game, but the presentation in this game feels much worse. There's very little agency right up until the ending, where the main goal is suddenly revealed and then handled almost immediately.
- By adding more characters to the story, each and every single one of them is left under-cooked.


TLDR:
I'd still recommend the game for those who enjoy Metroidvanias or those who are looking for more Ender Lilies.
The gameplay is great, and definitely left me feeling satisfied.

However, Ender Magnolia doesn't hold a candle to the enthralling world of Ender Lilies.
In Ender Lilies, I fondly remember traversing somber, sorrowful, and beautiful environments as the only survivor of a blighted kingdom.
In Ender Magnolia, I remember travelling through a theme park of varying locations to fight bosses only to be abruptly shown the ending credits.

This just feels like a direct upgrade to me from Ender Lilies, a game I very much enjoyed. the movement system is an absolute joy. Simply incredible.

Binary Haze managed to pick all the good points of Ender Lilies and enhance it even further in Ender Magnolia. Boss fights are more dynamic, exploration is way more fun now, due to how secrets now force the player to get creative and use attack moves to increase jump height and distance, instead of solemnly focusing on traversing skills, and the map now has proper topography.

Plus this game is a sight for sore eyes. The maps and character models are very beautifully made, and together with the amazing soundtrack that Mili composed for the game, I was able to explore all the maps entirely without getting tired or bored.

Anyway, GotY for me, and this year barely started!

Mostly-great. The budget visibly ran out and there's a drastic drop in quality in the endgame, and there's more than a few times where I picked up important documents pertaining to my companions and they just. Didn't react? The story is significantly weaker than the first game's, but that's also kind of the point. Actual spoiler:
However, the fact that Society Still Exists in this entry means that there's people to talk to in addition to your companions. I can't really be certain whether it's intentional in a Ye Olde English way or a translation quirk, but the dialogue is a bit stiff and it kind of lessened the experience for me.

Music is (still) good, with more instruments being brought in to reflect the nation's scientific progress, and the bosses have both higher highs and lower lows compared to the first game. I'm personally fond of the one that's been skill-checking a large portion of the playerbase (she could honestly do with a slight nerf tho).

Overall this is objectively better than Ender Lilies from a gameplay perspective, but I still like Ender Lilies more for story reasons.

This is incredible. The first game courted a few criticism on things like: the stupid faceplant animation from the main character in the early game, the brain dead map system, and some of the worst anti-exploration end game area in this genre. Ender Magnolia not only "fixed" all of them, but actually improved upon the formula to lodge solidly in my S-tier Metroidvania collection.

THE GREATS

Ender Magnolia has much, much better ability design compared to the first game. You get more distinct "spirits" that each has a bunch of customization options with very, very little overlap. You can tell the devs put a lot of heart and soul into this aspect of the game, and paid attention to make every combat ability truly unique.

The map has also been drastically improved. Each room turns a different color once you've collected everything in it, and the visuals of the map correctly resembles the topology of the room in actual play. This is something that every other games should emulate.

Finally, the devs leaned hard into the abilities giving you additional traversal capabilities. You can actually cover a ridiculous amount of horizontal air distance just by combining a few abilities, and I can't wait to see how the speedrunner community totally abuse all these mechanics to sequence break. This is one of the few games that makes me feel like a speedrunner myself.

THE MEDIOCRE

The early to mid game bosses are... way too easy. Not that they're designed badly, but more like the game itself is extremely forgiving. Your dash has an incredible amount of iframes, and by the mid-game you will get ways to cheese enemies, a parry that can be spammed to deal with bullet hell situations, and an ability that has even more forgiving parry timing with crazy repose that trivializes a lot of encounters. All in all, combat is satisfying, but more on the forgiving side of things.

THE BAD

Unfortunately, the level design continues the trend from the first game, as being largely uninspired. The biomes are beautifully drawn and distinct, but those looking for interesting and innovative puzzles and platforming challenges will need to look elsewhere - this game is pretty lax on those two fronts. Additionally, with all the movement tech you get, it can be difficult to design any kind of challenging platforming segments at all. If you want a path of pain kinda thing, well, you're not going to find it in this game.

SUMMARY

All in all, this is an AMAZING game. I can't recommend this hard enough for all those who enjoys a good metroidvania.

If you liked Ender Lilies you'll likely enjoy the follow up, even what's available so far / while it's in Early Access. Much will feel very familiar early on, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. And what is new in the first few areas/hours is promising - including new depth to the upgrades, equipment, and skills. There's a lot of promise / potential here, and an enjoyable framework to build off - but is very short compared to the first game / others in the genre currently. To be fair this also feels much more like a demo than an evolving / updating near-final Early Access version; so hopefully it's barely scratching the surface.
The story seems intriguing so far and like it'll be an interesting continuation of the world / lore from the first game, especially with references to priestesses and Blight already sneaking into the first few hours. The people of this world don't seem to have learned anything from the downfall of Lands End, and like we're in for another appropriately bleak adventure through a collapsing world - this time surrounded by more magic and steampunk(ish) visuals and vibes, instead of the more medieval / gothic settings, enemies, etc. I dig it so far, and look forward to seeing how this all ties together in the world and story.

In the end, I'd recommend Ender Magnolia to anyone who liked the original, though others just looking for a new metroidvania may want to play the first one and/or wait for this one's full release. It's still a good time and the price point is likely to rise on full release - so it's worth picking up now too, especially if you expect to play the final release eventually.

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
IMPORTANTE: ESTO ES UNA REVIEW DE LA VERSIÓN EARLY ACCESS. EN CUANTO EL JUEGO HAYA SALIDO DE ESTE ESTADO SE HARÁN CAMBIOS CORRESPONDIENTES AL PRODUCTO FINAL.

¡Arranquemos con una pequeña introducción a este juego!

En los primeros minutos, tenemos una breve cinemática en la que hay una charla que habla sobre los Homúnculos, seres artificiales que funcionan mediante magia a los cuales dicen que no son muy distintos de nosotros, pero que estos seres ya atacaron a varias personas. Unos segundos luego, vemos que alguien nos habla (sin saber su nombre) y dice habernos enseñado todo lo necesario para nuestro viaje y que confiemos en nuestros compañeros.
Asi da lugar a nuestra protagonista, Lilac, una taumaturga (también conocida bajo el nombre de "Afinadora") que despierta entre escombros, sin entender en donde está, ni como está viva, pero sin poder recordar gracias a quien. Unos pasos más nos encontraremos con un homúnculo, el cual nos ofrece su poder a cambio de salvarle la vida, comenzando así nuestra aventura.

Dicho esto, comencemos!

Género: Juego de Rol de Acción (ARPG - Action Role Playing Game)

Gameplay: Muy similar (por no decir igual) a Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights, un juego de acción con velocidad normal y con ataques que podemos combinar. De momento, limitado y sin más de 5 opciones, pero con variantes para customizar cada ataque y formar nuestro gameplay a gusto. Los monstruos cuentan con barras de cansancio las cuales podemos bajar y dejarlos en un estado breve de aturdimiento, aprovechando así ventanas para hacer daño. Tenemos un movimiento para rodar (dashear/impulsarse) el cual usamos para evadir sin problemas
Cómodo pasaje entre distintos check points para terminar de explorar zonas. Aún se mantiene el indicador del mapa cambiando de color cuando una zona está completamente explorada, ahorrandonos tiempo para seguir avanzando. Los controles son bastante cómodos y se siente fluido, sin ser espectacular ni mucho menos mediocre. Contamos con algunos NPCs con un poco de díalogo e items que podemos ir encontrando a lo largo del viaje que nos cuentan el lore del mundo (al igual que también pueden encontrarlo en la descripción de los items)
Tenemos equipamiento el cual podemos ir cambiando y comprando en el mercado.
Contamos con 4 jefes principales y zonas para cada uno. Con bichos propios para cada lugar. Se aprecia la variación.

Voces: No hay

Dificultad: Por el momento, no se puede seleccionar una dificultad, pero, por lo que se puede ver en los puntos de checkpoint se podrá cambiar. Lo encontré facil, no es realmente un juego complicado, pero esto siempre cambia en cada persona. Podés hacer bastante daño sin mucho problema, pero te puede costar caro en algunos momentos.

Duración: Imagino que si no explorás absolutamente nada, durará 2 horas y monedas (tal vez un poco menos). Yo exploré al 100% el mapa disponible y me tomó 4 horas. Cuando quieran pasar por ciertos lugares, les va a saltar un cartel que diga "Esta zona aún no está disponible para la versión actual del juego)

Música: Mantiene la calidad de Ender Lilies. Por el momento, me quedo con más canciones de Ender Magnolia que Lilies

Visuales: Un lindo trabajo artístico, como su anterior juego!

Historia: Por el momento, va normal, ni lo uno ni lo otro. Hay que tener paciencia ya que es una Early Access y aún no hemos visto nada. Por ahora, no es realmente necesario haber jugado Ender Lilies para comprender lo que está ocurriendo, pero, en el caso haberlo jugado, podrán encontrar ciertas cosas que sabrán que vinen de ahí.

Algo que me gustó mucho: La música

Algo que no me gustó tanto: -

Que esperar del juego completo: Ender Lilies nos ofreció 3 finales, uno que te cruzás de forma obligatoria, otro por explorar de forma casi completa, y otro por explorar todo, me intriga saber si repetirán el mismo formato. Hay que tener en cuenta que apenas son 2 a 4 horas de juego y no conocemos casi nada. El feedback siempre es importante y eso puede acelerar el tiempo para que esté en su estado completo.

Si leiste esta reseña, te agradezco por tomarte el tiempo de hacerlo y ojalá le des una chance a este juego!

Y como es de costumbre, ¡dejo acá uno de los soundtracks que más me gustaron! Realmente considero preciosa esta canción, con ese aire de misterio y soledad, Muy pero MUY del palo de estos Ender Juegos (Si, acabo de inventar el termino)

Exitos a todos!

I just finished playing this game, and I’m very impressed. I’ve been a fan of Ender Lilies for a while now, so there was no way I was going to miss out on the sequel. One thing I really appreciate about this game is that I can now adjust the difficulty settings separately, like Monster HP, Attack, Stagger, etc., and gain more rewards based on the difficulty level I configure. Honestly, I think that’s such a great feature. I’m the type of player who loves a good challenge—high risk, high reward—but I know not everyone’s into super hard games like I am.

Some people just want to chill, enjoy the story, soak in the atmosphere, and piece together the puzzles and lore, which is also a big part of what makes this game so great. With this system, I was able to fully enjoy both the gameplay and the story at my own pace.

Oh, and I have to mention—the map system in this game is so much easier to use!

TL;DR If you've played Ender Lilies (EL), the prequel game, you will love Ender Magnolia (EM).
Overall Score: 5/5

The combat system is refreshingly different: a more limited ability roster allows each to shine in its own way, none of them are limited use between benches, meaning enemy density is generally higher in every area. Lilac controls very well (outside of sometimes being a little too grabby for ledges and walls). Contact damage is now only a concern for enemies actively trying to body-slam you (beware that gap-closing enemies seem to be able to cover infinite distance), which is conducive to the heavy combat focus.

I have to dedicate an entire little section to gush over the in-game map. Binary Haze Interactive clearly listened to the uproar of the map in EL and took it to heart, as the map in EM is absolutely fantastic. They've definitely taken advantage of this fact, too, to make the area designs their own variants of convoluted, so be ready to trek around for a while.

The game is relatively well balanced on Normal difficulty (which is what I stayed on for the duration of my first playthrough). The addition of multiple difficulty sliders allows some customization that some may find helpful, as opposed to EL's set difficulty. As usual, some bosses are very difficult at their point in progression, and some are a welcome breath of fresh air. The difficulty curve for the areas feels much fairer than in EL, in which the final two areas were a bit of a headache to get through (IYKYK).

If you're thinking about it, don't sleep on this game. Very fun and rewarding experience. And if you've played Ender Lilies (why are you still reading, and not playing?), you will love the additional lore and mysteries handed to you.

This line from another review pretty much sums up my experience: "one step forward, two steps back."

On the surface, the visuals and gameplay are as good as the last game, the fighting system is much smoother here, and you get to unlock more skills/ moves in the early half of the game.

But for the backbones, the soul and the reason why I love this series (or at least the first game), the music and story, rather than getting better, they're on the same level as Ender Lilies at best, and in a way borderline worse. While the scores do what they're here for, only 1 to 2 of them are memorable, instead of at least one third of the last game's entire OSTs. Not to mention, the ending song is a HUGE letdown here. I could actually feel the bittersweet flowing thru me as I sat there listening to Bulbel by Mili and staring at the credits, but in this game,

Now lets talk about the story. I'm not against the devs trying this new approach of having interactive NPC rather than pure texts. But the problem is, none of the NPCs are memorable; they all feel so superficial that I can't see them as anything but plot devices. And then the endings, in the last game, there are endings, with 1 being the true ending, and u unlock each progressively and in different area. In this game, there's only , and , the only difference is a few more lines and 1 more phrase for the boss, I don't even know if the music changed in the last phrase just like Lilies did.

So yea, I'm pretty disappointed with this sequel. But I'm still gonna buy the next game if there's one, hopefully the devs can see how they screwed up here and make up for it in the next entry.

Genereally liked the game, but over all I enjoyed Ender Lilies more.

The combat in this game deffinitley feels better and more smooth than lilies, but I feel like the exploration of the world felt significantly more interesting in the first game.

The more I play games that try to fit a more complicated story into a metroidvania, the more I feel like it's a futile effort that just hurts overall experiance. Super metroid -> Dread, Rabi Ribi -> Tevi, Ender Lilies -> Magnolia. All of those games hurt because to tell a structured story they can't let you experiance them out of relevant order.

In the first game, the map felt very interconnected with most zones having multiple enterances/exits to other zones you could at least partially explore based on your unlocks, while here everything feels very guided. At few moments the game lets you choose between which of the 2 paths you want to finish first, but at the end, there isn't really any moment where you feel like you are free to explore, a singular path is just laid down in front of you, at best the path splits into two farily obvious paths that quickly connect back onto eachother. New abilities rarely unlocking new paths in old areas, only bonus collectables, as the path to the next zone is usually just located behind the boss room of the previous.

Also, there is a complete lack of endgame movement puzzles like the Bottom of the Well chasm and climbing the tower next to Tower Alcove from the previous game.


The only comparable thing i can think about is the chasm in the land of origin where you need to jump under couple of stalactites in a row.

TLDR, Compared to the first game, the combat is better, but the world exploration is worse. If there is a 3rd game I wish it returned to the storytelling structre of the first, while keeping the more responsive combat of the second (but bring back the faceplant dodge 1st game had in early game)

If you enjoyed the first game
Then yes I highly recommend this game. This does what the first game does but better in every way. From overall combat, to map design, to exploration, to music, to atmosphere, everything. You also get movement abilities early and the maps really open up.


Overall thoughts
-Straight up a good game, it's worth the price and even better with sales. The movement of the game is tight and feels good to move around. That includes tons of movement tech to get to areas and collecting items earlier than intended rewarding the player. You get access to most movement tools early and the maps really get a chance to shine early on and to the end the of the game.

-Combat and gameplay is fun too. You get access to variations of tools that let's you customize your approach to enemies and boss depending on your preferred play style. Some options are stronger than others but everything is usable. With the additions of more unique relics you can even make builds for survivability, status ailments, breaking enemies faster, or just tanking by healing as you deal damage.

-Music, while tastes are subjective, is good. Capturing the melancholy of the environments. Or the more lively parts of the towns of the game.

-Story is interesting, can't much without spoiling but it's good.


-Nothing really stands out as awful just some minor annoyance or observations which in all honesty, really is just splitting hairs.
-Enemies feel they do too much damage while sometimes it feels like they take too little. You can change how much damage you take and how much health they have in the difficulty setting so that's kinda negligible
-Some runs back to later bosses can suck
-Often times I see myself swapping relics and abilities for bosses and exploration and would like to see a loadout system just to make swapping things out easier.


- Great maps that rewards exploration and advanced movement
-Art and Music are beautiful
-Combat and gameplay allow for different approaches to encounters and exploration
-Story is good
-Bosses and enemies hit too hard and are tanky but you change adjust this in the settings
- It getting annoying swapping out abilites and relics just for bosses, would suggest loadouts to make it easier

If you enjoyed Ender Lilies at all, play this game!! If you have never even heard of Ender Lilies, you should still play this game!! If you are a fan of metroidvanias at all, play this game already!! It is an upgrade to EL almost every way, while i love EL to death the main issues were that the boss quality was inconsistent (I'd only say like 3~4 of the bosses were A-S tier), and the level design was good but not great, and the balance of the spirits were really off. The story, lore, setting and primary gameplay was stellar but there was room for improvement, and Ender Magnolia improved it in every way! The bosses are all really good (Luiseach's healing homunculi is kinda bs but besides that i have no complaints), the level design was SUPERB, like genuinely i never felt lost and only had to look up 2 things to get 100% of achievements, the map is super intuitive and it feels amazing to discover secrets, all of the homunculi are fun to use and have their niches (as well as a lot of characterizations, talking to them at benches was one of my favorite parts of the game!), the equipment (especially scarabs) and relic system added so much variety to builds (though, my one complaint would be i wish you couldnt just buy 30 relic slots, but its more of a nitpick) and the scrap system is a genius way to encourage variety in your combat! The music, story, lore and setting were just as good if not better than the first game (though i personally prefer EL), and the final boss was WAY better than EL's, its not as cinematic but its a genuinely amazing fight. There's honestly so much more i could endlessly praise about this game, but for now i will just say: It was genuinely such an amazing experience to play, and i cant wait for the boss rush and ng+ updates! 10/10

This game is a one step forward, two steps back.

Its a step forward in terms of production values, better concept and overall much more interesting and memorable setting, and two steps back in terms of everything else, aka the actual game.

This game is not the actual metroidvania and is extremely linear, with 90% of the game (with the exception of maybe the last 10% near the end) being the literal straight line. You can't sequence break it, do anything of the ordinary or find any interesting upgrades outside of the pre-designed path. The game does not even try to hide it. The good side is that you can't get lost like in many other vanias, the bad side that it is technically the linear platformer. This, with much weaker and less creatively designed bosses, and the game tendency of enjoying wasting your time make it a rather bland experience.

This is why, even technically 100%-ing the game and unlocking both endings, and overall enjoying the journey, I can't really recommend this game and feel like it was fundamentally a very weak game experience and overall a waste of time.

Wow. I only just started this game and the atmosphere is amazing - the art is somehow more beautiful than the first game, the areas are well-created and linked together in interesting ways, there is adjustable difficulty that gives you more or less exp, and the game gives you Dash + Double jump in the first 20 minutes of playing - no sluggish, boring movement for the first hour like many of this genre!

I waiting until this game was out of early access and I'm so glad I did. I was just playing another metroidvania before (Record of Lodoss War for anyone interested) and dropped it because nothing stood out to me (asides from the element switching which felt more like a hassle than anything) unlike this game, which has everything from art to music to environment going for it.

I mistakenly waited until the game was out of EA before buying it and ate the +$10 price hike, but it was well worth it for what might be my GoTY so far. If you haven't already played Ender Lilies, do yourself a favor and take a look at one of the best Metroidvanias I've played sitting at the top of my list among the likes of Hollow Knight and even above Ori and the Blind Forest/Will of the Wisps, then come back and play this one next.

Post-Ending Edit: WOW again. What a great game - similar to the first one it does't waste your time with backtracking by indicating which rooms have been explored completely. I was surprised and impressed at the sheer amount of different upgrades this game ended up handing over, as well as the build variety for your various summons. Took me a little under 20 hours to 100% - true final boss was a fairly big difficulty spike, but it felt satisfying to beat.

An ending to a blighted sorrows, and the blooming of a cleansed world~
The culmination of the struggles fought for a kingdom once ruined. Ender Magnolia closes the tales of the blighted land in a more heartwarming, bright finale for the series~
Awoken alone in an abandoned site, and the encounter with a solemn homunculi kickstart the journey of Lilac & Nola throughout the Land of fume~
The search for each other's memories brought upon journey of danger and perils, amidst a world grasping for life, one truth and revelation after another~
Apart from the previous game Ender Lilies, the world is torn down and sick, but still is more beautiful than the past. The environment is worth gazing to appreciate the bright colors harmonizing with the settings of the world, and the music is more abundant and livelier in this series. More vocals to enjoy in your journey~
You can almost feel the emotion emanating from the somber melody and chorus singing~

Gameplay
The gameplay is a direct successor of it's previous iteration, but is now more polished, fluid and easy to maneuver. The map feels somewhat similar in size, but the interconnecting rooms are still abundant compared to previous game. Like it's compacted, so there's plenty to explore around~
It maintain the same souls-like difficulty, with no "Game over". Just simply wake up, and repeat as much as you see fit. Exploration progress is also lenient, in the sense of any discovered or salvaged item is kept, even if you're defeated before your next respite~
And if I remember correctly, the previous game only allow fast-traveling when you're resting. In this game, you're allowed to fast travel at any time, moment, situation as you'd like! Just by accessing the map~
And it follows the same map update system, where the game will tell you if you've 100% the exploration of specific maps, by color coding it~


Instead of spirits, you'll encounter "Homunculi" that will join you on your journey~
Ender Magnolia offers more categorized attack type, lesser than the previous game, but more refined, easy to manage & choose~
They've also removed usage limit, in favor of cooldown for certain Homunculi skills. So if you're a returning player, combat will feel more loose, and not as punishing if you missed your hits~
Also, instead of 3, you now have access to 4 companion to help you on your journey~
And compared to "Ender Lilies", you can actually max out every single Homunculi that joins your party! So feel free to upgrade any that you see fit, as it become available~


The world is now more inhabited, with survivors and fellow homunculi NPC. There's more dialogue and talking that can be done compared to previous games. It's worth it to see what the people have to say about the surrounding and situation, as some even changes a bit after certain progression in the game~
As the result of it, there's more human touch and influence upon the world. It's a mix of mechanical & nature, of building and ruins. Each and every one is more prettier than the last~
The colors and artworks is also more brighter in contrast to the grim setting of "Ender Lilies"~
I've actually spammed Steam Screenshot multiple time as a result of it, everything is so captivating to look at, whilst listening to the ost of each individual area~

The game has a new "Extra" menu you can access while playing. Which gives you a special currency in-game that allows you to purchase new outfit option, unlock enemy bestiary/animation, and even concept art of the game!
Particularly the enemy bestiary, you can see each individual animation available to the enemy, which can prove useful for learning attack timing, if you need a more safer method of studying it~

A more than worthy sequel.

Quick updated thoughts after 100% Normal.

+ The best map in a metroidvania.
Clean with everything in the UI labelled and available without extra steps to access. Move around and zoom in/out with sticks instead of mapping those functions to buttons needlessly. Custom map markers that can all be removed at once with a button hold though with how well this map is made you don't ever need any map markers, I never used any and had clarity of layout and what was in each area.

Besides fog where you have not been and grey in areas with something still to be done there's larger sections around pieces of the map that gives another layer of clarity to what sections of certain parts of the map that have not been fully explored. Every time you unlock another ability backtracking have never been this smooth, new sections to unlock for currency, path to a new area etc. and they are almost always convenient thanks to how the world is designed, you get a large scope but the feel of a much smaller map. Because the map is so well done it's combined with the world design to make exploration and backtracking feel intuitive like it's never been.

+ Soundtrack is excellent.
It's a dark and dire world that seems to almost be out of life yet there's a yearning in the haunting melodies that creates a sensation of hope and beauty in other areas portraying a dark and depraved history or the eerie to almost invasive mechanical noises of the Biological Research Facility to the regal sounding Sorcerer's Academy. Every area has music that speaks volumes before you learn about it from the story or is simply a great piece.

+ Movement and combat feels tight.
You have plenty of options with eight summons that each have three abilities of which you can pick four at a time to use. From standard weapon attacks to a dashing punch, bouncing saw blades, homing projectiles that fires automatically etc. Four attuner arts at a time as well that serve as an ultimate attack once you've charged them from attacking enemies. Using your jumps, dashes, abilities, arts, relics, equipment and if you choose two different parries, one from an ability with three versions and one that has many different versions from equipment it gives you a lot of options.

+ A ton of air mobility.
Double-jump and air-dash are given early which combined with air attacks that have a short hover per attack and you get some extreme air mobility since you can renew attacks between each air action so [jump> combo> dash> combo> jump> combo> dash> combo] and there's other abilities and actions that will give you more options like Garm's Ascent which is a charged super-jump and Lunar Manifestation which is a dashing-slash that can be aimed horizontally upwards and more.

+ No contact damage.

+ There's much detail in the layered backgrounds and use of colours and effects that make the stages come to life through a variety of areas.

+ Dialogue and the story is paced to give enough context while quickly letting you keep exploring.

+ It tells you how long ago you saved when you quit.

+ Fast travel from anywhere and it's quick.

- There's slight stutter.
- Damage output felt lacking for bosses, while you die very quickly.
- There's one really bad run back.

TL;DR: Good game, but a far cry from Ender Lilies. Won't be GOTY or anything. Worth the play, but try to get it on a sale or something.

Gameplay-wise, you'll def get your metroidvania fix out of it.
The combat is fluid and quite entertaining but, not very sophisticated (just mash X and dodge right) I still much prefer the old one. Parrying felt completely useless, unless I was using the humunculus skills (which are quite OP).
The story is OK but not as immersive and captivating as the first game, and it kinda felt unbalanced. Some characters have good development, other really don't, so the story does feel a bit scattered, even when you try to read everything and put the pieces together, link the dots and all. And (it could just be me) but it felt like there were a lot of things left unexplained or left lacking in expectation.
I think the difficulty settings are a bit too much: scrollbars for balancing... that'll just encourage folks to min-max to favour their playstyle and still go out thinking that they played on a HARD. I still don't get the point of fragments... just for cosmetic stuff? That should have been free instead of a grind. Three different currencies when one is useless for gameplay feels dumb.
Attires are cool, but I played the entire game hoping that different attires would give me different perks. But nah - just cosmetic. Might as well have added a kitten attire.
Some of the relics don't really seem to make a difference, and they're not very well explained at all, so i just went and min-maxxed DPS within my possible slot allocation.
The game is generally a fair bit easier than Ender Lilies too so, if you're already a seasoned metroidvania player (or at least finished Ender Lilies), you probably should up the difficulty a bit. I felt like Hard was good balance to start with. I had a bit of trouble with a few bosses that felt BS at first, but turned out I just wasn't supposed to be there yet (still felt achievable).
Having to fight that one boss 3 times, at different stages of the game also felt pretty cheap. And weirdly , the first encounter was the hardest. Even on his ultimate form for true ending. Oh, and you'll remember that you hate shield enemies too.
So yeah. Very nice, feel-good kind of game to pass the time but don't get yourself too hyped up with it.
And FFS, devs/studios/producers... SINGING MID GAME IS A BAD IDEA. It's distracting. It's corny. It's cheesy. It's annoying. By the end of my 10th hour on this game, I couldn't stand that asian chick singing ♥♥♥♥ that I can't understand but are CLEARLY words that I feel like I should be understanding. The soundtrack is very nice, not a bad voice or singing or anything, but IT NEEDS TO BE ->BACKGROUND<- MUSIC. Not Beijing karaoke. Just PLEASE give that asian girl a flute or smth and ask her kindly to STFU.

If you liked ENDER LILIES, Hollow Knight, Afterimage, or the Momodora series, you'll definitely love this game. This has, from what I can tell, slightly better art quality than ENDER LILIES (highly impressive, considering ENDER LILIES was already top-of-the-line); somehow even BETTER animations (????? genuinely confused how this was pulled off); the combat has been revamped from ENDER LILIES, making it more fluid, complex, and an even better time; the plot is deep and emotional, equally as well done as the first game, though it now takes a different route; the music GOES SO DAMNNNN HAAARRRRDDDDDDD RRRAAAAAHHHHHHHHHH; there's now a new Equipment system, with a shop related to it; there are various Extras like animations, clothing, etc, there's now a difficulty slider with cosmetic rewards for taking on harder challenges, and the design art is there too.

To give a brief summary:
In this game, you play as Lilac, a young girl with a mysterious past, who's missing her memories. She is a rare 'Attuner', someone capable of assisting and utilizing the Homunculi. In this fatally injured world, only a notch better off than the one presented before us in ENDER LILIES, we must explore the Lower Stratum, saving Homunculi, Attuners, and all in-between, whilst exploring our past and figuring out a way forward for everyone to survive with peace of mind. This makes a notable contrast from ENDER LILIES; if, in ENDER LILIES, we were giving a dead Kingdom its burial and cutting the chain of unending, past-death-persisting suffering, then in this new game, ENDER MAGNOLIA, we are reigniting the flame of a society on its last breath; we are here to restore, to save, all which has not yet been blighted, and possibly look for a way to permanently rid the world of the suffering the Blight causes.


If you enjoy Metroidvanias, or 2D Action-Platformers in general, then this game is a must buy, right alongside its predecessor, ENDER LILIES. If I had any influence over the Game Awards, I would nominate this for Game of the Year, despite this being a January release. Once more Binary Haze Interactive, Live Wire, and Adglobe strike an absolute beast of a game; they truly never miss.

tl;dr: loli stand user simulator is back with a cuter loli and more advanced stands. Overall a solid game and somewhat of an improvement over Ender Lilies, but still not enough to make it really stand out in the vast sea of metroidvanias in my opinion.

In terms of gameplay, attacks have hitstop now, hallelujah. It was completely missing in the previous game as far as I remember, and it goes a long way towards making the combat "feel" good.
The approach to combat skills is slightly different, with each party member adding 3 different skills to your arsenal, but you can only equip one of them per character, so you can't mix and match however you want. There are also no combat skills with a limited number of uses anymore. I think the types of skills are more interesting this time around, and they allow some fun playstyles and combos. However the overall difficulty is still on the lower side even on the maximum setting, and there is still absolutely no punishment on death, not necessarily a bad thing but it is what it is.
The game will keep you busy for around 25 hours if you take it slow which I think is just right, but if you're looking for replayability you'll find very little, as it is very easily 100%-able in a single playthrough. Even getting different endings boils down to just swapping an item before the final boss.

In terms of story... it exists, I guess. I genuinely appreciate that the dialogue and lore entries are short and to the point, as watching long cutscenes and reading bloated dialogue is not really what I sign up for when I play action-oriented games, but at the same time I feel like they didn't really try to give a lasting impression, and I think it's a bit of a shame because it seems they did try in other aspects like overall atmosphere, graphics and soundtrack.
This was a thing in the previous game as well. Overall it's ok, just don't expect to have your mind blown in any way.

No significant change in terms of graphics and sound; still a relatively pretty game to look at and Mili is back at the soundtrack, which is still excellent as expected and even gave us a few particularly memorable tracks this time.

In the end the final verdict is the same as Ender Lilies, worth a playthrough if you're a metroidvania junkie, but if you're looking for the next Hollow Knight this is not the right place (have fun waiting for Silksong lmao)

Review of Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist
I want to start off by saying that this has been an absolute joy to play and a big thank you to the Ender Magnolia developers!

Now, for the review I'm going to section this into two parts one which focuses on the broader "is it good?" and another regarding "does it sequel?"

Synopsis:
Ender Magnolia is a game that offers a intriguing mystery at the very start of the game and drops you into the stunning world as a young teen(?) named Lilac who has lost her memories. You quickly learn that you are something called a attuner someone who tunes homunculi to stave off madness using this power you are quickly joined by a companion named Nola who similarly has lost her memories, together you will explore a post-apocalyptic magic-punk world on you're quest for answers.

Gameplay:
The game feels and moves smoothly combat is both intuitive and challenging, there is a large sprawling map to explore and upgrades hidden everywhere. The unique and interesting abilities that you gain from you're companion homunculi you encounter on you're journey are a blend of original and tried and true and I feel that they landed exceptionally well in Magnolia.
Now there are some small negative things such as certain movement abilities feeling a little rough or some abilities feeling slightly under-powered but this is nearly not noticeable. Add to this the fact that difficulty setting is built into the game so that if you feel the game is too hard or easy you can adjust the experience. (I my self didn't touch it, wanted to play as the developers intended.)

Now then, Ender Magnolia is a sequel after all and to a top contender amongst the metroidvania genre and begs the question does it live up to the hype? The short answer is that it exceedingly does so. The long answer is that Magnolia does everything a sequel should, it expands the lore and sheds clear light on many theories from the first game why this is can be explaind by the fact that the Land of Fumes is far more intact than Lands End was and has a large magic academy with a "Library" amazing right?
Magnolia is also a clear improvement in the spirit system and gameplay in general, and to give a clear example, I would say that the improvement between the games gameplay is akin to the difference of ori and the blind forest and ori and the will of the wisps.

If you like metroidvanias, this should definitely be on you're radar. If you liked Ender Lilies then this is a must buy. I give this game my highest recommendation it has earned a spot in my top 10.

A good-great metroidvania and sequel to Ender Lillies. Compared to its predecessor it has vastly improved gameplay, lots of new extras/features, and even better art/music (is that even possible?). These changes do seem to have come at the cost of reduced immersion and narrative quality however, as several plot points, characters, and areas feel rather underdeveloped or rushed. The pacing of spirit acquisitions and lore is also a bit awkward (heavily early and endgame loaded), but those are really the only 'negatives' (balance/DoTs like burn can be fixed with patches). It's a phenomenal game with a lot going for it, and it shows us that it is still possible to make beautiful, captivating, and fun to play games at affordable prices in the present day.

Overall, kudos to the developers for managing to deliver a solid sequel and recapture a lot of the magic of the original. Shoutouts to the stellar soundtrack (really matched each area and told the story of the game through it), Ending B (the appearance of a certain character in particular), and how you managed to falseflag me into thinking X character would be the ultimate evil/final big bad of the game several times. There's always deeper layers.

Looking forward to an "Ending C" DLC (if it is in the works), and otherwise ENDER 3!

Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights is one of my favorite Metroidvania games of all time. I was so happy when I heard the news that Binary Haze Interactive developed a sequel.

With Ender Magnolia: Bloom in the Mist, they have raised the bar.

There's been a lot of quality of life improvements from Ender Lilies (no contact damage, a slider for difficulty settings, and an easy-to-understand map UI interface to ensure that you have 100% every area) that makes Ender Magnolia a step above Ender Lilies. Combine that with a beautiful soundtrack and a gorgeous looking game, you're in for a treat.

You do not have to play Ender Lilies to understand the story of Ender Magnolia but it does help with some references from the first game.

Treat yourself to a great time with Ender Magnolia; you won't regret it.

review_text:

Это был шедевр
Магнум опус метроидваний, шикарный сиквел Ender Lilies.

События игры Ender Magnolia происходят спустя несколько десятилетий после концовки первой игры. Действие игры разворачивается в Дымной стране, где сосуществуют люди и "гомункулы" (искусственные существа). Поднимающиеся из земли испарения скверны свели гомункулов с ума и они обратились против людей, став неконтролируемыми монстрами.

Утратившая воспоминания девочка Лайлак приходит в себя в подземной лаборатории Нижнего сектора. Она обладает силой "настройщика", которая может спасать гомункулов. Пройдя дальше по лаборатории, она встречает гомункула у которого амнезия, и они заключают договор. Cразу же влетает крутой трек, и в этот момент ты понимаешь, что игра будет не хуже Ender Lilies.

Пройдя первого босса, вы выбираетесь из лаборатории и добираетесь до города, по пути слушая главную музыкальную тему игры. Вот и начинается ваше приключение в мире игры Ender Magnolia.
Появился сюжет, геймплей остался такой же, а некоторые улучшения и изменения очень сильно повлияли на положительное впечатление от игры.

Уже в самом начале игры заметны классные улучшения некоторых моментов, которых в Ender Lilies не хватало/не было.
1. Карта теперь 10/10. Теперь на ней есть картинка области, и после полного исследования области, её серый окрас превращается в синий. И самое имбовое - у каждого закрытого прохода есть знак стоп, а когда даётся новая способность, то на карте исчезает этот знак и теперь там можно будет пройти.
2. Контактного урона больше НЕТ!! И у всех гомункулов неограниченное количество использования.
3. Анимации персонажей во время диалогов и сама графика стали ещё лучше, а звуковые эффекты - приятнее. Видеоролики с воспоминаниями выросли в качестве. Интерфейс тоже сделали очень красивым.
4. Анимации персонажа и его гомункулов чувствуются мобильнее. У каждого гомункула по три уникальных навыка.
5. Появились НПС, которые могут ещё давать сайд квест. При специальном событии у скамейке, духи будут разговаривать сами с собой, раскрывая вам свой и игрового мира лор.
6. Артефактов стало ещё больше и почти каждый из них имеет уникальный эффект. Дальше по игре дадут функцию улучшения артефактов.
7. Появились новые виды снаряжения: реликвия, кольца и спутник. Реликвия даёт бонус при уклонении, кольца влияют на основные характеристики, а спутники дают пассивный бонус, иногда урезая некоторые основные характеристики.

Я считаю это основной плюс игры.
Хоть мир и застыл в меланхоличном состоянии и стоит на краю гибели, но всё равно есть в нём прекрасное, и это чувство передаётся через диалоги, локации и музыку. Так, например, город стал моей самой любимой локацией из-за музыки и сайд квеста Руби. Бэкграунды к локациям стали детальнее, а саундтрек делает все локации очень атмосферными.
Как и с ситуацией саундтрека к Ender Lilies, почти весь саундтрек Ender Magnolia идёт в плейлист. Музыка стала более разнообразной и намного лучше (хоть это и субъективщина, но да) по сравнению с первой частью. Отдельно можно написать про тему боссов, потому что нам завезли: Parasyte -the maxim-, передающее сожаление пиано, джаз-фьюжн, Nier:Automata, сиквел трека из Ender Lilies (Bloom - Outro), и многие другие невероятные треки.
Хоть и Mili song в титрах Ender Lilies мне нравится больше, но в Ender Magnolia он получился очень атмосферный и как же мне зашло пиано, которое открывает эту песню...


Ааааээээ... здесь их почти нет.
Я проходил на самой высокой сложности и мне не очень понравился босс, который призывает лечащего миньона. И мне очень сильно не понравилось, что к одному боссу проходить нужно через других трёх боссов, которые ресетаются после смерти. Зачем-то убрали возможность перепройти босса на скамейке. Ну и всё наверное...

Я ХОЧУ ЗАБЫТЬ ВСЁ ОБ ЭТОЙ ИГРЕ И ПРОЙТИ ЕЁ СНОВА. ЛУЧШИЙ САУНДТРЕК 2025. ИГРА ГО- .

Я думаю тут видно, что мне очень зашла Ender Magnolia xd. Ждал её с анонса, купил сразу же ранний доступ и не играл в него, чтобы после выхода можно было испытать фулл экспириенс. Я буквально испытал то же чувство после прохождения Ender Magnolia, какое я испытал после прохождения TUNIC. Это точно того стоило.
Если вам понравилась Ender Lilies, то Ender Magnolia вам точно зайдёт. Это буквально Hollow Knight и Hollow Knight: Silksong. Я теперь не так сильно ожидаю Silksong, потому что не думаю, что он сможет превзойти Ender Magnolia для меня...
Поэтому пока все ждут Silksong, я скажу, что для меня Ender Magnolia это и есть истинный Silksong.

Improved in so many aspects like gameplay, chara/environment/map design, exploration, OST (mili my beloved) and boss battles compared to Ender Lilies.

The characters and spirits (homunculi here) can all interact with one another, making their relationships feel so much closer and enjoyable to see.

But I think because I finished another metroidvania before jumping right into Ender Magnolia, most bosses here felt too easy. There are plenty of bosses where I one-tap them in the first try in normal difficulty. I struggled a lot more with Ender Lilies. And the last boss here doesn't have a second phase. Such a shame, because the last boss of Ender Lilies has so much impact in terms of lore and ending.

The lore is ambiguous as always, just like most metroidvania. It's not bad, quite enjoyable actually. But I think Ender Lilies' lore has a lot more depth (and definitely more tragic).

Oh, and achievements here are still easy to 100% just like the previous game. No missable at all.

8/10.
If you like Ender Lilies, you'll definitely love Ender Magnolia.

Great platforming and tight combat bogged down by an emotionally flat story, uninspired characters, and pretty but forgettable soundtrack. The map tracks which rooms were completed, which makes backtracking for hidden items and paths less tedious, while also streamlining exploration to a fault: discovering secrets is not as rewarding when their location is significantly narrowed down. Traversal skills are obtained linearly, but sequence breaking for weapon upgrades is satisfying and relatively easy. Movement and combat are snappy and refined, except for the water sections, sorely standing out. The sequel to Ender Lilies is a dramatically more polished experience that's fun to slash and rush through but lacking in imagination and love.

It's not quite the mindblowing masterpiece that Hollow Knight and Nine Sols are, but it still sits within their company. Very competent metrovania with a beautiful world and intriguing setting. Big world with great enemy variety, cool abilities, and pretty cool characters.

The game lacks slightly in the story, which was never the strength of metrovanias so not a huge negative, and the combat, which is. Combat is a little simplistic and some aspects of it (i.e. the new parry mechanics) are easy to abuse, especially coming off Nine Sols. Despite some great difficulty options and being much harder overall, it's still not quite at the level of HK or 9S, but that might not be a negative for some.

If you're new into metrovanias and want to try them, this is the perfect place to start. If you hate them, however, this game won't change your mind.

A Polished Dark Fantasy Metroidvania with Stunning Presentation but Flawed Late-Game Design

Ender Magnolia delivers a visually stunning and enjoyable metroidvania experience, but its frustrating late-game design choices hold it back from true greatness. The dark fantasy aesthetic is reminiscent of Ender Lilies, one of my favorite games despite its flaws. This sequel captures the same haunting beauty, with gorgeous graphics, detailed environments, and smooth pseudo-3D animations. While the Spine-authored animations are sometimes a bit stiff, the colorful and intricate backgrounds are truly beautiful.

Gameplay: Polished and Accessible
Gameplay is smooth and refined, with a modern take on metroidvania mechanics. You quickly acquire essential traversal skills like double jump, yet meaningful upgrades continue to appear throughout the game. There’s minimal backtracking, save points are generously placed, and fast travel unlocks early. The mapping system is one of the best I’ve seen in the genre. It’s also possible to teleport to save points at will, with no need to carry anything back to them.

These choices ensure accessibility without sacrificing challenge—until the late game, where frustrations begin to surface. You also get to upgrade weapons and stat-modifying items, and I found experimenting with loadouts for different situations enjoyable.

A Story That Doesn't Overstay Its Welcome
The story shifts away from the darker tone of Ender Lilies, introducing multiple talking NPCs and companions who are quite talkative. While the plot leans into typical anime "good vs. evil" tropes, it’s serviceable, with a balanced amount of dialogue that neither overwhelms nor bores.

Late-Game Frustrations
Unfortunately, the game falters in its final act. The last three levels abandon the elegant design of earlier stages, introducing surreal, stadium-sized levels with excessive padding. Spongy enemies capable of near-instant kills (via shock clouds, lasers, and similar mechanics) make combat frustrating, almost turning the game into a platformer-shooter hybrid that feels out of place.

Boss Battles
Boss battles are equally divisive. While I completed most of the game on normal difficulty, I found some encounters infuriating due to their reliance on Souls-like mechanics. Tight timing windows for blocking and unavoidable full-screen attacks punish average players, forcing a defensive playstyle that doesn’t leave much room for creativity or cheesing.

You know, I’d let those top 1% of players enjoy the bosses "the proper way," but let me hide and cheese if I need to. The inclusion of a mini-boss gauntlet before a major boss added to the frustration, with one-hit kills often undoing 10 minutes of otherwise flawless gameplay. That’s why I skipped Number 7 and the factory robots by switching to easy mode.

If you didn’t play the first game, the main character is (once again) a glass cannon, and there are no i-frames, so a single laser or projectile cluster (or a few rats, lol) can end you quickly. This wasn’t as much of an issue in the first game. Additionally, the ending felt rushed—for me, the final boss was like, "Oh, you were the final boss? Okay."

Music and Audio: A Highlight
Mili’s music and the sound design are top-notch, adding immense value to the atmosphere. The soundtrack elevates even the game’s weaker moments.

Final Verdict (after 100% completing the game)
Ender Magnolia is a beautiful and polished metroidvania that excels in its presentation and early-game design. However, its late-game flaws, from bloated levels to punishing combat mechanics, hold it back from reaching masterpiece status (in my opinion). If you’re a fan of the genre, definitely don’t skip this game—it’s still very much worth playing.

The review contains spoilers for this game's prequel, which is also highly recommended and particularly for it to be played prior to this, though such is not strictly necessary.

Overall, this game shows that in terms of proficiency that Binary Haze is in a good place. This is mechanically a triumphant improvement over their previous game, being sharper, more responsive, having more developed art assets, and just looks to be all around a better game. There are very few areas that feel unjust in the secrets they keep, there are satisfying and minor movement exploits, growth feels natural and very few progression blocks feel unjustified. Movement's nice, combat's nice, story's nice.

If I had to manufacture negative things to say about the game, I would say that there are too many currencies and advancement tracks. This isn't too much of an issue, you handily max out any abilities that end up fitting your playstyle, and unlocking them in the first place isn't difficult, it's just something that completionists are going to be rolling their eyes at. Gallery points in the style of modern Capcom games, ability upgrades, relic upgrades, equipment unlocks, leveling. Progression feels nice, but this very quickly crosses the border into tedium. And while it was full enough to stay entertained, the map is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ huge. It ain't gotta be that big, and it ain't even bad that it is, but it's just so big!

Mili returns to the soundtrack, filling the ambiance with an outstanding and engaging melancholy.

Ender Lillies: Quietus of Knights had to it a sadness and bitterness that I've not really seen in other games. This is something that Ender Magnolia has followed in the footsteps of, but not as much in the same direction. It's a much more typical narrative in other senses. ELQoK had a much more advanced crisis, so at once the personal scales presented in the narrative were lesser and more intimate at once. At the same time, you attune to less spirits that have a wider array of abilities, so the lesser amount of companions feel more filled out.

I recommend not only this game, but its prequel if you haven't played it.

Gameplay was as smooth as Ender Lilies', but far more fleshed out. I constantly found myself swapping relics and abilities depending on the area I was in or the boss I was facing, and the movement was fluid and satisfying. Every boss was unique with its own gimmicks, and no bugs encountered

And as usual, Mili songs were beautiful and felt right at home with the atmosphere

Huge W for Ender fans, 11/10

Amazing game, and a great sequel. I'd even say the game is probably better as a game then Lilies, but I liked Lilies more. I'll start with the pros: The sounds of the game, the look of the game, and the feel of the combat all still pop. Felt the summons flow together better. They got rid of contact damage too which feels great. The parry timings as well still feel hella crisp. The movement tech you can pull (No.7, auto, beast, auto, dash, auto, jump, (repeat)) is kinda insane and can lead to some fun skips. The difficulty when set to hard was a nice setting once I knew it was there too.

The three issues I do wish they'd change. First, Velgrynd just straight up has his hit box come out before the actual animation of his arm moving plays for me at least. Second, you can see the stats and look of attack spirit arts in the menu, but I so no real description for what the none attack spirit arts did in menu which is kinda goofy. Third, No.7 dash attack stopping at ledge is kinda a pain in the rear.

And now a bunch of nitpicks, most of which are probably just a me thing.
[1] Vibes are still great, but I liked the feel of the first one a bit more with the ruin kingdom aesthetic. [2] Map is phenomenally done, but I just like the first entries more though the new one is a lot more user friendly. [3] I kinda liked collecting a bunch of different summons rather then the current slimmer list, but it does let the character be more focused and fleshed out; so kinda mixed on it. [4] Some relics like the .5% life steal ring just really bad, holy buckets. [5] I adore the Lars dash you get later in the game but I liked juggling the abilities for the jump puzzles more in the first. Honestly your options for movement tech in the air in this game so strong it is kinda nutty and a bit less fun cause of that fact.

A fantastic sequel, there are so many improvements I won't go to in to detail but all around, graphics, sound design, level design, boss design (With one exception), and overall gameplay feel better, smoother, and more polished than the original.

TL:DR For anyone who enjoyed the first game, grab this one. For those that haven't: go buy the first game its amazing, then come play this one, it is also amazing.

Points of Note:
The design of basic enemies feels a little off at times, which is a shame because it was so good in the first game. The way enemies with shields are made makes it way too annoying to hit them at times, and certain enemies bullet (Or laser iykyk) pathing is obnoxious and makes it next to impossible to not die sometimes with next to no counter play. However, most of the enemy designs are very well made, and it is just a few archetypes that miss the mark imo.

Map design and layout are beautiful and give you just a perfect mixture of lost and exploring so you never feel too confused the first time you go through a zone. However, the abscence of a blue completion colouring on the minimap, compared to the first game, (which I think may be a glitch) makes it next to impossible to figure out what rooms you've cleared and where there are still items to find. Furthermore, the "hidden rooms" in this game are at times a little too hidden.

The map in this game feels bigger than the first but I don't know for sure if that is the case. Either it feels very nice and like you are actually going places. Although it can make navigating the map a little difficult near the end-game due to how large it is.

The bosses in this game are for the most part, incredibly well designed and give a great balance between difficulty, style, and engaging combat. They also feature a much wider variety of tactics when compared to the first game. Though sometimes they can lack a little of the rememberability of the first games bosses.

That being said, I can't leave a review here without talking about the final boss. So spoilers ahead:







Otherwise, great game would highly recommend. I see it as the Dark Souls 2(but better) of Ender Flowers games.

This takes all aspects of what made the first game good and added upon it! The music and audio is amazing (personally I prefer the main song from lilies but that is up to taste) with the stunning vocals back from the first game. Combat is enhanced with new options, status effects and more advanced movement added on what they had in the first. Other games should strive to have the map system that this game has. Its clear, shows me exactly what rooms I have not cleared, what areas still have quests within them and all this to add my want of exploration.

Now whats something I dislike with the game? Some fights are better balanced than others, where mechanics of a boss can become more frustrating that interesting. Lucky I only had this happen to two of the bosses in my entire playthrough. I will always despise parts of games where you are forced to take damage during exploration, which some parts of this game has. They do however balance this out with save points and extra heals, but I will never understand why some games thinks this makes for a fun mechanic.

In conclusion, this game is a masterpiece and a worthy successor of the first game. They took what they had in the first one and made it all better, more advanced and bigger. What more can you ask of a sequal?

I give it the rating of 9/10 and would recommend getting it at full price. The studio deserves it

I would leave a neutral review if possible

I just finished 100% of the game on hard difficulty and enjoyed most of it, so I can't leave a negative review, but there were certainly some parts of the game that were very frustrating

The map is fun to explore but long runbacks between areas full of certain poorly designed enemies was one of the biggest annoyances I encountered. Having no I-frames on hit means avoiding projectile spamming enemies will often times end with getting 100-0'd by multiple attacks hitting at the same time
There's some very very fun and satisfying boss fights to learn and beat, but for every great boss there's 2 bad/uninspired bosses that are a slog to fight. Inaccurate hitboxes also lead to a lot of bosses feeling cheap in their attacks, filling a massive space outside their weapons visual range in a few frames
I only ever ended up using a few of the allies and not really switching between their abilities, 2 of which being autonomous and the others being some of the first acquired in the game, the ally variety and quantity in this game feels disappointing compared to the previous.
A few more minor things. Hitting enemies rapidly causes freeze frames like in many fighting games, but it can also delay their attacks if you are throwing out a lot of attacks at once. leading to damage that would've otherwise been avoided. The dodge feels a bit floaty, and the animation and the I-frames don't feel in sync. I just liked the art in the first game better, this game is still beautiful though.

All in all, if you enjoyed the first game or other metroidvanias you will enjoy this one, but be prepared for some sections of the game to test your patience.

The sequel to Ender Lilies : Quietus of the Knights is on par with it.

- The gameplay is still good and while I generally dislike one-hit attacks (mainly in the second half of the game), it didn't ruin my experience.
-The exploration is very simple but that's what I really like about it as a completionist : I don't need to ckeck and reckeck every area to make sure I didn't miss anything, the game clearly tells you when you're done with an area.
-The art and music are still as good, the music still being one of the better things about the game. And I like that this time around, we actually have cinematics instead of just images.
-I prefer the setting of this story compared to the first game and the fact that you can interact at certain points with the allies/abilities that you have collected but the story is still pretty simple with really nothing that I found super notable.

While there is nothing super inventive or new compared to the first game, I still really liked it.
9.0/10

Played this on with everything on 2x.

Overall great game for anyone that's looking for a Metroidvania.
Pros:
- Level Design was amazing
- Artwork is amazing.
- I felt like Parrying felt amazing and way better in this game compared to the prior game(especially when you're next to a laser and you can proc your parry nonstop)
- Bosses felt challenging(giving them 2x hp was a mistake for me but I wouldn't have it any other way)
- I think some of the puzzles you had to solve were actually interesting.
- If its not for you, you can lower the difficulty if you want, I think putting everything that 2x the difficulty was probably the reason I liked the game a lot. I couldn't make a mistake and would die.
- The controls felt so smooth, I went back to Ender Lilies to just check how different it was, just felt super responsive.
- The relic choices were pretty nice, felt like you could play multiple different ways.

Cons:
- The rats

Probably one of the more funner things I found in the game was that I was able to visit some areas you're not supposed to because of having certain relics and weapon attacks that would allow you to float long enough to get into certain places.

Overall I had such an amazing time playing this game and would recommend this to anyone that likes metroidvanias.
