It's a pretty decent if short experience.

I think the most impressive thing about this game was the art. Each zone and character/enemy is quite gorgeous honestly, and you can tell that there was a focus on the design here. Some areas have like 5+ parallax scrolling layers and it's just very pretty. Your movement speed is also never really so high that you don't have time to look around although some might consider that a downside lol.

The exploration was fairly decent. There are quiet a few hidden and useful items to find. Backtracking when you find a new tool is quick. I wish the map indicators that told you that you had found everything in a zone was a late game unlock or toggle, because I like exploring for myself. However, either way is fine. Areas were pretty small. I wish there was more. The game is quite short for me. Finished it in 2 long ~8 hour sit downs.

As for combat it was mostly good. I played the game on hard from start to finish. The variety of attacks you get access to, and the ways you can change and buff your build, are very high. Probably too high considering the length of the game? By the time I had finished the game I still hadn't tried out even half the abilities I had access to. Certain later game enemies were more annoying than fun to fight but overall it was fun to engage in combat. I'd recommend raising the enemy health before most bosses as I finished most fights very quickly and usually in 1-2 attempts.

Nothing in particular stood out to me as bad during the experience. Maybe there is a bit of a lack of lore/storytelling, but the art honestly does enough to make up for that.

Honestly, just like the first game, for the price point I enjoyed it and hope these developers keep making more.

I loved the first game so much, I not only replayed the game 8 different playthroughs, with different accounts and systems, I also bought copies of the game for friends for their birthdays to have to at least try it.

With that said, Ender Magnolia had me with really high expectations as to what would come. I played the Early Access during the initial release, so that shaves off about 7 hours from my total playtime as of this review with 20 hours my first playthrough. Getting both endings and getting everything except upgrade all Homunculus abilities since you need the grind money for their parts, and upgrading your health to the highest extent.

Without getting into spoilers for both the story and general gameplay, I will say that the game improves in almost every way gameplay-wise. From the Map being detailed, manual markers as an option, secret tracker, NO CONTACT DAMAGE, higher particle effects density, to smoother platforming, the game took the majority of criticisms they received and probably read online to make the experience more accessible without taking away the original charm of the game's hard, but flexible difficulty.

The narrative, while not mind blowing in the same way the first game could wow a player the first around, is pretty consistent with not only the way it was delivered (more dialogue now because of NPCs being alive this time, flavor text, and cutscenes), but would recall a lot of events from Lilies to get the full context.

In almost every way, the gameplay is objectively better than Lilies. The QoL mentions before on top of a rebalanced system makes the game very smooth to play overall. It might be debatable on if Lilies "Quantity of Spirits but with 2 L:oadouts" is better or not as fun Magnolia's "Less Quantity of Homunculus but with more options per Homunculus and only 1 Loadout". I think that is very preferential, but the QoL changes will most likely sound more appealing to many others, even if they probably didn't play or gave up on the first game.

The game, I would argue, is generally harder. Despite the frustrating moments I had with a couple of biomes' exploration and some boss fights, I still loved the journey overall. As Ender Lilies was my Game of the Year in 2021, Ender Magnolia, despite being only the beginning of the year, is my favorite game so far.

Ender Magnolia is a 9.5/10

Although I prefer Ender Lilies a bit more, Ender Magnolia is a great sequel nonetheless.

Instead of spreading the abilities among many "stands", Magnolia condenses them into 10 homunculi, each with 3 different abilities, which mean you're more likely to use all homunculi rather than just a selected few like Lilies. Lilac also can only wield 4 homunculi at once unlike Lily's 6, but each homunculus can also unleash an ultimate move, so that balances out a little. Movement unlocks are similar, with skyward dash being the only new addition, which is kinda disappointing.

The story still focus around the the blight and rain of death apocalypse, but Land of Fumes is in a much better state than Land's End. The people here was able to devise a countermeasure, albeit temporary, thus small settlements still remained, provided you will some sort of hubs with merchants and upgraders. Lilac will encounter NPCs everywhere, and instead of purifying the souls of the dead like Lily, Lilac actually saving the homunculi from the blight, making the overall stake and danger of the situation less serious.

Mili still did a wonderful job with the OSTs. Naturally like the story, the music this time is more hopeful, and reaching the good ending rewarded you with a full lyric ending theme. The game is appropriately long for its price, it took me 32 hours to get 100% completion, and I didn't have to grind too much as most of the achievement can be unlocked during the course of the game. I most likely will not comeback to this anytime soon, but maybe I will comeback to Ender Lilies in the near future and 100% it this time.

I'm leaving a thumbs up, but I certainly wish there was a neutral rating to give.

I was excited for this because I enjoyed the first and was hoping that, with tweaks, the game could be great. I don't really see that here. The art is obviously amazing. The story is ok and the combat is pretty good. But there are just so many things that I found dragged the experience down. The map design was strange (you'll have things like unlocking a shortcut after a long stretch without a bench, then a bench will be in the room next to where you unlocked the shortcut, or you'll have a boss fight that's a few screens away from the bench, meaning there's just a time tax to retries). I played on hard so I get that this might not be an issue for other difficulties, but by the end common enemies can two-touch you, and bosses can, similarly, just kill you immediately. So by the end of the game you just have this comically long health bar that disappears at the slightest sneeze from an enemy.

This is a serviceable metroidvania with great art. If you've already played every great MV out there then it's probably worth checking out, but it's a genre that already has a lot of exceptional titles. I don't think I would support another sequel in EA, nor would I pick up a sequel day one. I'm definitely interested in future releases
but I refuse to be swayed so easily by beautiful art when everything else that makes up the game is just ok.

The sequel to Ender Lilies is everything I hoped for and more. The combat, which previously felt imprecise and rigid, now feels incredibly smooth and responsive. Interestingly, there’s currently no contact damage, and you can even dodge through projectiles, which adds to the fluidity. From the very start, the addition of a dash and double jump ensures movement feels natural and dynamic, avoiding the clunky pacing of the first game’s early stages.

They’ve also done something remarkable with the art—it’s somehow even more stunning than before, a truly impressive feat. The animations feel much more fluid, making the world even more immersive, mesmerizing even. A small but thoughtful touch is being able to chat with your companion at rest points, this new addition adds a refreshing sense of connection.

Altogether, it feels like a polished, upgraded experience in every way.

I played Ender Lilies about a month before Ender Magnolia launched, hoping to prepare for this new entry. After spending considerable time with both, I can confidently say that while Ender Magnolia surpasses its predecessor in several respects, there are still areas where it falls a bit short. Taken as a whole, though, I would give a slight edge to Ender Magnolia—both are excellent Metroidvanias, but this latest release refines some core mechanics in ways that really resonated with me.

One of the clearest improvements here is the combat system. Build variety has increased dramatically, with more options for attack, defense, and passive damage that let you adapt your play style as you progress. I personally favored the scythe, passive damage boosts, and the ranged attacker Yolvan for most of my run. By late-game, I found that stacking automatic damage was absurdly powerful—wielding the scythe alongside both Owl homunculi and Lorna Frost allowed me to remain relatively passive while still dishing out huge damage. Compared to Ender Lilies, I experimented far more with different loadouts, which was both fun and necessary since Ender Magnolia is noticeably harder than the original.

That added difficulty is a mixed bag. On the one hand, I loved tackling bosses like Luiseach (the toughest by far, in my opinion) and Gilroy’s first encounter. Figuring out how to dismantle these more challenging fights was immensely satisfying. On the other hand, the difficulty curve felt erratic. Many bosses were simple pushovers, and then the game would suddenly hurl a much tougher foe at you out of nowhere. Moreover, a lot of the mid- to late-game difficulty felt cheap rather than rewarding. Enemies increasingly relied on area-of-effect and projectile spam, turning this action-platformer into a makeshift bullet hell that tested my patience more than my skill. The hitboxes on those AOE attacks felt “loosey-goosey,” so when half your screen was covered by them, it became a chore rather than a challenge. In the final sections, I found myself sprinting past many high-HP enemies simply because they weren’t worth the headache.

Overall polish is also marginally better than in Ender Lilies (which was already quite smooth). Grammar and capitalization in dialogue and item descriptions seem more consistent in Ender Magnolia, and the character designs are massively improved. In the original, it was sometimes difficult to discern what, exactly, I was fighting, but here each enemy is rendered with far more clarity and style. Several new enemies and allies—like No. 7, Hati, and Lito—are particularly memorable, and boss designs stand out more vibrantly this time around. The “memories” mechanic similarly builds on what worked in Ender Lilies, adding an extra flourish of narrative color without feeling repetitive.

Where Ender Magnolia trips up, especially compared to its predecessor, is the storytelling. It aims for that Souls-like/Hollow Knight-inspired approach—vague environmental clues, scattered logs, and cryptic dialogue—but it falls flat in execution. Even though I appreciated giving Lilac actual dialogue instead of making her a silent protagonist, I never felt entirely sure why I was doing half the things I was doing. My main objective was apparently to reach Upper Stratum, but Gilroy’s motivations and villainy weren’t clearly explained, and the backgrounds of Lilac and Nola remained frustratingly obscure—especially since Nola ends up being central to the game’s title. Ender Lilies was also opaque, but at least I could follow the high-level plot beats. Here, the storytelling felt muddled enough that it undermined the climax. The ending left me underwhelmed: Ending A seemed rushed, and while I tried my best to unlock Ending B, I couldn’t find any use for the Stele of the Land of Origin, even though I practically cleared the entire map. Souls-likes often thrive on ambiguous endings, but in this case, it felt incomplete rather than intriguing.

Despite its narrative shortcomings, Ender Magnolia remains a thoroughly enjoyable experience. The game is visually gorgeous, boasts a lovely soundtrack (I’m particularly fond of the vocal tracks, which I believe are in French), features creative boss battles, and offers a deep combat system that kept me hooked for hours. I had hoped for more explicit ties to Ender Lilies—there are scattered references to blight and priestesses, sure, but they mostly flew over my head. Even so, I recommend Ender Magnolia for its mesmerizing art direction, lively character design, challenging (if sometimes exasperating) combat, and overall polished feel. I’ll definitely continue to support this franchise going forward.

After finishing Ender Magnolia, I can say its a really great game. The story wasn't great though and I even managed to get parts of the story out of order which was really confusing, like there was a rest conversation where they discussed a scene and a character I hadn't even seen yet. Also I didn't get to use one of the movesets because there's an area that was blocked off with a barrier when I first went to it, and I thought I'd get an item to unlock it but no the barrier disappeared at some random point in time so I didn't go there until I went hunting for the true ending, and the last moveset unlocked at the end of that area, so the end of the game kinda soured for me but.

Gripes aside, game looks and sounds better than the first, which already looked and sounded amazing. The condensing of moves into 3 per ally that joins and having a small number of allies feels way better than just getting copius amounts of dudes in the first game. Combat also just feels... better in this game, like I can't quite put my finger on it but it feels better to fight enemies. Exploration is also really fun and feels good (aside from the aforementioned barrier thing) and manages to be a big map chock full of goodies to find everywhere and going back to previous areas with new abilities, which is one of, if not the, most important things for a Metroidvania. Also the addition of 3 extra types of equippables, as well as the returning relics, puts some much needed extra build choices over the first game.

Ended up clocking in 26 hours, with 3 being from EA and couldn't keep my save from, so 23 hours to beat, which is the sweet spot for Metroidvania length for me, somewhere close to 25 hours.
Definitely would recommend, solid 8/10.

An absolutely phenomenal metroidvania that improves upon the original in most respects. Extremely good gameplay. Beautiful environments. Good music. Passable storytelling.

I can't really stress enough how good this game feels to play. You have a lot of tools at your disposal and most of them feel really good. I usually just play a game once and move on but I've gone back four or five times to refight the final boss with different weapon configurations just because I really enjoy this game's mechanics. The bosses feel a lot less annoying than Ender Lillies, and the addition of an extra spirit button makes combat options feel even more flexible.

A couple notes, though:
-Damage is extremely high. A 'tanky' build might survive three or four hits instead of two or three, everything hits extremely hard. Normally I hate this but it didn't frustrate me as much in this game because your character has a lot of tools (good mobility, an iframe dodge, a parry, ranged combat options, decent healing) and checkpoints are mostly generous... but I could see this being an issue for some people

-While the music is good, the size of the game means there's more track repetition than in Ender Lillies and I think EL had higher highs with its music.

-Unlike EL, there are a lot of characters with personalities and dialog in this game. I enjoyed the story for the most part (it's nothing groundbreaking, but it's intriguing enough and works), but can definitely feel a bit like some characters are underserved just because there are so many of them.


But like, IDK, this game is just so good to play. I'm thinking about playing it more right now. The game is satisfyingly long, (like 20-25 hours to 100% it) but I just want more content more zones more bosses. More stuff I can spam parry to shoot homing magic bullets at. This is the most fun I've had with a metroidvania in a long time.

Pros:

- Beautiful art and music
- very expansive difficulty setting getting to set not only health/damage but finer detail like attack frequency. Harder scaling rewards you with currency used to get outfits / concept art
- simple but pretty fun play style changes with equipment; the equipment in the game lets you modify what your parry does, how many and how effective your healing charges are, whether to sacrifice defence for more damage etc. For example can run equipment that makes your healing abilitiy do nothing but get a large amount of HP with regeneration over time. This feels pretty different form having less HP but more damage + 4/5 healing charges that restore basically full bar. Maybe you don't like parrying and would rather trade the ability to parry for more stats
- learning boss patterns with the parry mechanics were pretty fun

Cons:
- Sfx balancing feels a bit off some effects like lightning are way too loud compared to other sfx. I turned sfx volume way down to hear more of the music but sucks normal attack sfx are very very quiet compared to some enemy effect
- Kind of standard as far as metroidvanias go; it is a very crowded genre and while very good don't think it is ; the most unique aspect the, summoning combat I think could be expanded more. For example the pressure abilities turning off after using a power/parry was kind of annoying. It is mechanically easy enough to re hit the button as you do the parry w/e but kind of awkward.
- amnesia as a story device is over used + repeats similar beats from the last game
- I think voice acting would really help this game I know it is indie and there are a lot of characters but even just quips when running into characters would be nice


TLDR;

Very good if somewhat standard metroidvania I left it running a bit so don't know my exact playtime but can 100% it in 15-20 hours with great art, bosses and very customizable difficulty

A sequel to Ender Lilies: Quietus of the Knights, which I personally consider one of the finest Metroidvanias to come out. For the most part feels and plays like an even more polished version of the first game. Virtually no technical issues, smooth gameplay, largely fair enemies and bosses. Hilariously, mice pose a legitimate threat that doesn't quite feel intended, due to very short cooldown on attacks. But developers already rolling out patches fixing few issues game has.

Much like first game, mopping up map to 100% and getting the other (true) ending is relatively straightforward and well telegraphed to the player. An argument can be made for deep and obtuse Metroidvanias, but I for one prefer games that don't push the players to look up guides. Map is very informative on which rooms still have things to find in them. Traversal option upgrades are meted out in a balanced fashion, steadily throughout the game. With, perhaps, a bit of a slow start early on. Combat is baby skin smooth, with customizable difficulty you can change at any rest point and enemies well designed to properly display the incoming attack. Towards the later parts of the game bosses and enemies do get a fair bit more brutal with the speed of attacks though, but that's something a player can customize to their liking.

Visually and sound-wise the game is quite a superb 2D example, much like the first game. Good design, good style, gorgeous visuals without requiring an arm and a leg for hardware to run. Music is marvelous, sound queues are crisp and provide valuable feedback.

If there is a point to criticize... sadly, that would be the story. Don't get me wrong, I feel the story is well written and well presented. With just the right mix of direct story telling and indirect journals and pages to find. But I feel that compared to the first game, second one leaves somewhat wanting for more depth. Bosses especially felt less engrossing in their backgrounds, while in the first game many locations and their bosses felt like a chance to experience a short dark fairy tale. Certain plot poits are retreads of the original ideas from the first game. Which does seem intentional and warranted, but also takes away some of the impact that could be experienced the first time.
On a flipside - the story relevance to the first game is both there but also not big enough that one has to play/remember the first game to properly experience second one. Just the right amount of a nod and "Hey, I think I know where this is going" for veterans without compromising new player experience.

On the other hand, Ender Magnolia is a noticeably longer game, standing at around 20 hours of playtime to 100% with reasonable effort. Compared to about 15 hours give or take for Ender Lilies. The bigger scope doesn't feel like a bloat or unwarranted, at no point it feels necessary to grind enemies to be able to afford items you want. A definite step up without sacrifice in quality of content.

All in all - a strong recommendation from me if someone is looking to play an exceptionally well made and well paced Metroidvania. The obvious asterisk being - buying both this and Ender Lilies game. Because why not get two of the great games and support a developer with such high standards for releases.

Strictly an improvement in almost every way over Ender Lilies. Roughly 26h to 100% on hard for me. The bosses are amazing and I love the level design so much. The map is perfect (almost) in telling you if you are missing any items anywhere and if they are visible they will be highlighted on the map automatically (no need to tag manually even though you can do that too).

On hard it is punishing difficult roughly 50% in and going forward, but manageable. There are spikes in difficulty when you transition between districts but nothing super crazy. The very last area however is... challenging lol. The last boss on hard even more so. It was impossible for me to beat without heavily relying on counters which of course requires timing. On easy/normal it was much easier. The game has a difficulty sliders so you can tailor it to your wishes (really great system).

Platforming isn't too difficult at all, it's the enemies you have to wary of. The ability gating is done perfectly. It was a joy to explore and learn each foe/boss (and some will literally blow you away if you face them head on). The variety of abilities and gear provides a lot of room for experimentation and different playstyles, huge plus in my book.

I only have a few remarks on what could be improved. At some point I almost missed one character late game because the map kept saying it is locked away behind impassable wall, but that wasn't the case. I thought it was just a bug. While I personally enjoyed having 3 mini bosses + regular boss in a row (no save point between), not everyone will be appreciative if they are struggling. It's worth it though :D

The music is nice and really completes the mood, but I wish it was a little more pronounced/assertive if that makes sense. It is too mellow at times.

Must play for any fan of Ender Lilies or Metroidvanias. Recommended also for others who like challenging combat.

9.5/10

I first installed the demo for this months ago and was so impressed, I wishlisted and didn't play again, as I wanted to come in and enjoy it fresh on release.

It released yesterday, grabbed it straight away, and for the first time in months I have a game that I can't drag myself away from. It's so good and here's why I think that:

The dev is doing this on his own and is very responsive, very active, fixes bugs and gives guidance in Discord, and generally makes you feel like you're in great hands.

Graphically I find the game very pleasing, it's not too cartoony and the little people are somewhat realistic, which I like in my sims! I also love that I can scroll in close and watch them working. Some games don't let you get close enough.

The balance is great, not too rushed and not too slow, there are lots of parameters available to customise your game experience.

The music is pleasant and not too irritating. I usually slap that stuff off straight away but 9 hours in I still have it on now. It's peaceful and calming, as are the ambient sounds during game play. None of the audio detracts from the experience (as an autistic gamer, that's important to me.)

Sure there are a few little bugs and glitches still being ironed out, but that's to be expected, and watching the dev work on them in real time is very cool.

I'm crap at writing reviews. Buy it and see for yourself, I don't think it will disappoint.

I like it. Both you and I have probably played similar games in the past. Yes in some ways they are all the same and this one is too, because it's in that genre. But this one seems to be done with care and love of the game. It's smoother, and works as you'd expect. There are no tutorials and little help, but the UI has lots of hints (like tooltips) and few bugs if any. The only problem that I've run into is tooltips on resources (iron, etc) suddenly stop showing up when you hover or click on them. Low poly models but it's a strategy game, and this level of detail is just fine for me, and irrelevant as you zoom out. Also I'm glad the effort was spent on the game play rather than the appearance. Overall, this may be my favorite strategy builder of this nature. It just works. It has a few frustrations (I wish farm fields or cattle fields were available from the start since sometimes there isn't hunting or fishing available anywhere within the discovered map. Also iron is pretty important (for tools) and last time I played, there wasn't any near my town, at all (other side of the map).

I have a few more "I wish" cases but I don't want to make this sound like a negative review. I only wish for these things because I love the game so much and the closer you get to 10/10, e.g. 9.5/10, the more that last 0.5 seems to bug you. ;)

I would get this game for sure, and at the time of this review, it's on sale at 35% off! Grab it!

It's a pretty nice medieval city builder. It took me around 22 hours to get my city to 500+ population and get 100% achievements in the game, which in my book counts as completing everything that the game has to offer. Personally I don't see myself playing it again, as there is simply no more challenge left in the game for me, but I think it's worth playing at least once.

It has everything you'd expect from such a game, and it's really charming. I like the visual style and the mechanics are pretty good. Big towns become a bit unwieldy from logistical perspective, but it still works okay enough. It's completely possible to be self-sustaining at any population level, but trading is there to get you over the hump when you rapidly expand the town, and fill-in for the non-renewable resources (especially stone).

Raiders are a bit meh. They pose a challenge early in the game, an in late-game stage you have to cheese them a bit, increasing the army size over 40 to 50-ish is pretty unfeasible as you'll be desperate for more workers. Still, it's better that they are there than not, as it gives you something to do and a reason to build the walls and be careful with expanding the city.

So, full disclosure, I'm a sandbox gamer. I'm not interested in grinding gameplay, I just want to unwind and build a town.

Do I recommend this game? Yes... but it still needs some polish.

The positives:
- graphics are cute
- houses can be built in different styles
- life milestones of your settlement's inhabitants are tracked
- some of the soundtracks are quite beautiful (although a few more would be good please)
- perk cards are a nice touch
- the devs continue to add small features to the game

The negatives:
- no tutorial or tool tips to tell you useful things like cutting down a forest will reduce the wildlife in the area
- at the time of writing, the village could only be upgraded to Level 2 (I assume this will change)
- after a few hours in "sandbox mode" the game becomes repetitive
- no matter how many labourers you have, build queues always seem to take forever to process, at which point the game becomes an unplayable grind
- if you stop building houses (for instance, to develop other features of the settlement), labourers suddenly get old and die en masse, leaving you with no one to build your properties
- if you don't stop building houses, your village can quickly become overpopulated, leaving a strain on supplies such as food and clothing

The game feels like it's still in the Early Access stage, even though it no longer is. It lacks the sophistication and polish of other city builders, but it's no slouch and is still fun. The devs are still actively working on this, and I have hope it will flourish into a thoroughly enjoyable time waster. For me, after a few hours of play I ultimately hit a grind wall and stop playing.

This game must be made by someone with passion for strategy games. You can tell by just how fast the ui flows, how well the graphs are graphing but most importantly by how the game combines the cornerstones of strategy games, mechanics like moving units (even citizens, similar to dawn of man), mechanics like fog of war, assigning jobs, leveling skills in those jobs, WALLS - and with that inspirations from more tower defence kinds of strategy. It just mashes these different mechanic you don't usually see working together and it makes them work really well together. Kinda reminds me of "The Dream" for Manor Lord, which also took mechanics don't usually seen together (like city building with "Total war-like" fighting, with 3rd person camera view in addition to classic strategy birds eye view, emphasis on graphic fidelity, etc.).
For me Manor Lord lacks towers and castles, forward scout bases and it leaves many things to be desired in how the information is presented to the gamer, this game absolutely fills that niche for a very comfortable price.

Now the main minus - no workshop no mods. Yeah, don't get me wrong i think developers can do what they want with there time and work but this one really hurts for game standing on such solid foundations mechanics wise. But i've heard dev talking about not including modding to this game because it's his first "big" game and he has no prior knowledge in modding and never modded a game, so i still keep my hopes up that one day we will get there.

Первое - эта штука полностью вторична, здесь нет никаких цепляющих фич, отличающих её от любой другой подобной градостроилки. Абсолютно стандартный набор зданий (домик, лесоруб, шахтёр, ...) и производственных цепочек (причём хлеб - это лейтгейм). Просто копипаста любой дефолтной игры этого жанра.
Второе - всё дико медленно, скорость х4 здесь как х1 в некоторых других играх подобного плана. Сделано как будто для затягивания времени, чтобы вы дошли до конца возможного контента после 2 часов стима на рефанд. Причём есть ограничение для второго тира зданий - это население 100+, а население тоже неторопливо поднимается и чисто естественным приростом, без миграции.
Третье - насквозь тупой ИИ, который может нарезать петли по одному и тому же маршруту, потому что он идёт на работу, а, не, он проголодался, а, не, он заболел, а, не, всё же проголодался. И с учётом мееееедленной походки он дай бог отработает 5-10% времени от этих петель на месте. Кстати, это касается и налётчиков - вы можете просто приманивать их открытыми воротами, закрывать оные перед носом у них, повторять до момента, когда ваши лучники из соседней башни закончат расстреливать мишени.
Четвёртое, раз уж про налётчиков. Налётчики - это просто механика для затягивания времени, потому что от их убийства вы не получите ничего, а если откупитесь или победите их - только не потеряете ресурсы. Ни оружия, ни брони, ни голды вы с их хладных трупов не залутаете.

Через 4 часа словил вылет на ровном месте. ГГ ВП.

Классный сетинг, минимализм, атмосфера, безумные мелодии, которые я бы хотел сыграть на своей гитаре, при перезаписи сохранения не спрашивают мою уверенность, спасибо. На этом из плюсов все.

Чтобы построить эффективное здание нужны люди, нужны инструменты, нужны дома поблизости, счастье. Ок. Понятно.

Чтобы были люди - нужно построить хижины и на этом все. Еще раз, в этой игре не приходят жители, ты не можешь их захватить или купить, или искусственно расплодить, здесь нельзя детей принуждать к труду. В итоге я вынужден ждать, когда взрослые расплодятся, потом когда дети станут взрослыми, и все для того, чтоб заставить их работать на благо империи (захихикал фростпанк). Через 7 лет(примерно тогда приходят первые варвары), я получил всего лишь 30 жителей, которых даже на еду не хватало.

Чтобы получить инструменты – нужно получить дерево, потом их в доски, параллельно добыть уголь и железную руду, потом руду в слиток и в итоге получаем 5 зданий. Ровно столько надо, чтоб +- начать получать инструменты, каждому зданию для эффективности нужно как можно больше людей, а про них я писал выше. Для этой эффективной цепочки, по моим подсчетам, надо около 20 людей. На старте дают примерно 20 инструментов, они заканчиваются через 3 игровых года, потом начинает висеть плашка о том, что инструментов не хватает и -30% эффективности всех жителей. Разраб либо недодал, недоглядел, либо специально замедлил, чтоб я не успел оформить рефанд(у него это получилось))

Чтобы построить дома поблизости – нужно построить дома поблизости, для их строительства применяются свободные люди.

Чтобы было счастье – нужно строить колодцы, строить парки, разнообразие пищи, смывать калл за работягами, убирать трупы и т.п. В этой цепочке столько зданий, что считать невозможно, уж тем более эффективное кол-во людей, сколько это 100? 200? На каждую постройку нужны ресурсы, люди, все упирается в них. Как, в игре про менеджмент и градостроение, эффективные здания - это цель не номер 1? Первичная – это прожить данный год. Во многих подобных играх людей всегда искусственно добавляют, здесь тебе даже торговец не может их привезти, ты просто заперт в своем поселении и никак не можешь повлиять на скорость роста своих людей и, как следствие, количество работников.

При выборе места видна вся карта - как только начинаешь, сразу напускается туман войны, камон, зачем он тут, для чего. Я одобряю туман войны в любом случае, это классная механика в любую игру, добавляет разведку. Однако в этой игре нЕчего разведывать: все стартовые биомы, все ресурсы, все дикие животные, все болезни – все это доступно на стартовом спавне, это же будет и в темном темном тумане. Плюс, я вижу всю карту в самом начале при выборе точки спавна.

В игре есть воины, оборонительные башни и стены, однако вашим врагом будут варвары, которые спавнятся где захотят, воруют ваши пожитки и убегают. Каждый воин – это обычный работяга, которого научили воевать, не в военное время он ничего не делает, он не улучшается, не тушит пожар, он просто я. Им можно только разведывать территорию и бить диких животных, которые тоже непостоянные, а в зависимости от сезона года могут появиться или исчезнуть. Если разработчик выбрал такой сеттинг, то варвары как будто лишнее, либо стоило добавить другие поселения(иначе зачем стены с башнями?). Кстати, менеджмента с воинами вообще нет, я не могу даже кнопкой выбрать всех воинов, только отдельно всех лучников или мечников, не могу выделить конкретных юнитов в группу и выбирать по hotkey, нет "удерживать позицию" или "защищать точку" и т.п. TL;DR - It's a nice but short game with quite a generic feeling. Newbies, beware: no tutorial. If developers keep adding features, it can become a good, distinct game, but it now feels more like a basic settlement-building blueprint.

It is a nice game, indeed, as other reviews state, very close to Farthest Frontier, with some aspects more emphasised and less emphasised.
Warning: There's no tutorial. If you've ever played this type of game, you'll know what you're doing. If it's your first game in this genre - you won't have a good time in the beginning.

To me, the game feels more like an Early Access base template for a settlement-building game. I didn't encounter any significant bugs that unassigning and assigning back people to a building or trade wouldn't fix (I'm looking at you, vanishing archers).
The only major thing that disturbed my game was bandits getting spotted only when they were already inside the walls of my settlement. Either they spawned inside, or my settlers were blind - there were gatherers and hunters beyond the gate they'd have to enter through. Any kind of watchtower could help - like a basic structure (that employs 1-2 settlers without the need for archer barracks, who can shoot arrows but less proficiently than military archers, and perhaps reduce nonexistent crime?), which could raise the alarm and close gate(s) automatically.

The game entertained me for a few hours (6?), but it didn't feel much like a challenge after unlocking and building most of the buildings. There are games with more complex resource supply chains, there are games with more complex combat (here you only have 2 unit types - swordsman and archers, enemy bandits only have 1 melee type unit). There's not much left to do in the late game beyond making more archers and towers and fixing damage after earthquakes.

i love this game and do recommend it, i just wish there were a few adjustments.

first off the game looks great, runs great, feels great, very good UI. non intrusive pop ups etc. its a great colony sim rts.

however there are things ive found to be a complete turn off when playing the game.

builder/laborers. why do these jobs give the most trouble? its like they spend too much time walking around, they don't focus the right storage containers or buildings, they don't help supply or unload resources other than for building.

So you'll have a house on build priority 1, but theres no wood in storage, however even if you have trees/rocks selected to chop down or collect, the laborers don't actively pursue the resources for the buildings, you kinda have to re-assign roles to get them to start working in proper order.

then also How time moves in this game make 0 sense at all. (biggest complaint

for instance a level 1 house is a 2x3 sized object, for a single villager to walk past 4 houses in distance/units, the world would have already went thru 4 day cycles in the game.

now you may think oh the time moves fast on x4 speed, great! well not really because your villagers AGE.

so this causes villagers to expire faster, while their labor output essentially remains the same.

realistically a villager should not age by half a year by the time they move from their job to storage and back home.

it just doesn't feel good to watch a guy quite literally die of old age because time moves waaay too fast compared to the villager actions/production value.

On top of that, there needs to be some kind of adjustment to the way the game scales population/food. Right now at level 1 pre 50 population, you can only build a gathering hut (gathers raw food/medicine from plants), hunter cabin for wild animals, and a fishing dock. NONE of these are enough or sustainable to eventually work up to other forms of food production, and thats because all these avenues of food gathering predicate on pre-generated resource nodes you may or may not be lucky enough to spawn next to/with.

So with that it mind, once you start building enough houses to house more people so that you can unlock more buildings, you will become bottle necked by food scarcity, you will have a major famine, and you will lose almost 40% of the time.

Definitely needs the early game fleshed out more, it just feels like theres no where to really go before you hit lvl 2 and above.

I got this game on sale for €12.01, and overall, it's not bad, but it feels like a work-in-progress rather than a fully polished release. The graphics are quite nice, and I appreciate the use of AI, which adds a bit of charm to the game. However, the speed of time progression and the movement of people are painfully slow, which detracts from the experience.

Combat is underwhelming—it's boring, easy, and doesn't offer much excitement or challenge. Resource management could use an upgrade, as it feels overly simplified, and the building mechanics, especially with the second level of the town center and houses, make the game feel more like a version 0.5 than a 1.0 release.

That said, the game does show promise. The developers are heading in the right direction, but they need to expand on the content and refine the mechanics significantly. I hope they add a lot more to this game before moving on to a sequel or another project. With more updates and polish, Settlements Rising could become a solid city-building experience.

Would I recommend it? Maybe, but only on sale, and only if you’re okay with something that feels incomplete

Ok, so it's definitely a good game and worth the money, if you like builders/colony sims.

I should disclose I had about 10 crashes over the 20+ hours I played. I fixed them by reloading the autosave and saving to a new slot.

I should also praise the developer for quickly addressing some feedback I had, the most notable one being the earthquakes. Prior to my suggesion, and earthquake would destroy buildings, you'd get a message at the end about what was destroyed and then it was up to you to find those locations and figure out what needed rebuilding. Not ideal, to say the least. Well, within a couple of hours of my suggesion, the dev implemented the usual system in such games, where destroyed buldings left an automatic order for rebuilding. That helped me A LOT in the end game where an earthquake destroyed about 30 buildings (the biggest catastrophe I had in the game).

All said, the game doesn't add much innovation in the genre, but what it does - it does very well. Besides building, you can defend from raids, you can go on exploration missions with ships (nothing fancy, you click and then there's a chance after a few minutes to succeed and get rewards), you can trade with about 7-8 other settlements via ship trading menu once you've discovered them. There are nifty "enhancement cards" you can use on your buildings. You get them every so often after enough people have been born or immigrated. Reminded me of "Kingdoms Reborn", if you've played that game.

The game is well optimized. At 500+ population (and you don't need much more than that), it ran seamlessly, and I don't have a very good computer.

Give it a go if you're a fan of such games, you will not be disappointed.

Неплохой градострой, брал по скидке за ~400р.
Из плюсов:
+ Играется легко, на базовом уровне все понятно и нету странных усложнений, строй домики и расширяй то что твой город производит, часть потребляют сами жители, излишки продавай, недостающие докупай.
+ Интерфейс и взаимодействие довольно удобные, не помню чтобы были какие-то моменты которые ты не понимаешь что и почему произошло.
+ В целом неплохая и простенькая графика.
Из минусов:
- На данный момент до потолка можно дойти очень быстро, мне хватило 5 часов чтобы выстроить мощную оборону, довести кол-во жителей до ~200 и построить все возможные постройки, а после этого играть будто бы особого смысла нет, только если вам нравится расширять город просто ради расширения города, без каких-то новых механик и пр.
- ИИ налетчиков максимально туповат, вместо того чтобы тренировать большую армию лучшее решение сделать килбокс и поставить туда побольше башен с лучниками. Много лучников при желании можно даже не делать. Ворота открываются и враги игнорируя расстояние и какую-либо целесообразность бегут туда, закрываешь и открываешь другие, враги бегут к ним. Из-за чего эта механика очень быстро перестает быть какой-либо проблемой.
- Система карточек интересная, но стоит либо изменить сами карточки, либо то как они получаются. Например уменьшить их бонусы, но чтобы он давался навсегда. Ибо за всю игру я получил около ~6-7 карточек, из которых реально хоть немного полезными была разве что одна, на еду когда с ней были небольшие проблемы. Сделать большую часть карточек временными - наверное самый большой недостаток этой механики. Какая карточка лучше? 75% производства вина в одной постройке на 4 года или +500 вина сразу?(которую кстати можно отложить и использовать в любой момент) Ответ очевиден (Карточка кстати в постройке остается навсегда и ее никак нельзя оттуда убрать, при сносе здания карточка тоже исчезает)
- Туман войны просто бессмысленнен, не понимаю зачем он нужен (тем более если всю карту ты изначально видишь когда выбираешь место для центра города).
- Не хватает графиков по производству конкретных ресурсов и более подробной статистики по производству из конкретных построек.
- Очень нужна более четкая визуальная разница между обычными домиками и некоторыми производственными зданиями, когда город большой приходится тыкать каждый домик чтобы вспомнить где именно у тебя стоит хижина сборщика. (Самый простой и удобный способ это сделать - разный цвет крыши у разных построек)

По итогу обзор скорее средний, но игра будто бы оставила скорее положительное впечатление, не было того что прямо сильно испортило впечатление, большая часть минусов это скорее пожелания.
Самый большой минус из всех вышеописанных это все же количество контента в игре, если разработчик выполнит свое обещание и не забросит игру, то она точно стоит своих денег.

P.S. Хоть игра и версии 1.0 сейчас, я бы сказал что это все еще ранний доступ и скорее всего решение разработчика выпустить игру в релиз было сделано точно по той же причине по которой огромное число разработчиков последнее время делает точно также (Чтобы мгновенно сделать большое количество продаж, да и люди охотнее покупают и играют в релизные версии нежели в ранний доступ, даже если по факту контента в игре как в раннем доступе)

I enjoyed this game. It's relatively short does not bring anything new to the table, but stable and competently executed. When I said short - it's right size for what it is, anything longer would not be able to keep my interest. Clean UI, easy to understand.

Many games in the genre rubber-band you so it is not possible to get over the hump. I understand why they do it, because for many players once you got over the hump it's no longer interesting, so to keep it interesting you are being rubber-banded. I prefer when the game allows you to snowball, it's an acknowledgement that you did something right and feels good.

I probably would be frustrated by the enemy waves, if I have not read this on the discord: Build a wall to isolate your settlement with enough gates, if there are not enough and the enemy spawns far from a gate, they will breach the wall instead. Now close all the gates but one which should be not too far from the enemy. As the enemy reaches the gate close it and open another one - they will go there. You can rinse and repeat. While they are doing it pick them up one by one with archers towers along the wall and militia. To repeat: I liked this bit, if the enemy would randomly breach and then head to the centre of the town, it would have been frustrating.

Speaking of Discord - the dev is responding to questions there and taking feedback, but otherwise it's quite empty, not enough of player base to keep the discussion going, and no one but dev is actually answering the questions. Which is fine by me, just a headups if you are expecting a thriving community.

There are a lot of small issues, but more often than not they do not matter, I probably counted a dozen. Here is the most severe one, so you could gauge the magnitude of it:

When you build a building in the game, the building is build by builder but for them to start labourers need to clean the building site first. Unfortunately the labourers do not prioritise cleaning those building site, and your building can sit there for half an hour in real time, because your labourers are doing something else. You can mark a building as a build priority, but that also only affecting the builders not the labourers. This is quite annoying. The best way to overcome this, for me was, if I could afford it, to convert some other professions temporarily to labourers, so that there is more probability that _someone_ picks up the task I need.

The end game has a trade system, which allows to trade away the surpluses and get something that you need but do not have. Although it's not without flaws I liked it, because it gives an alternative way to complete your goal.

And speaking of goals: there is no win condition: once you've build everything and you see that your colony is sustainable, this is it.

Just finished the first level. For anyone who is already a programmer and understands how software engineering works at a basic level this game is basically LEETCODE in game form (Which is really insanely cool and got me to code for an hour straight today)

For some background I have been a full stack developer for about 7 years mainly working on web dev projects. I know a lot of JS some C# some LUA and now thanks to this game ill be able to add python to that list. So far this game has been helping me understand pythons very strange syntax.

I really do recommend this game to anyone REALLY looking to get into programming but not so much for someone who just does it as a hobby.

For someone who doesnt understand what a variable or an object is you might have a hard time understanding the core concepts. Every item in the game has some variables that are publicly available to use (Meaning code from outside of the objects code can alter them) and your goal is to basically utilize these variables to complete a task. It may take you awhile to grasp this concept but this game does a pretty good job of teaching it in my honest opinion.

I will try and update this later as ive only completed the tutorial and the first level (Please note the first level only took me an hour because i wanted to try and perfect it for the extra points which was where the REAL difficulty kicked in) but so far as of level 1 i gotta say ill probably be playing this daily until i complete it.

Positives:
Fun so far!
Lots of replay value if you go back to improve your prior solutions or rework other player's solutions to get an even higher score etc.
Pretty nice looking
Create your own scenarios!

Negatives:
I lost a little bit of time on silly things to do with the mechanics of the game itself, e.g. the lack of visual indicator whether the arm has grabbed the item (though you get used to this and it has a property you can monitor), the fact that if you reset the game state (to get the best time) in your code, positions may be registered prior to game initialisation.

I felt that the challenge increase was reasonable up to "triangulation", then it became quite a bit harder with the game not providing enough guidance, requiring watching the first couple of minutes of a video tutorial.

I have a few wishes that may or may not be addressed eventually: please let me reduce the GUI scaling and unlock the camera from the selected item, and not change my selections when selecting something else etc. You have to fight the controls a lot, though this does direct you to use print statements or the debugger, the speed of starting the python code is quite slow just to quickly test things.

I've only just started, but I already know I'll love this (in that special way software engineers love their work - by constantly seeming mad at it, and yet somehow never giving up 😂) Overall, really nicely put together - very obvious this was a labour of love❤️

A couple of little things I've noticed (which I'm pointing out for the dev, mostly):
The in-game code-editor is bugging me man... it seems to be like 250ms behind me at all times (esp. when trying to highlight code), and the auto-indenting is occasionally annoying (bro why you indenting my elif to the inner-level when I backspaced to the outer one?)
The code editor is resizeable (nice), but the Run/Stop/Clear buttons don't appear to be anchored to the bounds of the window properly, and can end up outside it.




Strong 7 to light 8 for me - and given it's just come out of EA, I reckon it's only a handful of decent patches from a strong 8, perhaps even into 9s territory. It's honestly impressive this works at all, let alone how well it does - I can only how much work went into creating and wiring up the various parts of the simulation environment.

If you already code even a bit - this one is a no-brainer.
Hell, even if you don't but are interested in it - you'll struggle at first, but this should be a fun way to learn 🙂

My favorite programming game !

There are sometimes a few bugs but none that prevent from playing the game.
I would also say the game would be very difficult for a total beginner in programming and there are very few levels that are really "easy". Most of the levels are hard (or very hard) and there isn't a solution available for every level. However, this really forces the player to use his brain in order to find solutions.
I would also like to see challenges that require the use of classes instead of just functions.
Nonetheless, this game is definitely worth every penny and if you're into programming, you should buy it without hesitation !

It's hard for me to decide on whether to actually recommend this game or not. I don't know ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about coding but I do have some experience in scripting. While I am glad to try this game out, I don't see myself coming back too often or at all just yet. The learning-curve is actually insane for new people like me. Yes, the dev makes you fully aware that this game is difficult and that SOME prior programming knowledge is recommended/preferred.

However, this is my first introduction game into learning coding involving puzzles. I'm super grateful that the dev has gone out of their way to make video tutorials if you can't solve a level when you get stuck or don't know where to start. Major kudos to that.

My whole playtime is just only making it through the tutorial levels. Once you finish a level and advanced to a real one, the difficulty and assets are increased by a BIG margin as you are EXPECTED to remember every detail of what you learned in the tutorials. This is the biggest drawback for me because; a tutorial level could consist of a few conveyor belts that challenges you to figure out how to move only a certain maximum number of them. Now once you finish that tutorial level and move onto a real level, there will be trigger zones, multiple different objects that you need to navigate in all separate directions, an object spawner and an already provided code for displaying a timer since the level includes an extra challenge of completing the puzzle in a certain time frame. A good incentive to keep learning but a horrible choice to throw in for newcomers and why it was necessary to be needed in the first beginning level.

The game CAN be fun but only for experienced people. The general best way people learn are from repetition. And this game has none of that. You definitely throw yourself in the fire when the dev walks you through the video tutorial because there are lots of other terms and variable types you didn't even know existed that you can use AND when semicolons should be used in your code (this is never explained. You have to eye-ball this detail when reviewing if your code is even right when you think you've written it exactly as the dev has) So after that I practically gave up.

The dev encourages you to learn but it's executed poorly. If there was repetition and better ways of having players know what and when to use for their codes, then I think I would've done a LOT better and feel more comfortable getting into the coding world. I like this game, there is a lot to it with great depth, but I'm unable to move forward with it.

Великолепная задумка и отличная реализация! И даже стоит купить, чтобы поддержать автора в столь прекрасном проекте, но пока есть несколько критических замечаний для разработчика:
1. Язык. В игре, например, на русский переведены только сами задания в чек-листе и меню. Ни контекстная справка, ни объяснения заданий не переведены. Облегчает ситуацию то, что объяснение в видео можно поставить на паузу и "полезть в словарь", или также поискать перевод материала из справочника, но по всем заданиям есть таймер (к счастью, не обратного отсчета) и время отнимается на поиск перевода.
Рекомендация: Сделайте контекстный перевод по клику хотя бы на отельные слова. Это проще чем переводить все и проверять, тем более что контекстная справка по словам уже есть, так почему бы не добавить туда и перевод?
2. Нет плавности в развитии сложности игры -- сначала просто, потом чуть сложнее, а потом класс задач резко повышается. Для обучения так не комфортно, может пропасть интерес. Это игра действительно в текущем виде не для тех, кто хочет НАЧАТЬ учиться программировать, а для тех, кто УЖЕ умеет.

I really wanted to like this. I like the concept of slapping a Python interpreter into a game and using actual code to manipulate the objects in the game to solve puzzles.

But, I played for a few hours (repeated a few puzzles because I can't properly kill the game on my laptop to trigger a cloud save sync), and I'm just not sure who this is meant for.

I don't see how this is useful for engineers. Maybe I didn't get deep enough into it. But, one of the beautiful parts about programming is that you can usually get set up and tinker with random ♥♥♥♥ that's new to you without investing any monetary cost. Anyone who wants to learn a real game engine can just download Unreal or Unity, spend a few hours on free online tutorials, and just go build something or follow a dirt-cheap Udemy course. So, maybe the purpose is to just screw around and have fun. For me, the general jank of the game didn't make it very enjoyable.

For non-engineers who actually want to learn programming, I don't feel like this is a good introduction. Again, I think there's a very cool concept here. By writing Python within the actual game, it lets players focus on the act of writing code (and the effects of that code) without having to deal with the mental overload of dealing with a full game engine. And while the C family of languages is more valuable in the game space, Python has always felt like the best starter for people who are new to programming.

Problem with recommending this to the latter group is that I'm kinda baffled by the execution. Yes, there are a few levels where you can manipulate objects by clicking them and setting parameters on a drop-down. That's good. It leads naturally to manipulating those objects in code. The first few levels ease you into things through that mechanism. Once you start having to write code, they explain basic concepts like "if" statements and "for" loops. There are basic details left out (like the fact that Python is strict about its whitespace), but the example code gives enough context for a newbie to deal with those.

I feel like the game loses teaching value after that. It moves to puzzles where you have to do vector math. The game doesn't even pretend to teach you what a vector even is. You just end up in a puzzle that needs it. A newbie could do some googling and figure it out eventually. But at that point, I feel like you'd be better suited to just do an actual Python tutorial. There's some neat ones out there that teach this stuff far better.

Getting back to the topic of jank, the vector part is especially egregious to me. The game does a bad job of informing you what the axes and coordinate systems are are. I click on a conveyor belt for the first time. I know if I input a positive number for the speed, it will go forward. If I input a negative number, it will go backward. Why can't I see which direction is which? I just have to guess via trial and error. Eventually, I get to a puzzle with more belts. At that point, I can see the awfully rendered direction arrows and know which is which. But, I needed to see those in the first conveyer belt puzzle. Visual polish would go a long way here.

That same problem carries on when you're trying to position objects in 3D. Some functions need input based on absolute positions. Other functions only take inputs on relative positions. And the game's documentation makes zero effort to explain what "relative" means for a given object. It just boils down to trial-and-error to figure out what the inputs are actually supposed to be.

I tapped out at that point. The ability to visualize coordinate frames and positional grids are basic QOL features that any game engine would be crucified for excluding. To be clear, the game *does* have some of that information. But its rendered poorly when it does exist. Add that to bugs and some further jank in the camera, UI, and physics, and I just wasn't having fun.

I didn't get far, so maybe it gets better later. But I can't see who I would recommend this to.

I do think this is a good Python programming simulator, but, if you're a beginner, you might want to come into this with a drive to learn new things on your own outside of the game. The levels have themes to them that are supposed to be approached with their respective concept in computer science. If it is a new concept - you're probably going to have to do research on your own or watch the tutorial (not all levels have them). If you've never programmed anything, I might try playing around with some Python on your system before getting this (it's easy to set up and learn basics with info online, and this game's tutorials don't cover much).

A large part is learning and exploring this specific game's Python library as well. This is good practice for learning the syntax of a library and reading the documentation.( There is documentation linked from in game to your browser). And a nice thing- there are detailed in game drop downs with code snippets for many of the in game functions and classes.

The game restricts you from using some features that surprised me a little bit at first. Mainly the 'global' keyword, which makes some things harder at least for a noob like me. But that brought me to research why global is frowned upon if used too much. So like I said the game gives you reasons to research these things on your own. It also restricts 'sys', some other keywords, you get the picture. But, there's always a solution to the levels regardless.

Do I think this game is for someone who knows NOTHING? No. Like I said, maybe try Python first. Unless you only want to play the tutorial and SOME 'easy'(levels are marked by difficulty) levels. I'm not going to lie - I think you should AT LEAST have over 50 hours of programming at least *something* to get the *full value* out of this game, even if it's small like a Scratch game (MIT educational game engine). (And even then, you're going to be googling if you never touched Python!)
For context: I have less than 6 months experience programming, and I am in the top 90th percentile of a 'medium' difficulty 'logistics' problem for execution speed, but 'hard' problems are crazy hard for me to grasp at this point. (Yes, there are leaderboards, and you can even share your code on the leaderboards!)

Does the game have bugs? Kinda. Sometimes, for example, an xy axis overlay wont load, or the lighting will be weird, but reloading the level fixes it. Sometimes if you reset the environment and run your code in quick succession , everything hasn't fully spawned. I had a save issue with my code once as well. So maybe keep your code on your clipboard before exiting. Nothing major other than that. Also I have an inkling the game may run heavy on memory use, so don't expect to be running many things alongside this game, it may just be me though.

Overall, I definitely think there's a lot to do in the simulator and you can sink some real time into this and get a little more programming experience, which is always good. Pick it up if you're learning computer science!

So, what to say about this game? Is it even a game?
Its essentially a physics simulation with a plugged on python interface and some (pretty hefty) tasks. The art style and set-up embraces and pushes a feel of realism. Yet, that kind of "brute-simplicity" is what i love about the game and what gives it its unique and powerful style. Like, why didnt anyone do that before?

What makes it different than other great problem-solving games? Tbf, I do somewhat miss the strangely-beautiful placed background stories of zach-likes which add alot to the immersion to help me suspend disbelieve. But is that perhaps by choice? With the only point of story-telling being, that every time i have to start the game inside the game again? Is this genius move or just an artifact?
On the other hand, it still works for me, since i still feel quite proud after solving a task.
The game can be really fun at times. Playing around with the objects or watching the drone do exactly what i told it to while rather silly and adorably failing at the task had me crack up a quite a few times. Most of the time its ofcourse challenging and somewhat frustrating, yet satisfying to solve a task in the end.

So, is it even a game?
Well, to me it is (GOTY). With its unique and innovative way of exploiting inderterministic physics simulation (every simulation run is different) it stretches and breaks the boundraries of existing puzzle/programing games and gives me this new kind of head aches. Adding (and teaching) a real-world programming language into the mix makes it usefull to me and a pioneering educational game for others.

Thats why i can recommend it to anyone who likes to learn some coding or who likes a little coding challenge.

If you're ever playing Factorio and wishing that you could just import numpy instead of fussing with combinators, then this game may be for you.

This game is a set of physics simulation puzzles that are solved by writing Python scripts. What you receive is a neat sandbox in which to test and debug your solutions. The game is a bit janky, as will be your ostensible solutions, no doubt. For the bugs that exist, you can even send in a pull request to https://github.com/maschere/pyjop/tree/main/pyjop, a fact that makes this simulation hit perhaps a bit too close to home for the work of software development.

While the challenge and sometimes tedium of programming remain in this simulation, what you won't find are strict deadlines, project cancellations, micromanaging, or some of the other potential frustrations of software development in situ. While for those new to programming, this may indeed be one of the most challenging games on Steam, those who have accumulated many thousands of hours in the craft may find it relaxing akin to a cozy game like Stardew Valley.

Even after just one hour of playing, it is clear that this project is a labor of love by the creator Dr. Maximilian Scherer.

PS: If you check the GitHub for pyjob (the interface for this game), one of the recent commits reads "1.0 WIP", showing that sometimes you just have to ship it.

Overview
This game is really awesome, as long as you have a decent head on your shoulders about Object-Oriented Programming, and at least the basic syntax of python. This game is not necessarily about learning python, and more about challenging and shaping the way you think and solve issues. I won't say you need an advanced knowledge of python, because this basically runs a psuedo-custom version anyways. In fact, it may be better if you don't have advanced knowledge, because trying to do things the way you think they would be done will lead to errors about functions not being subscriptable 8/10 times.

It runs pretty well. Upgrades aren't really gated, so you can unlock whatever is important to you in whatever order you feel like (for the most part). Really awesome concept for a game in the first place. The challenges are really unique, and present great opportunities to not only solve the challenge, but also how to get all of the required information to solve the challenge.

Solving the challenge "the right way" will get you on the leaderboard. The good news is, you only need to do it once for each achievement at most. The bad news is the leaderboard is completely focused on "optimizations", or whittling your code down to the barest of bones. This means you completely ignore any best practices or ways to actually solve the challenge in favor of putting all your code in one line with as few calls and commands as possible, and basically no variables. This also means a lot of times that your best score will be heavily reliant on RNG, so good luck. Also the assistant is basically useless, and in-game documentation is lacking. You can click the link to open full documentation in the browser, but that really seems to be more of things work at a library level, rather than documentation of functions and methods available to you while solving puzzles.

This game is fun, and it's a real brain scratcher most of the time. Now that I've managed to get a second place run early on, I'll focus on solving the rest of the challenges the "correct" way, and come back for the last achievement later. I would to see a separate scoring system for "correct" implementation, maybe with a focus on repeatability? Say, number of times completed out of 10 runs, with a score ceiling on lines of code, perhaps?

Reminds me of my Python programming experience during my degree

"I like the way this sucks!"

Just be aware that this game is more towards someone who has some experience in coding than someone who wants to start coding. The game immediately expects you to do stuff after some basic tutorials, and the in-game tutorials is just not enough for that. You'd definitely need to seek external sources like W3Schools if you're someone who isn't familiar with coding. Hell I'd even recommend you to code using your own IDE to catch some errors along the way (the game supports coding using your own IDE, though I haven't tried it yet).

This is absolutely not for everyone. Make sure you're really into programming before getting this.

I really wanted to like this game because it combines two of my favorite things - video games and programming; however, the game's current state is too buggy to be enjoyable. Throughout the tutorial and first level, buttons would stop working until I restarted the game, game would be choppy or slow for too long after starting each level (my specs are well above recommended, r5 5600 and rx6750), and in-game code running after it was removed (tried restarting the level, resetting the code, and completing the level, but none of those worked until i restarted the game). My biggest issue, though, was that the game didn't work properly until I had to restart it. I spent quite a while on the first level after the tutorials because the RFID functions of the scanners just weren't there and trying to call them using the code returned that they weren't available, so I assumed I had to use distance only. Spent over 45 minutes doing that until I realized that the buttons in the code editor didn't work either. After restarting the game, the RFID functions magically appeared under the scanners and the code editor buttons worked. Wasted so much time because of that. Again, I really wanted to like this game, but these simple bugs just left a bad taste in my mouth. I may revisit again in the future.

Game was better in earlier releases before they made it super competitive.

The addition of extra objectives for partners to complete makes the game much more one-sided, given that the objective of the worm is still to just kill the partners, but the effort needed to escape increases exponentially with the number of partners. Some of these objectives, like herding, and finding the train key appear to not even work correctly in the latest build.

The group I'm in decided to pick this up after about a year of not playing it to see what has changed. We had 4 partners and 1 worm. There were 5 objectives that the partners had to complete, two of which being the classic objectives of finding the key and fueling the train.

The other objectives were:
- Herding
- Repairing the track
- Delivering sarsparilla

The person who decided to take on the herding objective found the flower required, as well as the cattlebug, but no matter what they did, they weren't able to get the cattlebug to follow them. They were holding the flower, and no interact button was appearing on the cattlebug. Likewise, walking away while holding the flower did nothing to get the cattlebug to follow them.

The person doing the second objective discovered that it was actually the most difficult of these three (save the for first being impossible to complete). To repair the track, you need to blow up structures with dynamite to get parts. It takes 1 part for each segment of track that needs repaired, and each structure yields 1 part. We had 6 segments of track to repair. The quarry, where dynamite spawns was in one corner of the map, while the town, where all the structures were was in the opposite corner of the map. One person would never be able to complete this, and blowing up the train cars, the previous iteration of this objective, was already difficult enough with even a slightly skilled worm.

I attempted to handle the third objective and to my horror, it appears that once you are carrying the sarsparilla, you can't put it down. Dropping the sarsparilla causes bottles to break. If all the bottles in the case break, you have to get another case to deliver. If you are carrying a case when the worm grabs you, the case violently flys out of your hands and a large number of the bottles break - in my case, it appeared to be all of them. Again, this objective seems extremely difficult to successfully complete given that the only way to reliably avoid the worm when you are being actively chased is to grab onto structures and rocks, which you can't do if you're carrying the sarsparilla, which you can't drop unless you want to break some of the bottles - see the problem? To add to this, there appears to be a limited number of cases on the map. It doesn't look like more spawn in if you start to run out, so I guess it's just possible to fail this objective.

== From a worm perspective ==

The developer claimed to have fixed and/or removed sandstorms. While I did not have any issues with them as a partner, it appears that in the latest build, they are still in the game, unchanged since their initial release.

The ability that lets you create a conical wall to enclose players with received an extremely strong buff some time between when we stopped playing and now. Now it's just objectively one of the powers the worm should always have equipped. In the past, it started off as disparate segments of a wall that would slowly close to encircle the partner. Now it's just an extremely high, continuous (no breaks or gaps), somewhat large diameter circular wall that encloses the partner as soon as the power is used. It is very possible with this iteration to trap multiple partners, and they have **no means of escape**. The only way out of it is to avoid being eaten, which even if the diameter has been increased over a fully enclosed wall of the previous iteration, it's still small enough to where the worm should easily be able to kill at least one partner inside.

Heart jars also now apparently have a 90 second cooldown? That is to say, in games with multiple partners, heart jars will now take 90 seconds (this may be configurable) to spawn from the second a partner dies. The jar does not spawn immediately, and partners must now dodge the worm until the jar spawns. I suppose this change was made to validate the hard work of killing a partner, but tunneling is still a valid strategy the worm can employ without any penalty whatsoever. All this change does is serve to punish partners for dying.

Also, the instructions in the in-game manual for partners in general seem to be incomplete and/or incorrect.

I would have recommended this game in the past, but in this iteration, it's a hard pass. It appears to be trying to pass itself off as a serious competitive level asymmetric multiplayer game like Dead By Daylight, and I don't think it's working for it. I was hoping this game would remain a mostly chill, sometimes tense game to play, but given that the devs (probably with pressure from a small portion of the community) decided to ramp up the competitiveness of the game to maximum overdrive, I'm not interested in playing it anymore. It just isn't fun anymore.

I tried to play, but you can't play without other players. I went to the server list and there were no public servers. I went to "play private game", then converted it to a public server. I left it up for almost 10 minutes. No one joined. Unless you have a group of friends who are willing to also buy the game, you are unlikely to get any playtime/value out of this one.
Further, even though the game recognizes both mouse/keyboard and controller, it doesn't let you play two players against each other locally. Since it's pretty rare now to have a bunch of people local together on a LAN all having computers, and since this game doesn't have a community ready to play, I am going to say DEFINITE NO on this game. It doesn't give expected value for the purchase.
I'm not returning it because it could easily be a good game if I could actually find people to play with, but until the community grows to where you can find a game as a lone player (or the dev adds some basic NPCs for single), this will remain a negative review.
Other: I checked back and there were two games. However, on spectating, while it looked like people were playing, they were both the same map. Also, I didn't see a way to have multiple people play splitscreen locally (I have multiple controllers + keyboard). So you have to have a bunch of people you know with the game, each with their own copy, and you'd have to schedule a time with them to play as there aren't many games up and those are pretty long.

This game was fun for a while, but a couple things ruined it pretty fast:
-- steep learning curve on only one mode of gameplay that gets repetitive as soon as you learn enough to play it
-- the game is only fun if you have 6+ friends on at once, and if you want to play publicly, well
-- almost no public games (if there is one, it ends in an hour and half the time everyone leaves before you can play)
-- no updates

About the gameplay and my first point:
-- not enough powers, quests
-- Worm is overpowered unless you have very experienced pardners, and at that point quests are memorized and it gets very repetitive

If you join the discord, there's a very small active community and
-- they're mean or have thousands of hours in the game. It's not fun playing with them.

I've talked to the devs about all of these problems and they don't care -- they are working on another game. If this game had large updates, more players, and more game-modes, it would be worth the money. But as it stands, this game is good for 2 playthroughs and then it will be collecting dust :(

I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you
