This is a conflicting game for me. In concept it is an incredibly fun game, if incredibly grindy in places, however the thing that kind of ruins it is its balancing. It isn't balanced at all.

The game is open to solo or group play, but in reality it is not solo friendly AT ALL. The first dozen or so quests are doable but after that forget it. If you aren't in a group you will just get slaughtered over and over. You will get a mission the texts says is simple, you go to the location and half a dozen vessels bigger than yours with mini guns will spawn literally around you and sink you in seconds, irrespective of what weapons you have or platings, or insta-repair kits its just a bit of a mess. At other times things called courier (like a world boss) will cross your path, other times enemies will literally just spawn on top of you literally giving you no chance to react, manoeuvre or defend, its sort of a mess.

Also you have other people running around as its a multiplayer game, which means you also have to contend with their spawns on top of your own at times, additionally you can be doing a mission and have other people suddenly blowing up your targets which can take xp and loot from you as you do not get loot for an "assist" even when that assist is one of your own missions mobs.
There are also random spawning mobs and POI's on the map that can literally spawn right on top of you whether you are in the middle of a quest or not.
And running isn't all that easier either as only flimsy ships go fast and even then they can only boost for a limited amount of time and enemies seemingly have no limit on their boosts and will follow you relentlessly all the while hitting you with you never really ever outdistancing them.

The other thing is shipbuilding. Everyone wants bigger and better ships and you will see other players with them. You begin with a Dinghy, you quickly get a second ship (choice of two) and a quest later will get you a third, that ends up being worse than your second ship. As part of developing a base you get you will have a ship yards etc.. and can get a shipbuilder npc who tells you if you can kill the crew on an enemy ship and take out the helm you can board an enemy ship and take it for your own and if you bring it back to them you will then be able to make that hull of ship from then on. Cool right? not so much...

This system is itself a little bit of a p.i.t.a as firstly actually shooting the crew and helm of a ship is only really simple on early ships, later ships the helm and the gunners tend to be protected and they will not die before the ships hull itself does and the ships sinks making boarding vessels a pretty difficult prospect on top of that as previously mentioned you then have to contend with many other players wandering by "thinking they are helping you" and shooting your ships thereby preventing you from boarding them by sinking them too I have had this happen countless times.

It is just a janky way of doing things and incredibly frustrating that makes any sort of vessel hull progression impossible outside of dumb luck.

If this game had private or personal servers and the ability to change settings, like difficulty and numbers of enemies etc.. you could avoid most of this stuff but as things stand its just a huge mess, The Devs really need to give some consideration to the fact that a multiplayer game does no inherently mean "grouped" there can and are many solo players in multiplayer games and their game balance needs to take that into consideration, as it stands its a "potentially" good game with so much potential missed due to janky mechanics and poor balancing..and that is a genuine shame.

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
Поиграв на бесплатных выходных могу сказать одно: игра - унылое Г.
Сюжет никакой. Скорее даже немного туповатый. Повествование унылое. ОЧЕНЬ много принеси-подай квестов. Десятки минут ты просто плаваешь от точки до точки и... Всё. Да, постоянно борешься с противником, который выныривает буквально из ниоткуда. Логика тоже отсутствует. Фракция противников - Шарки. В команде у нас - девушка из этого племени. Разработчики предлагают просто всю игру фигачить невинных "акулолюдей", если исходить из их же повествования. Игра - отдельно, сюжет - отдельно. Касаемо плавать от точки к точке - это основа геймплея. Отсюда вытекает главный недостаток (по моим меркам)...
Физика. Предмет, который разработчики в школе прогуливали. Вес катеров (различных) не ощущается как каждого, так и в сравнении - водоизмещение просто вышло из чата. Все катера ускоряются мгновенно до 9-10 единиц скорости, потом набирают свои 20-30-40. Если нужно остановиться, то замедление будет таким же резким, но с непонятным размазанным замедлением. А при переходе за 0, что происходит мгновенно, лодка резко ускоряется до 10 в обратном направлении. Это похоже больше на баг, чем на запланированное поведение катеров. Течения реализованы отвратительно. Скорость течения 15-20, скорость катера 30, значит, если плыть по течению, будет 50? Ну все же в школе учились, точно 50! А вот и нет! Итоговая скорость будет 35, дай бог 40. По этому в течениях нет ни смысла, ни логики (они же ещё просто хаотично размазаны по карте).
Боёвка тоже отвратная, как и стрельба. Если у тебя разные типы вооружения, ты не постреляешь, либо одно, либо другое. Болванчики из экипажа стрелять не умеют, нужно из каждой группы оружия стрелять отдельно самому.
Игра стоит дорого. Внутриигровые покупки - присутствуют. Океан гринда, в котором я захлебнулся. Если бы играть было интересно - можно было бы дать 7/10. Но учитывая всё вышеперечисленное (плохая физика, никчёмный сюжет, неинтересные задания и многое другое), тут 3/10 и то с натягом. Так и хочется вручить авторам учебник физики за 7 класс.

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
Вся игра - один большой пример того, почему "геймдизайнеры" мобильных игр всегда будут в кавычках. Тупое следование общим лекалам, токсичные практики и отсутствие оригинальности - вот, что даёт опыт разработки "игр" для мобильных телефонов. Стаж работы над ними надо как нечто отрицательное рассматривать, потому что этих деятелей потом надо не только с нуля учить игры дизайнить, но ещё и отучивать от той дичи, которую в помойке "рынка мобильных игр" считают чем-то нормальным.
Принести в премиум (для несведущих - она же "buy-to-play", она же "купи и играй", она же, блин, НЕ "free-to-play") игру без микротранзакций массу механик с мобилочек, призванных, вообще-то, целенаправленно раздражать игрока и замедлять его прогресс (дабы подтолкнуть его к покупке микротранзакций) - плохая идея. Внезапно, да?
Прежде, чем добавлять что-то в сию игру, тут надо ножом ампутировать всякую дичь.
Как устроен абордаж (что за игра про водные битвы без абордажа?): сносим с корабля весь экипаж, не потопив его в процессе -уже непростая задача, просто утопить в большинстве случаев проще- после чего подплываем к его тушке и-и-и... Получаем мобилочковую "О нет! В трюме пожар! Нужен огнетушитель или комплект для абордажа , иначе облом на лут!". Это что такое, товарищи? Зачем? Прицельно отстрелять экипаж уже достаточный челлендж сам по себе, это что за... Короче, будь это мобильная F2P игра я бы понял, зачем все эти "комплекты абордажа" (ты плати, плати!), но, какбы, сюрприз - в нормальных играх это дичь. На человеческий абордаж в лице хотя бы миниигры я уже и не расчитываю в наши дни, но вот это вот... В общем, мысль, надеюсь, ясна. В топку все эти ваши копмлекты. Их нельзя купить за реальные деньги, ну так зачем всё это?
Квесты. Квесты ужасны и они повсюду. Они кошмарны. Убоги. Нелепы. Их много и от них не сбежать. Опять же, для мобилочковой игры вести игрока всё время за ручку, как тупенького младенца - норма, но в нормальном обществе за такое, знаете ли, презирают. 90% квестов даже не "убей 5 пиратов и принеси их туши", это вообще "отвези письмо неписю №11". И одно дело, когда такие вот "квесты" на самом деле рандомно генерённые, но тут вся эта тоскливая беготня ! С озвучкой! Да, каждое "О, спасибо за письмо от [непись-отпраитель], вот у меня ещё письмо для [ещё один бессмысленный и беспощадный непись]" ещё и озвучено! Более глупую трату ресурсов разработки для феерически бестолкового выхлопа я даже представить не могу.
Есть строительство базы. Опять, насквозь поражено вирусом мобильного дизайна. Есть "техдерево". Это не техдерево, потому что никакого выбора у игрока нет. Всё открывается строго по порядку, одно за одним, удариться в какое-то направление в ущерб другим невозможно (все "технологии" могут быть только одного тира, новый тир открывается тогда, когда полностью закрыт прошлый). Хуже того. Хочешь открыть новые предметы? КВЕСТ. Квест "сбегай к неписю №14 за финтифлюшкой, он пошлёт тебя за ней к неписю №32, тот скажет, что её украл непись №7 и в итоге будет маленький бой". Повторять для каждой "технологии". Честно, я закончил первый тир и дальше мне уже было так тоскливо... У меня ресурсов хватит на открытие всего второго уже, я бегать туда-сюда устал, дайте мне вместо этих квестов таймер и я буду немного менее задолбавшимся.
Ещё на базе есть верфи. В них можно, эээээ... Собирать новые корабли? А ещё "улучшать" старые, но это можно делать и без верфи. Но если делать это на верфи, то будет -внезапно- ! Интерфейс верфи опять полон лишней дичи и телодвижений. Пока корабль висит на верфи, на нём нельзя выйти в море. Снять его с верфи - один клик. Хочешь поработать над другим кораблём? Сними этот, повесь новый. Два клика. Логично? Логично, ? Если кликнуть по другому кораблю в списке - получишь сообщение "снимите текущий корабль!" с требованием, эм... Нажать на кнопку "снять корабль". Почему нельзя просто снять текущий и повесть другой, не заставляя игрока делать бессмысленные лишние движения - нипанятна. "Шоб у игрока не было непригодных к выходу в море кораблей"? Так, блин, перед выходом в море и проверяй, пригоден кораль, или нет. Просто, ЗАЧЕМ?
Вообще, вот этот вот вопрос "зачем?" у меня возникал постоянно. Зачем абордажные комплекты? Зачем ремонт за пробки, стоящий "походного" ремонта (на тот нужно немного ресурсов, за пробки сумма раз в 50 выше стоимости ресурсов!) и доступный только в избранных портах? Зачем вообще два вида валюты? Зачем разделять два инструмента для добычи -драгу и удочку- когда для смены между ними достаточно просто снять одну и повесить другую (что можно делать в любой момент без ограничений. Ну, покуда желаемый инструмент в трюме)? Зачем мы крафтим оружие из "запчасти пулемёта 1", хотя уже готовый пулемёт дропается чуть не чаще этих запчастей, да и на базе после определённых мучений можно собирать оружие по-человечески из обычных ресурсов? Зачем, зачем, зачем?

Окей, про плохое, вроде, всё, теперь про хорошее. Бои. Да, они слизаны с crossout, но они, блин, работают. Они даже часто весёлые. Они работают (хоть мне и хочется сказать, что "не благодаря, а вопреки"). Собирать свою лодку интересно (хотя пока набор деталей бедноват). В целом игра не вызывает отвращения или чего-то такого, но... Но вот опыт господ геймдизайнеров в работе над "играми" для мобильных устройств торчит отовсюду. Поиграйте, пожалуйста, в нормальные игры, а не "игры", к которым вы привыкли, и уберите всю эту дичь. Не позорьтесь. Иногда "less is more".

Ну и цену надо в два раза снижать, за полную брать я не рекомендую однозначно. За половину... Может быть. Я вот за бесплатные выходные даже с некоторым удовольствием поигрался, но что-то дальше понял, что уже устал от этого симулятора морского почтальона. Жаль, нельзя "нейтральный" отзыв оставить, а так пока будет негативный. Но игра не безнадёжна.
  На этот обзор есть ответ от разработчика

Age of Water is a game with a phenomenal core experience but some of the other bits are a "mixed bag"

I'll leave an actual review at the end; but I want to leave a few points good and bad first:
The AI actually does a decent job and provides a reasonable challenge throughout the majority of the game, however towards the T5 that difficulty does feel to taper off to some degree. However that may be where I am progress wise.

The overall feel of progress feels great for the for the first 3 tiers of hulls. By tier 4 it slows massively and tier 5 gets even worse. It is more than manageable but does a less than great job at keeping you feeling engaged at the later stage.

The pacing isn't too extreme or too slow but there is a that grind does feel like it starts to set in. The game at points can feel slow as there are some parts where you're forced to do random delivery jobs, kill groups of enemies, do convoys, etc. to level and progress without a core quest giving real purpose. (This may be on me as I avoided some mission types I disliked and eventually was forced to do them.)

The Gold Edition (I own this version) I feel provides an extremely negative outside image of this game by making it appear to be pay to win to a casual outsider who only checks reddit.
The medallions given are mainly for cosmetics but temporary damage boosts, hull repairs, boarding kits, etc. can be bought with them as well which some may argue is a P2W advantage. I disagree as the medallions given are so few it barely matters and there is NO option to purchase additional medallions they must be earned. I feel like a number of people will see a Gaijin published game with a price tag that has a currency attached to it and assume its P2W like a few of the publishers other titles. (I attempted to explain this as a War Thunder and Crossout player)
The PVP is separate and entirely optional if you want to engage with it and interact with it that is entirely up to you which I love. I don't mind PvP but sometimes I just want to mindlessly farm and not worry about someone sneaking up and melting me. So the fact you are given a large choice how you play and how you earn has made me love the variety of gameplay.
I have high hopes for this title as long as it is maintained and updated with content because there is so much to love; but I am afraid it may have a negative stigma attached to it due to the publisher and premium edition existing.

Overall I think the game is more than worth a try; it provides a truly enjoyable experience at its current state.

I bought this game Thurs Jan 16 in the evening ours around 8pm. This is important when you look at my current hours in game while writing this review. If I was on your side of this that would tell me a lot about the game.

So what is AoW?
Well it is NOT Atlas. It is NOT a Survival game. AoW is a MMO PVE game where you can CHOOSE PVP if that is what you want and only if you want it. Other than that you can see there is hours of enjoyment in the game. Solo play is 1,000% possible yes you read that right. I have played solo much of the time so far. I have a friend that bought the game too but often we do our own thing and maybe share some of the tougher battles.

Performance, well at the end of this review I will share something many do not, my PC Specs as Steam sees them. From what I have noticed my FPS has never been under 100. I have game on Ultra everything in 2k. Never really seen any performance issues that were lasting. Yes at prime gaming times you get the Latency warning but to be expected with the crowds coming in. Whatever happens on the back end that clears up rather quickly.

Support, if you go to Discord they are very active there. Yes Discord not Reddit, Steam, Facebook, all the others. They may be active on all of those do not know but in Discord I have seen people post issues and 5 minutes later a response from a Dev that they need logs. 2 minutes later they are already working to solve the issue. How much more Support can you get. Issues with the 3rd party company that runs the online stuff? AoW devs are willing to step up and try their best to help you navigate that.

In the end if you are looking for something like Crossout on water, this is that game. From what I have seen so far there is 0 P2W but who cares it is mostly PVE anyhow so really effects no one.
Almost forgot do you like PVP but more on an on your terms deal? Well AoW does that. Server events are all PVP BUT and it is a huge but, if you participate when the guys with the end game stuff show up to spoil it, no worries. PVP events you loose nothing and have no gear to try to recover, you simply do not loose it and respawn near by to quickly get back in.

Refreshing Adventure, But Needs a Bit More Guidance



I've really come to enjoy playing Age of Water. The world they've created with all its water-based environments is simply stunning, and it's one of the highlights of the game. Diving into the depths or sailing across vast oceans feels truly immersive. It's like stepping into the Waterworld movie, but in a game format, where the post-apocalyptic aquatic setting is brought to life with breathtaking detail.

The combat system is another strong point; it's engaging and keeps you on your toes, making each encounter enjoyable. However, there's one aspect that could use some improvement - the mission structure.

One of my main gripes is that missions do not come with a recommended level. This can be quite confusing as you're left guessing whether you're equipped to tackle a mission or if it's something you should come back to later. Knowing the appropriate level would make planning your journey much smoother and less frustrating. You often find yourself wondering if you can or can't do certain tasks because of this lack of guidance.

Overall, if you love water-themed adventures and don't mind navigating some guesswork with mission difficulty, Age of Water is definitely worth checking out. I recommend it, but with the caveat that the developers should consider adding those recommended levels to missions in future updates.

Rating: 7.2/10

Have been looking forward to this for a long time. Pretty disappointed, to be honest.
They are Billions was ... fine-ish. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ campaign, and the survival was just lacking replayability. No actual progression outside of it, which can be either good or bad, depending on your point of view. But I'd love to have an actual "rogue"-lite mode where I can level up heroes, gain advantages, unlock new tech, etc. In addition to the classic survival mode that is all just about survival.

Speaking of which: It's basically the same as They are Billions, which is a huge shame. With the addition of 6 unique hero units, there's not much to it. You have some basic and TWO advanced units and that's it from what I can see, unless there's a "hidden tech tree". Siege weapons seem to be the name of the game. I died on death night 3 on my first attempt. The gameplay is more involved, though, with you having to go out during the day to clear out enemies to gain experience, resolve, and just expand. This is fine ... mostly.

The combat itself is ... problematic. At least in the campaign the units behave terribly. In the one survival game I've played, things seemed a bit better, and everything was somehow way more fluid. Which is good. It's never going to be a good RTS, though. Units are floaty, and push each other around, path finding is bad, sometimes units just refuse to attack a target for some reason, other times they randomly SWITCH targets, thus taking MORE damage from enemies, instead of just killing one. I assume this might be a coding issue, wherein the units are instructed to "spread" their attacks to avoid 10 archers all firing on the same target, i.e. overkilling it by a large margin. That works when you have a big army. It doesn't work when you only have 1 or 2 units ...

Graphics are okay, but as is now tradition for UE5 games, they're just terribly programmed. The game is laggy, stuttery for no reason, and in later nights FPS go down by quite a margin, despite the game not actually looking very impressive. Think: Age of Empires 2 HD, but with 3D graphics. Not that you'd notice it. Zooming in the game has extremely blurry textures at times, and ground textures are odd. I'm not the only one noticing that. The devs know about it, but seemingly have not deigned to fix that in 2 years time.







These are some examples. Luckily, in survival mode you will be way too busy to notice anymore. The management portion of my brain took over.

Lastly, the campaign ... it's ... there. So far I'm wholly unimpressed. The first few missions have you fighting bandits. I kid you not. The story is lackluster, the characters bland, the voice acting ... is a choice. I'm not sure why the game wastes 4 prologue missions on this drivel. Supposedly, there are 3 factions in the game, though all seem to get access to the exact same units and upgrades, the only difference being their heroes and some stat allocations, maybe. In any case, they could've created a big map for the tutorial to take place and then just move from place to place, instead of making each its own map...

For how long this game has been in Early Access I'm not really impressed. It's They are Billions in a fantasy setting with a BIT more RTS stuff. Otherwise it is EXACTLY the same. Build houses to generate money, build farms to generate people, build lumber mills and quarries to generate wood and stone. That's your economy. The rest is upgrading your military and economy. It's lacking in terms of variety, making every survival game pretty much the same, except for the different heroes. All in all, I think I'll get my money's worth out of it, but I can't really recommend it. Not for the actual price, and not for the reduced one right now. There's probably a reason they've reduced the game by SIXTY FIVE percent AT LAUNCH ... before having to contend with the flood of negative reviews that's already starting to show itself. Grab a bit of money, while you call this version 1.0, then abandon it, and probably just create a new studio...

Edit: Some updates on the campaign and survival, now that I've almost beaten the former.
It's a lacklustre RTS light campaign. The story is middling, the writing is barebones, it "does the job", but that's about it. Most problematic, though, is that it's actually 90% against other factions, even non-playable factions like the Alderin, instead of the nightmares, who - so far - only have played a very minor role in the entire thing. And you can clearly see that the game was not designed around fighting other humans. It's a grind, a slog to get through, compared to fighting nightmares.

As for the survival mode: despite the various factions and some minor differences in unit designs (ballistas, instead of catapults, hunters vs. arbalests, etc.) and the unique hero, who becomes kinda worthless towards the end, even on max level, there's just not much variation. There's TWO kinds of towers, ONE kind of wall, and at best 2 to 3 types of units you're going to build at most. In every game. So the only difference comes from the difficulty you select. And the randomly generated map. It's just not enough to stand out, unfortunately. You could've gone all out, even had meta progression to unlock stuff. But sadly, it's just still very bare bones.

It also still runs like ♥♥♥♥, constantly micro-freezing, at least during the campaign missions. Haven't noticed it so much in survival. Despite being on an SSD and the game, otherwise, running fine, even with thousands of monsters on screen.

This game is a fantasy version of They Are Billions - but with saving. The addition of saving does NOT make it any easier, just simply less frustrating. Supposedly co-op is being added soon, I'll believe it when I see it. Maps are shockingly crowded and small, which brings great concern for if co-op is added. You will frequently hit the map border by ACCIDENT, whereas in TAB it was a genuine effort. Resource RNG can really screw up a run early on, so expect quite a few false starts.

The campaign is hot garbage, I suggest you not waste your time on it. The real game is Survival.

Pathfinding and AI for your units is REALLY bad. They often get stuck on eachother (especially on patrols, almost every time), ignore orders just to stand there and die OR alternatively units will occasionally follow orders not assigned to them and wander off alone, they take the weirdest and most convoluted routes to get to a destination, position themselves so their backs are facing hordes while fighting a single enemy, I could go on - essentially you have to babysit them the ENTIRE time they're doing stuff, I honestly don't suggest having more than one group outside of your base (for clearing) at a time, unless you're very proficient at micro.

Honestly, I do like this game, but They Are Billions just does it all better. The bad AI & pathfinding really ruins it for me, personally. I would say hold off until the co-op update (hoping these issues get addressed) and just buy TAB if you're unsure which to purchase.

Not sure y I spent so much time in this game, can't tell if it's because I like it or I just simply like the genre. This game is basically at its core, a copy of They are Billions but instead of steampunk, its medieval. I'd like to recommend this game because it's clearly a huge effort and does A LOT of things well. All of the design aspects are great, the animations, the units, the general art style, the sounds, the music, the voice acting is all top notch and honestly reminds me of old school blizzard quality (think wc3 campaign). The game even does a decent job of separating itself from They are Billions by giving you heroes to choose from, some semi interesting modifiers and basic skill pts to upgrade your army as a whole BUT the actual gameplay is kinda ass... The campaign even though the story is interesting (although predictable), the missions themselves are not, so I think I lost interest by like mission 2 or 3. Now, the survival mode at first seems fun but you will quickly notice that in order to win, you absolutely have to reach those red crystals and to do that you have to cut through hordes of heavily armored units that have broken aoe abilities that completely destroy your units in 1-2 hits so you have to be on top of your micro but because the unit ai and pathing is kinda broken, you can literally lose a significant chunk of your army in a split second. The only way to actually do this is by quickly teching up to siege units and then getting impalers to snipe out the broken aoe units. Using regular pikeman is extremely inefficient as even though they have a little bit of armor shred, you'd need like 50 of them and then the game breaks. Then there is the issue of the map, just like they are billions, you need to expand... A LOT. By the time you reach the final wave, your base will cover the majority of the map and that in itself creates problems because the siege units are so slow, its very easy to lose all of your army to the annoying mist that spawns during horde nights since it very likely that your units will get stuck behind your slow moving catapults that get stuck on trees, buildings, terrain or just path incorrectly and simply get vaporized by the big bad cloud -- actually the reason y I decided to write this review lol.

Kind of a rant, I guess I got my money's worth in time played alone but like I said, the game appears interesting at first and you will sink a lot of time into reloading your saves and you'll think "oh if I just place this tower here, move this catapult here, I'll be good", then the final night arrives and you'd wish you just refunded instead. GG

A game with so much potential. Great art design and music, the basic premise is good, and the mechanics at their base level are solid. Expand, build your forces/base, survive a wave night, and repeat. It will be good fun, and the wave nights will get your blood pumping. Unfortunately, the potential is squandered by a mediocre campaign, poor balance, and an astonishing amount of bugs. I've played on multiple occasions throughout early access, and while many bugs have been fixed, time has only added more.

I prefer single player at heart, and didn't care for multiplayer. I was thrilled when they announced the campaign, but it simply does not measure up. Ten missions, with very poor dialogue between a small cast of very unlikeable characters, just doesn't have enough time or space to do anything interesting with the worldbuilding. No one does anything to prove themselves redeemable or even compelling in an evil way, and somehow these are the characters that we are supposed to care about and play in survival mode as well.

Some spoilers for the campaign, but these are the main characters. A spineless veteran who is just dragged along by the plot, a whiny girl who's sole character trait is emulating teenage girls who are mad at dad for not letting them do drugs, a drunk slaver, an arrogant wannabe queen (did you know she's a queen? Here, let her remind you that she's a queen again), an archer who feels like he should be in a different game entirely, and an edgelord who likes to be evil and edgy but not in a fun way. Don't forget the generic insane evil religious leader who is arguably mind controlled from the beginning, and an actually pious and decent holy woman that is always relegated to the background in favor of the main characters being sad and angry and really unintelligent. By the end of the campaign, I didn't care who won. I wanted them all to lose.

Talking about the heart of the game, the survival mode, I had a great time with it for a while. Exploring random maps (Even if it's one single tileset) and finding chokepoints and places to expand is great at first. After a while, the balance issues start to become more apparent. Certain playstyles and units are strongly favored over others, and while the devs have made efforts to balance things in the past, they will often swing too far one way and then swing too far back to fix it. While it's still possible to play outside of the meta, it will be significantly harder and more work for you to do, and the payoff just isn't there when you're playing what has effectively been the same map and enemies since the beginning of Early Access.

I won't talk too much about bugs. They're aggravating, can cause crashes, and can diminish your experience. One that has consistently bothered me since I first started playing is the epic last stand music going quiet in the final battle. Really kills the vibe. Polish issues are everywhere, with unit animations not fitting right, wacky pathfinding, and so much more.

All in all, I want to love Age of Darkness. On paper, it does everything I want, but the execution is missing. One day I want to see this game be amazing and huge and famous, but I don't know if it will ever get there. I sure hope so though.

Age of Darkness: Final Stand — проверка стратегии на прочность

Age of Darkness: Final Stand — это стратегическая игра на выживание, в которой управление ресурсами и тактическое планирование определяют успех или поражение. Проведя значительное время в режиме выживания, я могу отметить как его сильные стороны, так и недостатки кампании, которые мешают игре раскрыться в полной мере.



Режим выживания: напряжённый и многогранный



Основной режим игры предлагает сложный, но увлекательный опыт. Игроку необходимо управлять ресурсами, укреплять поселение и грамотно использовать героев, чтобы выстоять против волн врагов. Динамическая сложность и необходимость адаптации делают каждое прохождение уникальным.






Режим выживания действительно заслуживает внимания и способен удерживать игрока часами, предлагая интересные стратегические решения.




Несмотря на сильную основу в виде механик выживания, кампания ощущается недостаточно проработанной. Основные проблемы связаны с однообразностью заданий и недостаточной глубиной повествования. Она скорее служит обучением, нежели полноценным самостоятельным режимом.





Если разработчики уделят кампании больше внимания, добавив вариативность и улучшив баланс, она сможет стать достойным дополнением к сильному режиму выживания.




— это крепкая стратегическая игра с выдающимся режимом выживания и слабой кампанией. Любителям хардкорных испытаний и глубокой тактики она безусловно понравится. Однако тем, кто ищет сюжетную кампанию с интересными миссиями, стоит учитывать её текущие недостатки.

Really great base for a survival RTS game, however it desperately needs some work in terms of netcode, latency and more client-side dependency considering its a co-op game not a PVP game, having 2-3s delays at 170ms is pretty insane, makes it near impossible to play with others that aren't in the same region as you as microing against spitters and bursters is crucial if you don't want to lose an entire group of units at once.

Lots of crashing/networking issues, and crashes pretty much end your game in multiplayer especially if you're playing on higher difficulties where you have to go back 4+ days for the auto save.


In terms of balance the game still has a bit to be desired but there is still ongoing work with that so we'll see how it develops, currently melee units are a little useless. Would be great if there was melee with armor shred or armor pen as currently there's no reason to not just spam ballistas because of how vital it is to shred elites.

Some hero skills such as Merek's just don't activate properly half the time, either the animation goes through and nothing gets hit, or the animation doesn't play at all but the skill goes on cooldown. Can also get pushed around mid leap and end up really far from your skill destination.

Sometimes you get an elite spearmen/wraith right next to your base and you just have to go to a new seed.

Honestly these issues get resolved it would be a great game but until then it just has too many issues to play and enjoy reliably.

I will start with the problem before the full review

THE MAIN PROBLEM: Crashes are... (not) frequent??? let me explain; the game can run but there is a good chance that it crashes. However this can happen really early in the game or really late in the game. However once it happens the save is corrupted if you reload the crash will happen again. The cause? Unclear, lets say you crash on night 3 after the 2nd Horde night. If you load an autosave (which is after Horde night 2) you replay the other days and night again and can do something completely different how ever that crash on night 3 will happen again. At this point you have played for an hour or so and you need to restart losing all progress. For frequent crashes i would expect the game to crash once every 30 minutes. But thats not the case here. If the game gets stable this would be a positive review but it is not. So dont get it if you cant deal with being forced to replay a run cause of a crash

THE REVIEW:
It would be unfair to say this game is bad but due to the main problem listed above i cant give a positive review

Lets dive in:
The game is "They are billions" meets Warcraft 3 in short.
You have a day-night cycle where during the day you can expand without worrying the AI to attack you and in the night the AI tries to take territory back. After "X" amount of normal nights you fight a horde.
You build troops and towers to defend your Base + HQ if the HQ falls you lose. You can make expand your base and get access to more resources by clearing areas with you hero and troops.
To win you clear "Y" amount of horde nights to fight the final horde. If you survive you win. That is the basic gameplay loop.

There is a campaign with your classic fantasy horde horror story which was clearly a later edition to the game but for those who like it, just know its there but dont expect anything like Warcraft campaigns. From a gameplay perspective the campaign adds some extra conditions to playing the base gameplay loop.

The main game mode is survival where you pick a hero and do the basic gameplay loop, and then there is Co-op survival. The later of which is what i mainly play (it provides the most fun).

So if you like RTS like gameplay vs AI + Wave fighting than good the base game will probably be in your wheel house.

MORE PROBLEMS:
- The pathing AI is not the best sometimes units get stuck, to unstuck them you either need to give an order to the complete opposite of the map of more nearby. Both of which might not completely unstuck them because if the original order is regiven shortly after they get stuck again.
FIX PATH FINDING


- The hero's are not balanced the main protagonist is the best hero you can pick there are 5 others they do different things but just dont really hold a candle to the main guy.
BUFF THE OTHER HERO'S (INTRODUCE MORE)

- Unit variety is small 2 out of 3 factions have almost the same unit pool with maybe 1 or 2 troops different. The third faction has slightly more variety but nothing truly different
MAKE THE FACTIONS FEEL DIFFERENT --> MORE UNIT VARIETY, MORE BUILDING VARIETY

- The campaign is boring TO ME
I don't think this game needs a campaign. Thats it really just remove it.

- Buildings dont build. When clicking to place a building it doesn't get placed. this seems to correlate to whether you slightly move the mouse during placement.... Its annoying.

- Upgrades in weird spots there are 4 places of upgrades
1. The Workshop mainly to unlock buildings and tecH, like a Static defence balista tower (this is fine)
2. The unit upgrades seperate button in overhead UI (This is fine)
3. New units in their respective building (this is okay bit weird but ok)
I mean its new tech which i would expect in the workshop but its in the building for the unit i can live with that i guess.
4. Upgraded versions of the balista tower (see 1) in the Siege workshop (this is NOT okay). All my new buildings are in the workshop BUT THE STATIC DEFENSE TOWER TECH IS IN THE SIEGE UNIT FACTORY WTF

Once the crashes are solved i MIGHT turn this to a positive review.
IF the devs also balance hero's and do some more faction design the this WILL be a positive review

tl;dr: This is a very tentative "yes" made under the assumption that the bugs get fixed and with the recommendation of only getting it on a very deep discount like it is right now. It's not a bad game by any stretch but it costs almost as much as They Are Billions while only having a fraction of the content. Maybe for some people the multiplayer makes up for the lack of content, for me it really doesn't.

The campaign while ok is very short and in a lot of places it feels like it's rushing you due to the time limits and not letting you explore at your leisure. I don't know why some are complaining about difficulty since most missions have a "gimmick" and are pretty easy to turtle in and then methodically wipe out the enemies, especially since the AI always seems to send the same attack force at you and doesn't really scale up as the mission goes on. Most of the maps are interesting but again in plenty of missions you just feel rushed and don't really get to "sit and enjoy the view" so to speak, in some you don't even really get to defeat the enemies either since they're completely optional. It's interesting that they sometimes give you choices on what path you can take but it doesn't really change anything about the final result or the story. The final boss is interesting but easily cheesed.

Survival mode is the "meat" of the game, just like with TAB, but while you have new gameplay elements like Warcraft 3 style heroes, hero gear and elites to deal with it just doesn't feel like it makes up for the low choice in terms of towers and units. It feels like they could have done so much more in terms of both since it's a fantasy setting but the content and replay value just aren't there, at least for me.

Bugs galore. The pathing in particular is still very bad, even after years of allegedly attempting to fix the issues, you will see your soldiers just splitting in very weird ways when given orders to engage the enemy, getting stuck in place because they can't decide who to go for or even rushing in a weird direction because they couldn't all path properly to the target or location you ordered them to. This was probably the source of most of my frustration with the game in the time i played it and it's definitely something you don't want to see in an RTS. Pathing still seems just as bad on the 1.0 version. I'm also noticing on the 1.0 a lot of times where the enemy melee creatures get stuck trying to move through your frontline to get to the archers essentially walking in place while they get stabbed to death because they're fixated on your archers.

I've also had some weird issues with hero abilities not triggering correctly/not doing "what it says on the tin" and control groups breaking. Also on the 1.0 the enemy AoE markers seem to not match the actual size of the ability with the abilities sometimes hitting your units even though they're way out of the marker. I have no interest in the multiplayer so i won't give it a separate section but that also seems to be very buggy for many players and they didn't even bother having a propery lobby system, expecting people to go to their discord to find other players to match with which is a very weird decision.

My final gripe is with the Alderin faction, it feels like it's only being cut to be added later as DLC despite the fact that it seems to more or less already have the prerequisites for a full faction. The excuse i've seen give was that the hero selection screens and one extra skin for the main building are very expensive to make and they don't have the extra funds for it. I'd like to focus on the part about the hero selection as i don't even understand why those animated selection screens are even a thing to begin with. This isn't a hero shooter or a moba, it's literally an element that adds nothing to the game and you only see it for a few seconds when selecting your character. Why invest so many resources in a flashy feature that has zero effect on actual gameplay? Why not give us an extra faction on the 1.0 instead?

Congratulations, Devs!
Developing a game is a challenging process, so I’ll do my best to provide fair and constructive feedback.

Overall:
The game requires more polishing and optimization to feel and play more smoothly. In terms of campaign design, some early missions have a steep difficulty curve, and there’s a lack of proper resource availability and management to support it.

Issues:

FPS drops occur during large enemy swarms, even on high-end machines.
Sudden freezes during checkpoints or any kind of background autosave.
The AI for player units needs an overhaul—heroes get stuck behind each other and can't reach their targets.
Player units often get stuck in the environment, necessitating frequent micro-management.
There's a constant feeling that there's not enough guidance on how to approach preparation phases or build defenses. It feels more like a trial-and-error process, which suggests a lack of polish in design.
The game needs a proper combat and economy tutorial that highlights the strengths and weaknesses of different strategies and approaches.
Player unit commands, while simple, feel somewhat limited. More unique and advanced unit commands could have added depth to the gameplay and enhanced the overall battle experience.
The game attempts to blend several different concepts at once. I commend the effort and vision, but it feels like the vision was only half-executed. Kudos for trying, but there’s clear room for improvement next time.

Buggy

Just finished campaign, game is very buggy, can't recommend until fixed or with more QoL changes.

Gameplay

TL:DR Buggier, Slightly worse version of TAB (Atleast at time of review)

Plays similar to TAB with World of Warcraft heroes mechanics. Heroes are powerful and is literally the lifeline of your army. Unlike TAB, you can build anywhere as long as there is line of sight, which I like better. Plenty of pathfinding issues with units.

The Market building doesn't automatically sell excess resources. Instead it has its own pile of resources with its own generation timer that you have to manually sell, which just overcomplicates things.

Gameplay loop is the same as TAB. Expand, establish economy, hunker down, fight enemy waves, rinse and repeat. The addition of the fog of war being harmful during waves is actually an interesting mechanic that ties with the line of sight requirement for building.

More emphasis on heroes and small unit tactics, units are more expensive (atleast the good ones you want to spam).

Impaler is goated, Archers become useless other than fodder when you get arbalests/hunters, Do not waste your money on soldiers, Sentinels are better for tanking along with your hero.

Just like with TAB, the survival was the main focus with the campaign seemingly tacked on.

Plenty of Bugs, here's a list:
- Enemy health in portraits sometimes don't update health and armor values.
- When you run out of resources while shift-clicking building, it stays unavailable even after resources regenerate. You have to get out of build mode and click the building again.
- Click and dragging to select units is inconsistent
- Grouping different kinds of unit production buildings don't work I.E. Grouping factory and barracks leads to none working in the UI, they have unit portraits with no option to produce units. Only similar buildings grouped works.
- When a unit dies within a group you selected, the main unit shown reverts back to the first unit. For example, you have Edwin and Aelis in the same group. You use Edwin's skills, then tab over to Aelis. You start using her combo (V, C, X to recover lost guards) but then a unit dies because they're ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ idiots who prefers to hit walls over the enemy shooting at them five feet away, and you suddenly return to Edwin with no abilities. Really frustrating in the heat of the moment where microing your heroes and their skills become essential.
- During the second-to-the-last mission, when destroying the keeps providing the sacrifices, I'm getting the audio cue "Our keep is being overrun!" or something like that, but my keep was fine. It's the enemy keeps I was attacking triggering it.

- Expand the unit formation, or atleast make it so we can orient the direction the formation is facing, and make it a different button from the s key which should be for the stop command.
- Put walls way in the back of target priority.

Spoiler!

Age of Darkness: игра которая меня задушила.

Поначалу все шло отлично: я начал проходить компанию и меня встретили приятная боевка, графический стиль, интересная (на первый взгляд) система экономики, огромные топлы врагов, с которыми ты, на равных, сражаешься небольшим отрядом, все было хорошо...
И тут началась 7-я миссия, которая меня буквально задушила: раскрылась вся "глубина" местной экономики, необходимость микрить как тварь и огромного количества багов, но обо всем по порядку:
Экономика: поначалу комфортная система, где у тебя 10 домов, 4 фермы, 2 лесопилки и 2 каменоломни по итогу превращается в 60 домов, 20 ферм, 10 каменоломен и 10 лесопилок - именно столько тебе нужно поставить, чтобы клепать юнитов не ожидая по минуте пока у тебя накопятся ресурсы хотя бы на одного, а копятся они ооооооочень медленно: тебе прилетает доход не постоянно, а раз в минуту (металл раз в 2 минуты). И в итоге ты сидишь и все это время смотришь на эту шкалу дохода когда тебе нужно построить каждое здание или создать юнитов, которые дохнут как мухи: баланса между затраченными усилиями на создание юнита/здания и его выживаемостью/эффективностью практически нет.
А теперь представьте размер такой базы? По сути где то с треть карты и все это нужно оборонять.
обороняться от противников просто банально не комфортно: самым эффективным способом защиты базы является твоя основная армия, но в пределах базы никаких способов быстро перемещаться по ней просто нет: они мееедленно бегут на своих двоих до точки прорыва или предполагаемой атаки, из за чего строить огромную базу просто не хочется, а ты должен, иначе твоя экономика будет неэффективна и ты проиграешь. Тут хочется вспомнить опыт WarCraft 3 или StarCraft2, где у тебя есть или юниты, позволяющие быстро лоцировать войска, или свитки телепортации, позволяющие быстро принять бой в нужном месте в пределах базы. Тут это тоже критически нужно, а этого нет. Ладно армию долго перемещать, но что с башнями и стенами? Хочешь сделать нерушимое укрепление, где башни сами могут удержать периметр? Шиш тебе: башни стреляют меееееедлено, по 1 цели, а если это АОЕ башни, то мало того что они стреляют мееееедлено, так и урона они наносят мало. Так мало того: стоят они очень дорого на каждую ты будешь копить по минуте. И нет никаких царь пушек или механик, которые позволили бы тебе удержать направление и не подпустить к стенам. А сами стены, такое ощущение, что сделаны из пластика: так быстро их прорывают. Чтобы стены были хоть сколько то эффективны их приходится строить в 3-4 слоя, а нужно ли говорить, что стены тоже не дешевые?
тут хотелось бы вспомнить опыт WarCraft 3 или StarCraft2 и разные типы урона там были добавлены не просто так: какой урон лучше бьёт по здания, какой то - по легким юнитам, какой то - по тяжелым и тд. И это позволяло тебе строить юнитов в зависимости от боевой ситуации. Тут есть просто "Урон" и есть просто "Защита". Есть еще дополнительная броннированность цели, но ее могут снять (я так и не понял как, но это происходит довольно быстро) и она больше не работает, на этом все. Т.е. логично было бы стенам сделать тип брони "Здание" а обычной мелочи поставить какой то "Режущий" урон и они наносят зданиям сниженый на 75% урон, что спасло бы стены от их бесполезности и необходимости строить их в несколько рядов. Нет: твой базовый пехотинец получит по лицу столько же урона от монстра, сколько и каменная стена.
Перечислю только часть из них, но из них будет понятен тотальный писец происходящего:
1. Башни могут выбрать целью юнит за зоной поражения и перестать стрелять. У меня так на одной линии обороны просто ни один вражеский юнит убит не был, хотя башен там было аж 5 штук!
2. Герой применяет способность, но его толкнули на пару пинов в сторону? Мана потратится, способность не применится и уйдет на кулдаун.
3. Сломанный рынок: продаю железо, оно не тратится - золото приходит.
4. Отсутствует приоритезация целей: если перед твоей армией находится вражеская линия стены и за ней 3 башни, то пробив дыру в стене они... продолжат бить другие стены. Начнут бить здания противника если они ближе и игнорировать самих противников.
5. Умерший юнит все еще считается игрой живым: ему платится жалование, ресурс жителя и продовольствия не возвращается, из за чего часть экономики может работать буквально на "мертвые души".
6. Юниты толкают и мешают друг другу наносить урон.
7. При разборе здания казармы если в нем нанимаются юниты, то ресурсы за них не возвращаются.
8. На месте уничтоженных зданий могут появится "битые" поля сетки строительства: у меня так одна стена превратиласьв зигзаг не потому что я этого хотел, а потому что не мог поставить стену туда, где ее только что разрушили.
9. И т.д. и тп.

состояние игры просто не позволяет мне ее рекомендовать, как бы я не пытался для себя сгладить недочёты выше, но уж слишком эти недочеты важны с точки зрения игрового опыта, который хотелось бы получить от игры. Баги же могут застать в неподходящий момент и настолько критично могут повлиять на игру, что твоя вроде бы успешная катка может пойти по одному месту.
Спасибо всем, кто прочитал это полотно текста <3

Decent game in the vein of TAB and DNO, can recommend for fans of those games. Campaign was very middling, not sure who 'awarded' this campaign as they touted it as "Award-Winning", it's average at best. Very short (7-10hrs), fairly easy. Writing is very basic and there is no real depth to characters. One of the main characters is basically just like, okay I'm bad now. My biggest complaint of the campaign was that most missions you BARELY get to play with the game mechanics. Most of the time you are just attack moving heroes across a map. only to arrive at a base that is half built already, then the "timer" starts. Almost every mission has a timer in which you have to do something. So you never really truly get to learn how to play the game because they just build all the starting buildings for you and its then just build units and rush objectives.

Survival is very obviously the bread and butter of this game. I'm having way more fun with this than the campaign. I love that maps are designed to have choke points, really encourages early exploring and planning the meat of your base around where these choke points are. Heroes are strong, but not overpowered. Units aren't super unique in how you use them, and the armor mechanic of the higher tier units can be a bit lame at times to have to return to base to "re-armor" them, just wish it would slowly regen out of combat but faster if you are at your base.

Pathing of units is really bad at times if you send them all after 1 target, they bunch up and instead of surrounding the unit, half the melee units just don't attack. This can be frustrating when fighting "Elites" or enemies with AOE since your units will just form the perfect bunch to all get hit unless you are micro-ing constantly. I've lost all of my melee units not paying attention for a split second.

Overall I am enjoying this game and got my monies worth. 8.5/10 survival mode, 6/10 campaign.

I have had a blast with Age of Darkness ("AOD") and can happily recommend it to any who are looking for that mix of RTS and Tower Defence that 'They are Billions' ("TAB") is famed for. This game will feel so familiar if you have played TAB before but it does enough things differently to not feel like a reskin.

Before getting in to specifics of what I like or dislike, I feel I should first defend the campaign. You will see from many reviews that the campaign is almost universally reviled but I think people are expecting, perhaps, too much. The campaign does exactly what you would want it to:
1) It slowly introduces new mechanics so you get to learn as you play; and
2) It tells an interesting (enough) story that isn't winning awards but equally gives some backstory to this games' setting and world; and
3) It plays significantly differently to the main 'survival' mode that it feels refreshing.

To compare the campaigns of AOD and TAB, the former smashes the latter out of the park: TAB's campaign is a series of 'normal' survival maps interspersed with small hero focused missions (that are also generally despised). AOD's campaign is an actual narrative and has you fight against humans and nightmares (the games' horde creatures) over its run time. I have enjoyed my time with the campaign and think that it makes the game stronger, not weaker.

Turning to the core of the game: survival mode.

Like TAB, you need to survive against increasingly difficult waves of enemies and, when you beat the 5th wave, a massive final wave attacks from all previous entry points together. You are encouraged to expand out into the map as much as possible to horde resources and continue building an elite force to defend you.

Much like TAB, towers are actually a noob trap and the best defence is a vast army. Like TAB, once you realise the whole game is made trivially easy with the spamming of a single unit type, it takes something away from the magic. The game has reasonable unit variety but, no matter which faction you play, the only thing you will ever need is T3 walls and Impalers. Nothing else matters; Impalers are everything.

This is where I think TAB has the balance down a bit better because, in TAB, whilst certain units are very powerful (and you can spam one unit type to win the game -snipers-) every unit is viable; even at the end of the game. In AOD, if you don't build Impalers, you will likely lose. You can try with other units but you would need thousands of them and an ungodly amount of walls to try and slow the enemy down. Impalers do all that with only tens of them.

To sing some praises before concluding:
1) AOD has three factions which adds to the replay-ability (they could do with being a touch more visually distinct but that is not to take away from them)
2) You can call waves early in AOD if you feel ready which gives you more control on events.
3) You get powerful heroes in AOD that TAB doesn't have. They are EXTREMELY powerful and will be your main weapon for most of the game.
4) The voice acting is really high quality.

All in all:
- Extremely recommended if you loved or liked They are Billions
- Recommended if you like RTS or Tower Defence

Так! С чего бы начать... Игра, полная копирка They are Billions (далее ТАВ), но со своим виденьем экономики, масштабов и боев.
1. Анимации болванчиков ломаные. Да их можно прерывать и это выглядит крайне убого.
2. Юниты могут застрять в текстурах и Вы даже не поймете почему миссии не идут дальше.
3. Баги в регистрации исполнения заданий. Задачу выполнили, а игра может посчитать иначе. А значит забудьте про 100% закрытие миссии. Вперед на реран! Плюсом сами задания могут сумбурно менятся, лочится и это происходит так резко, что даже опешиваешь немного, но при этом в списке задача остается, а выполнить её нельзя, да и метки пропадают.
4. Ваша армия стоит дорого и от неё толку 0. Вся сила только в героях, которые качаются полгода. Герой умер? Реран. И при этом в задачах Вам этого никто не укажет, что они обязаны выжить в течение всей миссии. Вам об этом скажут, только если прочитаете вводную перед стартом. Собственно журнала задач с подробностями тут то же нет.
5. Оборонительные сооружения полный мусор. Дозорная башня, в которую надо садить тех же мусорных юнитов лучников. Стены, не тверже бумаги, её ломает бомж с мечем за ударов 10. А если их будет 10 на пару с лучниками? БАЛЛИСТА, наносящая АОЕ урон не способна ваншотнуть простых зомби!!! Вдумайтесь! В тебя летит огромный болт, а он сносит 5хп, отталкивает и оглушает. Да базовый лучник сносит от 30-50% хп врага за 1 выстрел и стреляет быстрее. При этом башня стоит космических вложений!
6. Экономика. Игра предполагает минималистичность и аванпосты, а не сплошная стена утыканная турелями. Рельеф бесконечных лесов не позволяет сделать одну огромную базу. Казалось бы это хорошо... Пара ферм и каменоломен, а не сотня строений как в ТАВ, но количество ресурсов необходимых и мусорность оборонки и войск сводят всю минималку на нет, а места на карте не много. Плюс у строений есть эффективный радиус добычи ресурса. Лишние здания в радиусе и минус к получаемому кэшу. Стоит учесть что ресурсы приходят раз в 1 минуту и ТОЛЬКО с 1 здания. То есть, если у Вас 2 ратуши или 2 лесопилки, каждая из них будет ровно 1 минуту доставлять ресурсы, а не одним общим временем.
7. Несоразмерность занимаемой площади к полезности самого здания. Представьте себе ратушу (главку) размерами 6х6, четверть экрана. А теперь склад для ресурсов, такого же размера. Вам как бы намекают, что нефиг жировать, а места для базы не шибко много.
8. Параметры урона и защиты универсальны. Вояка с луком будет наносить героям, зомби, людям и строениям полноценный урон. Уменьшается только количеством защиты. Казалось бы просто, ♥♥♥! Но нет, из-за этого как раз оборонка и армии становятся мусором.
9. Трекинг убитый в хлам. Юниты просто идут паровозиком и если надо сломать башенку размерами 1х1, 2 мечника упрутся в спину спереди идущему и будут стоять так до бесконечности, пока руками их не подведешь к ней в упор.
10. Приоритеты целей нанесения урона. Юниты будут атаковать всё что видят, но не то, что надо! Это как будто вы отправили группу на массовую атаку кнопкой А (мочить всё, что на глаз попадет), а всего то нажали правой клавишей на врага. Убили 1 болванчика из 10, а дальше можно мочить всё вокруг: здания, стены, декорации...Нахрена нам убивать оставшихся 9? Кто ближе тот и забьёт их, может быть.
11. Очень странные решения в баффах от строений поддержки. Склад даёт буст всему производству ресурсов, кроме еды в радиусе здания. Чем еда не угодила? Она так-то важнее остальных ресурсов будет. А рынок вместо уменьшения потребления еды домам или прироста золота, дает буст военке. Что? Почему? Ладно хоть монетный двор увеличивает прибыль с домов, тут вопросов нет. Плюс данные баффы работают даже на стенки и сооружения защиты))) Было забавно смотреть, как моя деревянная стенка бустила прирост денег.
12. Логика работы рынка. По идее на рынке Вы продаете ресурсы, что у Вас на руках. Но тут два пула ресурсов (я понял это так) Один пул принадлежит Вам и он отображается, а второй находится в самом рынке и заполняется судя по всему уже избыточными Вашими ресурсами. Я покупал железо и продавал дерево с камнем, пул рынка уменьшался, а вот мой объем даже на единичку ресурса не уменьшился, но металл поступал на баланс. Это очень странное решение... Не порядок!

Итого: продукт вроде был в раннем доступе, а с релизом будто из него и не вышел. Советую повременить с покупкой, т.к. выше описанные проблемы сильно влияют на геймплей. И реранить миссии кампании просто становится крайне нудно.
UPD прошел 8 миссий кампании, это просто духота. Герой может и танковать, как Геракл, а может за секунду улететь на тот свет, хрен пойми от кого. Бросаю эту пакость до лучших времен...

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
В принципе хорошо и своих денег стоит.

Кому я не рекомендую эту игру: тем, кто ищет какой-то особо разнообразный геймплей и не любит игры в жанре защиты с помощью башен.

Советы:

- постарайтесь как можно быстрее получить доступ к огнеметным башням, усиленным баллистам и самым укрепленным стенам, а иначе ваше поселение с высокой долей вероятности не переживет волну в 5000 особей;

- не стройте большую армию, так как в этом нет смысла, так как орда в 3000-5000 единиц уничтожит даже самую многочисленную вашу армию и героя заодно;

- активно расширяйте свою территорию, зачищая её от монстров, стройте фермы и дома, добывающие рудники;

- для более быстрой зачистки вам понадобится небольшая по численности армии (зависит от типа юнитов: если это мобильные укрепленные баллисты, то достаточно будет с десяток, а если это пехота - то тут можно нанять и с три десятка человек).

Из минусов: это всё еще ранний доступ со всеми вытекающими недоделками. К примеру, даже если территория огорожена со всех сторон стенами, внутри поселения на участках во тьме могут возникать монстры в обычную ночь. Решение: либо всё застраивать плотно, чтобы не было ни одного неосвещенного уголка, либо строить башни или очаги с огнем, дающий широкий обзор.

Почему-то сгруппированных юнитов уже нельзя потом из этой самой группы удалить или в целом сформировать новую группу вместо действующей. То есть если вы привязали к горячей кнопки определенных юнитов, то они будут состоять в этой группе до самой своей смерти или навсегда. В целом микроконтроль и поведение юнитов в бою оставляет желать лучшего: все-все необходимо делать вручную.

К сожалению, юниты не держат строй и нет кнопки "Идти строем, ориентируясь на скорость самого медленного юнита", чтобы ваша пехота и арбалетчики двигались единым строем.

Поиск пути до точки назначения реализован посредственно: ваши юниты непременно срежут путь через не раскрытый вами еще участок карты, где тьма и много монстров соответственно, если это будет кратчайший путь. Впрочем, это может придирка.

Монстры-самоубийцы имеют очень много единиц жизни. Необходимо не один и не два арбалетчика для уничтожения таких опасных тварей. Спасают мобильные баллисты, которые своими снарядами могут отбрасывать этих тварей назад. Но если их нет и зазеваться, тоодна такая тварь, взрываясь, может уничтожить с десяток другой ваших юнитов и значительно ранить героя. Неизбежно при зачистки карты можно отвлечься на строительство той же базы в реальном времени и, не заметив такую тварь, потерять часть армии.

Плевуны обладают очень высокой живучестью, на мой взгляд.

Кампания не заинтересовала и играл только в режиме "Выживание", но пишут, что у кампании открытый финал и история сюжетная не завершена.

ОБЗОР ПРОДУКТА В РАННЕМ ДОСТУПЕ
I have not played Survival mode yet, which I know is the core gameplay, as a disclaimer. I started out with the Campaign, and it just was...not good. I played a lot of They are Billions, and I knew that this was an attempt to recreate that, but I felt like it really struggled in a few key points, and I don't know if they are Campaign failures or game failures. My hope is to revisit this at some point, and try survival and just give up on the campaign, but my experiences with it were so bad that I uninstalled and have to move on for a while.

Unit pathing is very, very bad. Units just stagger around, in ways that don't always make sense, making it hard to predict where they will go. Your units also LOVE to target walls over enemy units, no matter how I set their priority settings. This makes combat extremely micro-intensive, which is just not something I am at all interested in. I prefer macro-level gameplay, and the way the game plays right now almost mandates that you pause constantly and micro-manage every single one of your units, or they're going to be targeting random nonsense as you get picked off by the hordes.

Some of this wouldn't be a big deal, except unlike TAB, which is all ranged units, at least early on in this campaign, the overwhelming majority of units are melee. You can imagine why melee-heavy units are a problem when they do not path well, and end up blocking each other. Heavy ranged units in TAB also allowed you to use static defenses well, but with melee, your units need to get out there and mix things up, you can't rely on static defenses so much without heavy unit micro. Again, maybe some won't mind that but I struggled with it.

The developers seemed to indicate that they know that there are unit pathing problems, but they are not going to work on it while they add multiplayer to the game. I personally don't care about multiplayer, and I'd rather they get the game they have working rather than add on new features, but that's their choice. Perhaps if/when they ever revise some of these things, I will try the game again. Until then, I can't recommend it as someone who doesn't have the desire to get down into these micro level details of every fight.

The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

The Good:
- Decent They Are Billions clone
Since we all tired fighting against hordes of zombies, fighting instead hordes of nightmares is something fresh.
- Couple new (and old) mechanics
Heroes, fractions, points of interest and elites - quite good. Veil - just excellent.

The Bad:
- No late game content
There is no wonders, no expensive technologies. Nothing. All your economy - just how munch land do you controlling. All your defence - just 2 (_TWO_) type of towers. Huge step back.
- Map.
Something dark on something bleak. U need to pause and enlarge map to clearly understand topology of landscape.
- One biom
Correct me if i wrong, but for 33+ hours i didn't see any anything than dark forest. Any desert? winter? jungle?


- Performance.
Early access has way more framerate. UE4 fine engine, hire some freelance with optimizing experience.
- Walls and tower
You know, in real life you could climb up on the walls and fight invaders from there. Just like in Stronghold (2001). Why did you copy-paste such miserable mechanic?

Conclusion:
This is fine game, both with own problems and discoveries for this sub-genre. For now I vote for this game. Just for now! There is a lot of potencial and, if developers continue their work this could be new leader on the block. Just look how developing Against the Storm, where players lost in new content. But if you adopt They are billions policy and there will just only bug-fixes and some minor improvements, i will change my mind.

Игра про развитие и защиты базы, практически 1 в 1 – They are billions, но со своими особенностями.
Сюжет – определенно неплохой, по крайней мере следить за ним было увлекательно. Есть пара «вот это поворот!», ну и в данном режиме, игра предстаёт как обычная, но очень кривая rts’ка.
Игра выглядит приемлемо, но сильно ест процессор, так как количество юнитов в кровавую ночь может составлять десятки тысяч. Да и без юнитов она странно работает, а ещё загрузка в игру долгая даже на sdd, а ещё может во время игры зависнуть на 10-15 секунд, либо вовсе вылететь.
Экран выбора героя – моё почтение, сделано очень круто и красиво, жаль героев мало, как и юнитов, а игра уже считается почти законченной, зимой только кооператив обещают выпустить на двух игроков, может и фракцию подвезут.
Поиск пути юнитами очень сильно сбоит, если не проследить – можно сильно разочароваться в разработчиках.
Своё удовольствие от игры получить можно, если вы её не бросите раньше из-за совокупности проблем, перечисленных выше, порой за одну карту я перезапускаю игру 1-2 раза.
Брать только по скидке. P.s. если вы любитель достижений, то лучше пройдите мимо, ибо тут есть десяток очень долгих достижений (например убить 15 миллионов чудовищ, когда за одну карту я максимум набивал 217000), нужно стать фанатом этой игры, чтобы получить их все.

Провел в игре 250+ часов, думаю, что можно и обозреть

Начнем с минусов:
Да, похожа на They are billions, да, есть баги и вылеты, все еще
Компания неоднозначная, большая часть миссий - затянутая скучная жвачка, которая позволяет лишь немного разнообразить геймплей. Основная, возможно, ее ценность в том, что в процессе раскрывается лор фракций и героев. Особенно упорным можно пройти, а можно не отвлекаться от основного геймплея режима выживания.
Так же к минусам могу отнести, в некотором смысле, необходимость жесткого микроконтроля, особенно на первых волнах, где нет возможности создать плотных танкующих юнитов и стрелков, которые легко превращаются в универсальную толпу зачистки при должном колличестве.

Улучшения для юнитов - срань, добыча кристалов - срань, механика с уничтожением кристалов и ускорением той самой волны/орды - срань.

В режиме выживания, если не угадал с направлением волны супостатов, то все, гг. Фортификации и юниты, на которые были затрачены ресурсы,и размещенны на не верном направлении уже не спасут поселение - переигрывай или загружайся.


Теперь к плюсам:
Челлендж, играть правда не просто, приходится проявлять чудеса того самого микроконтроля, параллельно не забывать развивать экономику и думать над тем, провести укрепление фортификаций и выстроить дополнительный ряд стен, или же добавить лучников или пошло оно все, я закрываю игру, долбитесь сами в это недоРТС.

Разнообразие фракций
Оно есть, хоть и не очевидное. В зависимости от выбранных героев и стороны, на которой они выступают, будет меняться геймплей и тактика
Синие:
Терпят, хилятся, требуют меньшего приложения скилла именно в микро, так как прощают больше ошибок за счет доп здоровья и наличия бронированных-толстых юнитов

Красные:
Плюс демедж, сильные стрелки, требующие жесткого микро и прожима кнопок асассины.

Зеленые:
Оборачивают в свою пользу механики страха (вообще-то это дебаф), крошат бронированных юнитов стартовым пушечным мясом, разменивая толпы дешевых болванчиков в обмен на продвижение по карте и захват территорий. Агрессивный беспощадный стиль игры, так же прощающий многие ошибки, ведь основной юнит стоит буквально ничего и создается с дьявольской скоростью.

Резюмирую
Дип дарк фентези rts-рогалик не для всех
Геймплей один в один как в They are billions c поправками на фэнтези стилистику и героев, вокруг которых строится многое.

So I mainly played solo Survival mode, and it was pretty damn fun! Coming from They Are Billions, I had a chuckle at people saying this game is too hard - it's actually way more forgiving, especially since you can save your progress and a single mistake won't instantly destroy your whole base (at least on lower difficulties).

The game's solid, but there are some things that scream to be added, at least for me. The hero system feels a bit basic. Would've loved to see some items for them to make them more unique. Also, while each faction has their own hero, the regular units don't feel different enough between factions.

It would be great to have more unit variety, and some massive "you can only build one" super units that are almost as strong as heroes. I realise this might be just wishful thinking on my part, and it might be tricky to balance, but sometimes you just want to have fun with an absolute powerhouse unit and crush endless waves of enemies.

The exploration part of the game could use some work too. Right now it feels a bit meh - finding some cool items, extra heroes, or at least making the units you discover veterans would make exploring way more exciting.

Even with these issues, I still had fun playing it. If you're into survival strategy games but found They Are Billions too brutal, this might be right up your alley. Not perfect, but definitely worth checking out.

I was looking forward to this game so I'm sad that I can't recommend it. I will, however, change my review if they resolve the issues in it. I didn't play the release for long but it was long enough to experience a few deal breakers.

Deal Breaker 1:
Attack move has awful prioritization and sometimes doesn't even work properly. Units will simply attack whatever is in the area. I had units attacking a piece of a wall while enemy units were around them or even attacking them. I had to end up constantly pausing and redirecting units. A game with this kind of scale should not have this kind of micromanagement.

Deal Breaker 2: Unit and enemy AI is atrocious. I'll have a group of units get attacked and a couple of units from the group will react while the rest just stand there spectating. Enemy AI is just as bad. I ran past a group of enemies in a narrow corridor to attack the larger group behind them. I was trying to gather them all up for an AoE attack but the two in the corridor just turned around after chasing me for a bit and went back to where they were standing. Hello? I'm literally invading your base. Why are you leaving?

Deal Breaker 3: The early game imbalance is nonsensical. What exactly is the point of walls and gates if they can be destroyed by a small squad? What is the point of ballistae if they barely do any damage? I literally could not set up any kind of defenses to stop the enemy and had to micromanage my army to defend my walls and towers.

Deal Breaker 4: Unit pathing is awful. I'll have a group of units attack something but the units in the back part of the group can't walk around the units that've stopped to attack and instead will kind of slide along the units in the front doing nothing. If there was no room on the left/right I'd understand but they could literally just walk around them and join the attack.

As I said, if they fix these issues, I'll update my review but sadly these are foundational issues that should've been resolved in early access. So I really don't see this getting fixed, but I hope I'm wrong.

Overall, I enjoyed the game more than I expected I would. I hated They are Billions, to the point of refunding it, so I was sceptical of a similar concept, however this is a much better game, IMO. The art style and hero-centric game play is very Warcraft III, which I enjoyed. The campaign is surprisingly well designed, if a little repetitive. Voice acting is decent, story is reasonable, and took me a good 15 hours to beat. The survival mode has serious legs; given how challenging it is, I expect it would take quite a few attempts to beat on the harder difficulties. It's also random in enough ways to keep it fun, but not enough ways that you'd feel cheated by bad RNG. The game is certainly not without its bugs, however. Unit pathing is an issue, sound will sometimes turn off and randomly turn back on 10-15 minutes later, and crashes aren't uncommon. Overall, a great buy on sale, but full price would be pushing it until the bugs are resolved.

While I'm not new to the RTS genre (dabbled a bit in TA:Spring, Supcom 2, Ashes of the Singularity and Beyond All Reason to name most of them), this game has been my introduction and go to for the Survival RTS subgenre. I've been playing this on and off since early-Early Access.

Most people see this game and will think of TAB since they're the same genre of RTS. But I quickly came back to this.

I'm currently in act 2, mission 4 of the campaign (been holding off till it was finished). And while I enjoy it, the story it self is pretty fun so far. And I like that some missions will give you multiple choices that affects how the rest of the mission goes. Although they DON'T change the rest of how the campaign goes. The Survival mode is the best part of this game. There is also co-op Survival mode, but I heard it still a bit buggy so if you're only interested in co-op maybe it's a wait and see for you.

The Survival mode is all about surviving a certain amount of Death Nights (DN), which will become more difficult after each one. Spawning stronger monsters and in greater numbers. The days before a DN you clear the map, level your hero character and expand your base and recruit soldiers. Build light sources to keep the Death Fog out when a DN happens (you do not want that appear inside your base)!

When a DN happens you get afflicted with a random debuff, beat the night and the debuff gets replaced with a buff (you get to pick one of 3 options each DN) that's with you till the rest of the run.

Sounds simple right? It is until a Titan kicks in a gate of your walls which causes 1000s of smaller zombies to rush in, overwhelming the defences which where doing alright 10 seconds before.

The only 2 complains I have is that units seems to be able to push other units, so I quite often had swarm of units trying to attack one monster only for them to push the monster around like a train. The second is that the path of DNs isn't always clear and you need a certain building to tell you where they're exactly going. Since a wave spawning in North-West (for example) isn't always going to attack your base from NW despite that side being the closest (in walking time) or the least defended.

Edit 20-01-2024: Played some more of the campaign and the choices you get in other missions of the game (other than the one mentioned earlier) aren't as impactful. They usually let you pick a tech to use in the mission, or an optional side objective to do.

There are PLENTY of bugs 2, units ignore enemies when attacked from range, terrible pathing, 80% of the time the army splits up and one half goes RIGHT into nightmares, sometimes hero abilities do nothing when casted and go on CD (Merek and Vizargo dashes), or worse, the ability does get casted, but anywhere other than where you aimed it (Vizargo's spikes and the bow hero's snipe ability).
It feels like the game wasn't tested enough before the 1.0 release, there's WAY too many common bugs that really suck the fun out of the game.
STILL, there's been a lot of patches and that's really promising, but the state of the game currently barely feels like a beta test rather than a 1.0 release.

I will update this if i see changes and a more stable version than now.

TLDR:
DON'T buy it if you want to play Co-op, you wont finish a single game without constant crashing, if you do, disable cloud saving, restart after crash so you can actually load the game. And set autosaves to daystart and nightstart.
Campaign is cool! But there's a LOT of annoying bugs, they are really common.
